HEADLINE: Claire Sterling, 76, Dies; Writer on Crime and Terror

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Claire Sterling, an American author and correspondent based in Italy, who was known for her writings on terrorism, assassination and crime, died yesterday in a hospital in Arezzo, Italy. She was 76 and lived in outside of Cortona, near Arezzo.
She had cancer of the colon, her husband said. 
 Mrs. Sterling was based in Italy for more than 30 years and traveled widely. Her most recent book, "Thieves' World: The Threat of the New Global Network of Organized Crime" (1994, Simon & Schuster), was praised by Stephen Handelman, of the Harriman Institute of Advanced Soviet Studies at Columbia University, as making "a significant contribution to post-cold-war debate" by affirming "that the growing interdependence among nation-states and financial institutions has made it easier for crime syndicates to cooperate across national boundaries."
In an earlier book, "Octopus: the Long Reach of the International Sicilian Mafia" (1990), she examined the Sicilian Mafia and charged gangster-chieftains based in Palermo with creating a multinational empire with the United States as its longtime main target.
In her 1984 book "The Time of the Assassins," Mrs. Sterling examined the attempt by a Turk, Mehmet Ali Agca, to kill Pope John Paul II in 1981. She contended that Mr. Agca had "come to Rome as a professional hit man, hired by a Bulgarian spy ring." She presented what she called "massive proof that the Soviet Union and its surrogates have provided the weapons, training and sanctuary for a worldwide terror network aimed at the destabilization of Western democratic society."
Mrs. Sterling's contention about a Bulgarian role in the attack was disputed, but writing in 1991, she maintained that Italian courts in 1988 had "expressed their moral certainty that Bulgaria's secret service was behind the papal shooting."
She also attracted wide attention with her 1981 book "The Terror Network," which traced connections among terrorist groups around the globe. William Abrahams, who edited the book for Holt, Rinehart & Winston, said that while she was writing it, the Italian Government posted a guard at her house to protect her.
A decade later, the New York Times columnist Anthony Lewis reported that William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence in the Reagan Administration, had held up a copy of "The Terror Network" before a group of official intelligence experts and had "said contemptuously that he had learned more from it than from all of them."
Mrs. Sterling's first book was "The Masaryk Case" (1969), about Jan Masaryk, the Czechoslovak Foreign Minister who was reported to have leaped to his death in 1948 from a window of his Prague apartment. She concluded that he had been killed by Soviet or Czechoslovak Stalinists to keep him from defecting to the West.
In her decades abroad, she also wrote articles for The New York Times, Atlantic Monthly, The Reporter magazine, Life, Reader's Digest, Harper's, The New Republic, The Washington Post, International Herald Tribune and The Financial Times.
Mrs. Sterling was born Claire Neikind in Queens, received a bachelor's degree in economics from Brooklyn College, and worked for a time as a union organizer among electrical workers.
In 1945 she received a master's degree from the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism, which awarded her a Pulitzer Traveling Scholarship.
She went on to work in Rome for what she described in a 1981 interview as "a fly-by-night American news agency." She learned Italian, and when the agency went out of business, she returned to the United States and joined the staff of The Reporter magazine, which began publication in early 1949.
Mrs. Sterling recalled that when she applied for the Reporter job, Max Ascoli, the magazine's Italian-born publisher and editor, said, "If anybody's going to write about Italy around here, it's me." So because of her union experience, she became the labor editor.
In 1951, she married Tom Sterling, a writer. She remembered that "Max Ascoli's wedding present to me was a six-month assignment in Rome."
Mrs. Sterling's six-month assignment lasted 17 years, ending only when The Reporter ceased publication in 1968. By then, the Sterlings were accustomed to life in Italy, where Mr. Sterling had written some of his more than a dozen books. So Mrs. Sterling, keeping Italy as her base, began writing her Masaryk book.
She is survived by her husband; a son, Luke, of Cortona; a daughter, Abigail Vazquez of San Francisco; two grandchildren, and a sister, Ethel Braun of Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Fiscal Triage At Hospitals: Doing Less With Fewer

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
Thousands of hospital employees have lost their jobs this year, and tens of thousands more have had their working conditions change drastically as hospitals deal with a drop in revenues caused by lower reimbursements from Medicaid, Medicare and insurance companies.
The cuts this year have been made at institutions across the city, from prestigious, world-renowned medical centers to small local hospitals. Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn, for one, laid off 95 employees. Flushing Hospital Medical Center in Queens cut 60. Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx cut its personnel budget by 5 percent. New York Hospital let 126 people go -- 89 at its Manhattan location and 37 at its psychiatric center in White Plains. In addition, 22 psychiatrists and 4 psychologists on contract at the White Plains site were told that their positions were being eliminated. 
 The layoffs and reorganizations -- the largest the industry has seen in decades -- are expected to accelerate now, health care professionals said, as the city's 75 public and private hospitals absorb the latest round of budget deals from City Hall and Albany.
The displacement has shaken the lives of people throughout the hospitals -- file clerks and pharmacists, laundry workers and dietitians, nurses and social workers. Even doctors, whose jobs have traditionally been spared from cost-cutting realities, have been laid off now.
Pearl Bailey is one of the casualties of the current budget season. When she gets up in the morning, she chooses a professional-looking outfit from her closet -- a simple skirt, a matching sweater, a pair of hose and some comfortable shoes. She does her hair, fixes her makeup and leaves her apartment in Howard Beach, Queens, with the flow of rush-hour commuters heading off to work.
But instead of boarding the No. 15 bus and transferring to the No. 4 subway that for 15 years took her to her job as a lab technician at Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital on the Upper East Side, Mrs. Bailey does errands in her neighborhood, goes to a computer class and wonders if she will ever find her way back into the health care industry.
"I love my job -- loved my job," said Mrs. Bailey, who was laid off recently from the hospital. "I loved greeting the patients. I loved being very precise in drawing the blood and analyzing it. I even loved the lab coat I wore. I could see the layoff coming and the people at the hospital, they were all very nice to me. But after 15 years and all my time there, I felt like I was being thrown away, like garbage."
For the lucky, the staff cuts have meant new assignments to unfamiliar tasks and the gnawing tension that their job security is tenuous. And health care professionals all over the city say that those people left working in hospitals are being asked to shoulder an intolerable workload, one that could prove dangerous to patients and staff.
"We are already seeing increased rates of bedsores because we don't have the staff to turn the patients as often as we should," said Anne Bove, a critical-care nurse and instructor at Bellevue Hospital Center. "People are not getting their medications on time. Nurses just can't possibly get them out in the set time intervals because there are so many patients they are looking after. And what does this do to the staff? It leaves them feeling tense and inadequate."
And for people like Mrs. Bailey, who is 48, there are financial worries, a drop in self-esteem, loneliness and the fear that it will be a long time before they work in a hospital again.
"My job was me, it was who I was," said Mrs. Bailey, adrift in her apartment on a recent afternoon. "Now the few people still left in my old department have to chip in and do my work and I, I wish I were them."
The flood of layoffs has been particularly distressing, representatives of hospitals and employees said, because health care had been promoted lately as a ripe field expected to be a source, not a sieve, for jobs.
"The health care community was growing steadily and was expected to continue to grow," said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, a trade group representing 167 hospitals and nursing homes in the New York region. "But now we are seeing major dislocation."
Linda Ruiz has worked in health care for only three years and already she has lost jobs twice because of downsizing brought on by the vicissitudes of managed care and government cutbacks.
Ms. Ruiz said she thought she was beginning a new career in the health care field three years ago, when she decided to work as an assistant in a chiropractor's office. She had graduated from the Fashion Institute of Technology and had looked forward to a career in fashion, but she found that new international trade agreements had left the industry in a flux and newcomers, like herself, on the outside. "Health care was supposed to be a growing field," said Ms. Ruiz, who is 33. "It seemed a smart way to go. Not anymore. I can tell you that very personally."
The chiropractor let her go a year after she started working for him when health maintenance organizations and managed care companies cut his reimbursement rates and he was forced to cut his staff. She then got a job as a medical records clerk at Peninsula Hospital, a small, private community hospital in Far Rockaway, an ideal seven-minute drive from her apartment in Rockaway Park.
In February, after two years, Ms. Ruiz was laid off.
"The axe was at my neck for a while," she said. "But when it fell, it still hurt. I thought I had found a new career."
The blow to her self-image was harder that she had expected. She feels as though she has failed to get a foothold in any field. The help-wanted ads offer no relief and she can no longer face visiting friends at the hospital.
She is now taking a computer course paid for by her union, Local 1199 of the hospital workers' union, hoping to improve her skills and eventually, somehow, to find a new hospital job.
Financially, Ms. Ruiz is barely making ends meet with no margin for the unexpected, like breakdowns in her 18-year-old car. For six months, she will get about half of her $23,000 annual salary -- about $220 a week -- in unemployment compensation. The union gives her an additional $150 stipend every two weeks.
Keith Hanson is among the fortunate. He was not one of the 445 people who lost their jobs this year at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. But each day when he finishes his shift as a nurse on the AIDS unit, he said he breathes a sigh of relief for one disaster or another that was barely averted.
"There are just fewer and fewer people working with patients who are sicker and sicker," said Mr. Hanson, who works a 7 P.M. to 8 A.M. shift three days a week. "It's a prescription for problems. Look, when I first started nine years ago, they guaranteed us a 4-to-1 patient-to-nurse ratio. Now on average I have seven patients a night and because of managed care, the people who come to the hospital these days are in an emergency situation or in much worse shape than when I started."
There used to be more specialty staff to share the work, Mr. Hanson said. A special team of nurses was responsible for starting intravenous lines, freeing the bedside nurses for other chores. Now that team has been disbanded and the work absorbed by the dwindling number of regular nurses.
"Every night something happens," Mr. Hanson said. "I get to someone who is already gasping because he needs to be suctioned. Someone else is about to fall out of the bed because he needs to get to the commode and I couldn't answer the call bell fast enough because I was in with someone else or in the middle of fixing I.V. bags. We are barely in control of this unit. We are running from emergency to emergency."
Elliot Bardavid, a social worker at the Rusk Institute of the New York University Medical Center, said his colleagues were in a perpetual state of anxiety, worrying about patients and fearing for their own jobs.
"There's no relief," said Mr. Bardavid, a social worker for 18 years. "It's a very disheartening and frightening environment."
It is a situation that is unlikely to change soon. In fact, many health care workers warn it is likely to get worse as new cuts in Medicaid and Medicare financing and pressure from managed care force hospitals to pare their staffs even more to stay afloat.
"Whoever hasn't had layoffs will have them," said Dr. Herbert Pardes, vice president for health sciences at Columbia University and dean of the university's College of Physicians and Surgeons. "We're asking psychiatrists to take on more patients, maybe 20 percent to a third more clinical responsibility. We have to for financial reasons. And there's a danger in this. If this thing is driven so hard by money, what kind of care or sensitivity is there for the patients? And what kind of reward is there for workers feeling overburdened and misused? On the one hand, we could be more efficient. But you could go to excess with these cutbacks and I believe the balance is in danger of tipping in the wrong direction."
For Mr. Hanson, the AIDS nurse at St. Luke's-Roosevelt, the anxiety of working in a hospital that he believes is understaffed has already proved too much to bear. So he is leaving the hospital this month to begin work in a hospice in lower Manhattan that takes in people dying of AIDS.
"I am going to a place that is more nurse-friendly and more patient-friendly," said Mr. Hanson, who is at once relieved and regretful about his decision. "At this point in the hospital, talking to people, ministering to people is out of the question. The nursing part of nursing -- holding hands, care issues -- are impossible given these conditions. I spend most of my time interceding in acute medical emergencies. We don't have any time to provide emotional support. This isn't the same hospital I came to. I doubt any hospital is."

HEADLINE: On Sunday;
Being a Man And a Father Is Being There

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
BY biology and familial connections Geoffrey Canada is the father of four. By mutual affection and choice he fathers many others.
Mr. Canada is a man of many faces. He is president of the Rheedlen Centers for Children and Families, a group based in Harlem that aids poor children. He is on tour for his first book, "Fist Stick Knife Gun: A Personal History of Violence" (Beacon Press). He is a black belt in tae kwon do. He is a Harvard graduate. 
 Mostly, though, the 43-year-old Mr. Canada is a father to children in a poor neighborhood where social pressures conspire against paternal involvement. So in his 12 years at Rheedlen, Mr. Canada has been there to talk long into many a night and to wipe away many a tear.
"You have to make a commitment to stick with them for years," he said of his work. Rheedlen provides tutoring, classes for parents and many other supportive programs.
Over the years, Mr. Canada's children have faced pressure to drop out of school, drug-addicted parents or being hunted by people who wanted to kill them. He is proud that many have bloomed and prospered, going on to professional schools and jobs and avoiding premature parenthood.
"GEOFF'S been like a real father to me," said Alex Echavarria, 23, a friend for 11 years. "He kept me off the streets. He'd come around the block, knocking on doors, trying to find out why we missed karate class or why we did whatever."
Mr. Canada grew up poor in the South Bronx, mostly without his father because his parents were divorced. He knows that the streets are far more cynical and ruthless than when he was young, but he knows that the hunger to belong to something larger than oneself persists.
What distinguishes Mr. Canada, who is black, from a cacophony of voices calling for better schools and social programs -- which he also supports -- is his insistence that a paramount issue is the increasing disconnection of black men from families. Not only are most black children now born out of wedlock, but too many have no real relationship with their fathers.
"These kids don't see themselves as part of a historical movement but the end result of one," Mr. Canada said, comparing this generation with the hopeful one that desegregated schools and won voting rights. "They believe this is how things are and will be forever. They're just out here, surviving. They accept that there are no jobs, they accept that schools are bad, they accept that most of their friends don't have fathers."
Mr. Canada was lucky enough to come of age at a time when the nation was invested in sending smart children from the ghetto to places like Bowdoin College in Maine, which he attended before the Harvard Graduate School of Education. He was compassionate enough to come back home as the idealism of the civil rights era soured.
When he and his brother were young there was still dishonor in not having a father, even in the roughest neighborhoods.
"We used to go to church and when we walked down the block the guys would say things to my mother like, 'Hey, cutie,' and our faces would be hot with shame," he said. "I wanted a father very much for that role of protector of my mother."
MR. CANADA is sophisticated enough to know that the dearth of fathers is not some isolated phenomenon. It is connected to the lack of jobs in poor communities and the inability of men there to play the traditional role of provider.
"The jobs left, but the definition of what it meant to be a man didn't," Mr. Canada said. "Men say: 'I can't afford to feed my family. What does that mean?' Most of the culture is built on men working. Even successful men will find their ego and self-worth falter and suffer if they don't have that role."
His argument is that while black adults work on the economic piece, men and women of good will also have to insist that poor boys and girls refrain from exploitative sexual relationships, and redefine manhood to include nurturing as well as providing. The millions of strong, hard-working black fathers can do so, he says, by being role models and by reinforcing positive behavior.
So what makes Mr. Canada especially happy these days are simple things, like seeing young men caring for children and talking with teen-age boys who believe in love. These young black men who are usurping the code of the streets are as revolutionary as those who press other political and social concerns. For that, Mr. Canada is proud. And for his role, his many admirers send him Father's Day greetings.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN THE SCHOOLS: THE BUDGET;
School Chiefs See New Cuts Finally Hitting Classrooms

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
The budget approved by the City Council includes such large cuts to the Board of Education that after five years of belt-tightening, the reductions will for the first time broadly affect classrooms, students and teachers, according to district superintendents.
The $31.1 billion spending plan adopted by the Council on Thursday includes a reduction of nearly $500 million for the public school system. To help absorb the cuts, Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines, in one of his last acts before his resignation was announced last week, told the 32 community school districts and the high schools that they would have to spend a total of $125 million less in the next fiscal year than they did this year. 
 And that inevitably means that classes will get larger next fall, the number of teachers will drop and the quality of education will likely decline, eight district superintendents said in interviews last week.
"We're making profound decisions here that really will have an impact on the lives of little children," said Dr. Arthur Greenberg, superintendent of District 25, which covers Flushing, Whitestone and College Point in Queens. "I know it sounds dramatic, but I really think it's true. I don't have answers to the dilemma, but I know it's a terrible dilemma."
Many guidance counselors, assistant principals and teachers' aides are also likely to have their jobs eliminated, the superintendents said. It is uncertain whether these jobs or the teachers' positions can be cut by relying only on attrition and early retirement, or whether layoffs will also be necessary.
Some superintendents even said they were considering shortening the school day to save money.
Officials at the Board of Education decide broad budget policies, but it is up to each of the 32 community districts, which oversee elementary and junior high schools, and the high school division to decide specific spending cuts.
"It really is nightmarish," said William Casey, Superintendent of District 15 in Brooklyn, which includes parts of Carroll Gardens, Park Slope and Sunset Park. "I expect that we will see higher class size."
In District 3 on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, officials have devised a plan to save about $1.4 million, the amount they estimate they will lose in the next fiscal year. The plan calls for eliminating 18 teachers, 7 assistant principals and 31 school aides.
If district officials decide to carry out the proposal, said James E. Mazza, the superintendent, the average size of classes in the district's middle schools would increase to 30, on average, from 28.
Mr. Cortines acknowledged in his statement on Friday that the spending cuts would affect classrooms directly. "We are hopeful that our districts and high schools will find ways to shield core instructional programs," Mr. Cortines said. "But with a cut of this magnitude, reductions in direct services to children are unavoidable."
The Chancellor had informed a committee of superintendents of the $125 million reduction in a private meeting Thursday, just hours before his resignation letter was made public.
The city budget calls for the Board of Education to spend $7.28 billion in the next fiscal year -- a reduction of $470 million, or 6 percent, from the $7.75 billion being spent in the current fiscal year.
To maintain current services, board officials said, they would have to spend more than $7.75 billion in the next fiscal year, which begins July 1, because of inflation, higher enrollment and contractual obligations. Board officials said they have to close a gap of nearly $900 million between the projected spending and the budget as adopted by the City Council.
The officials plan to confront the gap in a number of ways, including administrative cuts at the central board and concessions that they hope to extract from the teachers' union.
The $125 million reduction ordered from the districts and high schools will also help close the gap. The amount of each district's reduction is determined proportionately, by its number of students. Many superintendents said the new round of cuts would be even more difficult because budget pressures over the last five years have already forced them to whittled away at many services and jobs.
After-school programs have been eliminated in most districts; art and music classes have been curtailed or eliminated, as have support workers like guidance counselors, assistant principals and school aides.
In District 15 in Brooklyn, 25 percent of the district staff has already been eliminated, Mr. Casey, the superintendent, said.
Now, he said, the jobs of teachers, guidance counselors, assistant principals and teachers' aides are all under consideration. "These are critical people, not administrative bloat, as the Mayor would have it," Mr. Casey said.
In District 23, in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville section of Brooklyn, officials estimated that the district would receive about $1.3 million less in the next fiscal year than it did this year, a cut of about 4 percent.
"This is not good at all," said Michael Vega, the district superintendent.
One way of cutting $1.3 million, Mr. Vega said, would be to eliminate 62 teachers, the equivalent of more than three teachers for each of the district's 18 schools. If 62 teachers were let go, the size of classes would increase to 37 to 40 students, from the current range of 28 to 32 students, he said.
Another option would be to eliminate all assistant principals, Mr. Vega said. But that would not save $1.3 million, and so the size of an average class would still increase by four or five students.
A third possibility, which Mr. Vega said he favored, would be to shorten the school day.

HEADLINE: 1995 N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;
In Detroit, a Red Wings Renaissance

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 17

 BODY:
Around a 2.9-mile loop of downtown Detroit there circles a shuttle train called the People Mover. Perched on a monorail above the city streets, the system opened eight years ago to promote business and to make the district more user-friendly.
For part of the route, the People Mover takes travelers through an urban ghost town of abandoned hotels, vacant stores and nearly empty streets. For the rest of the circuit, tourists see gleaming, modern hotels and office buildings on a sparkling waterfront that is especially bustling and festive during the summer months. 
 As with a drinking glass that is either half empty or half full, the pessimist and the optimist might ask: Is downtown Detroit half dead or half alive? Does the Motor City have any real direction these days or is the town just going around in circles, spinning its wheels?
A clue to those answers might be found at the Joe Louis Arena station, on the banks of the Detroit River. Leave the People Mover and walk down long ramps to a sports arena named after the Brown Bomber, once the heavyweight boxing champion of the world and one of the best-known sons of the city.
On the car-crowded streets here tonight were 20,000 hockey fans, many of whom made long drives from distant suburbs or from Canada, which lies just across the water. Amid the bright lights and television trucks, the people were filing into "The Joe" for the first game of the Stanley Cup finals between their Red Wings and the visiting Devils.
Most of the people were white, a fact not superfluous here. Part of the received wisdom of metropolitan Detroit is that it is one of the most racially polarized regions in the nation, that white people have abandoned the central city, a trend that accelerated after major rioting in 1967. Many believe whites are afraid to spend their money downtown. Isaiah McKinnon is one citizen who has heard it all and seen much of it and lived through it.
He happens to be black. He happens to be a hockey fan. He also happens to be the chief of police. When the Wings won their last Cup in 1955, McKinnon said he was "the only person of African-American descent sitting in the stands at Olympia." Now 52 years old, he recalls with fondness the era when he saw Gordie Howe playing against Maurice Richard. As a patrolman in 1966, McKinnon rushed Red Wings defenseman Doug Barkley to Ford Hospital on the night Barkley's career ended when a stick poked him in the eye.
These nights, McKinnon combines his business with pleasure.
"I do a lot of walking around the arena," McKinnon said, "and I'll have 150 people come up to me some nights and say things like, 'We love the city of Detroit. We were born here. We grew up here. And we want to come back.' "
Moreover, McKinnon said the fans thank him for providing an environment in which they feel secure. He said the recent success of the team "is noticeable in terms of uplifting spirit" and in the thriving restaurant business on hockey nights.
"It's almost an ecstatic feeling," he said.
One booming business isn't going to change long-term economic trends; one successful team, even a possible Stanley Cup champion, won't reverse decades of negative image, some of it self-inflicted. But if the Red Wings win the Cup this season -- with celebratory octopuses flying from the stands onto the ice in Detroit's bizarre tradition -- it will be their first championship since an era when the city was at its post-war peak. In that sense, things will have come full circle.
Back then, the Wings were a perennial powerhouse and the automobile business was flush. Nearly two million people lived within the city limits then, about double the population today.
American car manufacturers were virtually unchallenged in the world, and one of the major problems facing the city was a housing shortage. Today, one of the big nuisances is abandoned houses, some of which are torched by arsonists on the annual "Devil's Night."
Although it is only coincidence, the resurgence of the Red Wings has come at a time of renewed vigor in the auto business. William T. Wilson, a vice president and economist for Comerica Inc., one of the big local banks, said the value of a winning hockey team is "intrinsic, rather than trinsic" to the overall economic health of the region.
But he also stressed that metropolitan Detroit's bottom line may be healthier now than it has been for more than 20 years. The region includes about 4.5 million people in southeastern Michigan. The Red Wings, who wear a winged wheel on their shirts, are a symbol of an economy that is soaring.
"The Big Three have a ton of cash," Wilson said. "Michigan unemployment rates are the lowest in 23 or 24 years."
Wilson said that Detroit was "commercially devastated" by recessions and population loss in the 1970's and 1980's but that Mayor Dennis Archer, in office for 18 months, "has reached out to the business community and reached out to the suburbs."
"There has been a 180-degree turn in attitude toward business and the suburbs," Wilson said, adding the cautious note that some people are "still a bit cynical" about future relations.
Even before the Archer administration, a major suburban player working in downtown Detroit was Mike Ilitch, the owner of the Red Wings. As a young man in the 1950's, Ilitch sold aluminum awnings in the growing suburbs and sensed a new restaurant market.
He built his Little Caesars pizza business the way Henry Ford built his auto empire and Berry Gordy made music at Motown. In 1982, Ilitch bought the Wings for $8 million. According to Financial World magazine, the franchise, the most valuable in the National Hockey League, is now worth $124 million.
Working with the former mayor Coleman A. Young, Ilitch gained operating control of Joe Louis Arena as well as Cobo Arena and Cobo Hall, which are alongside the hockey arena. He restored downtown's Fox Theater to its former grandeur for shows and concerts and has added a Second City comedy club to his growing entertainment district.
Adding to the sports wing of his empire, Ilitch bought the Tigers baseball team three years ago. He wants a new baseball stadium downtown to replace Tiger Stadium, a couple of miles to the west, and possibly a new hockey arena to seat 25,000 customers.
But Ilitch has been frustrated by opposition to public funding for new stadiums. Some of it comes from a local organization called the Tiger Stadium Fan Club.
Frank Rashid, one of the founders, said the members have mixed feelings about the success of the Red Wings because the positive vibrations might encourage political support for Ilitch's new infrastructures.
"Mike Ilitch is not a civic hero," said Rashid, an English professor at Marygrove College. "He's a good businessman. He made a good deal with the city. The city made a good deal with him." Rashid said the success of the Red Wings "is not good for our cause."
"But we do cheer for our team," he said. "I'm a Detroiter and a Detroit sports fan. Of course I'm happy about the Red Wings." He added that he's also happy about rising property values in his Detroit neighborhood.
"There's a new mood," he said. "There's a lot of optimism."
One real estate development proposal is to turn some downtown land near the People Mover's Greek Town stop into an Indian reservation. That would allow Michigan tribes to run gambling casinos. Some of the proceeds might help fund new stadium construction.
At a news conference last week, Ilitch said: "Maybe things are starting to jell for us. Maybe it's all going to come together. Maybe over the next 18 months or two years, we could have some nice things happening for Detroit."
Although Ilitch regularly attends games at Joe Louis, he doesn't take the People Mover. He drives his black Mercedes into the arena and parks it on a lower concourse before retreating to a guarded private box.
Most of the conversation below him tonight was centered on the game. The fans, sophisticated from 40 years of "Hockey Night in Canada" over the airwaves, filled the air with cheers. Among their favorites: Detroit-born Mark Howe, son of Gordie Howe, who led the champions of the 1950's.
With Junior A teams, major college and minor pro clubs and leagues interwoven throughout the city and the region and about two dozen local athletes on N.H.L. teams, Detroiters are among the world's best-connected hockey consumers. John Ziegler, the former league president, is from the area, as is Bob Goodenow, the executive director of the N.H.L. Players Association.
Tonight's televised images, from inside and outside the building, carried over the Fox network to other American cities, would suggest something other than the standard Detroit stereotypes of "Murder City" or Rust Belt ruin -- that there is a healthy, positive beat in the heart of the city.
Dick Purtan, a local radio personality for 30 years and a hockey fan for longer than that, said success in hockey this spring "may help turn the city's image around in the eyes of outsiders.
"I think there's a rebirth," he said. "It's about time."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Too Much Of a Good Thing

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: BELFAST, Northern Ireland

 BODY:
Whenever you ask British officials about the Clinton Administration's decision to grant I.R.A. leader Gerry Adams a visa last year you get this pained expression and then some version of the question: "How would you Americans like it if we gave a reception at 10 Downing Street for Timothy McVeigh and a few of his pals?" The discussion usually descends from there into a venomous diatribe about how President Clinton, in his quest for Irish-American votes, fell prey to a Kennedy-clan conspiracy. At that point, if you're smart, you'll mumble something about the weather in London being unusually rainy this year and shift the conversation to European Union agricultural policy.
Yes, the Brits were deeply upset with Mr. Clinton's Northern Ireland diplomacy. Yes, that diplomacy was motivated largely by a Clinton desire to gain favor with the 40 million Irish-American voters. And yet, Mr. Clinton's decision to give Mr. Adams a visa in return for his commitment to a cease-fire may also have been the President's most original and successful foray into foreign affairs. After all, it has helped engineer the longest truce in Northern Ireland in 25 years. 
 What are the lessons here? The first is a simple reminder that more often than not diplomatic breakthroughs happen when key players do the right thing for the wrong reasons in the right place at the right time. Maybe Mr. Clinton was motivated by the wrong reasons, but his timing was exquisite.
My sense from interviews here is that the British were so emotionally scarred by their years in Belfast that they had lost sight of just how deeply the Catholic and Protestant communities wanted to end the fighting and just how much that popular sentiment had been communicated in subtle and not-so-subtle ways to the hard men conducting the street war.
By offering Mr. Adams a visa and American legitimation, in return for an I.R.A. cease-fire, Mr. Clinton gave Mr. Adams the political cover he needed to persuade his own hard-liners to yield to the public's desire to move from the barricades to the bargaining table. In effect, Mr. Clinton has "Larry Kinged" Mr. Adams, which the Oxford English Dictionary defines as "a verb meaning to transform a fighter into a respectable world figure by giving him the opportunity for repeated interviews on CNN." Britain was unable or unwilling to give Mr. Adams that kind of opportunity and therefore could not nurture this historic moment to halt the fighting.
But there is another lesson. When domestic politics drives foreign policy, the danger is an Administration will not know when to stop. This is particularly true in an age when the absence of an overriding Soviet threat makes it much easier for Washington to snub traditional allies, like Britain, in pursuit of domestic politics.
Last March, American officials tried to build on their cease-fire success by persuading Mr. Adams to begin talks with Britain on giving up I.R.A. weapons. In return, the Administration said it would grant Mr. Adams the opportunity to fund-raise for the I.R.A. in America. But Mr. Adams would only make a fuzzy commitment on decommissioning weapons -- one that did not impress London and one Washington would never have let Yasir Arafat get away with. So what happened? Mr. Clinton, spurred on by I.R.A. supporters, gave Mr. Adams the fund-raising concession anyway, and a White House visit, arguing this would help Mr. Adams come around. It hasn't. The cease-fire is holding, but the peace talks are now stuck on this weapons issue. Mr. Clinton squandered an opportunity to force another breakthrough.
It's not the first time the Administration has shown it doesn't know where to draw the line between politics and diplomacy. Last April, Mr. Clinton announced his decision to impose a full economic embargo on Iran. It was the right thing to do. But to maximize the political payoff, Mr. Clinton could not resist making the announcement at a World Jewish Congress dinner, while wearing a yarmulke. It left the impression with the Iranians, the Muslim world and the allies that the U.S. embargo was not a fundamental American and global interest, but was just pandering to a single U.S. interest group and therefore not to be taken seriously.
Every Administration introduces crass domestic politics into foreign policy. But you have to know when to stop. In diplomacy, the road to success is often paved with bad intentions. But so is the road to ruin. Wisdom is knowing where the fork is.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Cigarette Recall Is Good News for Lawyers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Regarding your article on the recall of eight billion cigarettes at a cost to Philip Morris of over $100 million ("Tobacco: Now Will You Stop Smoking?," Diary, June 4), one segment of our economy will certainly profit. With Philip Morris accusing Hoechst Celanese of supplying contaminated filter fibers, lawyers for both sides should reap a financial harvest. 
 Whether Philip Morris prevails or loses in this case, which promises to drag on for years, there will be no dearth of legal bills. Even some expert witnesses on chemicals may join the economic boom as one side attempts to show that the glycerol triacetate used in the cellulose acetate polymer as a plasticizer is the guilty party in the adverse reactions of smokers to these cigarettes. Whether fees paid to the lawyers and chemists contribute to the gross national product is another question, but hopefully if the brouhaha causes some smokers to stop, the economy will be well rewarded by lower medical bills in the future.
 
NELSON MARANS
Silver Spring, Md., June 7
 
The writer is a retired research chemist.

HEADLINE: Affirmative Action Never Ended Racism;
Gingrich on Wages

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In their joint meeting in Claremont, N.H., President Clinton and House Speaker Newt Gingrich clarified their stands on the minimum wage (front page, June 12). 
 President Clinton would raise it to $5.25 an hour, or about the poverty level for someone working full time. Speaker Gingrich would not raise it from its present $4.25, because "if you raise the cost of the first job for the poorest person, for example, in the inner city, that what you tend to do is increase black, male teen-ager unemployment, which is exactly the thing you don't want to do."
Although economists can be found on both sides of the question, the moral issue is clear: Any full-time job should pay at least enough for the worker to afford a life of dignity. The only exceptions are (1) the worker is doing a favor for the employer; (2) the worker is pursuing a hobby, or (3) the worker is being punished or enslaved.
Incidentally, Mr. Gingrich's statement is an example of the continuing need for affirmative action. That a prominent political leader should assume that teen-age blacks will be the worst paid only emphasizes the need.
 
GEORGE P. BROCKWAY
Chappaqua, N.Y., June 12, 1995

SECTION: Section 5; Page 12; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 665 words

HEADLINE: A Penny Saved Is a Penny to Spend

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES; WILLIAM GRIMES is a culture reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:
TO spend or not to spend, that is the question every traveler to Europe must face. Whether 'tis nobler to scrimp and pinch, trading three-star for two-star, first-class for coach, awesome for adequate, or to unleash the mighty power of plastic and in so doing pile up a mountain of debt.
Each year, my wife and I scale the mountain. 
 Our private road to credit-card hell is paved with good intentions. We would never dream of flying first-class. We stay in modest hotels. In France we gravitate toward bistros rather than Michelin monsters, and in England we eat lunch in pubs. None of this really counts, though, because it entails no real sacrifice. For us, it's normal behavior.
The problem lies in the thousand and one tiny decisions that tilt the scale of pleasure one way or the other. The better theater seats for an extra 7. The 50-franc glass of Champagne before dinner. The 4 P.M. pit stop at a patisserie for a cup of coffee and a Rococo pastry. The $100 for an enchanting but not strictly necessary Provencal tablecloth and set of napkins, so that later we might recreate the atmosphere of Arles in our very own backyard in Queens.
Then there are the incidentals. The generous tip to convince the Parisian waiter that Americans are nice and the French should like us. The large donations at museums and churches to prove that Americans appreciate Europe's cultural heritage.
It all adds up. So much so that two weeks after the Grand Tour, the postman has trouble squeezing our Visa bill through the front-door mail slot. It's a dramatic moment. Stunned silence gives way to mutual recrimination and the wailing and gnashing of teeth. The figure cannot be right. Surely a decimal point has been deployed incorrectly.
From the depths of misery, however, we rally. Yes, we spent precisely 250 percent more than planned. But so what? We had a good time. Humankind can be divided into two subspecies: spenders and savers. In the long run, spenders can't save, and savers can't spend. The spenders, like myself, actually enjoy pulling out a wallet and peeling 20's off a fat roll of bills. The act represents freedom, power, and all the pleasurable aspects of adulthood rolled into one flamboyant gesture. Travel encourages this impulse. On tour, I mentally assume the guise of a Restoration exquisite being transported through the streets in a sedan chair and idly tossing gold coins to the populace.
The savers, on the other hand, get their pleasure from thinking about all the things they are not spending money on. They're the ones who press their noses to the plate glass at Harrods and recite the prices out loud, expressing fresh surprise and outrage at every figure. This is a form of anti-shopping that, as far as I can make out, provides some sort of convoluted Puritan satisfaction to its practitioners. Others would call this Yankee ingenuity.
Actually, my wife and I apply our own version of this approach. Let's use Paris as an example. By not taking the Concorde, we save $4,000 on a round-trip ticket. By not staying at the Crillon, we save $1,800 for three days. Eating at La Caffetiere rather than Taillevent yields savings of about $250. Looked at from the right angle, these small economies provide us with working capital of more than $6,000, which my wife can apply to a locust-like ravaging of the Agnes B. store.
This year, sad to say, the dollar's pathetic performance has forced us into a temporary alliance with the savers. We rented a small flat in London to shave some badly needed bucks off the price of lodgings. Fringe theater is starting to look exciting. So are strolls through the park and architectural walking tours. We are actually beginning to enjoy the thought of all the money we'll save by eating breakfast and maybe a dinner or two in our own digs. This line of thinking is so productive, in fact, that I am now convinced that we can actually turn a profit by traveling to Europe. This year, Pierre gets a 10-franc tip.

And Bear in Mind
(Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
 COLD SNAP: Stories, by Thom Jones. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) A collection that turns a merciless, ironic gaze on the organic trap called life, in which spiritual beings -- humans -- are forever in jeopardy of mere chemical accidents or biological insults.
 
COMRADE CRIMINAL: Russia's New Mafiya, by Stephen Handelman. (Yale University, $27.50.) A reporter's account of post-cold-war Russia as a lawless land at the mercy of organized crime.
 
DEEP RIVER, by Shusaku Endo. (New Directions, $19.95.) Mr. Endo's novel follows soulless modern Japanese travelers to the Ganges, where they encounter the humanity and suffering of a few who have found faith.
 
THE HAUNTED LAND: Facing Europe's Ghosts After Communism, by Tina Rosenberg. (Random House, $25.) A moral, political and psychological investigation, by a wise journalist, of four post-Soviet societies struggling with their conduct under the old regimes.
 
THE INFORMATION, by Martin Amis. (Harmony, $24.) Mr. Amis's cool and brilliant novel is sustained throughout by the corroding, corrupting envy of an unsuccessful novelist for a successful novelist who is also his best friend.
 
IN THE TIME OF THE AMERICANS: FDR, Truman, Eisenhower, Marshall, MacArthur -- The Generation That Changed America's Role in the World, by David Fromkin. (Knopf, $30.) F.D.R. stars in a historian's incisive account of the men who made the 20th century what it is.
 
THE LOVE LETTER, by Cathleen Schine. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Helen is 42, capable and loves Edith Wharton. Johnny is 20, acne-spotted and -- like, excellent! -- a big Tom Robbins fan. In this comic novel they fall in love.
 
LYTTON STRACHEY: The New Biography, by Michael Holroyd. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35.) A substantially reworked version of Mr. Holroyd's two-volume biography of Strachey that appeared in the 1960's, this painstakingly researched portrait contains new disclosures about the lives and loves of Strachey and his Bloomsbury contemporaries.
 
MY USUAL GAME: Adventures in Golf, by David Owen. (Villard, $23.) Mr. Owen, a journalist, had a handicap numbering in the dozens when he set out to devote every waking moment to improving his golf game; he recounts his obsessive odyssey in hilarious detail here.
 
RETHINKING AMERICA, by Hedrick Smith. (Random House, $25.) An examination of America's economy and prescriptions for repairing it to accord with a changed world order, by a journalist who does not fear big subjects.
 
THE ROMANTIC GENERATION, by Charles Rosen. (Harvard University, $39.95.) A professor and pianist offers a fond, accessible analysis of the works of Schumann, Mendelssohn, Chopin and others during the period from 1827 to 1849. Mr. Rosen furnishes musical illustrations on the accompanying compact disk.

HEADLINE: THE CAPITALIST;
Separating Rich People From Their Money

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEWIS 

 BODY:
"It's remarkable. It's absolutely above board, thoroughly honest. It may sound a little bit too good to be true, but it's absolutely wonderful." . . . . . . . . MAY 2, 1995.

"We're not naive dupes, I don't think." . . . MAY 15.

"Oh, my God, I cannot believe it." . . . . . MAY 16.

JOHN C. WHITEHEAD, FORMER CO-CHAIRMAN OF GOLDMAN SACHS, SPEAKING TO STEVE STECKLOW OF THE WALL STREET JOURNAL, AS IT DAWNS ON HIM THAT HE HAS LOST CLOSE TO $1 MILLION IN THE FOUNDATION FOR NEW ERA PHILANTHROPY CHARITY FRAUD. 
 THE RICH PROBABLY ARE DIFFERENT from you and me, if for no other reason than they spend their lives being treated differently by you and me. Especially in America, where public goods are scarce and private wealth vast, a rich person is a walking pinata. He strolls through life stuffed with surpluses while the rest of us bash away at him with little sticks. Princeton University is now attempting to add $1 billion to its endowment, $500 million of it from just 100 rich alumni. Harvard wants $1.5 billion for its endowment and capital fund. Every time a rich person looks up there's another species to be saved, another disease to be cured, another election to be won. It's enough to make him impervious to us all -- or so you'd think. But then along comes New Era, and busts the pinata wide open.
Like most financial schemes this one wasn't very complicated. John G. Bennett Jr., the head of New Era, offered charities and rich philanthropists a special deal. Give him your money for six months and, with the aid of secret donors, he'd give you back twice the original amount. There were no secret donors, however. Over the last five years Bennett ran what became a $100 million Ponzi scheme -- paying out old suckers with money he raised from new suckers. (Keeping a few million dollars for himself, naturally.) The suckers included a pewload of evangelical churches, along with a cross section of the Wall Street rich -- Geoffrey Boisi, William Simon, Julian Robertson. "The wealthy are really a con man's dream," a former F.B.I. agent told The Journal, summing up the widespread view that rich people are especially gullible.
This may or may not be true. After all, there's no point in conning poor people, except for their votes, so who knows what they'd believe if given the chance? And if conning very rich people was all that easy, you'd think more people would get into the business. Anyway, it seems to me much more plausible that the rich are actually very difficult to steal from, and that Mr. Bennett required a special talent to pull it off. Thus, whatever else it is, the New Era scandal is instructional. It teaches us how to swing more accurately at the pinata.
THE MOST OBVIOUS RULE IS TO START AT THE top and work down. Mr. Bennett began by winning the confidence of John Templeton and Julian Robertson, two of Wall Street's richest men. He knew that the one person whom a rich person will follow blindly into a financial deal is an even richer person, in part because the richest people usually do get the best deals. (Within the Rich-American economy New Era looked perfectly normal, which is why it worked.) Also, rich people love to drop the names of people who are richer than they are. A managing director at Morgan Stanley will pay good money for the chance to say: "Julian and I are involved in this terrific foundation in Pennsylvania." And he did.

Rule #2. You never really con a rich person. You merely suggest, and let him con himself. Rich people need to feel that it was their idea in the first place. Bennett didn't really push his scheme so much as let it be known it existed -- through a former Reagan White House official who frequented the Links Club in Manhattan, a rich people's haunt. They then came to him.

Rule #3. Ask not what a rich person can do for you but what you can do for a rich person. Like everybody else, rich people want most badly what they can't have. The trick is finding something they can't have. Immortality, for instance. Bennett understood that rich people desperately want to rid themselves graciously of all the poor people asking them for money. Rich people are forever being made to feel cheap; everyone thinks they are twice as rich as they actually are, and should give away twice as much as they do. In joining Bennett's scheme a rich person was twice as rich as he was.

Rule #4. Find his children and you can forget the rules. Mr. Bennett met John Templeton Sr. through John Templeton Jr., and you can, too. Obviously, some rich people love their children, much as normal human beings do. But their love gets complicated. Many rich parents feel guilty about the amount of time they have spent playing with their money instead of with their children; rich children, for their part, have a talent for feeling unloved. Both parties believe deep down that the best way to solve personal problems -- indeed all problems -- is to throw money at them. What they're looking to buy here is a highly specialized service -- one part kidnapping and one part therapy.
YOU SHOULD NOT EXPERIENCE GUILT in providing it. The best schools do. (We'll take your kids if you build us a new gym.) The finest Wall Street firms do, too. (We'll hire your kids if you do put your money with us.) You may not have an admissions requirement to waive or a job to offer but at the very least you can befriend the child and give him something to believe in, while at the same time listening to his complaints about his parents.
If you pull it off you'll soon find yourself sitting on the front porch of the rich person's ranch. Beginners in this situation tend to chicken out at the last minute and ask for a mere few thousand dollars. But if you have done your job properly the rich person is emotionally involved in your putative cause, and willing to give millions. Which brings us to Rule #5. Bennett understood that rich people somehow are less rational with their millions than with their thousands. So ask for the millions. After all, it's not like they can't afford it.

LENGTH: 1206 words

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
What's New

BYLINE: By MAX FRANKEL 

 BODY:
THERE IS CONTROVERSY ABOUT THE nature of news. People think the media are too negative or too cynical or too opinionated. That the loudest of these complaints come from the most negative, cynical and opinionated talkers on radio does not disprove them. They are in fact chronic complaints and not now the most serious heard about the news business.
The public, as measured by opinion polls, does not so much object to "bad" news as it wants a balanced diet, with more "good" news. The public, as measured by its reading habits, wants considerably less news of every kind. And the public, as measured by television ratings, favors trashy gossip about the rich and famous, "magazine" exposes of skulduggery and hourly updates about a certain murder trial. 
 The response inside the news business has been mounting anxiety. Editors and reporters beat their breasts and confess to elitism; they have been persuaded that their education and income leave them "disconnected" from ordinary readers. Broadcasters fear that the proliferation of cable channels, portable cameras and interactive services is eroding the authority of responsible network news. Newspaper executives, similarly frightened by technology, denounce their own editors for being hooked on "old-fashioned" news and impervious to the "data gathering" and "packaging" skills that are required of modern "content providers."
Producers and customers alike are fussing about the true nature of news. Yet for all the hand-wringing, there is remarkably little discussion anywhere of what constitutes news, what it should be and how its definition is being altered.
In most newsrooms, the nature of news, like language itself, is taken for granted. When the editors of The Times design their front page, they work like chefs preparing a sauce -- no recipes needed. This is a good yarn, they'll agree, in ranking the day's events, utterances and reportorial discoveries. And that is the best story of the day. Asked why, they'll tell you a yarn is good if it's important or interesting or, better yet, both. Pressed to define important, they'll say it's news that's likely to have a psychic or material effect on world affairs, American society or local life. As for interesting, why that can be the birth of a panda in Beijing or a bear's rampage in Times Square -- you know, off-beat, wacky, cute, arresting.
Their instincts are superb but their definitions are hardly illuminating. The biggest news can be predictable (the inauguration of a President) or surprising (the bribing of a Vice President). It can be good news (a stock market surge) or bad news (a train crash). It can be yesterday's big event (a tax cut) or a glacial trend (global warming).
Since no one can precisely define the nature of news, virtually anyone can claim to be a journalist. Cynics often remark that freedom of the press exists only for people who own one, but no diplomas, certifications or registrations are needed to practice the craft. Newsletters peddling guns or stocks have the same standing in law as The Times or ABC News. The merchants of reckless gossip on "American Journal" can claim the same interest in news as The Wall Street Journal. The news business is a cacophony, if not exactly a democracy.
However amorphous the idea of news, serious journalists are not hard to define. Deep down, they think of packaging news not as a business but as a public service. They want to provide the information and analysis that a citizen would -- or should -- want to have to make political choices, to prevent abuses of power and to enhance the quality of life. But it's public service with a show-biz flavor. To make the news tastier, the best editors also look for gripping narrative, tales of human heroism and depravity that illuminate life, and then they'll sprinkle in some entertaining spice. To help pay the bills, they will also give generous space to features that sell papers (TV listings and sports stats) or advertising (whole sections about food or automobiles).
Only occasionally will editors stop to examine their basic habits. A. M. Rosenthal of The Times remembers the day he decided to stop covering Sunday sermons and to cover religions instead. I remember leading a discussion after the collapse of the Soviet Union about how important news would now shift from diplomatic and military concerns to international economics and trade. But being thoughtful about the news is not yet being smart about the news business. In sorting through the current complaints and anxieties, newsmongers need to think about some seismic shifts in their environment.
Who's first? The great scoops that used to send newsboys running through the streets shouting "Extra" don't count for much anymore. Most scoops don't last long enough for anyone to run three blocks. One reporter's news of a highly visible event, like an explosion in Oklahoma City, or an easily verified plan, like a Cabinet appointment, is easily matched by phone, fax and computer by a hundred other reporters. Even broadcasters rarely beat the competition by more than a few minutes. Nowadays, real scoops that really cannot be easily matched are reports that require extensive (and expensive) investigation and analysis. In the modern news business, brains beat out legs and elbows.
What's my line? Contrary to what they say, most people don't want their news "straight down the middle." They are really looking to have their opinions confirmed and reinforced. And major news operations now serve such large audiences that they cannot stray very far from center on any issue. So feisty "niche" magazines and arrogant talk shows will continue to take the place of what were once partisan papers.
When's it playing? Lists of things to do and places to go and apartments for sale and trades in stocks will soon cease to be news on paper. They are much more efficiently compiled and kept fresh by computers, which can customize every need, spit out relevant background material and even execute a transaction.
Where's the fun? As the last of America's evening papers die out, it should be obvious that the tired consumer seeking mainly diversion at the end of the day finds it more readily on television. All news is, in a sense, entertaining, but television shows are clearly better than even television newscasts at providing the frothy, passive entertainment once available only in the comics and columns advising the lovelorn. News teams that try to compete in this league are doomed.
Why, why, how and why? It's the last of the five W's they teach in journalism class that will surely define the craft in the foreseeable future. Readers and audiences that want primarily to be entertained, serviced and pandered to will not need traditional news outlets. Those that seek to ease the anxieties of modern life with news will want to understand the forces that shape their lives: why systems fail, why prices go up, how power is amassed, why someone won't do something. More than ever, they will want news that enlightens and liberates, news that only well-educated and well-supported journalists can provide.
Whether many enterprises can succeed at that trade remains very much to be seen.
