HEADLINE: As Aid Shrinks and Deficit Grows, Los Angeles County Faces Painful Cuts

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 16

 BODY:
After years of sunny expansion and quick fixes for gnawing financial problems, Los Angeles County has suddenly caught a bad case of the fiscal malaise of the 1990's: the prospect of a suddenly huge budget deficit and reductions in state aid are forcing local politicians to consider dramatic cuts in the nation's largest county government.
The problems have been mounting for years, particularly after the passage of Proposition 13, the 1978 ballot measure that put a rigid cap on property taxes in California. Even so, news that the county government now faces a deficit totaling perhaps $1 billion of the nearly $14 billion annual budget has caught many people here by surprise. 
 But beyond the cries of dismay and promises of a fight, most experts are warning that county services, particularly those to the poor, will have to be slashed. One of the largest hospitals in the country, the Los Angeles County-University of Southern California Medical Center, may be closed, welfare payments are likely to be reduced and new taxes may have to be enacted. Already there is talk of a 25-cent tax on each alcoholic drink sold.
The county government is currently the largest employer in Southern California, with about 85,000 employees. Some are predicting more than 10,000 people could end up losing their jobs. A chief reason the county government is so large is that, as in most states, it administers a large number of health and welfare programs mandated by the Federal Government. The county has a population of nearly 9 million, including about 3.5 million in the city of Los Angeles.
The troubles of Los Angeles are unrelated to the woes of its neighbor, Orange County, which became the largest municipal government ever to file for bankruptcy when it suffered huge losses on its investments in the bond market last year.
But in some ways the problems of Los Angeles are deeper, experts say, because they involve intractable issues like the growing cost of providing services to the poor at a time when Federal and state aid are declining. In fact, the problems are a direct outgrowth of the sudden urge to reduce spending at the state and Federal levels, since more than two-thirds of the county's budget comes from those governments.
To a large extent, the county's difficulties are a case study in today's budget politics. Many members of the new Republican majority in Congress have pushed for local governments to take more responsibility for providing welfare services formerly paid for by Washington, but Los Angeles's predicament raises the question of whether the local governments have the wherewithal to do so.
"This is certainly going to affect the quality of life and our ability to meet the needs of the poor people of the county," said Sally Reed, the county's chief administrative officer, who will present her proposed budget on Monday. "There will be significant reductions in the health area and the welfare area."
She added: "It's traumatic. It's the hardest thing I've ever done. But we're going to change the way in which we expect people to survive."
Two events have placed these concerns in the headlines. One is the presentation of Ms. Reed's budget. Community organizers are already digging in for a pitched battle over keeping hospitals open and maintaining services for the inner-city poor.
The other event is the expected sale of $1.5 billion in short-term county notes. The rating agencies are scheduled to announce their ratings of the notes on Monday, and they are expected to be sold on Wednesday.
Normally, such a note sale is routine, but this time it is the subject of growing anxiety. The county currently has the highest rating for such short-term securities, but the treasurer, Larry J. Monteilh, said he was already preparing to pay more than $1 million for a letter of credit, a kind of insurance policy on securities, in the event that the agencies lower the rating and frighten investors. It would be the first time the county had been forced to acquire a letter of credit for this kind of note offering, Mr. Monteilh said.
"We think the deficit numbers are fairly large, but it is a big county," said Peter Bianchini, an analyst with Standard & Poor's who is evaluating the county. "Their situation is no surprise, but it is troubling."
There are two fundamental factors at work. One is a result of Proposition 13.
Since property taxes were the principal source of county revenue, the measure created a crisis. Ultimately, it was resolved by the state government agreeing to allot additional revenues to the counties. That made up for a substantial portion of the shortfall.
However, the state itself fell on hard times several years ago, in part because of a steep recession. So, starting three years ago, the State Legislature eliminated the funds it had been providing the counties to cover the losses from Proposition 13. For Los Angeles County, that will mean the loss of nearly $1 billion in the coming fiscal year, which begins July 1.
The Legislature's action was a warning shot to county governments across the state. Yet over the past several years Los Angeles County's supervisors have resorted to what most here admit were one-time fixes rather than fundamental changes. The county borrowed heavily, rather than lay off employees or reduce services.
"The county failed to face up to the crisis imposed on them by the state's actions," said Zev Yaro slavsky, a county supervisor elected late last year. "Instead of making the tough cuts, they borrowed from their future revenues to pay today's bills. And they did it big time."
Indeed, the county is budgeting $439 million in the coming fiscal year just to meet interest payments; that marks an increase of more than $100 million from the current fiscal year.
Some have charged Ms. Reed with exaggerating the depth of the problems just to frighten residents into accepting big budget reductions. She rejected the charge but acknowledged that tough political decisions would have to be made. It still is not clear that county or state politicians are prepared to take those measures.
Antonio Villaraigosa, a member of the State Assembly from the district that includes downtown Los Angeles, said, "I am frankly aware of the fact that the State Legislature is abdicating its responsibility to the county by not providing them with sufficient revenue, but at the same time I think it is absolutely outrageous that Sally Reed would think of closing down the U.S.C. hospital."
He said he would propose, among other things, cutting Ms. Reed's salary and other administrative expenses before closing down the medical center.

HEADLINE: A Rivalry in Rabble-Rousing As Letter Writers Keep Count

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE 

 BODY:
Louis Jay Herman has an opinion on everything. And he is eager to prove it.
With little encouragement Mr. Herman, who lives on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, pulls out his master list detailing the 859 letters he has written to The New York Times since 1987. Another list synopsizes the 123 letters that have made it into print -- including the one bashing Pete Rose, another defending Italian Fascists against charges of anti-Semitism, a third making his argument against the need to floss daily. On a third list, he tracks the success of others whose great passion is writing letters to editors. 
 "I keep a close watch on my various rivals," said Mr. Herman, who has built a second career commenting on the times after retiring as a United Nations translator. "I want to know if I'm still No. 1. I am."
He and his rivals see newspapers and magazines as an intellectual casino of fleeting fame -- they write scores of letters to various publications hoping that a few will make it into print, putting their names on the lips of thousands of people whom they could not possibly buttonhole on the street.
In the past, frequent letter writers have been portrayed as blowhards, gadflies and rabble-rousers. In the 1950's, a staple of Steve Allen's "Tonight" show was a skit in which he read, with bulging eyes and clenched fists, actual letters culled from the papers.
But now, amid the flood of callers to talk shows and the flamers on Internet, people who write letters to the editor seem almost quaint, like contemplative souls committed to reason in a world where "in your face" is de rigueur.
"I don't even listen to talk radio," said George Jochnowitz, who writes five to seven letters a month to various publications. "I write because the process forces me to sit down and think about how I really feel about an issue, to focus, revise and clarify my views. A lot of time I'm just letting off steam, but I like to think it's well-thought-out steam."
Most big newspapers and magazines print only a tiny fraction of the letters they receive. The Times, for example, gets roughly 1,500 letters a week and runs 60; Time magazine receives about 1,500 and prints 35; The Nation gets about 100 and runs about 5, and National Review usually runs about 10 letters out of 150 in each biweekly issue.
Serious letter writers increase their odds by following some basic rules: keep it short, avoid profanity, always refer to an article that has appeared in the publication. Those who work hardest at it, like Mr. Herman, say their success rate hovers at 8 to 12 percent.
Still, they keep churning them out, because like all gamblers they are philosophers at heart: they understand they must sit through a lot of losing hands to score big.
They are also romantics, trapped in a relationship of imagined slights and seldom-requited love. They write to people without names ("Dear Editor") who never respond, and they say they are mystified as to why one letter is published and another lands in the waste basket.
But when a letter is printed, said Hugo S. Cunningham, an unemployed 42-year-old Bostonian, it is heartwarming -- a serendipitous smile from the one admired. "It's like out of all of the people who wrote in, they thought you had something important to say," said Mr. Cunningham, who has written more than 400 letters to magazines and newspapers in the last decade.
Mr. Jochnowitz, who is 57 and a professor of linguistics at the College of Staten Island, like most letter writers, fires off commentaries to a broad range of periodicals.
Conservative, liberal, neo-con, domestic and international -- it does not matter as long as they spell his name right. In the last 10 years his letters have been printed in Commentary, The New York Review of Books, China Today, The Daily News, The Staten Island Advance and The Times.
Letter writing became a passion when he returned from a teaching stint in China in 1984. "I had always known that Mao's China was not a paradise," he said. "But now the cruelty and repression was happening to people I knew, people who were my friends. I felt I had an obligation to share what I knew."
Once he got into the swing of things, Mr. Jochnowitz found there were innumerable topics he wanted to address, though Mao and Marx remain his most common subjects.
He often starts his letters with a question: "Why do good people so often believe in bad causes?" Or, "Will no one ever say a word against Shakespeare?"
Mr. Jochnowitz has still not received any answers.

HEADLINE: PULSE;
Going Out of Business

 BODY:
The number of business failures in the region fell last year, a confirmation of continuing economic growth in the area. Connecticut had the nation's largest drop in failures from 1993 to 1994, 48 percent. The number of firms closing up shop last year fell 20 percent in New York State, 23 percent in New Jersey and 17 percent in the nation as a whole. Analysts say business failure data is a good measure of the health of the business sector because it is one of the few economic statistics that can be broken down by region or industry, or both. It is often a lagging indicator of economic conditions, however, and many experts feel the region's economy is currently slowing.

HEADLINE: DANCE REVIEW;
Denver Ensemble Reaches Back For a Look at Black Themes

BYLINE: By JACK ANDERSON 

DATELINE: DURHAM, N.C., June 18

 BODY:
The American Dance Festival is always up to date. Every year it brings to the campus of Duke University here an array of premieres that attest to the diversity of modern dance. Yet even as it shows where modern dance is and hints at where it may be going, it is also concerned with where it has been.
On Saturday night at Page Auditorium, the Cleo Parker Robinson Dance Ensemble, a company from Denver, showed some of the ways in which choreographers have treated black American themes by offering works from the 1930's, 40's and 50's. 
 The most amazing of them was "How Long Brethren?," which Helen Tamiris choreographed in 1937 to a recorded score (for voices and instrumental ensemble) that Genevieve Pitot arranged from black protest songs. The dance was almost awesomely austere. Each of its scenes made use of only a few carefully chosen steps and poses, yet the piece had tremendous impact. And it was lovingly staged by Dianne McIntyre, aided by three members of the original cast: Pauline Tish, Ida Little Arbeit and Sasha Pressman.
Tamiris, who lived from 1905 to 1966, thought dance could express contemporary issues, and she was one of America's first white choreographers to depict aspects of black life. With its images of oppression and defiance, "How Long Brethren?" is very much a product of the socially conscious 1930's. But the monumental choreography for a cast of 16 women makes it more than a period piece.
The weightedness of the steps is especially remarkable. Bodies often bend low as if to suggest weariness. The dancers never merely walk, they trudge.
Two scenes are particularly impressive for their economy and power. In one, the way in which seven women twitch lightly while standing on boxes suggests that they are the victims of lynchings in their death throes. Tamiris here conveys a sense of horror through extreme understatement.
The finale is equally evocative. Dancers are packed so tightly in huddles that all sense of personal identity is lost. Hope, too, seems lost. But a soloist moves among the women like an idealist egotistically exhorting them to rebel. Karah Abiog danced this role with fervor, and the scene became a lament against injustice and a statement of faith in liberation.
Like her better-known contemporaries Martha Graham and Doris Humphrey, Tamiris was among the modern-dance innovators of the 1920's and 30's. Her works have been neglected in recent years. If "How Long Brethren?" is typical of their quality, more of them should be revived.
Katherine Dunham, who was born in 1912, is one of the pioneers of American black dance. An anthropologist trained at the University of Chicago, she knows how to do choreographic research. She also knows how to entertain.
She took an amused look at a 1920's Prohibition speak-easy in "Barrelhouse Blues," a comic sketch that dates from 1943. Ms. Robinson and Germaul Barnes played two young flappers who cavorted to a score by Jess Stacy. They managed to make their hip wiggles an erotic enticement.
Seated on a bar stool watching them was an older woman, portrayed by Stephanie Carden. She gazed on their antics with a worldly and slightly cynical expression that implied she had experienced the pain as well as the joy of love and now harbored no romantic illusions.
Donald McKayle conjured a romantic dream world in "Nocturne," which he choreographed in 1952 to pieces by Louis Hardin, a blind street musician who called himself Moondog. Mr. McKayle, who was born in 1930, has become an unusually versatile choreographer. "Nocturne" found him in a lyrical mood. Movements looked light and effortless, and the piece ended with a whole ensemble of embracing lovers.
Yet just as Moondog put quirky melodies into formal contrapuntal structures, Mr. McKayle also organized movement in tight, formal patterns. The illusion of ease is the result of artistic discipline.
In addition to glancing over dance history, the company presented "Wisdom of the Baobab Tree," which Ms. Robinson choreographed last year to a score by Jay Hoggard. Marceline Freeman was cast as an ancestral spirit, and she summoned an African community into ceremonial dances.
The choreography, though energetic, was vague and repetitive. Recorded voices chanted phrases that included "Ritual!" and "God Is Love." But the dancers seldom seemed involved in any specific sort of ritual, and the work as a whole was sentimental rather than inspiring.

HEADLINE: More Misery for Vietnamese Detainees

 BODY:
Only a few weeks ago, it looked as if the sad saga of the tens of thousands of Vietnamese stuck in squalid detention camps across Southeast Asia was finally heading toward a tolerable conclusion. Those who did not qualify as political refugees were headed back, under U.N. monitoring, to a Vietnam that was, if no paradise, at least less impoverished and repressive than the one they fled.
Then House Republicans attached an amendment to the foreign aid bill that calls for reconsidering the asylum claims of those already found ineligible and cutting off funding to monitor and assist returned refugees in Vietnam. This clumsy political gesture touched off riots in the detention camps against any further repatriations and halted the return flow. 
 Reinterviewing may sound like a generous offer, and many who voted for the provision sincerely wanted to help the Vietnamese in detention camps. But the more likely result is further suffering.
The amendment, which the Senate has not acted on and which President Clinton opposes, may never become law. And it is not at all clear whether Congress can compel the executive branch to grant political asylum to people who do not qualify.
The story of the Vietnamese boat people began nearly 20 years ago, in the years following Hanoi's triumph over South Vietnam. Millions of Vietnamese set sail in small boats fleeing ethnic and political persecution and economic misery. Many died at sea or fell victim to local pirates.
Those who made it to nearby shores were received with hostility and herded into makeshift camps to await possible acceptance elsewhere. Eventually, more than a million were admitted to the United States and tens of thousands were accepted by other countries.
Some 40,000 remain in Southeast Asian camps, more than half in Hong Kong. All have been formally found ineligible for asylum under international law, which requires well-founded fear of persecution. Procedural questions have been raised about a small number of screenings, and these might usefully be reviewed. But the House's call for a wholesale reopening will only hold out false hopes and prevent agreement to voluntary return. Meanwhile, cutting off monitoring and assistance funds can only hurt those who have already returned.
The Senate, if it truly cares about the fate of these Vietnamese, should avoid repeating the House's mistake.

HEADLINE: Don't Forget Our Foreign Aid Also Helps People

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Foreign Aid Has Its Uses" (Op-Ed, June 12): Brent Scowcroft makes a case for foreign aid as leverage for furthering foreign policy aims. What about that very small portion of foreign aid that goes to support programs in developing countries where the people may simply need help? 
 I am concerned that in the frenzy to cut the budget, Americans will forget that we're a nation of compassionate people who want to help those who just need a boost up to achieve those blessings of food, health and education that we all wish for each other.
As a private citizen I saw American foreign aid dollars at work in Bangladesh. It's good work, the kind the Republicans and Democrats alike can applaud -- helping people help themselves at the grass-roots level.
During my visit I toured the Women's Self-Help Clinic, which operates in Badda, a poor district in Dhaka, the capital. ("Poor" in Dhaka means your children are malnourished, never attend school and often subsist on the proceeds of begging.) The clinic serves the women of a square-mile area where 400,000 people live. Remarkable for a Muslim country, it is administered almost entirely by women.
The Women's Self-Help Clinic exists because of Danish, Dutch and American money, some from governments and some from private donations, and not least by the clinic's own efforts to sell what it can produce. This is true multinational cooperation of the most constructive kind.
The United States Agency for International Development supports the family planning activity of the Badda Self-Help Clinic and family planning programs all over Asia. And that support has achieved remarkable success. In Bangladesh the total fertility rate has fallen from about seven children per woman to about five.
This figure comes from a report by Ronald Freedman, published by the East-West Center's Program on Population. He writes, "When I first began studying Asia's fertility and family planning efforts 33 years ago, neither I nor other serious observers expected such rapid fertility declines to occur on that continent -- certainly not in populations with such large, poor, and illiterate strata."
Emerging trouble spots in the world are those countries whose societies fail because of overpopulation, illiteracy, famine. The resulting civil wars and floods of refugees call forth billions of dollars of emergency aid and even troop occupations that might be avoided through programs that address those social ills.
Don't believe we can't afford to help. We can't afford not to.
 
JULIE ANTELMAN
Chicago, June 12, 1995
 
The writer is with the National Opinion Research Center.

HEADLINE: Container Tax Repeal Means Jobs for New York

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your June 12 news article on lobbying in Albany for repeal of the soft drink container tax makes interesting reading but fails to emphasize significant points justifying the industry's position and that of Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature. 
 The container tax stripped the soft drink industry of almost all profits during the 1990's. Employment dropped by 40 percent and the number of bottlers was reduced from 109 to 47 over the past 10 years as a result of the combined effects of this tax and the 22 percent decline in the price per ounce of colas.
This tax was anticompetitive since it unfairly penalized only the carbonated beverage part of the soft drink industry.
The tax was originally imposed to help pay for a proposed environmental bond issue that the voters subsequently rejected, yet the tax was left standing. The bond issue didn't have anything to do with the soft drink and beer industries, since these industries already collected and recycled their packaging at no cost to taxpayers in New York under the returnable container law.
The result of the tax cut will be the creation of hundreds of new jobs over the next few years. In fact, one of my clients, the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of New York, plans to hire more than 600 new employees in 1995.
What the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, saw was bad law and bad economics, both of which were hurting the state and its citizens. He chose to insist that it be corrected, and that is the mark of real leadership -- bipartisan leadership shared with Governor Pataki and supported by Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver.
When the Legislature passes a bad bill, it is the hallmark of strong leadership to stand tall and to change it.
 
ROBERT J. MALITO
New York, June 12, 1995
 
The writer is a lawyer.

HEADLINE: Anti-Jobs Policy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Clinton Administration is ready to blame the Federal Reserve Board if the economy shows more signs of dipping into recession (Business Day, June 13). The Fed has been raising interest rates to slow down the economy, but the Administration now hints the rates should be lowered. 
 Sadly, the Administration is silent about the bipartisan policy, accepted by the Fed as well, that the unemployment rate must be kept at 6 percent or higher to control inflation by depressing wages. This antijobs policy is more important than the casual political talk in both parties about the need to create jobs and put those on welfare back to work.
 
FREDERICK C. THAYER
Prof. Emeritus, U. of Pittsburgh
Pittsburgh, June 14, 1995

HEADLINE: Don't Forget Our Foreign Aid Also Helps People;
Shaping the World

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Foreign Aid Has Its Uses" (Op-Ed, June 12), Brent Scowcroft makes a strong case against the devastating cuts in our foreign aid budget proposed by the Republican leadership in Congress. 
 General Scowcroft and I agree that foreign aid is a crucial instrument of foreign policy in regions of strategic importance to the United States, like the Middle East. However, I disagree that promoting sustainable economic development and democracy overseas "are not top priorities."
Support for the Middle East peace process is a priority for America today, but foreign aid is as much about the world of the year 2020, 2050 and beyond. What could be a higher national priority than building a world for our children that is less hostile to American interests?
The alarming increase in the number of the world's people who are born into poverty, pollution of the environment, the spread of deadly viruses and the amassing of weapons by undemocratic governments may not imperil us immediately, but solving these problems is no less important to our security in the long term. With the cold war behind us, exerting leadership to combat these global threats should be a priority of our foreign policy.
Cutting foreign aid may seem like an easy choice, since none of the proponents of these cuts will be in office 50 years hence. But there can hardly be a better example of "penny-wise, pound foolish." Even worse, it comes at a time when our opportunity to shape the world of future generations has never been greater.
 
PATRICK LEAHY
U.S. Senator from Vermont
Washington, June 13, 1995

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U. S. Threatens Japan Over Air Rights
The Clinton Administration threatened to bar Japanese airlines from some of their most profitable cargo routes to the United States in retaliation for Tokyo's refusal to allow Federal Express to broaden its operations.
While the aviation controversy involves far lower stakes than the auto dispute, the White House made clear that it was willing to use confrontation, across the board, to move Japan's bureaucracy. [Page A1.]
 
Saudi Arabian Jet Order
Saudi Arabia said it would proceed with a $6 billion aircraft purchase from Boeing and McDonnell Douglas. [D6.]
 
Second Bid for Bally Gaming
Alliance Gaming, an operator of gambling machines and casinos, offered $134 million, or $12.50 a share, in cash and stock for Bally Gaming International, a maker of slot machines. The unsolicited bid came two months after WMS Industries agreed to acquire Bally Gaming for $127 million in stock and cash, or about $11.85 a share. [D4.]
 
Prudential Settles Charges
Prudential Securities has agreed to pay a $725,000 fine to settle charges with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission that the firm failed to supervise properly a former broker who engaged in fraudulent trades involving energy futures. [D6.]
 
Goldman Earnings Jump
Goldman, Sachs has made $500 million in the first half of 1995, more than in all of 1994, some partners say, because of an increase in underwriting revenue, merger fees and rallies in the markets. [D8.]
 
Problems for a Prison Operator
When the newest jail run by Esmor Corrections in Elizabeth, N.J., erupted in violence on Sunday, it echoed the troubles dogging the company's rapid expansion. [A1.]
 
Newspaper's Future Cloudy
The editor of New York Newsday said an examination of the newspaper's viability was under way and that its parent company, Times Mirror, might even consider closing the New York City edition. [B3.]
 
A Refrigerator Search
The New York Power Authority is hoping to induce appliance makers to build smaller, energy-efficient refrigerators for public housing units to cut electric bills. [B1.]
 
S.& L. Report Criticized
Workers at the Dallas office of the Resolution Trust Corporation questioned the accuracy of a Treasury Department report that concluded the Government had made adequate efforts to recover money from wrongdoers at failed savings and loans. [B8.]
 
How an Index Is Made
A day spent watching how data are collected for the Consumer Price Index shows the messiness inherent in monitoring changes in a $7 trillion economy. [D2.]
 
I.B.M. Steps Closer to Apple
I.B.M. introduced computers based on the PowerPC computer chip and took a step toward offering the software that underlies Apple Computer's Macintosh. But I.B.M. executives were vague about the companies' relationship. [D6.]
 
Cuba Will Not Extradite Vesco
The Cuban Government told American diplomats that it did not plan to extradite Robert L. Vesco, who is wanted on embezzlement and narcotics charges. [A8.]
 
More Than Faux Jewels
QVC plans a campaign to help dispel its image as the "cubic zirconia network." Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D11.]

HEADLINE: Stocks Keep Setting Highs; Nasdaq Jumps

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Led by technology companies and bank issues, the stock market rose to record levels yesterday as the Nasdaq composite index posted its biggest one-day leap in 14 months. Sharply rising bond prices gave equities an additional lift.
The Dow Jones industrial average hit a record 4,553.68 yesterday, up 42.89 points. The broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 5.39 points, to 545.22, also a record. But the top performer for the day was the Nasdaq composite, rich with technology stocks, which rose 13.44 points, to a record level of 922.09. 
 So far this year, the Dow and the Standard & Poor's 500 have each risen nearly 19 percent and the Nasdaq almost 23 percent. These are bigger gains than these indexes posted in all of 1993 and 1994 combined.
Meanwhile, the dollar held steady in advance of a speech tonight by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, as well as the release, scheduled for tomorrow, of the Fed's so-called beige book report on the economy.
The financial markets have received mixed signals from the Fed and Mr. Greenspan as to whether the central bank will cut interest rates, which could help stocks and bonds, but send the dollar plunging as foreign investors shift to currencies paying higher interest rates.
After rising for three sessions, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.57 percent yesterday from 6.62 percent.
The bond market is factoring in a large cut in interest rates to 5 percent from 6 percent over the next six months, said William Gross, managing director of the Pacific Investment Management Company, one of the nation's biggest bond buyers.
"It bothers me a little bit," Mr. Gross said about the bond market's assumptions, but he continues to buy bonds. He avoids shorter-term bonds, like the two-year and three-year, but is still confident about 30-year bonds.
Still, stocks in New York yesterday continued to rise even when bond prices retreated in the last hour of trading, indicating that stock traders were particularly optimistic despite uncertainty about Fed policy.
One reason for this buoyancy wasthe $5.4 billion bid by the First Union Corporation for First Fidelity Bancorp, prompting takeover speculation in other bank stocks. Another was that several high-technology companies reported earnings or gave presentations to securities analysts and others in New York.
Of the top 10 movers in the top Nasdaq 100 stocks, nine were technology issues. The Intel Corporation, the big semiconductor manufacturer, led the index, rising 3 5/8 a share, to 61 3/4, on continuing indications of strong demand for computers during the normally slow summer months. Intel, a favorite among institutional investors, was also the most active stock at nearly 16 million shares.
The Microsoft Corporation, another institutional favorite, also rose 2153/16 a share, to 8913/16 , and the Oracle Corporation, a leading software company, rose 1 a share, to 38 5/8.
Part of the reason technology stocks were so prominent on Wall Street yesterday was New York visits by executives of high-tech businesses. Some of the biggest technology companies are making presentations at a technology conference sponsored by Bear, Stearns & Company in New York. Other companies are also in town for an industry trade show called PC Expo.
For example, Micron Technology Inc., after reporting record earnings and 53 percent gross margins last week, said yesterday at the conference that it might increase its profit margins further in the next several quarters. Micron shares rose 3, to 53.
"These conferences are just a fabulous lovefest," said Joseph V. Battipaglia, chief investment strategist for Gruntal & Company.
The other news event that helped lift stocks was First Union's acquisition bid, the biggest of its kind. With interest rates relatively low, the financial-services industry is posting record profits. Deregulation also provides incentives for banks and other institutions to merge, so when a big merger is announced, stock traders speculate on other mergers, lifting bank stocks as a group.
Twenty of the 22 stocks in the S.& P. regional banks group rose, led by First Fidelity, which agreed to merge with First Union. First Fidelity shares rose 10 1/4, to 59. Shares in First Union fell 1 3/4, to 45 7/8.
The dollar fell to 84.63 Japanese yen from 84.76 yen in New York trading and fell to 1.3970 German marks from 1.4002. The dollar has been stable for nearly three weeks, at more than 84 yen and around 1.4 marks.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 2.22 points, to 292.18, on volume of 323 million shares, slightly below this year's average daily trading volume of 332 million shares. Advancing stocks outnumbered decliners, 1,343 to 950. The American Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.81 point, to 496.21.
Among advancers was Lannet Data Communications Ltd., an Israeli maker of computer local area networks, which agreed to be acquired by Madge N.V., a Dutch company, for $300 million. Lannet shares rose 4 1/8, to 23 1/2. The Milwaukee Insurance Group rose 6 3/4, to 20 1/4, after Unitrin Inc. announced plans to buy the insurer for $94 million.
Among declining stocks was that of the Sunbeam Corporation, the household products company, which dropped 5, to 13 3/8, after it lowered estimates for second-quarter and full-year results. And Esmor Correction Services Inc., a manager of jails, fell 2 a share, to 17 1/2, after a riot by illegal aliens broke out in a detention center it operated in Elizabeth, N.J., for the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Local officials criticized Esmor's operation.

HEADLINE: The Battle To Protect A Shipyard From Cuts

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: KITTERY, Me., June 17

 BODY:
In the basement of his house here, surrounded by pictures of submarines, William D. McDonough, a retired Navy captain, has been waging what may be his final battle: the fight to save the 195-year-old Portsmouth Naval Shipyard.
As the military tries to streamline operations in the post-cold war era, an independent commission in Washington will begin voting Thursday on a list of military installations to be closed, a list that includes Portsmouth, the country's oldest public shipyard. 
 Sprawling across an island on the Piscataqua River between Maine and New Hampshire, the shipyard started building submarines during World War I and continued until 1971 and now overhauls and refuels them. The panel's recommendations must go to President Clinton by July 1, and then to Congress for approval.
"Our naval yard has been a major player in the national security of the U.S. ever since we declared our independence," said Captain McDonough, who was the shipyard's commander for five years until 1979. "We are the submarine yard. We have been in the forefront of every significant development in submarining -- the hull shape, the deep diving, the sound isolation. We were the first Government yard to build a nuclear submarine, the first government yard to overhaul a nuclear submarine, the first government yard to refuel a nuclear submarine."
The shipyard, which does classified work and is not open to the public, also has a central role in the town's economy, although Kittery is doing a booming business on a mile-long stip of outlet stores offering goods like discounted Waterford crystal and Ralph Lauren sheets. Of the 30,000 people who live in Portsmouth, N.H., and Kittery, 4,100 work here. The civilian payroll amounts to $221 million a year.
Portsmouth was one of 31 military installations the independent Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission added in May to a list of 146 bases already under review to be closed, reduced or consolidated. The Pentagon recommended the closing of two other big naval shipyards, Long Beach and the Ship Repair Facility on the island of Guam, but wants Portsmouth, which overhauls and refuels Los Angeles-class attack nuclear submarines, to stay open.
Eighty-five percent of the installations on the list will be cut, said John Earnhardt, spokesman for the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission, which is headed by Alan J. Dixon, a former Senator from Illinois.
Just as proposed base closings elsewhere have inspired grass-roots lobbying efforts, the battle to save the shipyard has brought together community leaders and citizens from Maine and New Hampshire, as well as the governors and Congressional delegations of both states.
The base here has an advantage in the New Hampshire Presidential primary: the White House strongly signaled to the Pentagon that it preferred that Portsmouth stay open.
But a computer analysis showed that over 20 years the Government would save $2.3 billion by closing Portsmouth, the base closure commission says. Most of the work now done at Portsmouth would be shifted to the naval shipyard in Norfolk, Va.
In an unusual gesture that seemed to indicate how difficult the decision on Portsmouth will be, all eight members of the commission toured the shipyard the day before the hearing.
In the fight to keep Portsmouth open, Captain McDonough helped organize 1,000 area residents into a caravan of 22 buses for a trip to Boston on June 3, when the base closure commission held a hearing at the John F. Kennedy Library.
Eileen Foley, the Mayor of Portsmouth, made the trip to Boston. Mrs. Foley, who is 77, was one of 25,000 civilians employed at the shipyard during World War II. "There were three shifts," she said. "It was continuous madness. Everybody worked all the time. It was a patriotic thing. You felt like you were the woman behind the man behind the boats."
Portsmouth built more than 70 submarines during World War II, more than any other shipyard. With its deep harbor and heritage of master shipbuilders, the shipyard has recorded a long list of firsts.
In 1690, long before it was established as a United States Naval Shipyard, builders there completed the H.M.S. Falkland for the British Royal Navy, the first warship built in North America. In 1776, the 18-gun sloop U.S.S. Ranger was built for John Paul Jones, the Revolutionary War hero. In 1917 Portsmouth built the first American submarine.
Threatened base closures are a part of life at Portsmouth since the 1960's. "We have gone through these periodic threats since immediately after the Civil War," said Captain McDonough, who heads the nonprofit Seacoast Shipyard Association here, which was formed to fight past threats. "It's nothing new to us."
Paul Parent has worked at the shipyard 21 years. "I've been through this since I started," said Mr. Parent, who is a rigger, a job that requires him to crawl into confined spaces in submarines to remove components for overhauling. "They were always going to close the Navy yard. We are the best in the business. Nobody can take that away from us.

GRAPHIC: Photo: William D. McDonough, a retired Navy captain, walked across the river from the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard, which he once commanded and is now trying to save. A commission is deciding whether to close it. (Ed Quinn for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. Threatens Aviation Curbs Against Japan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration broadened its confrontation with Japan today, threatening to bar Japanese airlines from some of their most profitable cargo routes to the United States in retaliation for Tokyo's refusal to allow Federal Express to expand its operations there.
The threatened sanctions, which would go into effect next month, are separate from the Administration's June 28 deadline for imposing 100 percent tariffs on 13 models of Japanese luxury cars unless Japan agrees to open its markets wider to American autos and auto parts. 
 The aviation case has far lower stakes than the dispute over autos. But White House officials said they intended to send a message to Tokyo: that the Administration was willing to use direct confrontation, across the board, as a tool to prod Japan's entrenched bureaucracy.
The new dispute also underlines a striking reversal of roles, one in which Japan is seeking a solution it says is unacceptable in the heated confrontation over automotive trade. And Washington, while opposing a specific market-share target for air carriers, is advocating just such goals in auto trade. [Page D1.]
The action in the airline dispute came at the end of a day of conflicting signals and countersignals on auto trade. Last-ditch negotiating sessions are scheduled Thursday and Friday in Geneva, and all weekend, Japanese officials floated the possibility that their car makers might agree to increase their use of American parts. But almost all the proposals, at least those the Japanese discussed publicly, were focused on increases in the "local content" of cars made in Japanese factories in the United States.
If the Administration settled for that, it would be backing away from a primary objective in the car talks. All along, it has sought to force the purchase of more American parts for cars made in Japan, where the intricate network of relationships between manufacturers and their suppliers is particularly tight and highly resistant to outsiders' entry.
American officials said that some of the new Japanese proposals represented a step forward. Nonetheless, the gulf between these offers and the minimum American requirements remained enormous.
"So far, we are hearing generalities," a senior Administration official said in the thick of the auto talks. "Where they are resisting is the tight, measurable parameters we need to demonstrate a few years from now whether they are meeting the goals we agree on. And that is the hardest thing for them to agree to."
In Brussels, Yoshihiro Sakamoto, vice minister of international trade and industry and the chief Japanese negotiator, told reporters that "pessimism would represent my honest feeling at the moment." He accused the United States of inflexibility, saying, "There are no signs whatsoever that would imply that the U.S. side will present new proposals which would form a compromise."
Such statements, by either side, are common in the last week or so of any trade negotiation. But they may well go beyond posturing in this case because Japan and the United States both know that the automotive market is such a visible and important business for each country that any bargain struck in the next week will form the basis for agreements for years to come in other industries.
"This is not about automobiles," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said in Halifax, Nova Scotia, during the weekend, where he attended the summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations. "It is about access to the Japanese market."
The White House today repeated President Clinton's pledge to proceed with the $5.9 billion in car sanctions a week from Wednesday if no agreement is reached.
But it is a prospect that leaves some officials nervous. The State Department and some in the Pentagon have expressed concern that the actual imposition of sanctions would harm the broader Japanese-American relationship, especially if it overlaps with a particularly sensitive period, the 50th anniversary in August of the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, and the Japanese surrender a few days later.
The timing helps explain why Secretary of State Warren Christopher met twice in Halifax with his Japanese counterpart, Yohei Kono. American officials said Mr. Christopher was trying to get the Japanese Foreign Ministry, which usually favors a softer line than the trade bureaucrats, more involved.
Still, the economic officials in Washington who argue that diplomacy has too often been placed ahead of economic interests remain dominant. They argue that sanctions are the best way to convince Tokyo that a new era has arrived.
The threatened aviation curbs are an example. That dispute began when Japan refused to approve Federal Express flights from its new cargo hub in the former Subic Bay Naval Station in the Philippines.
Under a 1952 aviation agreement with Japan, approval of the Federal Express Corporation's rights to land cargo in Japan from Subic should be automatic, the Americans say. Japan has withheld that approval, declaring that the aviation agreement -- signed during the American occupation -- is one-sided and needs to be renegotiated.
"We have tried to resolve this dispute through negotiations," Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena said this afternoon. "But the Japanese Government's failure to approve Federal Express's services, which are clearly provided for by the bilateral agreement, leaves us no other course of action."
Invoking a provision of the Federal Aviation Act, Mr. Pena proposed sanctions that would prohibit Japan's two largest cargo carriers, Japan Airlines and Nippon Cargo Airlines, from delivering freight to the United States that was picked up elsewhere in Asia and routed through Japan. He said Washington would consider barring flights originating in Hong Kong, Indonesia, Singapore, Taiwan and Thailand; the final decision would be made after hearings scheduled to end on July 14.
American and other foreign carriers fly out of each of those five countries, so the ban would have a minimum effect on the American economy. But the symbolic effect of blocking Japanese companies from routes worth hundreds of millions of dollars a year would be great.
The key question facing American negotiators in the auto talks is whether Japan's ambitious Minister of International Trade and Industry, Ryutaro Hashimoto, has changed his political calculations about the usefulness of saying no to Washington. Mr. Hashimoto is considered a leading candidate to become Prime Minister, late this year or in a subsequent reshuffling of governments.
But in Halifax, Mr. Hashimoto was accommodating and seemingly eager to get talks started again. On Friday he asked Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, to help arrange a meeting of their deputies before the Geneva negotiations. That gave the Americans their first faint glimmer of optimism.
Yet the differences are wide, and the pronouncements on both sides so sharp, that it may be too late for Mr. Hashimoto to find a way out. Similarly, Mr. Clinton would open himself to criticism, from his own party and from Republicans, if he appeared to back away from a confrontation that the White House has committed so much political capital to winning.

HEADLINE: Cuba Tells U.S. It Will Not Extradite Fugitive Financier

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
The Cuban Government told American diplomats today that it does not plan to extradite Robert L. Vesco to the United States even though Cuba hinted after arresting him in Havana two weeks ago that it would hand him over, Administration officials said today.
State Department officials said they were disappointed by the decision, which came after the Clinton Administration told Cuban officials that it wanted Mr. Vesco returned so that he could be tried on embezzlement and narcotics charges. 
 "The Cubans are telling us, 'no deal,' " said one Administration official.
Many American diplomats were surprised by Cuba's decision to arrest Mr. Vesco on espionage charges after he lived a life of luxury in Cuba for a dozen years. Several officials suggested that Cuba had hinted that it might extradite Mr. Vesco as a way to develop good will with the United States at a time when it is eager to have the 32-year-old economic embargo against the Cuban Government eased.
But some officials said they always doubted Cuba would turn over Mr. Vesco, a financier who fled the United States in the early 1970's during an embezzlement investigation, since he is reputed to have information linking many Cuban officials to criminal activity.
Joseph Sullivan, the head of the American Interests Section in Havana, which serves as a liaison office between the Cuban and American Governments in the absence of diplomatic relations, met with Cuban officials late today in what American officials described as a last-ditch effort to persuade Cuba to extradite Mr. Vesco.
CNN reported today that the Cuban President, Fidel Castro, had said in a private dinner on Sunday with the network's executives and journalists that it would be "immoral" to extradite Mr. Vesco and make him a "pawn of U.S.-Cuba relations." Mr. Castro was quoted as saying that Cuba would conduct its own investigation of Mr. Vesco.
American diplomats say Mr. Vesco must have done something to run afoul of Mr. Castro or his brother, Raul, the head of the Cuban military, because for years Mr. Vesco had been free to conduct his business dealings with their unofficial blessing.
Rafael Dausa, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, said Mr. Vesco has been charged with being "a provocateur or agent for foreign special services," although he refused to specify which country's special services Mr. Vesco was believed to be serving.
In recent interviews, American diplomats, intelligence experts and law enforcement officials said that during his years in Cuba, Mr. Vesco has been heavily involved in drug trafficking, money laundering and smuggling American goods into Cuba.
Administration officials said Cuba declined to turn over Mr. Vesco even though they had complied with Cuba's request to provide information about the numerous indictments Mr. Vesco faces in the United States. They include a 1976 indictment handed down by a Federal grand jury in New York for siphoning off more than $200 million from a Geneva-based mutual fund and a 1973 federal indictment in Washington for making an illegal $200,000 contribution to the re-election campaign of President Richard M. Nixon.
In addition, a Federal grand jury in Jacksonville, Fla., indicted Mr. Vesco in 1989 for conspiring with Carlos Lehder Rivas, a Colombian drug cartel leader, to smuggle narcotics. Ten days ago, prosecutors in Tallahassee, Fla., unsealed a 1984 indictment that charges Mr. Vesco with cocaine trafficking.
One senior State Department official said that after Mr. Vesco was arrested, an official in the Cuban Foreign Ministry told the American liaison office in Havana: "We have him. Are you interested in him?" The Clinton Administration read this as an offer to hand over Mr. Vesco if the United States were to reciprocate in some unspecified way. The State Department has said repeatedly, however, that the Administration would not make any reciprocal gestures in exchange for Mr. Vesco's extradicton.
A senior Administration official said that even though Cuba had strongly suggested two weeks ago that it might extradite Mr. Vesco, it emphasized today that it was not making -- and had never made -- any formal offer to do so.
Within the Administration, officials speculated that there were two reasons why Havana had decided not to extradite Mr. Vesco: he knew too much that could incriminate senior Cuban officials, and the Clinton Administration did not offer enough to make it worthwhile for Mr. Castro to hand over America's most wanted financial criminal.
American law enforcement officials acknowledge some ambivalence about the prospect of having Mr. Vesco returned. While it would be a coup to have such a well-known criminal sent back, they fear that it would be hard to prosecute him for financial fraud because some witnesses have died and the evidence has grown old.

HEADLINE: Public Housing Efficiency Plan, Step 1: Get New Refrigerators

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
The New York Power Authority has persuaded housing officials to throw away most of the 180,000 refrigerators in New York City's public housing units over the next nine years -- even if they are working fine. The authority will recruit manufacturers to build more efficient ones, and will provide them free to the New York City Housing Authority.
This, power officials say, is the way to make money in the energy business these days. 
 The key to the deal, to be signed today, is energy efficiency. Refrigerators use more electricity than anything else in an apartment, and the models now in use by the Housing Authority, some of which are 20 years old, are the kitchen equivalent of gas guzzlers. The Housing Authority believes that new models will save money on electric bills, while the Power Authority hopes that innovations like the free-fridge deal will help it keep customers and carve out a niche for itself amid growing competition.
Appliance manufacturers have made tremendous strides in refrigerator efficiency in the last few years, but so far only in the larger, more expensive models used in big suburban kitchens.
The reason is that homeowners buy refrigerators and also pay the electric bills, so they may consider efficiency when shopping. In apartments, tenants usually pay electric bills, so landlords tend to shop for the cheapest models. "The landlords have no motivation to buy the efficient one," said an energy expert who has pushed the new plan, Ashok Guptah of the Natural Resources Defense Council.
But in New York public housing, the Housing Authority buys the refrigerators and also pays the electric bills. The Power Authority, which took over serving the Housing Authority from Consolidated Edison in 1976, supplies the electricity. It believes that it can induce manufacturers to serve a huge, ready-made market -- public housing -- by adapting new technologies to make an apartment-sized, 14-cubic-foot refrigerator. The Power Authority hopes to line up several other housing authorities that it supplies -- and maybe some others out of state -- to sweeten the incentive for appliance makers.
"We think that between New York and a few other big cities, we have a market for 50,000 refrigerators a year, which is enough to get manufacturers excited about building them," said S. David Freeman, president and chief executive of the Power Authority.
Once the machines have been developed, Power Authority officials say, they may be adopted by landlords of other subsidized housing, like Mitchell-Lama developments or buildings for the elderly. And they may be sold at retail for co-op owners.
Mr. Guptah said that the new refrigerators could be developed using existing technology. His group helped organize a consortium of 24 utilities two years ago that paid a $30 million prize to the developer of a 22-cubic-foot "super-efficient" refrigerator.
If all the Housing Authority refrigerators are replaced with power-stingy models, the authority will save $5 million from its annual electric bill, now $79 million. For the first few years the savings will go to pay back the Power Authority for the new refrigerators; after that they will accrue to the Housing Authority, which will undoubtedly find another use for the money.
"The budget cuts are coming sooner or later on the Federal level," said John P. Hamill, a spokesman for the authority. "We don't have to wait till it happens."
Of the high-tech refrigerators, he said: "It's the future. We might as well get with it now."
The refrigerator deal is part of a contract to be signed today that extends an electricity supply agreement between the Power Authority and the Housing Authority until 2004.
The contract, combined with a contract signed by New York City in March, could also help assure the future of the Power Authority. The Authority has seen its costs soar because of Indian Point 3, a nuclear plant it owns in Buchanan, N.Y., that has been shut for 28 months. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said yesterday, though, that it believed the plant was ready to re-open.
Mr. Freeman, who organized a "bounty" program for old refrigerators at the last utility he ran, in Sacramento, Calif., has pledged that the authority will find its niche by being a leader in efficiency, which in electricity goes hand in hand with environmentalism.
The Power Authority estimates that Housing Authority refrigerators typically gobble 900 to 1,200 kilowatt-hours per year. A Federal standard implemented for new refrigerators in 1993 -- a kind of gas mileage rule for a kitchen appliance -- is 625 kilowatt-hours per year. The most economical models now on the market use 500.
But this is only the beginning; the Federal Government is expected to lower the limit in 1998 to 440 kilowatt-hours per year. And the Power Authority wants to go lower than that, 355 kilowatt-hours by 1999.
At 9 cents a kilowatt-hour, that puts the typical saving at $45 a year -- and the refrigerator will probably cost about $310, according to Scott Brown, an engineer with the Power Authority.
In the best case, replacing a 1,200-kilowatt-hour-a-year model with one that uses 355 kilowatt-hours would save about 1.5 barrels of oil at a generating station, and all of the related pollution.
The Authority has set aside $40 million for the program and asked manufacturers to submit plans to build the refrigerators.
When the refrigerator program is under way, the Power Authority plans to start replacing the 50,000 tenant-owned air conditioners with new models that will be owned by the Housing Authority. Those, too, should pay for themselves through increased efficiency, engineers believe. They are also considering replacing all the laundry machines with models that use less water, which would also save energy.
In the deal to be announced today, the Housing Authority will receive a rate freeze through 2001. And beginning in 2002, it will have the right to shop for power supplies on the open market, which will have the effect of putting a cap on what the Power Authority can charge. New York City signed a similar deal in March.

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Official Seeks To Close a Major Hospital

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 19

 BODY:
Facing a budget deficit of more than $1 billion, the chief administrative officer of Los Angeles County touched off a storm today by proposing broad cuts that include closing of one of the largest hospitals in the nation, the Los Angeles County-University of California Medical Center.
Saying this may be the last chance to bring the county's spending into line, the administrative officer, Sally R. Reed, warned that profligate spending and short-term fixes had brought Los Angeles face to face with bankruptcy. 
 Her proposals, which will be formally presented to the five-member board of supervisors on Tuesday, also include laying off 10,000 county employees, and closing 30 parks and 12 libraries. The proposals lay out across-the-board reductions of up to 20 percent in most departments, including children's services, the coroner, the district attorney, the sheriff and the courts. If enacted, the cuts would total about $1.2 billion.
"If we act this year, I'm hopeful we will be able to avoid insolvency," Ms. Reed told reporters today in presenting the $11.1 billion budget. "I believe this is our last chance to get our house in order.
"Closing the medical center will save us $310 million," she said, noting that the hospital needs $1 billion in repairs because of last year's earthquake and because of improvements required by updates in the building code. If closing the hospital is not approved by the supervisors, Ms. Reed's proposal offers a "Plan B" that would close four of six smaller hospitals operated by the county.
The board of supervisors is scheduled to open hearings on the budget on July 5.
Zev Yaroslavsky, a county supervisor, who is considered a swing vote on the board, praised Ms. Reed's proposal as "a starting point" but said, "I don't think we're going to close down the biggest hospital in this country." He said, "I don't think it would be approved."
Ms. Reed's proposals drew immediate fire from unions, hospital officials and political analysts.
"These are Draconian cuts -- it astounds me -- because in the end it could create larger problems than it solved," said Sherry Bebitch Jeffe, a political scientist at the Claremont Graduate School.
Harvey Kern, a spokesman for the 2,000-bed hospital, with 9,000 employees, said it was the largest medical center in the nation, with double the admissions of Parkland Hospital in Dallas, which he said was the second largest. Last year, he said, the hospital admitted 60,000 in-patients and served 855,000 out-patients.
The hospital's closing would leave a vast gap in medical coverage here, he said, particularly for the poor, who make up 40 percent of its patients. Half the hospital's patients are covered by Medicaid, which many private hospitals do not accept. "There are 2.9 million uninsured in Los Angeles County, and we are the flagship of the county system," he said.
The hospital has one of only three burn centers in the county, treats half the county's AIDS patients and delivers 10,000 babies a year, many of them to high-risk mothers, Mr. Kern said.
Unions representing county employees also criticized the cuts. Bart Diener, a spokesman for the Service Employees International Union, said, "We are not convinced that the only solution to the crisis is dismantling the health system." He said that the state needed to help the county more.
But economic analysts agreed with Ms. Reed that the county's problems were urgent and that if the hospital was not closed, other dramatic cuts would have to be made.
They said that Los Angeles's fiscal problems dated back to 1978 when Proposition 13, a statewide ballot measure, severely limited property taxes in California. More recently, the state has reallocated revenue from property taxes to education, putting more pressure on county and local governments to finance their own programs.
In addition, Ms. Reed said, the bankrupty of neighboring Orange County -- even though it had different causes -- had frightened investors and made it more difficult to raise money. Orange County's bankruptcy was caused by the failure of high-risk investments of county funds. "All of a sudden, nobody lends you money any more. As long as they lend to us, we stay solvent," Ms. Reed said.
As a sign of slipping confidence, Moody's Investor Service, the ratings agency, announced today that it had placed the county's long-term ratings under review until the county adopts a final budget.
Of the future, Ms. Reed said: "If all the budget propsals are adopted, Los Angeles County will be an organization of approximately 71,000 employees. This is one county employee for every 133 residents.
Los Angeles County covers a vast region with a population of 9 million, including about 3.5 million in Los Angeles.
State Assemblyman Antonio Villaraigosa, who represents the district with the hospital, said he would fight its closure. "Tough choices have to be made," he said. But he added: "What is an alternative? I don't know right now."

HEADLINE: Name-Calling a Talent In 'Mellow' North Korea

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 19

 BODY:
The latest big news is that "the U.S. imperialist war-maniacs" and the "South Korean puppets" are engaging in military maneuvers and plotting to attack North Korea, again.
The last time this happened was the Korean War, a "criminal war against Korea started by the United States," and America is now "shamelessly" planning a Korean War memorial. This is "a foolish attempt to justify its provocation of the war of aggression and its murder of people." 
 That is the way the news looks when it comes from North Korea. As the United States and its allies prepare to give oil and a $4.5 billion nuclear energy system to North Korea, there is little need to worry about being seduced by North Korean flattery.
North Korea and the United States reached agreement last Tuesday on the kind of nuclear reactors that will be given to North Korea, in exchange for its scrapping of its existing nuclear program. It would be harder to use the new kind of reactor for making weapons.
The tone of the North Korean reporting underscores how instinctively hard-line the country remains even as it seeks to build ties with the United States. The harsh attacks also suggest that while North Korea is a formidable negotiator, it has yet to understand the concept of public relations.
North Korean politics are extremely murky, and since the death of Kim Il Sung last July, his son and apparent successor, Kim Jong Il, has not formally been named to fill the vacant positions of President and Communist Party leader. A possible explanation for the North's harsh language is that leaders who are trying to open the country a little bit feel insecure and thus may want to sound as revolutionary as ever.
North Korea's invective against the United States is mild compared with what it says about South Korea and about South Korea's democratically elected President, Kim Young Sam.
Even though South Korea will pay most of the bill for the reactors and may soon supply rice to the North as well, North Korea is constantly engaging in no-adjectives-barred attacks against it.
"The ever-increasing crimes of American soldiers in South Korea are an inevitable result of the abominable flunkeyist treacherous act of the traitor Kim Young Sam serving the United States as he does his grandfather," the Korean Central News Agency said early this month.
The dispatch added, in an official North Korean translation, that Mr. Kim was "a dyed-in-the-wool pro-American stooge who fattens the U.S. munition monopoly plutes."
The invective does not mean that North Korea is adopting a more hard-line position. Some experts who monitor North Korean news outlets say North Korea may have even moderated its blasts against the United States lately -- without softening its attacks against South Korea.
North Korea, for example, has not lately repeated its comment made last month that "the United States is a hotbed of terrorism and the organizer, conductor and supporter of terrorist activities."
"I think the words they are using about the United States are getting a little nicer," said Chong Bong Uk, managing editor of Vantage Point, a South Korea-based newsletter that writes, unaffectionately, about North Korea.
In one sign of a more pragmatic position, North Korea has asked Japan for emergency supplies of rice, a rare and humiliating acknowledgment of its own food shortage. Japan has said it is willing to give at least 300,000 tons of rice, provided that South Korea does not object.
South Korea says North Korea should first accept an offer of South Korean rice, and talks are under way in Beijing between the two Koreas to try to settle the matter. The talks, the first between the two Koreas in a year, may result in deals to ship South Korean rice and Japanese rice alike to North Korea.
"Their tone has softened a bit about Japan recently," apparently because of the request for rice, said Noriyuki Suzuki, who monitors North Korean broadcasts for Radio Press, a Tokyo institute.
North Korea has been particularly irritated lately by American plans to open a Korean War memorial in Washington next month. The North Korean version of history is that the United States started the war by attacking the North, and that the United States has since used quislings to rule South Korea and block Korean reunification.
Workers' Daily, the leading North Korean newspaper, declared this month that the war monument is "an insult to and mockery of the Korean people."
"The United States is engaged in such a despicable act in a bid to justify its war of aggression on Korea and cover up its true color as the initiator of the Korean War," the article said. "It is also intended to instill the idea of aggression in the U.S. society and incite a fever of war against Korea."
Workers' Daily described the Stars and Stripes as "a symbol of aggression." It added that the monument "fully reveals the invariable aggressive and belligerent nature of the United States."
The North Korean newspapers and radio broadcasts do include other international news, like an account of the "first international seminar on illegality of the U.S. naval base in Guantanamo," in Cuba. Another recent article was headlined "Capitalist World Floundering in Economic Stagnation."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Regional Banking Giants on the Line

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
The decision that has long concerned smaller banks across the country -- whether to merge with a larger bank or remain independent -- is becoming a pressing issue for regional giants as well.
The willingness of the First Fidelity Bancorp of Newark, the nation's 25th-largest banking company, to merge into the 9th-ranked First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., is a sharp strategic departure for First Fidelity, whose recent practice has been to buy smaller banks. But if First Fidelity -- whose chairman, Anthony P. Terracciano, is highly regarded in the banking industry -- now thinks it is too small to compete, then many investors and analysts expect other banking companies will come to a similar conclusion. 
 "A lot of banks lack the management and resources to be effective," said Charles M. Vincent, head of equity investment research at the PNC Bank. "At some point these realities will intrude on management thinking" he said, adding that "I expect there will be a lot of other deals not far behind this one."
Thomas Hanley, banking analyst at CS First Boston, said the Northeastern part of the country could be a focal point of the next merger wave, partly because many bankers rejected merger overtures earlier in the 1990's, when they were recovering from heavy loan losses.
For many banking companies under $20 billion in assets, such as the Midlantic Corporation of Edison, N.J., UJB Financial of Princeton, N.J., or the Meridian Bancorp of Reading, Pa., "the First Fidelity deal means they could probably opt to sell sooner rather than later," Mr. Hanley said.
But for larger banks like PNC of Pittsburgh,the Bank of New York or the Bank of Boston -- all of which have grown through acquisitions and have a history of good performance, at least sometimes -- Mr. Hanley said, "They now have to choose between continuing to buy, or whether to merge."
In yesterday's trading, shares of many banking companies in New Jersey and Pennsylvania moved higher on hopes that they might attract a buyer looking to keep pace with the expansion by First Union. UJB, whose chairman, T. Joseph Semrod, has rebuffed earlier suggestions that the company be sold, rose $1.375, to $29.875,while Midlantic gained $1.625, to $38.25. Meridian Bancorp advanced $1.25, to $33, and Corestates Financial of Philadelphia rose $1.125, to $33.75.
Shares of larger companies were also strong, as the Bank of Boston climbed $1.25, to $36.275, while PNC was up 50 cents, to $27.125.
For bankers electing to merge, there are many possibilities. BankAmerica in San Franciso or Nationsbank in Charlotte, N.C., have ambitions to build national companies to match their grandiose names and both were rumored to be suitors of First Fidelity. Another choice for large regionals would be to merge with a bank of equal size.
Whatever strategies bankers follow, the desired result is a bigger and more efficient company spread over a large enough area that it is less threatened by a regional economic downturn. However, this has not always been the result of mergers, many of which have not produced the savings and revenue gains that were originally projected.
"To remain competitive, a lot of big regionals have got to become larger, to reach the critical mass they need to develop and sell new products," Mr. Hanley of CS First Boston said. "Bill Gates of Microsoft compares banks to dinosaurs, and the investments in new technology that banks must make will be daunting to many companies."
The forces pushing banks into mergers are not confined to the Northeast. Mr. Vincent of the PNC Bank said there were several banking companies in the middle of the country that could attract buyers, including Boatmen's Bancshares and Mark Twain Bancshares in St. Louis. Boatmen's rose 50 cents yesterday, to $34.375, while Mark Twain lost 12.5 cents, to $31.875.
John J. Mason a banking analyst at Interstate/Johnson Lane, a securities firm in Charlotte, said there were some banks with stellar records of profitability and growth, like the Wachovia Corporation or Suntrust in Atlanta, whose managers could make a plausible case for staying off the merger bandwagon. But many other well-known regional banking companies, including some of the largest, cannot, he said.
"A lot of banks that are big in their region are going to find that they do not have the size to be competitive in negotiations with suppliers and vendors," Mr. Mason said. "They may have thought they had a few years to wait, but they may find out in coming months that they don't have too many options."
The Barnett Banks, based in Jacksonville, Fla., for example is a large regional bank that Mr. Mason said could become a merger target. Barnett closed yesterday at $49.875, up $1.375.
While there are still many mergers to go before the winners emerge in the national banking sweepstakes, Mr. Mason said the alliances made now were important. "Races are not won by those who start last," he said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Price Climb Is Resumed By Treasury Securities

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities resumed their climb to higher levels yesterday, as market optimism of a Fed easing increased because of recent remarks by Fed officials.
Even as market participants remain divided over whether the economy is running out of steam or not, they expect an interest rate cut soon, traders said. 
 The 30-year bond rose 22/32 of a percentage point, to 11324/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, was 6.57 percent, down from 6.62 percent on Friday. Shorter-maturity bill rates and intermediate-maturity yields on notes also improved.
While some in the market are leaning toward the July 5 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee as the earliest possible date for a rate cut, the general belief is that the Fed will wait until the August meeting to cut interest rates.
Tomorrow the Fed will release its so-called beige book report, which will include the economic overviews from regional bank members of the Federal Reserve system. Investors will be looking for clues in the report that will give them an indication of the central bank's intentions.
Kevin McClintock, manager of fixed-income portfolios at Aeltus Investment Management, said trading volume yesterday was low, with most of the buying centered on speculation of whether the Fed will ease interest rates in July or August. "While I haven't heard much discussion about how much, I have heard it could be 25 or 50 basis points," he said. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
As a result of the speculation, "we've seen very volitile days," Mr. McClintock said. "There's a lot of money to be made or lost in the market, depending on whether the Fed eases or not. For example, a two-year right now yields 5.64 percent; if the Fed eases, we could easily trade at a price to yield 5.25 percent and if they don't we could go back to 6.25 percent fairly easily."
Right now, he says, the market currently seems to be taking any piece of data that is released, even if it has low information content, and studying it to determine where the economy is and what the Fed is likely to do as a result.
For instance, Mr. McClintock thinks the speech today by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, at the Economic Club of New York might draw more attention than normal, given the uncertainty in the market.
"It's been interesting," Mr. McClintock said, "Early last week a number of Fed governors steered the market into believing that unemployment and recession were the greater risks, and therefore imply a Fed easing was at hand. Then they did a reversal, and in the subsequent days they suggested an easing in July was not required."
Mr. McClintock said he had not adjusted anything in his portfolios and had instead chosen to be neutral since January. "We did not believe the slowdown was going to be severe enough and don't see a precusor for a recession," he said. "There is still wide availability of credit, home fixed-rate mortgages are below 8 percent and considered affordable, and we're starting to see some strength in department store sales. While auto sales are off their peaks, they are not declining rapidly."
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston, saw a good part of yesterday's strength coming from overnight buying. He said the market had seen alot of flip-flopping on Fed policy, and had been assessing the chances of a change. "The burden of proof is on those who think the economy will rebound," he said. "As a result the market should track to lower yields."
The Treasury's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills went quietly with no surprises, Mr. Alexy said. On average the three-year bill rate was 5.46 percent, down from 5.57 percent last week, and the six-month bill was at 5.42 percent, down from 5.56 percent.
In the municipal bond market, prices rose for the first time in four sessions as some investors found tax-exempt issues, which have lagged behind Treasuries, attractive. The average yield to maturity of the Bond Buyer's index of 40 various issues was 6.21 percent, down a basis point.
