HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Wait! Isn't This Backward?;
Roles Reversed in U.S.-Japan Dispute on Airlines

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 19

 BODY:
In the automobile trade dispute with the United States, Japan has said it cannot accept Washington's demands, saying they add up to "managed trade." If American cars and car parts do not sell well in Tokyo, Japan says, it is simply because they are not competitive.
But in another long-running trade dispute that erupted today, Japan is seeking precisely such managed trade. It wants to put a limit on the number of flights made by United States airlines to Japan, and beyond. Washington opposes such limits, saying Japanese airlines are simply not competitive, and has now struck back against Japan's latest moves. 
 Trade disputes are routinely presented by both sides as matters of broad principle. But a closer look at these two disputes shows that national interest is often the central issue. The choice of argument depends on who is winning and who is losing.
And the aviation dispute, overshadowed by the automobile issue, came to a boil today when American officials threatened to impose sanctions on Japan for failing to grant new routes between Japan and other Asian nations to the Federal Express Corporation. Japan's inaction, Washington says, violates a treaty on civil aviation.
But Japan says the 43-year-old treaty, signed when Japan did not even have an international airline industry, unfairly favors American carriers by giving them broad access to the Asian market. Japan says it has been trying to renegotiate the treaty for 20 years but has been rebuffed by the United States.
Now it says it will not award the routes to Federal Express until the treaty is renegotiated. And some Japanese officials are threatening to pull Japan out of the treaty entirely.
Officials from the two countries met last week in Washington to try to resolve the issue, and while Japanese officials saw some progress, Americans were disappointed, and have now threatened to bar Japanese airlines from some profitable American cargo routes.
Judging by the hard-nosed attitudes both sides are taking, the aviation and automotive disputes seem similar, reflecting Japan's increasing willingness to say "no" to the United States.
But when it comes to specifics, the two issues are almost opposites. What the United States argues in autos, Japan argues in aviation, and vice versa.
The United States wants Japanese car makers to adopt voluntary plans for buying American-made auto parts, calling the plans necessary to reverse decades of restrictions and discrimination that have hindered American companies.
Similarly, Japanese officials argue that they are justified in trying to place limits on the operation of American air carriers because of a need to end decades of unfair treatment of Japanese airlines.
The Clinton Administration says that much of the world -- not just the United States -- has had trade problems with Japan. But in aviation, Japan points out that the United States has had disputes with many countries, including Germany, France, Britain, Thailand and Chile.
"If you were to take a sweeping look at the aero-political problems affecting the international civil aviation industry worldwide, you might, after analysis, realize that a common denominator in many of these problems was one country -- the United States of America," Koki Nagata, vice president of corporate planning for Japan Airlines, said in a speech last month at an Asian airline industry conference in Singapore. The title of the speech was "The America Problem."
Japan and the United States also have the same counterarguments. Japan insists that American cars do not sell in Japan because they are too expensive, too big and too prone to breakdowns.
But in aviation, American carriers have lower costs and lower fares, because of the strength of the yen and because deregulation in the American domestic market forced the airlines to slim down.
"The dominant position of U.S. carriers is not a result of so-called imbalances in treaty rights," the American Government stated in a position paper. "U.S. carriers' success is the result of market forces at work." For instance, the paper notes, flying from Tokyo to Hong Kong on United Airlines costs 47,000 yen, or about $550, compared with 58,000 yen on Japan Airlines.
In the background of the dispute is the effort of the United States to win "open skies," the deregulation of international air traffic.
But Japan and many other nations argue that with limitations on airport landing slots, civil aviation can never be a completely free market. Asian airlines worry that the profitability of the lucrative Asian market will be destroyed by price wars and that they will be unable to compete with United States carriers, which can better draw on their huge home market for passengers.
"If we accepted open skies, that would be the death of the Japanese carriers," said Chikara Sugimoto, assistant vice president of international affairs for Japan Airlines.
Japanese carriers are already being pummeled by the strong yen and high costs resulting from years of operating in a highly regulated home market. They now carry 32 percent of the passengers entering or leaving Japan, down from 38.5 percent in 1986, according to Robert Rowland, an analyst at Barclays de Zoete Wedd in Tokyo.
Japan Airlines, which once ferried pilots and flight attendants to Narita Airport in Tokyo in chauffeured limousines, has lost money for several years. It is hiring Thai flight attendants and Canadian pilots because the strong yen makes it too expensive to hire Japanese ones. All Nippon Airways, mainly a domestic carrier, returned to profitability in the last fiscal year after losses the year before that.
The specific issue in the current dispute is "beyond rights." In the treaty between the United States and Japan, three American airlines were given virtually unlimited rights to fly not only from the United States to Japan but then beyond Japan to other Asian countries. Japanese airlines have limited rights to fly beyond the United States.
The three carriers that now control these rights -- the United Airlines unit of the UAL Corporation; the Northwest Airlines unit of NWA Inc. and Federal Express -- make 156 passenger and cargo flights beyond Japan each week. About 1.3 million passengers take these flights each year. By contrast, Japan Airlines, Japan's main international carrier, makes just two flights beyond the United States each week -- from Los Angeles to Brazil -- carrying 3,000 passengers a year.
Japan says that when the treaty was signed in 1952 it had just been freed from the postwar American occupation and was not in a good bargaining position. Since most of the passengers then were Americans, Japan had to grant beyond rights in exchange for winning the right to fly to the United States. In addition, since planes could not fly so far in those days, the American carriers needed to stop in Japan on their way to other Asian destinations.
But now, Japan says, most passengers flying between the United States and Japan are Japanese. And American carriers can now reach Asian destinations without the need to stop in Japan.
Japanese officials say the treaty states that its "primary objective" is to govern passenger traffic between the United States and Japan and elsewhere in Asia. They interpret that to mean that a majority of the passengers and cargo continuing beyond Japan should have boarded in the United States.
But that is not always the case. On United's flights from Tokyo to Seoul, South Korea, and to Bangkok, Thailand, for instance, more than 80 percent of the passengers get on in Tokyo, according to Japan's Ministry of Transportation.
In effect, Japan says, the American airlines are building a lucrative business connecting Japan and the booming Asian economies, a market that rightfully should belong to Japan and Asian carriers. Mr. Rowland, the analyst, said that United and Northwest get as much as a third of their profits from routes that go through Japan.
Japan says it does not want to take away existing beyond rights but does want to control the spread of new routes beyond Japan in the future. Japan also wants to even out what it says is an imbalance on flights between the United States and Japan, perhaps by controlling capacity growth. American carriers make far more flights between the countries than Japanese carriers do, and the Japanese airlines now have only about 30 percent of the passengers.
Now, Federal Express is applying to fly from Tokyo and from the new Kansai International Airport near Osaka to its new hub in Subic Bay, the Philippines, and also to many other points in Asia.
Japanese officials say Federal Express has been seeking 11 new routes. "That's too much; we can't put up with it," said Ryosei Akazawa, deputy director of the international air transport division at the Ministry of Transportation. More recently, the United States seemed willing to accept seven new routes, Japanese officials said.
The United States contends that the routes Federal Express is requesting mainly involve its shift of flights to Subic Bay instead of Manila. Washington has said it will not renegotiate the treaty until Federal Express's rights are honored.
Washington also argues that in the early 1980's, Japanese carriers had more than half the passengers on flights between the United States and Japan, a sign, the United States says, that the treaty is not to blame for Japan's low market share now.
American officials have indicated that they would be willing to consider granting new rights to Japanese carriers. But they say there is little that Japan really wants.
Mr. Sugimoto of Japan Airlines acknowledged that his company does not really want more flights to the United States right now because it loses money on the ones it now has. Japan Airlines would like to be able to fly to Mexico City from Los Angeles, he said, but other than that flying from Japan to the United States and then beyond does not make much business sense.
Because the United States is such a huge country, what Japanese airlines really want are rights within the United States -- the ability, for instance, to fly from Japan to San Francisco, discharge and pick up passengers, and fly on to Denver. American carriers are able to funnel passengers from American cities to a hub and load up planes bound for Japan. Japanese carriers cannot do that in the United States.
But the United States is not likely to open its domestic market since no nation allows foreign airlines to make such domestic flights.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Edges Lower as Traders See U.S. Interest Rates Dropping

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar edged lower against most leading currencies yesterday in thin trading, reflecting a lack of economic news and fear that United States interest rates could fall if the economy slows further.
"Today's trading followed the pattern of a lot of Mondays recently when there's no data out," said Margaret Kudaraskas, senior foreign exchange analyst at Technical Data, a Boston financial market research concern. "They are pretty directionless."
The dollar initially strengthened against the yen in Tokyo on media reports of a possible compromise that could resolve the automotive trade dispute between Japan and the United states. But the dollar weakened later when the United States said there was no compromise. 
 United States sanctions that will double the price of Japanese luxury cars take effect June 28 if negotiators in Geneva do not reach a deal.
"The market is playing a wait and see about what's coming out of the trade talks," Ms. Kudaraskas said.
The dollar was weaker despite strong rallies in the bond and stock markets in New York. Strength in American stocks and bonds tends to support the dollar by increasing demand for the currency among foreign investors.
But yesterday's rallies stemmed partly from expectations that interest rates in the United States are headed lower, and lower rates hurt the dollar by making bank deposits denominated in the currency less attractive.
In late New York trading yesteday, the dollar fell to 1.3970 German marks from 1.4002 marks on Friday. The dollar fell to 84.63 Japanese yen from 84.76 yen.
Against the mark the dollar stayed within a narrow range, reflecting trader fear of central bank intervention if the dollar, drops too far, said Jeffrey Yu, a senior dealer at the New York branch of the Sanwa Bank.
Marc Chandler, a senior analyst at the Deutsche Bank Securities Corporation, said the dollar got some support from comments by the Belgian Finance Minister, Philippe Maystadt, who said European Union finance ministers believed the goal of a common currency was unreachable by the 1997 target date.
Mr. Chandler said this helped raise demand for French francs, which hurt the mark and indirectly helped to underpin the dollar.
But the dollar was weakened, Ms. Kudaraskas said, by disappointment that the Group of Seven communique issued from Halifax, Nova Scotia, did nothing to bolster the dollar.

HEADLINE: In the Field With the Price Indexers

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del.

 BODY:
Her thick blue binder in hand, Diane Balaguer strides purposefully through the department store in the Concord Mall north of town. She checks the price of a women's pullover (short sleeve, solid color, no design) eyes a Hastings & Smith polo shirt, notes the seasonal absence of men's turtlenecks and then confronts the day's first challenge to statistical perfection.
Ms. Balaguer shakes her head slightly as she regards a rack of Towne raincoats, a style in the London Fog line (tagged at the same $99.90 as the month before). She considers Towne to be of slightly, almost imperceptibly, lesser quality than the Severn line (costing about twice as much) that they replaced this year. It's a matter of things like stitching and buttons. 
 Earlier this spring she had informed specialists in Washington of this not uncommon situation but they overruled her suggestion that she substitute another product. Thus do tiny imprecisions creep unavoidably into the Consumer Price Index, the most widely used inflation measure, one directly affecting the incomes of more than 70 million Americans, Federal income-tax brackets and the cost of school lunches.
"It's not a black-and-white sort of determination," Ms. Balaguer said. "Even though we ask very specific questions to try to get very specific answers, it takes a great deal of judgment."
When the price index is announced monthly by the Labor Department, the figure has the Olympian air common to Government statistics. But a day spent with Ms. Balaguer gives a vivid illustration of the messiness inherent in the immense task of monitoring changes in a $7 trillion economy. In any given month, she and several hundred counterparts around the country check the cost of 90,000 items -- ranging from catfish fillets to time spent in a hospital recovery room.
The Consumer Price Index has come under attack of late by critics who say it is inaccurate, though not because of the work of the pricing agents, pursued in Ms. Balaguer's case with an evident sophistication and zeal for detail.
Some, including Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, contend that the price index overstates inflation by as much as 1.5 percentage points. That results, among other things, in overly generous Social Security payments and other Federal benefits. Others, including its compilers at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, acknowledge an overstatement, but a much smaller one. A minority of analysts insist the index errs by understating inflation, especially for the elderly.
Congressional Republicans eager to trim Federal spending and mindful of Mr. Greenspan's criticisms, have incorporated a modest adjustment into their budget calculations that if approved would slow the growth of Federal benefits and slightly increase taxes.
The debate among policy makers, however, seems remote from the workaday world of Ms. Balaguer and her staff of seven permanent part-timers, who each month collect prices in a geographic arc ranging from Princeton, N.J., to Elkton, Md., including Philadelphia.
A trained economist who both supervises data collection and often goes on the road herself, Ms. Balaguer expresses no opinion about the debate over the price index.
The system takes account of the possibility of human error or subversion -- cross-checks of other data collectors' work is standard procedure. "We're taking our best shot," said Patrick C. Jackman, the index's chief day-to-day overseer in Washington. "I don't think we're picking up many bad quotes."
Drawing on an annual Government survey of what people are buying, and at what kinds of outlets, headquarters tells the field staff what items to price. The findings are shipped by courier to Washington, where they are run through the mill to be sure they make sense. Because the bureau promises its respondents confidentiality, it insists that none of the 10 outlets Ms. Balaguer visits be identified by name. But she did disclose not only how prices in May compared with April's, but also explained in detail how to handle such vexations as discontinued products, clearance sales and what to do in those rare cases when she suspects somebody of giving wrong prices.
One of the day's most complicated readings came at a garden shop just across the state line in Pennsylvania where, after finding 3 1/2-inch barrel cactus and 16-inch Boston ferns unchanged in price (at $4 and $25, respectively) Ms. Balaguer found that the requisite flower seeds, black-eyed susans, were no longer being stocked.
After being told this was not just a temporary situation, Ms. Balaguer's solution was to find a substitute seed in the same product line to enter into the system on the spot. With the aid of a table in her binder that produces random numbers and with some rapid-fire pointing at rows of seed packets, the answer emerged in less than a minute. From now on, she declared, "we'll use pampas grass" in the index.
Not every hurdle was so quickly overcome. She spent a sizable chunk of her 20-minute session with a hospital administrator to figure out how to adjust for a confusing reconfiguration of recovery-room charges that effectively halved the price.
"You have to be able to ask questions, to be a sort of Sherlock Holmes," Ms. Balaguer said.
Ms. Balaguer's stop at a beer distributor to check one-liter bottles of Canada Dry seltzer caused some embarrassment when she questioned the assertion of Richard Gropper, a proprietor, that the price was 84 cents. After she observed that this would mean a 9-cent rise from April he realized his mistake, adding that he was glad to help with the index since he periodically used it to adjust the rent of tenants in the doughnut shop next door.
The hardest items to price, Ms. Balaguer said, are electricity and natural gas, information the bureau gets directly from utilities in statistically awkward form. Children's meals and meals in Chinese restaurants also pose problems, even with menus to work from, because they tend to include beverages for which separate prices are required, Ms. Balaguer said.
Housing, which accounts for 41 percent of the urban consumer index, is surveyed by periodically questioning homeowners and renters. For both groups, the question is the same: What is the monthly rental value of the property? When necessary, such as when a house is vacant, she and her staff ask real estate brokers and neighbors to get housing data, Ms. Balaguer said.
Some surveyers might be bothered by one potentially onerous job restriction. But not Ms. Balaguer.
"We never carry purses because we're not allowed to shop while we work," she said. "Actually," she added, noting that she had originally worked in retailing, "I hate to shop."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Diane Balaguer, who checks prices for Labor Department use in calculating the Consumer Price Index, has to make a lot of judgment calls. Here she visited a discount drug chain store in Philadelphia on June 1. (Harvey Finkle/Impact Visuals for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Prices of Grain and Soybeans Get Lift From the Hot Weather

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Grain and soybean futures prices rocketed to new highs on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday as hot, dry weather settled in over Midwestern growing regions and increased the chances of a disastrous fall harvest.
Temperatures have soared well above average, into the 90's, for the last nine days, and meteorologists said yesterday that there was little relief in sight. The newly planted crops are desperately in need of rain; one reason is that above-normal rainfall this spring left seedlings with shallow roots incapable of finding water much below the surface, Joel Karlin, an analyst at Kemper Securities Inc. in Chicago, said. 
 "Even though we're not at critical growing points, a continuation of this weather will certainly stress the plants and cause some yield reductions," he said.
On other commodity markets, energy futures prices sank and silver futures soared. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose 1.39 points, to 236.54, testing the yearly high of 237.96 set on Jan. 20.
Wheat for July delivery rose 12 1/2 cents, to $3.93 a bushel, the highest price for the contract closest to delivery since Jan. 6, when it closed at $3.94 1/2 a bushel; July corn rose 6 1/2 cents, to $2.83 3/4 a bushel, its highest price since a March 30, 1994, close at $2.84; July oats rose 6 1/4 cents, to $1.47 1/4 a bushel; July soybeans soared 18 cents, to $6.07 a bushel, the highest price since a July 18, 1994, close at $6.18.
The National Weather Service said after the close of trading that Midwestern weather would be hot, with below-normal precipitation over the next 6 to 10 days.
Crude oil futures led energy prices lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange, reflecting talk that OPEC is considering suspending export quotas.
Venezuela's oil minister, Erwin Jose Arrieta, was elected president yesterday at the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' summer meeting in Vienna. He said the group should not rule out suspending quotas because it would send a message to non-OPEC countries, particularly Norway and Mexico, to stop increasing their output. The current OPEC quota is 24.52 million barrels a day.
July crude fell 62 cents, to $18.22 a barrel, a three-month low. July home heating oil fell 1.29 cents, to 47 cents a gallon; July unleaded gasoline fell 1.22 cents, to 60.28 cents a gallon; July natural gas fell 8 cents, to $1.62 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Gold futures prices rose to two-month highs, and silver futures prices also soared on the Commodity Exchange of New York on speculation that the Federal Reserve planned to lower interest rates soon to jump-start a slowing economy.
August gold rose $1.50, to $394.20 a troy ounce, its highest price since April 20. July silver rose 8.5 cents, to $5.50 a troy ounce; July platinum rose $2.80, to $443.80 a troy ounce.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Orange County's woes are boon to municipal bond insurer.

BYLINE: By Leslie Wayne 

 BODY:
IF bad news can make for good business at some companies, the financial crisis in Orange County, Calif., is a red-letter event for MBIA Inc., the nation's largest municipal bond insurer. MBIA makes money by selling insurance protection for municipal bonds that could go bad, and its stock has been climbing since Orange County's problems began.
The Orange County situation is helping MBIA in two important ways. For one, the bankruptcy of the wealthy county, once considered one of the nation's sterling credits, is expected to increase investor demand for insured municipal bonds in general. Moreover, MBIA picked up a big-ticket premium of $10 million, or four times the going rate, for insuring the $295 million of "recovery" bonds that the county issued last week. 
 The Orange County deal came after much soul searching within MBIA and after two weeks of on-again, off-again negotiations with the county. Then, just after the dust settled from that high-profile offering, MBIA announced that it would insure $329 million in bonds issued by the Denver Airport, whose credit rating hovers around the junk level. The Denver offering puts an additional $10 million in premiums in MBIA's pocket and represents an aggressive departure for the company, which does not typically insure credits as troubled as Orange County or the Denver Airport.
These two moves have put a spotlight on a company whose stock has risen by about 20 percent since the Orange County bankruptcy filing in December, to close yesterday at $67.75, unchanged for the day on the Big Board. Despite the steep climb, analysts feel that the stock has even more upward potential and predict MBIA will trade in the low $80's within a year.
"This is a top-flight company, and the Orange County deal was just opportunistic," said Joan S. Solotar, a Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette analyst. "Investors have seen huge run-ups in the stocks of other financial services companies and they are only beginning to look at MBIA."
MBIA's fate is tied to the volume of municipal bond offerings. That volume has been falling lately, but analysts expect offerings to pick up again. MBIA has been able to offset the volume decline by increasing its market share, largely because it has more capital with which to snare deals than its two biggest rivals: the Ambac Indemnity Corporation and the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company, part of the GE Capital unit of General Electric.
In the first quarter, the volume of municipal bonds issued fell 45 percent, but MBIA's premium volume declined only 16 percent. And analysts praise the company's efforts to offset the fluctations in bond volume by diversifying into such areas as managing municipal assets and insuring asset-backed securities.
"If you look at MBIA over the next five years," said Michael A. Smith, an analyst with Lehman Brothers, "you are looking at a company with a strong likelihood of earnings that will exceed the broad market. The municipal bond business won't disappear, and Orange County has only heightened investor concern about municipal bonds and will increase demand for insured bonds."
In 1994, MBIA earned $6 a share. Most analysts expect that to rise to a range of $6.45 to $6.50 this year and $7.35 to $7.50 in 1996. Another reason that analysts feel its stock could rise is that the company's price-earnings multiple is about 10, compared with the estimated market multiple of 14 for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
The Orange County deal was unusual because MBIA rarely touches bonds from issuers that lack an investment-grade rating. MBIA typically insures bonds with single-A ratings; once a municipality gets MBIA insurance, the bonds receive MBIA's credit rating, which is triple-A. This generally lowers the municipality's borrowing costs, even after paying MBIA's premium.
Carol Manning, an analyst at Prudential Securities, said the Orange County deal presented little risk to MBIA because the recovery bonds had a strong repayment source -- motor vehicle fees -- in spite of the county's financial problems. "The risk is more controlled than it would appear on the surface," Ms. Manning said.
Still, Neil Budnick, an MBIA senior vice president, said the decision to back Orange County "was not a slam-dunk; we spent months of negotiations with the county."
Mr. Budnick, however, said the risks were warranted: "We're not taking a more aggressive stance. The opportunity presented itself to structure a deal the way we liked, and we took advantage of it."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Arianna, Go Home!

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Arianna Stassinopoulos Huffington, if that's how you feel, go home! Love us or leave us!
And take some other immigrants with you -- the kind that, like you, talk about how America should be worried about allowing more immigrants in. For instance, that British-born fellow, I forget his name, who is running around promoting his book about how he fears that in America his little son, the one he tells us has blue eyes and blond hair, will have to grow up among too many dark folk. 
 Arianna, for somebody like me, an immigrant himself, and still remembering what I was taught in civics classes about how America was built by people from all over the world, it is hard to be mean to another American just because she or he is an immigrant too. But that is exactly why I'm picking on you.
I danced at your wedding to a young man from an oil family. Ever since, I have watched with great interest what you were doing in America -- how you helped make him almost senator from California, how some people believe that one day he will run again and this time you will make sure there would be no almosts, how you moved from writing books about art to books about the inner self, I believe, how you are now very close to Newt himself, and how you would get a big job if a Republican is elected President next year.
I did not agree with everything you were saying. But that did not diminish my admiration for your get-up-and-go. And I kept thinking: Only in America -- only in America could a girl born in Greece, an immigrant first to Britain, then to the U.S., a double immigrant you might say, become a nationally known political and literary figure a relatively few years after getting her visa. What a terrific example of the importance of immigration and immigrants.
Now here you are helping the anti-immigrant line. You heard me -- anti-immigrant. The people who promote that line professionally and whose side you take on TV never say they are anti-immigrant, of course not. They just say America should not let any more into the country for 10 or 20 years or at least cut way back -- a third, a half, whatever.
But you are not a political naive. Eliminating or drastically reducing immigration will not just deprive the U.S. of talented people by the millions, and hurt the economy by eliminating the jobs they create. It will also help anti-black, anti-brown, anti-yellow and general anti-foreign nastiness, of which we have good and plenty already.
And please listen to this: If opposition to immigration grows, some day being a former Greek will not be a political asset at all. After all, Greece is in Southern Europe, not what you might call Nordic or Anglo.
Surely you understand you would never have been able to enter America as an immigrant if some of your friends had their way about immigration before you got off the plane. So what are you saying? Pull up the gangplank, Jack, I'm aboard? That is not very good for a healthy inner spirit.
There may be other Greek-Americans who say after me lock the doors, but I have not met any. Greeks not only brought endeavor and brains to this country but they brought kinsmen who did the same.
Talk to Nicholas Gage, who wrote that classic book "Eleni," about hunting for the Greek Communist killers of his mother. His father brought him to America -- and about 100 others from their village. Among them, over the last three decades, they have created about 5,000 jobs.
Arianna, must you pick as your role models the narrowest-minded conservatives? Why not listen to Jack Kemp, Bill Bennett, Rudy Giuliani, Dick Armey, the House majority leader, and other conservatives who understand the importance of immigrants to America?
Now I have cooled down a bit. So, if you talk and listen to people like that I will rescind my expulsion order against you.
Just a few words, no more needed, about that British-born immigrant -- Peter Brimelow is his name, I remember now. His book is much too farbissen, my mother's Yiddish word for embittered, to be of value. Save time and money by reading instead Ira Glasser's seven-paragraph letter in The Times of June 16 about his racism -- a masterpiece of intellectual demolition.
That British immigrant really must go home. Mercy extends just so far.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
Baseball Network Faces a Full Count

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir 

 BODY:
What's going on with The Baseball Network?
Not much, regarding its future. The joint venture of Major League Baseball, ABC and NBC to air network games and sell advertising will not reach the $330 million in 1994-95 revenues needed to merit an automatic two-year renewal. 
 In 1993, the interim commissioner, Bud Selig, called TBN baseball's "destiny." Must be a non-manifest one; it doesn't even know if it will exist past 1995.
Baseball's owners barely touched upon TBN's future at recent meetings, except for some confusing, circuitous discussions. If TBN is baseball's destiny, why haven't owners given it a one-year extension, making 1996 the de facto second year of the deal and wiping out 1994's disaster?
"Nothing is served by talking about this," said Ken Schanzer, TBN's president. Dick Ebersol, the president of NBC Sports, said, "No comment."
"Silence should not be interpreted as inaction," Selig said.
But there are too many closed mouths. Is this all just another example of baseball's penchant for being out of control or are NBC and ABC quietly seeking legal assurance that they will keep getting baseball for nothing through 1996?
"I haven't heard that," said Eddie Einhorn, the co-owner of the White Sox, who helped push the TBN concept. "But I have to be closed-mouthed."
Bill Giles, the owner of the Philadelphia Phillies and a member of baseball's television committee, said a one-year extension has been discussed, but not acted upon. "We won't do anything until after Aug. 15," he said.
Aug. 15 is the first day of an exclusive 45-day period when one partner can ditch the other two and end the deal, or work out a new contract.
But why keep dawdling when so much about baseball is uncertain? Baseball will not resolve its labor and economic woes by the end of the 45-day period. A TBN extension is not directly contingent upon a labor deal, Selig says.
Meanwhile, NBC and ABC have strong economic motives to keep TBN. They may also want to keep baseball away from the ravenous Fox.
But it may not be in baseball's interest to renew TBN. Baseball needs money, and may have had enough of having to sell its own advertising. Owners who went along with the deal in 1993 because they trusted the TV committee may not want to be sheep again. They may want a traditional, up-front deal and may be looking for ways to talk to Fox and/or CBS without breaching the TBN contract.
 
Open Minded
 For all his insight and foresight, NBC's Johnny Miller needs to channel the emotion that chokes him up when he thinks about his 1973 United States Open victory into more personality. When excitement is needed, he is too contained. He needn't slobber, but he needs to show a verve that exceeds describing a clump of fescue grass. When Miller said that Corey Pavin's second shot on the 18th hole was "the shot of a lifetime," he sounded as jazzed up as if he were buying a box of tees.
Other thoughts:
*Pavin's 18th-hole shot was a beaut, but did not require that NBC focus on it, Pavin's reaction to it, and replays for 4 minutes 27 seconds. That segment required that Tom Lehman's and Greg Norman's important 16th-hole putts be shown on tape.
*Where was the blunt-spoken Miller when you needed him to say "choke" when Norman blew yet another chance to win a major tournament? And why didn't anyone have the guts to ask Norman about his aborted launch of the World Tour?
*Six hours is too long a telecast if the leaders don't tee off until 2 P.M. From 12:30 to 1:30 on Sunday, NBC aired little more action than a few Payne Stewart shots.
*Dan Hicks, who interviewed the victorious Pavin, needs question therapy. Of Pavin, he asked: "Do you have a sense of what your name will be placed in in history on this trophy?" How do you answer that probing inquiry?
*To NBC's credit: plenty of tee shots, terrific overhead views of shots in flight, snappy computer graphics of undulating greens and timely updates.
 
SportsChannel: 1 Error
 The once-unwatchable SportsChannel has a new logo, a better signal, a determination to be carried on lower-priced cable tiers, a responsive new management and a desire to take production risks. Great.
Yet it must decide what to do with its Mets' team. Fran Healy and Rusty Staub comprise an enervating, game-slowing duo who do not bring out Ralph Kiner's best. Perhaps the network will see some light when WFAN's Howie Rose fills in for Kiner on July 28, during Hall of Fame induction weekend. Or maybe they have noticed the authoritative nuttiness that Gary Thorne adds to Channel 9 when he fills in for Kiner beside Tim McCarver. Said McCarver, "The Mets haven't played many fun games, but we're having fun."
 
Bargain Devils
 SportsChannel pays the Islanders $12 million a year, but pays the Devils $4.2 million. SportsChannel will pay the Devils a $1 million bonus to win the Stanley Cup. . . . Game 1 of the Devils-Red Wings series Saturday earned a 4.0 overnight Nielsen rating for Fox. Among male octopuses 18-34, it posted a 6.8.
 
Sights and Sounds
 MSG's Jim Kaat stung the Yankees' principal owner, George Steinbrenner, on WFAN yesterday for signing Darryl Strawberry. "It's a lesson: listen to your baseball people," he said. "Now it's back to the Bronx Zoo again." . . . Odd sightings: HBO's and NBC's Jim Lampley hosting a sunglasses infomercial and Tom Roy, NBC's top golf producer, endorsing Titleist in a print ad.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
In Prose and in Verse, Stark Paeans to Hopper

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:

EDWARD HOPPER AND THE AMERICAN IMAGINATION
Edited by Deborah Lyons, Adam D. Weinberg and Julie Grau
Illustrated. 252 pages. Whitney Museum of American Art in association with W. W. Norton. $39.95
 The paintings are instantly, viscerally recognizable, not only because they've been reproduced so many times, but also because their style -- their angle of looking at the world -- has been assimilated, appropriated or echoed by so many other American artists. 
 To see Edward Hopper's brooding "House by the Railroad" is to be reminded of the infamous Bates mansion in the Hitchcock thriller "Psycho." To see Hopper's lonely diners in "Automat" or "Chop Suey" is to remember the lost, desperate souls in the fiction of Hammett, Chandler and Cain. To see the silent, post-coital couples in "Summer in the City" and "Excursion into Philosophy" is to think of the worn, dislocated people in Raymond Carver's laconic stories.
 The idea, then, of assembling a volume of stories and poems by writers inspired or influenced by Hopper (or simply simpatico with his vision) is a splendid one, intended to coincide with the Hopper show of the same name that opens this week at the Whitney Museum.
As it turns out, "Edward Hopper and the American Imagination" is a highly arbitrary literary collection. Why, one wonders, is there no contribution from Mr. Carver, perhaps the most quintessentially Hopperesque writer to come along in recent years, and instead only a glancing reference to him in a poem by his wife, Tess Gallagher? Why no stories from such Hopper contemporaries as Hemingway and Sherwood Anderson, whose portraits of small-town life might be read as literary analogues of the world Hopper so often depicted? Why no essay by Alfred Kazin, who has written so movingly about the painter's vision of New York City? Why no entries from younger writers like Stuart Dybek, whose short story "Nighthawks" explicitly refers to that famous Hopper canvas, even as it recreates the painting's mood of lyrical desolation?
If the reader accepts the volume for what it is, however, it does afford numerous pleasures. A kind of tribute to Hopper in pictures and words, the book illuminates the influence he has exerted on a broad spectrum of writers and poets, and in doing so, it underscores the qualities of his own work that have endured.
As the art historian Gail Levin points out in an essay in this volume, Hopper's work had strong affinities with Emerson and the transcendentalist tradition. Yet there was also a darker strain of anxiety in his paintings, a brooding disquiet that hinted at the unfulfilled promises of the American Dream, all set down with a new economy of language, the same language that would be employed by writers from Hemingway to Carver, language so spare, so compressed that it often seemed more like a philosophy than a style.
Many of Hopper's paintings are devoid of people, as though something troubling had just happened or was about to occur -- early-morning streets and out-of-the-way roads, the city in summer, the beach in fall. Others focus on those haunted places that people pass through on the way to someplace else: hotel lobbies, railroad stations, gas stations and motel rooms, places, as the poet Ann Lauterbauch writes, where you find "everything in transit," and "the temporal ignites." No doubt this is why his paintings possess such a strong narrative quality: we feel we have stumbled into a story in medias res and caught its inhabitants unawares. It is also why these paintings lend themselves so well to fictional improvisation.
In "Cape Cod Evening," for instance, Ann Beattie imagines the story behind the painting of the same name, speculating that the man and woman were Hopper's neighbors, the woman standing there in the new dress she'd just made, unable to put memories of her failed marriage out of mind, while her taciturn brother looks on, grousing about the stupidity of posing for a picture. In Walter Mosley's "Crimson Shadow," a cheap reproduction of a Hopper painting -- "South Carolina Morning" -- simply hangs on a wall, a silent reminder to the story's hero of all that he has lost since he went to jail.
Other stories in this volume do not directly concern Edward Hopper or his work; rather they feature characters reminiscent of those found in his paintings: isolated, solitary people, framed for us by the geometry of their surroundings, looking out a window or down a road, waiting for something to happen or remembering something that did.
There is Francis Phelan, the guilt-ridden bum from William Kennedy's novel "Ironweed," who believed "he would never attain the balance that allowed so many other men to live peaceful, nonviolent, nonfugitive lives," a relative of sorts of Norman Mailer's penniless drifter in "The Greatest Thing in the World" (1940), who stretches out on a flophouse bed and thinks of "women, and hamburgers, and billiard balls, and ketchup bottles, and shoes and, most of all, of the thrill of breaking a $5 bill."
But Hopper's people are not outsiders simply by class or by circumstance (think of the glamorous theatergoers in "Two on the Aisle," or the perfectly coiffed usherette in "New York Movie"); their sense of dislocation often comes from a more private place. Perhaps that is why we are able to see James Salter's wealthy, middle-aged heroine in "Dusk," who has been left by her husband and her lover, as spiritual kin to Paul Auster's young vagrant in an excerpt from the novel "Moon Palace," who has given up his old life to pursue a meager, solitary existence in the "manmade natural world" of Central Park.
Mr. Auster also describes that park as a world of "nature enhanced," a phrase that perfectly conjures up the world of Hopper's paintings, paintings that elevate the ordinary to the eternal while glossing the real with the surreal, paintings capable of turning light (the stark, puritanical light of New England at noon, the sullen, sensuous light of Manhattan at dusk) into a kind of emotional weather, paintings that articulated Hopper's own idiosyncratic vision of America and helped shape how successive generations of artists would see the world.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Detail From "Automat," 1927. ("Edward Hopper and the American Imagination")

HEADLINE: Prized Lab Shifts to More Mundane Tasks

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE 

 BODY:
ON Jan. 10, Dr. Robert W. Wilson, a co-winner of the 1978 Nobel Prize in Physics and a former astronomy wizard at AT&T Bell Laboratories, observed his 59th birthday at the South Pole, where he and other exiles from Bell Labs were using a radiotelescope to probe the structure of interstellar gas clouds.
His colleagues at the celebration, for which the South Pole Station cook had used a high-altitude recipe to bake a cake, included Dr. Antony A. Stark, who, like Dr. Wilson, now works for the Smithsonian Astrophysical Laboratory in Cambridge, Mass., and Dr. John Bally of the University of Colorado. All three had been caught in the squeeze created by the laboratory's termination of many of its basic research programs. 
 Dr. Wilson, who elected to take early retirement, Dr. Stark, Dr. Bally and another former Bell scientist working at the South Pole, Dr. Mark Dragovan of the University of Chicago, have all found new opportunities in astrophysical research. By conducting spectroscopic analyses of the microwave radiation emitted by interstellar gas, they are tracking the birth and evolution of stars in some of the Milky Way's stellar nurseries -- information vital to detailed understanding of the galaxy.
But many other scientists released by Bell Labs have had a harder time finding suitable work in the current climate of depressed financial support for basic scientific research.
While scientists see the recent developments at Bell Labs as a metaphor for a general decline in the commitment of American industry to basic scientific research, they also regret what they regard as the crumbling of a giant research establishment, a cluster of laboratories that changed the world with its inventions and discoveries.
By contrast, Dr. Arno A. Penzias, vice president of research at Bell Labs, and other senior Bell executives, regard the changes as vital to the scientific needs of the company and to advances in technology that contribute to the overall progress of science.
Bell Laboratories, formed by the telephone company in 1925, garnered seven Nobel Prizes in its glory days, from 1937 to 1978. (The name was changed to AT&T Bell Laboratories when the telephone company monopoly ended on Jan. 1, 1984.)
Three of the Nobel laureates, John Bardeen, Walter H. Brattain and William B. Shockley, were honored for their invention of the transistor, a device that has revolutionized technology and global society.
In other programs, Bell Labs played important roles in the development of lasers, fiber optics, solar cells, light-emitting diodes, communication satellites, cellular mobile radios, negative feedback principles for controlling processes, code systems for the National Security Agency, control systems for antiballistic missiles and much more. The company says it has been awarded more than 25,000 patents, an average of one a day over its 70-year life.
Bell Labs' achievements were not merely practical. They included one of the greatest scientific discoveries of all time, for which the 1978 Nobel Prize went to two physicists at Bell Labs, Dr. Wilson and Dr. Penzias.
Seeking to identify the source of radio noise that was interfering with microwave radio communications, the two scientists accidentally discovered the faint microwave echo of the Big Bang, the explosive birth of the universe some 15 billion years ago. That historic discovery drastically changed the course of astrophysical research and convinced most astronomers that the Big Bang theory -- and not competing theories -- correctly described the origin of the universe.
Paradoxically, Dr. Penzias, now a senior official of the company rather than a full-time research scientist, has had to preside over the termination of many Bell research programs in fundamental science, including most of the company's research in astrophysics.
Since "divestiture," as the 1984 breakup of the Bell Telephone System is called, the scientific staff of the laboratory has declined by only 10 percent, and the number of staff members with Ph.D. degrees has increased, Dr. Penzias said in an interview. Bell Labs, with an annual investment of $3.5 billion in research and development, now employs 25,000 people in eight states and 21 foreign countries, some 4,000 with doctoral degrees. Roughly 1,500 employees are engaged in "core research," the category that has been chiefly responsible for major achievements in fundamental science.
Still, the glory days of all of America's leading industrial research laboratories, including Bell Labs, seem to be fading. As support for fundamental science in the United States declines, so does the use of its scientists. A study published last week by the RAND Corporation and Stanford University's Institute for Higher Education Research concluded that American universities were now producing some 25 percent more doctorates in science and engineering than the United States economy could absorb.
Dr. Penzias acknowledged that the emphasis at Bell Labs was now on the development of commercially valuable devices and systems, not the pursuit of scientific knowledge per se.
"It's true that the changes have been made to benefit the shareholders and customers, not basic science," Dr. Penzias said, "but that's as it should be, because the world has changed. Science has already won many of its goals, and a lot of today's basic research goes far beyond any commercially interesting objectives.
"Take high-temperature superconductivity," Dr. Penzias continued. "A lot of people talk about developing high-temperature superconductors for magnetically levitating and propelling trains. But when you stop to think about it, the big transportation problems have nothing to do with train wheels and bearings. They have to do with funding, with the acquisition of rights of way for new tracks, and a host of practical issues that don't involve science or technology."
Critics say the commercial profitability criteria Bell Labs now applies to its research will hurt not only "pure" science but will ultimately undercut progress in technological applications. Prospects for basic research at Bell Labs' first cousin, Bell Communications Research Company (Bellcore), seem even more uncertain, because Bellcore has been put up for sale.
When the Bell System was broken up in 1984 to settle a longstanding antitrust suit by the Justice Department, the system's former parent organization, AT&T, retained Bell Labs as its research arm. Soon afterward, seven of the regional telephone companies (or "Baby Bells") split off by the divestiture pooled their resources to create an independent laboratory, Bellcore, which was to conduct applied research and computer software development for their joint benefit.
"I suggested that a separate, smaller research organization was needed for research in systems and software," Dr. Penzias said, "so in 1984 we created Bellcore, giving the new organization 200 or 300 of our own Bell Labs people to help them start up. Initially, Bellcore recruited its 500-member core research staff in our building, as a division of our organization."
One of the scientists who moved from Bell Labs to Bellcore was Dr. Fan Chung, a mathematician who specializes in combinatorics, a field whose practitioners analyze probabilities and calculate the number of ways an event can happen. Dr. Chung headed Bellcore's research in mathematics and information theory. Among her group's tasks was to analyze an epidemic of dangerous telephone failures that swept American cities in June and July of 1991. They found them to have been caused by an error in a computer code written by one of AT&T's subcontractors.
Last year, suspecting that basic research at Bellcore had a bleak future, Dr. Chung left the company to take a teaching post at the University of Pennsylvania. About half of her 20-member Bellcore research staff also left the company.
"Bellcore was really quite wonderful in its early years," she said in an interview. "In a very short time it gained status as a major research institution. It is terribly sad, what's happened to it."
The great advantage industrial research organizations like AT&T Bell Labs and Bellcore have over university departments, she said, is their interdisciplinary character.
"At Bellcore I was in constant touch with chemists, physicists, computer scientists and other experts," she said, "and because the doors between us were always open, we shared each others' perspectives and helped to solve each others' problems. We could think about broad solutions. University departments are more insulated, and it is harder to cross the boundaries between disciplines."
The seven regional telephone companies that own Bellcore decided in April to put the company up for sale, and the future of its research program, which now accounts for less than 10 percent of Bellcore's $1.2 billion budget, will be settled only when and if a buyer is found.
In an article published on June 2 in the journal Science, Bellcore's research director, Dr. Robert Lucky, was quoted as saying: "My whole career was based on research. But we were swept up with the times; basic research is not affordable in this environment." Subsequently, Bellcore's director of public relations, Barbara S. McClurken, said the company's scientists, including Dr. Lucky, had been barred from further comments because of "the currently delicate legal situation."
In a statement approved by Bellcore's management, she said: "If Bellcore's current owners were to sell their interests in Bellcore, we have every expectation that our applied research organization would continue to play a critical role in helping us meet the business and technical objectives of our customers."
At Bell Labs, some fundamental research even in such unworldly fields as astrophysics has survived, because some research techniques are recognized as directly beneficial to practical applications. An example is the work of Dr. J. Anthony Tyson, an astrophysicist who specializes in plotting the distribution of galaxies throughout the depths of space, information that sheds light on the birth and evolution of the universe. Dr. Tyson is permitted by Bell Labs to continue his investigation because it has applications to commercially important problems.
"Tyson's work involves the detection of statistical distortions in the distribution of galaxies," Dr. Penzias said, "and to pursue this field requires sophisticated techniques in pattern recognition and data storage -- things that we care about."
Pattern recognition technology has become important to Bell Labs in many fields, including the rapid scanning of millions of lines of coded computer instructions for errors, obsolete or contradictory instructions, fraud and "viruses" -- destructive instructions inserted by saboteur hackers.
"The change in research priorities," Dr. Penzias said, "is not a nice message for fundamental science. But the opportunities in applied science are greater than ever. Until I got this job as a research director, I had only three patents to my name, but in the last four years I've been awarded eight more. We all have to change to meet the changing needs of our companies and of society."

A picture in Science Times yesterday showing two researchers at AT&T Bell Laboratories and the equipment they used to detect radiation left over from the Big Bang was printed in mirror image in some editions, and the caption reversed their identities. Dr. Arno A. Penzias was shown at left, with glasses; the bearded man is Dr. Robert W. Wilson.

HEADLINE: U.N. Expert Raises Estimates Of Iraq's Biological Arsenal

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 20

 BODY:
The senior United Nations official monitoring the program for destroying weapons in Iraq told the Security Council today that Baghdad's clandestine biological warfare program is larger than previously assumed and that part of it remains unaccounted for.
Rolf Ekeus, the chairman of the special commission, reported in April that before Iraq was defeated in the Persian Gulf war in 1991, it had acquired 39 tons of a substance called complex growth media, which is required to cultivate germs for biological weapons. The United Nations inspectors could account for only 22 tons, he said, which left a significant discrepancy of 17 tons. 
 But today, Mr. Ekeus said that the earlier estimate of the amount of growth media acquired by Iraq was too low, and that Baghdad had acquired additional components needed to make biological weapons.
"The numbers have increased since we reported in April," Mr. Ekeus said at a briefing this afternoon. He declined to give specific figures, but said the new information is "rich in detail."
Mr. Ekeus said the evidence also showed that Iraq has encountered a "bottleneck" in trying to build a weapon sophisticated enough to deliver deadly germs.
There is no evidence that Iraq tried to acquire more material after its defeat at the hands of the United States and its allies, Mr. Ekeus said. What is missing was acquired before the war, he said, and its whereabouts remain unknown, except by the Iraqis.
Iraq's cooperation in destroying its weapons of mass destruction is a condition for lifting sanctions imposed by the United Nations in 1990 after Iraqi forces occupied Kuwait. The removal of sanctions would let Iraq resume selling oil, its major earner of hard currency, on the world market.
Mr. Ekeus said his commission was generally satisfied with the dismantling of Iraq's ballistic missiles and chemical weapons. "We have confidence that Iraq does not have any significant proscribed capability" with those systems, he said.
Mr. Ekeus said that when he visited Baghdad from May 29 to June 1 the Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, proposed a deal under which the United Nations would close its files on those programs in return for more details about Baghdad's biological weapons program.
But members of the Security Council reacted angrily to the proposal.
"They're trying to do deals all the time," Britain's representative, Sir David Hannay, said of the Iraqis after the meeting. "But we're not buying carpets, we're talking about compliance with Security Council resolutions, and I'm afraid that conditions of that sort will not be acceptable to the Council."
Until now, France and Russia had inclined toward lifting the oil embargo that is the principal economic weapon against Iraq, which has the world's second-largest oil reserves and had been the No. 5 oil exporter before the war.
Madeleine K. Albright, the United States representative, expressed similar outrage. "The Iraqis are acting as if they are in a position to bargain, as if they were in a bazaar, about what they will comply with and not comply with," she said.
Mrs. Albright said Mr. Ekeus reported "that there is more than the 17 tons missing, that he cannot even tell us at this moment how much, and also that there has been some imports of various kinds of equipment, which concerns us a great deal."
Speaking for the United States, she continued, "from our perspective, things have gotten worse rather than better in the biological weapons area."
The new report said that Iraq's failure to account for the missing items led to the earlier conclusion "that there is a a high risk that Iraq purchased them and at least in part used them for proscribed purposes -- the production of agents for biological weapons."

Road to Jordan Cut, Rebels Say

DAMASCUS, Syria, June 20 (Reuter) -- The Iraqi opposition in exile said today that rebels had mounted heavy machine guns on pickup trucks and set up roadblocks on the highway between Baghdad and the western Iraqi town of Ramadi.
In Baghdad, the Government's security apparatus has detained dozens of army officers suspected of disloyalty, said a statement from rebel group, the Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution in Iraq. It is a Shiite Muslim group which has its headquarters in Teheran.
It said the rebels, who are from Ramadi, were using the pickups to try to clear forces loyal to President Saddam Hussein off the highway, which is the main road to Jordan.
There was no independent confirmation of the report, the latest of many about unrest near Ramadi, on the Euphrates 60 miles west of Baghdad.

HEADLINE: Builders Start Fewer Homes In a New Sign of Weakness

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
Lower mortgage rates failed to revive the housing market during May, the Commerce Department said today, as builders broke ground on fewer homes and apartments in a fresh sign of economic weakness.
The annual rate of starts on homes and apartments fell 1.3 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.24 million units, in contrast to a revised gain of 1.4 percent in April. 
 Housing starts fell in four of the year's first five months, even though 30-year mortgage rates are more than 1.5 percentage points lower than at the beginning of 1995, when they were more than 9 percent.
Analysts said the most troubling part of May's report was the slump, to a two-year low, in construction of single-family homes. They said the decline indicated that consumers were not confident about taking on long-term financial commitments.
Construction starts on apartments and multiple-unit buildings rose 10.8 percent in May, to a rate of 288,000 units. But starts on single-family homes, viewed as a better measure of consumer sentiment, fell 4.4 percent, to 951,000 units -- the lowest rate since 939,000 units in March 1993.
"That's very disturbing," said David Lereah of the Mortgage Bankers Association. "It underlines that the housing sector is in trouble when you have a 170-basis-point fall in rates and still there is no sign that housing construction is coming back any time soon."
A fall of 170 basis points is equal to 1.7 percentage points. That is the amount by which fixed mortgage rates have fallen in the last six months.
David Seiders, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders, said a large supply of finished but unsold homes was causing builders to be cautious about new projects.
"Inventories of houses, just as in manufacturing, are high but they are not grossly excessive," Mr. Seiders said. He said there were signs of rising consumer interest in June surveys that showed more traffic at model-home sites.
Mr. Seiders predicted that housing starts would be at least 10 percent lower this year than 1994's 1.46 million units. He added, though, that "it's by no means a housing disaster."
The Federal Reserve meets July 5 and 6 to consider whether to change short-term interest rates. It has held rates steady for more than four months after increasing them seven times over a year.
Bob Davis, an economist with America's Community Bankers, said he did not expect rates to be cut in July. He also said the housing market was starting to stabilize.
 In testimony this morning to the Senate Banking Committee, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, indicated no alarm over the decline in housing starts, which he said was within expectations.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
New Speculation on a Rate Cut Creates Weak Day for the Dollar

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar slumped against the German mark and other currencies yesterday after new signs of weakness in the United States economy increased speculation that the Federal Reserve would soon cut interest rates.
Trading was light in advance of a speech last night by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan. Currency dealers awaited Mr. Greenspan's comments for clues to whether the Fed would reduce short-term interest rates. 
 But in Asian trading early today, the dollar was little changed after Mr. Greenspan told an audience in New York last night that he was reluctant to cut rates despite the increased risk of a mild recession.
"We can't judge by his comments" whether the Fed will soon cut rates, said Masahiro Yamaguchi, assistant manager for foreign exchange at Tokai Bank in Tokyo. At midday there, the dollar traded at 84.33 yen, down slightly from 84.45 in New York late yesterday.
The dollar fell in New York after the Commerce Department reported that housing starts fell 1.3 percent in May, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.24 million units. It was the fourth decline in the last five months.
"The weakness of the economy is definitely an overhang for the dollar," said Hillel Waxman, currency trading manager at Bank Leumi Trust Company in New York.
The dollar was also weighed down by comments from the president of the German central bank, Hans Tietmeyer. Mr. Tietmeyer said he "cannot yet be satisfied" with progress made toward price stability, suggesting that the Germans would not soon reduce their rates. Big wage increases still pose inflation risks, he added.
Steve Flanagan, currency trader at Credit Agricole in New York, said, "Tietmeyer's comments dampened any rate cut hopes in the short term." Lower German rates, or higher American ones, help the dollar by making dollar-denominated investments more attractive.
The American currency fell as low as 1.3870 marks yesterday, the lowest level since May 31, when coordinated dollar-buying by the Federal Reserve and a dozen other central banks buoyed its exchange value. The dollar settled at 1.3907 marks, down from 1.3970 on Monday.
As currency traders in New York awaited Mr. Greenspan's speech yesterday, speculation mounted that the Fed could reduce rates as soon as July 5-6, when its policy group, the Federal Open Market Committee, next meets.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Report of Slowdown in Housing Sends Lumber Prices Plunging

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Lumber prices plunged yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as a report showing fewer housing starts in May pointed to weaker demand for building materials.
On other markets, copper rose while crude oil fell. The Commodity Research Bureau index gained 0.12 point, to 236.66. 
 Housing starts dropped by 1.3 percent last month, the Commerce Department reported, to an annual rate of 1.239 million, the slowest pace in more than two years. The decline surprised analysts, who thought falling mortgage rates would have encouraged builders to begin new projects.
"This housing market is in bad shape," said Gary Leeper, general sales manager at Timber Products Inc., a lumber mill in Springfield, Ore. July lumber fell $8.80, to $218 for 1,000 board feet on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
The number of built but unoccupied homes rose to the highest in five years, the Commerce Department said, raising the prospect that housing starts would suffer until the existing stock of unsold homes was depleted.
Copper prices rose to a five-month high after an unexpected drop in London Metal Exchange inventories showed strong global demand.
The exchange said that its copper stockpiles plunged by 17,675 metric tons, or 8.6 percent, to 186,325 metric tons since its last report on Friday. Copper for July delivery rose 0.7 cent, to $1.402 a pound, on the Commodity Exchange in New York, its highest price since Jan. 25. Copper prices have surged 13 percent in the last month.
Crude oil fell as rising production in Nigeria, the North Sea and possibly from OPEC members later in the year eased concern that inventories are low at the start of the summer driving season, when gasoline demand rises.
The expiring July crude contract fell 21 cents, to $18.01 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, a three-month low. The active August contract slipped 6 cents, to $17.97 a barrel. July unleaded gasoline rose 0.56 cent, to 60.84 cents a gallon, while July heating oil rose 0.14 cent, to 47.14 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: Disney Announces Plans For a Wildlife Theme Park

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, June 20

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company today announced plans to build its largest theme park yet, one that would combine rides with real wildlife for what the company's chairman, Michael D. Eisner, called "an entirely new experience for our guests."
The Wild Animal Kingdom is to open in the spring of 1998 as the fourth theme park at Walt Disney World Resort in Florida. Five times the size of the Magic Kingdom, it would take up 500 acres of Disney-owned property in Orange County near Orlando and devote nearly a fourth of it to creating a habitat for more than 1,000 animals, some of them endangered. 
 Mr. Eisner would not disclose the cost of the project at a news conference today, but analysts who follow the company estimated an investment of $600 million to $800 million. Company officials said they expected to employ 4,000 people in the construction and open the park with a staff of 3,000.
Disney today also announced other new projects at the Walt Disney World complex, including expanded shopping and dining areas and a new convention hotel. The activity reflects a positive economic outlook for the company after reduced or flat attendance in the last few years at Disney parks, analysts said.
Mr. Eisner said today that Walt Disney World was having "a banner year."
The aborted plans to build a historical theme park in Virginia are seen as another incentive for Disney to proceed now with the animal adventure park. While the Virginia project met with opposition from historians and environmentalists, Wild Animal Kingdom was developed with the assistance of an advisory panel of animal experts who have embraced it as an opportunity to excite the public about wildlife.
"We're all concerned that we've got to broaden the audience and the level of caring," said William Conway, president of the Wildlife Conservation Society in New York and one of the unpaid consultants on the panel. "It worries me that people are more worried about the trials and tribulations of Mickey and Minnie than the trials and tribulations of wildlife."
Disney officials, who visited zoos and other parks around the world before coming up with their design, said the park would be divided in three major sections -- the real, the mythical and the extinct -- to offer visitors encounters with live giraffes and make-believe unicorns, journeys like an African safari and a Jurassic Park-type trip to the dinosaur era.
"Anyone who's seriously concerned about preserving the wild places of the world is going to be very impressed," Joseph Rohde, the park's creative director, said.
Most of the animals would come from zoos, said Rick Barongi, general manager of animal operations. A minority would be refugees from endangered habitats, he said. The park plans to emphasize wildlife protection through research and a "conservation station" that would help visitors connect with wildlife organizations in their communities worldwide, officials said.
Mr. Barongi said the park would open with more than 1,000 birds and mammals but would also offer reptiles, fish and insects.
"Kids love bugs," he said.
Although mostly welcomed, Disney's latest venture was criticized by the People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, which noted that the company's record with animals was not unblemished. Jennifer Allen, a spokeswoman for the group at its Maryland office, said that in a 1989 incident Disney was accused of mistreating several vultures that landed at its Discovery Island zoo at the Walt Disney World complex.
Bill Warren, a Disney spokesman, confirmed that some of the vultures died while being captured by zoo employees "acting clearly against the philosophy of this company." He said there were dismissals and a change in the zoo's top management.
Ms. Allen, calling the new park "a glorified zoo," said conservation should be taught through interactive computers and other methods, not by holding animals in captivity. "They can say all they want, but this park is to make money," she said.
But Mr. Conway pointed to a Congress bent on revising -- and, he said, weakening -- the Endangered Species Act as evidence that there was a dire need to spark the public's interest in wildlife.
"We're at a time when population is growing so rapidly that the only wildlife we'll be able to save is the one we care about," he said.
