HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Yankees, Phone Home!;
GTE Role in Venezuela Is Warning on Privatization

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela

 BODY:
In the three years since Venezuela's creaky state telephone company was privatized, the new American managers have increased the number of lines by 50 percent, doubled international circuits and quadrupled the number of working pay phones.
So, Venezuelans have been heaping praise and honor on the country's largest single foreign investment, right? 
 Not exactly. In the same three years, Bruce E. Haddad, president of a consortium led by the GTE Corporation of the United States that runs Venezuela's Cantv phone company, has been arrested once, called to testify before congressional committees 23 times and has faced marches by union workers chanting "Gringos out of Cantv." Last year, Government bureaucrats suddenly refused to allow his company to buy dollars, forcing it to default on millions of dollars in overseas loans.
Through it all, Mr. Haddad -- who is also president of Cantv -- has remained upbeat. "You have to take a long-term view, you have to expect ups and downs," said the 41-year-old Florida native and longtime executive of GTE's telephone company in the Dominican Republic.
Venezuela has one of Latin America's rockiest economic environments, but GTE's experience here serves as a warning to American business about the hazards of operating in a region that is starting to open politically sensitive public utilities to foreign investment.
From Mexico to Brazil to Argentina, Latin American countries are seeking foreign investors to run former government monopolies like power generation and telecommunications. As American companies take up the task, they are sometimes encountering echoes of the nationalist passions that led to widespread seizures of foreign-owned utilities in the 1960's and 1970's.
And with Venezuela's economy heading for the worst performance in Latin America for the second year running, Yankee capitalists have become a convenient scapegoat for a left-wing Government that is widely blamed for economic mismanagement.
At the very least, as GTE has discovered, running a public utility with 2.3 million subscribers can be vastly more complicated, and certainly more politically sensitive, than building cars or selling soap.
Venworld, the GTE-led consortium, paid $1.9 billion for a 35-year-controlling concession of Venezuela's telephone company in 1991. The president at the time, Carlos Andres Perez, was a free-market advocate who welcomed the foreign involvement.
Since then, Venezuela has gone through two coup attempts, four changes of government and seven communications ministers. Rafael Caldera, Venezuela's current president, often follows policies at odds with those of Mr. Perez, his lifelong political rival.
"There are still people in Congress debating whether Cantv should have been privatized to begin with," said Joseph A. Mann, editor of Political Impact, a newsletter here. "The Government should go out of its way to help Cantv. But I think that Caldera firmly believes that the company should be in the hands of the Government."
Last year, without a political godfather, Cantv repeatedly became embroiled in conflicts with Mr. Caldera's new administration. After the Government imposed exchange controls one year ago, the company found itself far down a long list of businesses seeking to buy dollars.
"While 98 percent of our revenues were in local currency, 95 percent of our debt payments were dollar-denominated," Mr. Haddad recalled.
With leftists initially controlling the Government currency board, which must approve foreign-exchange transactions, the American-controlled telephone company was promptly cut off from access to dollars.
"I granted two hours of my time to listen to the petition of the president and vice president of the company," Ivan Pulido Mora, then board coordinator, petulantly told reporters last August in response to questions about Cantv's foreign-exchange requests.
Although telecommunications has been a rare growth sector of Venezuela's troubled economy, the foreign-exchange problem took almost a year to resolve. In May, the company renegotiated its debt to 40 foreign banks, winning a Government guarantee of near-automatic access to dollars to service the debt.
The disruptions -- and Venezuela's general economic slump -- caused Cantv to slash its capital investment plan by 40 percent, to $408 million this year. Even with this reduction, Cantv investments will total $2.4 billion for the first four years of private operation, 10 times the $239 million invested during the last three years of public ownership. In addition to GTE, Cantv's controlling consortium of private investors includes AT&T, Telefonica de Espana, Banco Mercantil and Electricidad de Caracas.
Relations with the Government took another nasty turn last August when Cantv briefly cut off 80 percent of Government ministry telephone lines for nonpayment of Government telephone bills totaling $100 million. Since then, the unpaid debt has stopped growing, partly because officials allowed Cantv to install pay phones in Government buildings for public employees to make personal calls, cutting down on the monthly bills.
"We now have people in Government that we can deal with," Mr. Haddad said, noting that the Government now routinely approves requests for dollars and for rate increases based on inflation. "This is not some financial play -- this is a long-term commitment."
In addition to sometimes hostile politicians, the American managers have had to cope with a xenophobic labor unions. From the outset, union leaders opposed privatization, to the extent of trying to disrupt the ceremony granting the foreign investors the telephone concession in 1991. Led by the Radical Cause Party, the unions have also tried to block GTE's merit-based management system, preferring the political criteria that prevailed in the old state-company days.
"The Cantv multinationals raise rates and oppress workers," read one union poster showing a malevolent Uncle Sam figure pointing a pistol at passersby.
Despite the union problems, Cantv managed to negotiate a favorable deal. Two weeks ago, after seven months of negotiations, the company signed a new general contract giving it greater flexibility in setting hours and shifts and in defining the duties of the company's 12,000 unionized employees.
Last week, Venworld announced that Gustavo Roosen, a Venezuelan businessman with close links to the Caldera administration, would become Cantv's chairman. At the end of June, Mr. Haddad is to move to Irving, Tex., to work as international vice president for GTE Telephone Operations, the GTE subsidiary that oversees the Venezuela operation. He will continue as president of Cantv.
While Venezuela's Government and unions often have treated the American company managers roughly, Venezuela's public is increasingly pleased with the service they provide. With the average wait for a dial tone down to three seconds, customer satisfaction has hit about 80 percent, up from around 30 percent before privatization, Cantv surveys show.
Beyond political issues, Cantv's management has had to cope with Venezuela's roller-coaster economy.
After booming in the early 1990's, Venezuela recorded South America's worst economic performance in 1994. In a repeat this year, Venezuela is expected to record the continent's highest inflation -- about 70 percent -- and its only shrinking economy, a contraction of roughly 2 percent.
In last year's economic chaos, half of the banking sector collapsed. This year, the cash-short Government has fallen into arrears on its foreign debt payments and is expected to take over three failing insurance companies.
At Cantv, though, it is a different story: Its results are expected to swing back into the black from a 1994 loss of $220 million.
"We firmly believe that the long- term prospects for Cantv are excellent," a recent Salomon Brothers report read. "Venezuela's current economic problems will not last forever."
With oil revenues expected to be 20 percent lower than last year, the Government's budget deficit is heading toward 10 percent of the country's gross domestic product. And with foreign interest fading, the nation's privatization program has virtually stopped.
Although the Government planned to raise $1.5 billion this year by selling most of its remaining shares in Cantv, sales have been indefinitely suspended because of lack of investor interest. Although large mining companies are scheduled for sale, some foreign investors say they are staying away, citing Venezuela's exchange and price controls and the Government's rough treatment of Cantv.
"I just don't understand it," one American mining executive here said, shaking his head. "The Government should have given Cantv special treatment as an example for other companies interested in privatizations."

HEADLINE: Trump Tries to Convert 50's Style Into 90's Gold;
Makeover Starts on Columbus Circle Hotel

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
It is not reliably recorded that Midas ever touched a building. But Donald J. Trump, the developer, has made a successful grab for an aging glass skyscraper on Columbus Circle, and today construction officially begins on his plan to turn the walls of the old Gulf and Western Building into gold. Gold-tinted glass, anyhow.
Mr. Trump's well-publicized financial difficulties may have tarnished the lustrous image he enjoyed a decade ago, but his new project seems designed to prove that esthetically at least, he has not lost the tycoon's touch. 
 A 1950's International Style glass skyscraper in a 1980's gold lame party dress: that's one way to describe the look of the Trump International Hotel and Tower, Mr. Trump's latest Manhattan real estate venture. Designed by Philip Johnson and Costas Kondylis, the 45-story building tries to inject the developer's trademark flash with a dose of upscale architectural quality. The result is an undeniable improvement over the dull dark box that has loomed over this privileged location for the last 25 years.
But Mr. Trump's towering, brassy display is likely to raise howls of derision from those who were hoping that the glitzy 1980's had died of shame. And the building, which is due for completion in 1997, may well infuriate those who believe that Columbus Circle deserves the uniform design treatment of a classic civic place.
Like the Grand Hyatt Hotel, the project with which Mr. Trump made his Manhattan debut, the new tower clads an old building with a new skin. The Gulf and Western Building's walls of dark glass and light concrete ribbing will be stripped away. In what the developers describe as "a tribute to the tradition of Ludwig Mies van der Rohe," the pioneering modern architect with whom Mr. Johnson collaborated on the landmark Seagram Building on Park Avenue, the new skin will feature spandrels and columns covered with bright golden-bronze glass. In addition, the steel structure of the building, notorious for swaying in not-so-high winds, will be reinforced with a new concrete core.
Financed by the General Electric Pension Fund, and developed by Mr. Trump in association with General Electric and the Galbreath Company, the $250 million project will piggyback a luxury apartment building atop a hotel in one high-rise structure. The 167-unit hotel, with one- and two-bedroom condominium suites intended mainly for corporate owners, will occupy the lower 17 floors. The 28 remaining floors will have 166 luxury condominium apartments. Separate entrances and lobbies will open onto Central Park West beneath a gilded canopy.
A ground-floor restaurant will use a wedge-shaped terrace facing Columbus Circle. A small public park, landscaped by Thomas Balsley, will flank the western side of the building. The design's period look, and its "international" theme, will be accented by a small replica of the Unisphere, the stainless steel symbol of the 1964-65 New York World's Fair. Or perhaps the monument, which will grace the entrance to the 59th Street subway station, is intended for travelers to Queens.
This is not a major work by Mr. Johnson. Still, he has introduced considerable refinement to an essentially crass idea. In fact, the design's chief merit is the contrast between the commercial vulgarity of the gold skin and the relative subtlety with which it is detailed.
By eliminating the crown at the top of the Gulf and Western Building, and the tall colonnade at its base, the design gives the tower a more dynamic vertical thrust. The projecting V-shaped columns will enliven the shaft with their rhythmic proportions and the light reflected from their beveled sides. Stainless steel trim at the tips of the columns will give the gold color the impression of greater depth, diminishing the likelihood that the building will look like one gigantic, upended ingot. The relationships in scale between spandrels, columns and window mullions are clearly the work of an architect with a fine eye for proportion.
If Mr. Trump is not building a masterpiece, he has least acquired an interesting footnote in architectural history. For Philip Johnson is the architect who helped coin the term "International Style" and was for many years its chief American advocate. The Seagram Building, including the Four Seasons Restaurant on its ground floor, may well be the style's supreme work. Later, Mr. Johnson boasted that he had "put the nail" in the style's coffin with his design for the Chippendale-topped AT& T headquarters (now Sony Plaza) on Madison Avenue.
Those who revere the Seagram Building may be forgiven for feeling that Mr. Johnson's new design hits another nail, if a golden one, into that coffin. The enduring beauty of the Seagram Building is tribute enough to Mies van der Rohe, and to Mr. Johnson's own contribution to a classic skyscraper style.
In any case, Mr. Johnson's new design should not be seen as a true indication of his current architectural interests. Rather, the design makes an esthetic virtue out of a commercial necessity. By retaining the Gulf and Western Building's height and footprint, the design enabled the developers to avoid the challenge of public review.
But what is most vexing about the design is precisely the symbolic stridency with which its golden skin proclaims the triumph of private enterprise in such a publicly conspicuous place. Columbus Circle is one of the city's choicest sites. It has long aspired in vain to attain a true civic dimension. Efforts to develop the Coliseum site have raised enormous public outcry, and even lawsuits. Now a new Trump flagship sails into these troubled civic waters, carrying with it more than the faint air of a floating casino, or perhaps the winnings from one.
Mr. Trump has played by the rules, and then some. With monsters like the Gulf and Western Building and the Coliseum hulking around Columbus Circle, no one can honestly look at this new design and say, whoops, there goes the neighborhood. It's even reasonable to applaud this venture as a vote of confidence in the renewed vitality of a city trying to lift itself out of an economic slump. But Mr. Trump's golden slab should also be yet another reminder that the health of the public sector is what we ought to be worried about.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mixed, With Dow Slipping 3.12 and Nasdaq Index Up

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The financial markets, with the exception of the hard-charging Nasdaq exchange, were on cruise control yesterday before last night's speech by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, that might give clues to whether the central bank will cut short-term interest rates soon.
Stocks were mixed, bonds were little changed and the dollar was steady in overseas and New York trading. Unusually heavy trading volume -- some 384.3 million shares changed hands on the New York Stock Exchange -- indicated some confusion among traders, however. 
 Analysts said that the financial markets might be caught between a rock and a hard place because of Mr. Greenspan's speech. If he does not imply that the Fed will cut interest rates, traders may bid down stock and bond prices. If he does imply the Fed will cut rates, traders have already priced stocks and bonds to take much of the move into account.
Somewhat separate from stocks and bonds is the still weak but relatively stable dollar. A cut in interest rates, or even talk of it, is sure to stampede many currency traders away from the dollar and toward the Japanese yen and the German mark. But it is not clear whether a steady interest-rate policy would lead to a steady dollar. The currency has been hurt by long-term problems like the United States-Japan trade deficit.
After falling nearly 19 points, the Dow Jones industrial average closed yesterday at 4,550.56, down 3.12 points. The Standard & Poor's 500 fell 0.24 point, to 544.98.
By contrast, the Nasdaq composite index, rich with technology stocks, rose for the seventh session in a row. The index added 7.74 points to close at 929.83, another record.
Long-term interest rates held steady in the bond market. Bond prices inched downward and the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.58 percent from 6.57 percent.
The dollar has been stable for nearly three weeks, above 84 yen and around 1.4 marks. Yesterday, the dollar fell to 84.45 Japanese yen from 84.63 yen and to 1.3907 marks from 1.3970 marks.
Still, with the major stock indexes posting records almost weekly all year, "we had all the ingredients for a pullback" in stocks, said Alfred E. Goldman, director of market analysis for A. G. Edwards & Sons. "It's what didn't happen today that's significant. Typically, you'd see more profit taking, but we got very little downward pressure today."
Of the top 10 stocks in the Nasdaq index, all were high-technology companies, led by Intel, the semiconductor maker, which rose 3 1/4, to 65. The most active stock, at 17.6 million shares, was Intel.
At this point, many technology stocks do not need external news events to prompt institutional and individual investors to buy them. And those portfolio managers who do not own these stocks may buy them for what is known as end-of-the-quarter "window dressing" to impress clients. Moreover, many Silicon Valley executives are in New York for the Bear, Stearns technology conference and for PC Expo, a major computer trade show.
Hardware and software companies have been posting impressive gains. The American Stock Exchange computer technology index of 26 leading computer companies, including Intel and I.B.M., has risen nearly 44 percent so far this year and rose 2.47 percent yesterday. By contrast, the Dow industrials are up 18.68 percent so far this year and down 0.07 percent yesterday.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.42 point, to 291.76, with advancing stocks lagging declining stocks by 1,063 to 1,230. The American Stock Exchange composite index rose fell 1.13 points, to 495.08.
Among advancing stocks was Bolt Beranek and Newman, a computer networking company, which rose 9 1/8, to 27 5/8, after AT&T picked Bolt Beranek as an Internet access provider for business. Micron Technology, a semiconductor company, rose 4 3/4, to 57 3/4.
Among declining stocks was Transmedia Network, a provider of discount dining cards, which fell 2 7/8, to 8 1/8, after management said third-quarter and full-year results would be below Wall Street expectations. Esmor Correctional Services, which operated the detention center in Elizabeth, N.J., where illegal immigrants rioted over the weekend, fell sharply for a second straight day. Esmor fell 2 3/4, to 14 3/4.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Tokyo Plans Retaliation on Air Sanctions

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 20

 BODY:
Reacting angrily to Washington's threat of sanctions on Japanese airlines, the Japanese Government has begun planning to retaliate by blocking some flights from the United States.
Japan is contemplating prohibiting certain cargo flights of Federal Express and Northwest Airlines that originate in the United States from continuing beyond Japan to other Asian nations, Japanese officials and aviation industry executives said today. 
 "Japan will inevitably be forced to impose appropriate countermeasures if the U.S. actually imposes sanctions," Shizuka Kamei, the Minister of Transportation, said in a statement. He called it regrettable that Washington had announced possible sanctions even though his Government had been trying to resolve the issue by negotiations.
Another ministry official said the announcement of retaliatory measures could be made as early as Wednesday.
Such steps would be taken in response to the announcement in Washington on Monday that the United States had started actions to bar certain Japanese cargo flights to the United States in retaliation for Tokyo's refusal to let Federal Express strengthen its operations between Japan and other Asian nations, using facilities at Subic Bay in the Philippines. Tokyo says a three-decade-old agreement governing aviation between it and the United States is unfair and should be renegotiated.
Japanese officials said they still hoped to resolve the matter through diplomacy, as the American sanctions do not take effect until the second half of next month at the earliest. If Japan imposed sanctions of its own, however, the tensions could increase.
There was also some concern that the aviation dispute could disrupt efforts to arrive at a compromise in the two nations' pointed dispute over automotive trade.
Officially, the United States and Japan both say that the aviation and auto issues are separate. But it seemed clear that in announcing the proposed aviation sanctions three days before last-ditch auto negotiations were to begin, Washington was sending a message of toughness to Tokyo.
That message might well cause the Japanese to stiffen their position, at a time it seemed there had been some movement toward compromise in the auto talks. "This is not going to help," a United States official involved in those negotiations said.
The special session on cars and car parts is to take place in Geneva on Thursday and Friday. If there is no agreement to open Japanese markets by June 28, 100 percent tariffs on the import of 13 Japanese luxury cars into the United States will take effect.
The Japanese have held off from imposing automotive countersanctions against American imports because it would be awkward for them to take such a step while arguing at the World Trade Organization that Washington's sanctions violated international trade rules. Aviation issues, however, are governed by separate agreements outside the new trade forum.
Both disputes are potentially complicated by the attitude of Mr. Kamei, who as Transportation Minister would be involved in a settlement of the aviation dispute as well as the auto dispute.
In April Mr. Kamei, a right-winger, said the United States was "enslaving" the Japanese people by keeping the dollar weak against the yen. It is thought that he might want to be seen standing up to the United States as a way of increasing his popularity, just as the Minister of International Trade and Industry, Ryutaro Hashimoto, is said to have furthered his political ambitions by maintaining a strong stance on automotive trade.
Tokyo's response to the threatened aviation sanctions came amid dismay from some Japanese officials, who had hoped for further negotiations. Officials said Foreign Minister Yohei Kono had requested more talks when he met with the American Secretary of State, Warren Christopher, last week in Halifax, Nova Scotia, at the economic summit meeting.
Mr. Christopher turned down Japan's request, officials here say. But the Japanese were still under the impression that negotiations were possible.
The United States said it was punishing the Japanese in the area of aviation because they had refused to grant Federal Express new routes beyond Japan to other Asian destinations, particularly to the new cargo-distribution hub it has built at Subic Bay, the former American naval base. Under a 1952 aviation agreement with Japan, approval of those routes should be automatic, the Americans say.
Japan has argued that the 1952 accord, signed under the occupation and before it had its own international airlines, is biased in favor of American carriers and that in any case, the United States is violating it. It has said it will talk about the Federal Express routes in the context of a broad renegotiation of the agreement.
Washington's threatened sanctions would bar Japan Airlines and Nippon Cargo Airlines from carrying to the United States some cargo picked up elsewhere in Asia and routed through Japan. Washington said it would consider barring such cargo from as many as five areas -- Hong Kong, Indonesia, Singapore, Taiwan and Thailand.
Toyoichiro Nakata, president of Nippon Cargo Airlines, said at a news conference today that the United States had "gone too far" in proposing sanctions. He said the sanctions would deal a "severe blow" to the company, since about 10 percent of its total cargo consisted of goods that originated in Asia and were headed toward the United States.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Prices Flat in Subdued Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were flat yesterday in subdued trading, as investors and dealers waited for more evidence of a slowing economy and for signals from the Fed.
Traders said light selling pressures hit nearly all maturities ahead of a scheduled speech by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, to the Economic Club of New York last night. 
 "The bond market has sailed through some fairly choppy waters recently, and there are those that wanted to position themselves defensively, electing to take profits ahead of what may be a volatile session overseas," said Eric Hamilton, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston. Few people were willing to make any sizable commitments, in case the speech gave any clues as to the Fed's intentions ahead of the Federal Open Market Committee meeting next month.
The 30-year bond fell 7/32 , to a price of 11317/32 for a yield of 6.58 percent, up from 6.57 percent on Tuesday.
Treasury secretary Robert E. Rubin told the Senate Banking Committee yesterday that all signs were that inflation was under control for the foreseeable future.
Mr. Greenspan, who also testifed in Washington before coming to New York, told the committee that he was monitoring the economy and that there was no single economic indicator that was "all revealing." Analysts said his comments yesterday gave no clue as to what direction he might be leaning.
The Commerce Department reported on May housing starts yesterday. As expected, they fell 1.3 percent, to 1.239 million units. Building permits gained two-tenths of 1 percent, to 1.245 million, and single-family home starts fell to 951,000, the lowest since March 1993.
The housing report yesterday was overshadowed by Mr. Greenspan's scheduled speech. The Mitsubishi chain store sales index was unchanged on a week-over-week basis, and up to 7 percent year-to-year, with sales characterized as mixed and roughly on plain. "Sales have been mediocore but steady in the past few months," said James Hale, fixed-income analyst with MMS International in San Francisco, "suggesting consumption growth rather than the recessionary conditions some are declaring."
Mr. Hale said, "The report is timely and covers a key variable regarding the future of economic growth and how consumption is fairing, and it is for that reason, it and the Johnson Redbook are likely to be watched more closely than in the past."
Thomas E. Donne, vice president and a senior vice portfolio manager at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, who says he has been "agressively neutral" for over months, said. "The rally has pretty much discounted a lot of what we already received in the price of securities, and it will need additional information of a soft economy before moving any higher, he said."
He added. "If you look at the recent comments by the Fed chairman, the jury is still out." He expects the Fed to remain on its present path.
"The three reasons I think the Fed will remain cautious," Mr. Donne said, are "that (A) Gradualism works. This is a $7 trillion economy, you just can't turn it on a dime. (B) The Fed has to preserve its image as an strong inflation fighter, which is good for the economy because it gives people confidence in the Fed, and (C) The international scene, where the trading situation is very fluid. We're in difficult negotiations with the Japanese, and for the Fed to move at this point could be viewed as an intrusion in the process. So the Fed is more likely to play this close to the vest."
Elsewhere, in the municipal bond market states, cities and agencies sold $2.7 billion of new securities yesterday. In the day's largest competitive issue, Georgia awarded Goldman, Sachs & Company $303.2 million of triple-A rated general obligations bonds priced to yield from 3.95 percent for an issue due in 1997 to 5.60 percent in 2012.
Meanwhile, the recent deluge of corporate debt sparked by low interest rates continues to keep rolling. Cox Communications Inc., Nabisco Holdings Corp. and Fleet Mortgage Group Inc. plan to sell a total of $1.65 billion of debt in the days ahead, traders say.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Japan Contract Is Void

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Imagine if someone came to you and said he had a novel idea for resolving the Bosnia crisis: Japanese intervention.
Think about it: The Japanese are neither Muslims nor Christians, so both sides would view them as neutral peacekeepers. Japan is not a member of NATO, so it comes with no baggage of having bombed one side. There is a distant connection between the Japanese and Hungarian languages, so they might be able to communicate with some of the parties. Japan wants to be a member of the Security Council, so this would be the perfect test case. And Japan's Trade Minister is without a doubt the toughest negotiator in the world today and thus the perfect person to go head-to-head with the Serbs. 
 Well, you would sputter, that's absurd. And you would be right. It is absurd. But that's the point. Japan today is the second-richest country in the world. But it does not assume global economic or security responsibilities commensurate with its size, and we have grown so used to that situation that even suggesting otherwise seems the height of folly.
Ending that situation, at least in the economic field, is what the U.S.-Japan trade war is really about.
The Japanese auto industry cuts right across the Japanese economy. It is the epitome of the Japanese system of using government regulations, interlocking supplier networks and plain old monopolies to keep foreign competition out. By threatening trade sanctions against the core of that Japanese system unless Japan opens its markets more, Washington is saying to Tokyo that the U.S.-Japan relationship that existed during the cold war, and the roles it assigned both countries, is over.
During the cold war the U.S. struck a devil's bargain with Japan. Washington gave Tokyo free access to U.S. markets and allowed Japan to practice mercantilist economics -- building up its export industries with protection from foreign competition, while importing as little as possible. In return, Japan gave the U.S. military base rights and its total allegiance in the global cold war struggle against the Soviet Union. In other words, we got an unsinkable aircraft carrier in the Pacific and Japan got to focus on making Toyotas instead of tanks, with a protected market to boot. As the Japan specialist Chalmers Johnson puts it, in return for Japan not being neutral in the cold war, "We gave Japan something we never permitted the Europeans, which was that Japan did not have to meet international standards for economic reciprocity."
No more. What this trade war is about is telling Japan that while the U.S. may accept Japan remaining a secondary military power, it will not tolerate Japan behaving anymore like a secondary economic power. The cold war bargain is null and void. Japan is going to have to start taking responsibility for the global economic system, not just preying on it. And that means it must recognize that its trade barriers, its structural trade surpluses with the rest of the world and its reluctance to stimulate its economy distort the global trading system and are a drag on the whole world.
The reason changing Japan requires a trade war is because Japan does not want to change. It's had a great deal going. For 40 years, U.S. Presidents had to practice diplomacy, balancing off competing strategic and economic interests, while Japanese prime ministers got to practice commerce, focusing exclusively on their economic interests and keeping their markets closed.
Presidents Reagan and Bush should have started really pressuring Japan to change years ago. But they didn't, and now the system is so out of balance, the yen so strong against the dollar, Japan's global trade surplus so huge and its politicians so inured to ignoring their global responsibilities, that the adjustment process is going to be even more wrenching. But not as wrenching as it will be five years from now if nothing is done.
Will Japan make the adjustments? I'm not sure. Old habits die hard. The day you see Japanese generals in the streets of Sarajevo is the day you will see General Motors in the showrooms of Tokyo.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Slower Growth Is Seen for U.S. and Japan

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PARIS, June 20

 BODY:
Undermined by weak consumer spending, the economies of the United States and Japan could grow more slowly this year than predicted in May, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today.
Over all, the economies of industrialized nations will continue to grow steadily. But the United States and Japan, the two richest countries, may not fare as well as previously predicted, the O.E.C.D.'s chief economist, Kumiharu Shigehara, said. 
 The O.E.C.D. now forecasts that American economic growth will be 2.7 percent this year, not 3.2 percent as forecast in May. The revision was prompted by signs that consumer spending and manufacturing output have been weaker than expected.
"This weakness of consumption is a puzzle," Mr. Shigehara said at a news conference. "Is it a blip or a signal of continuing weakness?"
Given data released today in Japan, Mr. Shigehara said that Japan's economy may not grow 1.3 percent this year, as forecast last month. The Japanese economy grew only one-tenth of 1 percent in the first quarter of 1995 from the previous quarter, and consumer spending rose by the same amount, the Government reported.
The news conference coincided with release of the World Economic Outlook, which is prepared by the O.E.C.D. twice a year.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan's Trade Lightning Might Not Strike Twice

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
When Japan realized more than a decade ago that it needed a political strategy to deal with American demands to open its markets, its trade bureaucrats bought a giant map that showed the boundaries of every Congressional district in the United States. They hung it in the Ministry of International Trade and Industry and used colored pins to show which districts had just received a new Japanese car factory or parts plant.
Investing in America turned out to be a brilliant strategy, both good politics and good business. Now, a week from the sanctions that would cripple the sale of Japanese luxury cars in the United States, the Japanese Government is hoping to make lightning strike twice. In return for getting the United States to drop its demands to open their market, Japanese officials and car makers are floating the idea of increasing annual production in the United States by 400,000 cars over the next three years, and raising the percentage of American-made parts in every model. 
 For President Clinton, it could be a tempting offer: the promise to create more jobs in Ohio and Tennessee, places where, as the Japanese well know, he could use more than a little help in the 1996 election. But his economic advisers say the Japanese are still fighting the last trade war, and if making a few more cars in the United States is all they have to offer when last-ditch talks begin in Geneva on Thursday, there will be no deal.
"We can't solve this problem in America," said Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative. "We have to solve it in Japan."
What makes the confrontation particularly nasty is that a lot has changed in the United States and Japan -- and in their relationship with each other -- since the first pins were pressed into that map on the wall in Tokyo. Those changes are evident from the strategies both sides are bringing to Geneva, strategies born of past agreements gone bad and odd politics in both capitals.
For Mr. Clinton, the objectives are clear. Five previous Presidents, starting with Richard M. Nixon, have promised to break through the system of corporate relationships that keep outsiders from prospering in Japan. Five have failed.
Certainly, there has been no shortage of trade agreements in that time, in everything from citrus fruit to window glass, and in some cases American suppliers have prospered. But in this fight, Mr. Clinton has promised to change not the trade numbers but the system. His objective, he and Mr. Kantor have said many times, is to end the days when Japan can make its home market a sanctuary for Japanese producers, where they can charge high prices free of the kind of competition they face around the world.
That is why the offer to increase production in the United States, an attractive deal a decade ago when the American auto industry was laying off workers and seemed headed into a ditch, is not so attractive today.
"This Administration is the first to really focus on the anomaly of the Japanese system -- that the Japanese have internationalized their business abroad far more than they have at home," said I. M. Destler, a professor at the University of Maryland who is a leading historian of past trade conflicts. "But that is a much harder deal to strike. Politically, it is a lot easier to open a new plant in America than to allow in imports into Japan."
It is so much easier to add capacity in the United States that the Japanese were planning to do it anyway -- with or without pressure. With the yen hovering around 84 to the dollar, it is ridiculously expensive to make cars in Japan and ship them here, and the Japanese auto makers did not get where they are today by losing money.
The Honda Motor Company, for example, said a year ago that it would increase its production in the United States by 110,000 units a year, to 720,000 a year, and raise the number of engines it produces here by 50 percent within several years. As a matter of economic survival, other car makers have developed similar plans. Indeed, the offer whispered by Japan in recent days appears to be largely a compilation of those previously announced expansion plans.
Of course, every car made in the United States, rather than one imported from Japan, helps close the $66 billion trade imbalance. But increased production here does nothing to solve the central problem that this dispute is about: winning equality of access for American companies trying to sell in Japan, the world's second-largest car market. And as both sides know, the rules set in the auto dispute are going to be replicated in trade agreements to come, in a variety of other industries.
So the challenge facing the American negotiators is to find a way to win guarantees that far more American parts will be purchased by Japan's auto makers and repair shops, all the while pretending that such a "voluntary" agreement does not lock the Japanese into binding commitments. Such quotas would constitute managed trade -- something Americans say they do not believe in (except when there is no other choice) and that the Japanese say they can never accept (except when they are given no other choice).
The challenge for Japan, meanwhile, is to assure the least disruption of the tight business relationships that are the foundation of its social contract with its own workers, including its tradition of lifetime employment. Today that system is threatened as it has never been before.
In private, of course, both sides are figuring their bottom lines, how much they can afford to bend. But it is an enormously complex equation, a game of three-dimensional chess. Japan has to weigh the economic losses implicit in any deal against the damage that no deal at all would wreak in its relationship with its most important ally. And its trade minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, has to decide what will play better as he seeks the prime ministership: a hang-tough attitude, or a compromise that shows he can handle the bullying Americans.
For his part, Mr. Clinton senses that this issue is a political winner. But the choices will get harder in the next week. Already there are voices in his Administration warning that a prolonged fight will damage the security relationship with Japan and the value of the dollar, and perhaps even threaten the trade gains already made by the United States.
Only in the last few weeks have both sides begun actively discussing those costs, and wondering what kind of brinkmanship will make the other blink. It may take weeks or months of sanctions to bring that thinking to a conclusion. And time may well be on the side of the Americans.
"Look to September for a deal," an adviser to Mr. Clinton said the other day, mentioning the month before Japan's new car models are supposed to arrive on American showroom floors. "That's when the Japanese will get motivated and we'll be getting nervous."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk

HEADLINE: Doubts Voiced By Greenspan On a Rate Cut

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

 BODY:
In the strongest statement of his intentions since economic growth began to stall earlier this year, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, indicated last night that he was reluctant to cut short-term interest rates right away despite an increased risk of a mild recession.
Speaking to the Economic Club of New York, Mr. Greenspan said it was uncertain whether the country would slip into a recession in the next few months. But in an open acknowledgment of the new constraints imposed by currency markets, he said it would be a mistake to stimulate business activity by lowering rates if that led investors to pull money out of the United States, weakening an already shaky dollar. 
 Mr. Greenspan left open the possibility of a cut in interest rates later this year if more signs emerged that the economy was heading into worse trouble or if Congress passed a budget that would significantly narrow the Federal deficit. During a question-and-answer session after the speech, Mr. Greenspan said that he detected an easing of the inflation pressures that prompted the Federal Reserve to begin raising interest rates last year.
The chairman said current interest rate policies were under review in light of the economy's weakness, and he hinted at possibly vigorous debate within the Federal Reserve committee that sets short-term rates; that panel is scheduled to meet on July 5 and 6.
A few members of the panel, including Alan S. Blinder, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, have publicly expressed concern that the economy is now in considerably worse shape than they had expected it would be after seven rate increases during the 12-month period that ended on Feb. 1. Still, Mr. Greenspan is widely thought to have the influence to insure that short-term rates will fall only if he wants them to.
"Of one thing I am certain: our Federal Open Market Committee meeting in a couple of weeks will be most engaging," Mr. Greenspan said. "I am also confident that the consideration given to the stance of policy will be in the context of our longer-term goal of price stability. A consistently disciplined monetary policy is what our global financial system increasingly requires and rewards."
Mr. Greenspan's remarks on the growing force of international currency markets represented a break from decades of Federal Reserve policy, in which domestic considerations were given primacy, at least in public.
Mr. Greenspan, in his speech, discussed how the increased flows of money across national borders had made it harder for any central bank -- even the Federal Reserve -- to avoid the kind of swift retribution suffered by countries, like Mexico, that are seen as pursuing reckless economic policies.
"While there are many policy considerations that arise as a consequence of the rapidly expanding global financial system, the most important is the necessity of maintaining stability in the prices of goods and services and confidence in domestic financial markets," he said. "Failure to do so is apt to exact far greater consequences as a result of cross-border capital movements than those which might have prevailed a generation ago."
In afternoon trading today in Tokyo, the dollar fell slightly as traders said they had trouble drawing conclusions from news service reports of Mr. Greenspan's comments. During night trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, bond future prices climbed as traders bet that Mr. Greenspan might yet cut rates soon.
The Federal Reserve chairman's resistance to reducing short-term interest rates is likely to disappoint both the Clinton Administration and the financial markets.
Because changes in interest rates affect the pace of economic growth 6 to 18 months later, a rate cut in July would be likely to stimulate the economy during the 1996 election year. Some Administration officials, particularly the President's political advisers, had been hoping that Mr. Greenspan would cut rates soon to provide insurance against an economic decline next year even if such a move meant accepting an extra risk of feeding inflation.
Leon Panetta, the White House chief of staff, said on June 11 that it would be helpful if the Federal Reserve lowered interest rates soon. But Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin has strongly reminded his colleagues since then that such remarks could be counterproductive if they convinced financial markets that the independence of the Fed had been compromised and that inflation might be allowed to rise.
Whatever the complaints from the White House, they appeared to have made little impression on Mr. Greenspan. During the question-and-answer period after his speech, he praised the Administration generally and Mr. Rubin in particular for not pressing the independent central bank. "Our relationship with the Secretary of the Treasury and his predecessor, Senator Bentsen, has been exemplary," he said.
Mr. Greenspan spoke last night at a dinner at the New York Hilton in midtown Manhattan attended by more than 1,000 corporate and financial leaders -- probably the central bank's single most important constituency. His remarks appeared intended as an explanation to them of his reasons for postponing a cut in interest rates that many traders and analysts in the stock and bond markets had started to take for granted.
When Mr. Greenspan, in Seattle on June 7, raised the possibility of a recession but emphasized the economy's long-term health, stock and bond prices fell for three consecutive days as many investors were dismayed that a cut in short-term interest rates seemed less likely. The markets then rose when Mr. Greenspan said in Basel, Switzerland, on June 11 that the economic slowdown might turn into a mild recession, a comment widely interpreted as making a rate cut more likely.
But in Seattle and Basel, Mr. Greenspan made only brief off-the-cuff comments. Yesterday he provided a detailed picture of his thinking and specifically mentioned for the first time the coming meeting of the Open Market Committee.
Mr. Greenspan said the current slowdown reflected an effort by companies to pare their inventories of unsold goods, which have risen sharply this spring. But the economy's long-term health will depend on the pace at which businesses, consumers and government actually buy goods, clearing the shelves and creating a demand for more goods to be produced.
As he had in Seattle, Mr. Greenspan welcomed the decision by companies to cut production to reduce inventories. If the stockpiles had continued to accumulate even as spending slowed, the economy might have faced a more severe recession later, he said last evening.
"The process of slowing to a more sustainable pace has not been entirely smooth -- anyone who thought it would be is not a very close student of economic history or human nature," he said. "It is difficult at this point to judge with any confidence how these various forces will work themselves out in the period ahead."
The impact of economic demand abroad and of the Government's spending at home will affect how quickly inventories return to more typical levels and how soon the economy resumes a faster pace of growth, Mr. Greenspan said. Growth appears to be stagnating for many of the United States' biggest trading partners, notably Japan, and that may reduce sales of American goods to these countries.
Mr. Greenspan spent most of his speech last night reviewing how the new techniques in communications and trading have changed the international financial system. The same complex financial deals and computerized trading that apparently allowed a single trader at the British investment house of Barings to lose almost $1 billion earlier this year have also allowed investors to move vast sums to whatever country offers the highest returns on investments with the lowest inflation.
All this has made a unilateral reduction in interest rates difficult for any country, even the United States, which has traditionally been more insulated because of the sheer scale of its economy and the special status of the dollar in currency markets. Although he did not elaborate, Mr. Greenspan's remarks suggested that the Fed might not cut interest rates until after the Bundesbank of Germany had done so.
The German mark has emerged as the main rival to the dollar in international currency markets. Despite the mark's rise this year, Bundesbank officials have been reluctant to cut rates because of concerns that this could feed inflation in Germany.
During the late 1980's, the Reagan and Bush Administrations and the Federal Reserve were also worried about the value of the dollar, and made repeated efforts to persuade the Bundesbank to cut rates. But the Fed avoided public acknowledgment then of the importance of the dollar in its decision- making.

HEADLINE: ABOUT REAL ESTATE;
Fairfax County, Va., Gets 4 New Office Buildings

BYLINE: By JAMES R. HARDCASTLE 

DATELINE: FAIRFAX, Va.

 BODY:
Four large office development projects are under construction in Fairfax County, ending a five-year drought in new office construction in the county.
Fairfax County, which wraps around the western and southern edges of Washington, Arlington County and Alexandria, Va., saw explosive growth in the 1980's, when about 50 million square feet of office space was created, according to the county Economic Development Authority. But the market collapsed at the end of the decade, and developers forfeited to lenders on many unbuilt sites. 
 The four projects are being designed and constructed to meet the needs of the corporate customers who will be occupying them. Two of them are for major management and technology consulting firms: American Management Systems and Booz, Allen & Hamilton. The third project is for the Student Loan Marketing Association, better known as Sallie Mae and the fourth is for the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac.
Freddie Mac has already moved into a 290,000-square-foot, four-level structure and later this summer will begin using a second building, with 190,000 square feet of space.
"The build-to-suit market largely exists because the existing office market is unable to service the requirements of some companies," said Brian E. Lee, a senior real estate officer in Washington with the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company of Milwaukee.
Vacancy rates in northern Virginia have dropped from a high of 22 percent at the end of 1990 to a little more than 9 percent at the end of the first quarter, said Ben Orme, the manager of CB Commercial Real Estate Group office in Tysons Corner, Va.
There are about five prospective users exploring build-to-suit opportunities of 100,000 square feet or larger in northern Virginia, Mr. Orme said. He said there were only about 12 alternatives available today for users seeking in excess of 100,000 square feet of contiguous space.
Yet with current average rents still about $15 a square foot a year -- and rent for top-of-the line space in Tysons Corner just beginning to go over the $25-a-square-foot mark -- developers still cannot justify or finance speculative construction.
The projects for American Management Systems and Booz, Allen started when the companies agreed to sign 15-year leases for the buildings, which cleared the way for financing. American Management will be moving early next year into a 250,000-square-foot building along Interstate 66 west of Fairfax City. Gilbane Properties Inc., a unit of the Gilbane Building Company of Providence, R.I., is building the project.
Booz, Allen will be moving into a 206,000-square-foot building in Tysons Corner that is being built to the company's specifications by a joint venture of a unit of the Carr Realty Corporation, a Washington real estate investment trust, and Cousins Properties Inc., areal estate trust in Atlanta.
Freddie Mac's buildings are in the Westpark office park in Tysons Corner. Freddie Mac's partner in the project is the West Group of Tysons Corner, which owned the site.
Opening early next year in Reston will be Sallie Mae's new 450,000- square-foot headquarters building. The building will be near the Reston Town Center, about six miles west of Freddie Mac's new buildings.

Trade Deficit Deepens On Surge of Car Imports
The nation's trade deficit widened substantially in April to a record $11.37 billion as a rush to buy Japanese luxury cars contributed to a new import peak. The surprisingly big deficit prompted analysts to pare second-quarter economic estimates.
The stockpiling of Japanese cars appeared to reflect well-founded fear that Washington might take punitive action. [Page A1.]

LENGTH: 1071 words

HEADLINE: C.I.A. REPORT SAYS CHINESE SENT IRAN ARMS COMPONENTS

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 21

 BODY:
The Central Intelligence Agency has concluded that China has recently delivered important components for missile systems to Iran and Pakistan. Senior Administration officials said today that the shipments could violate an international missile accord and require the United States to impose punitive economic sanctions against China.
The report comes when diplomatic relations with China are deeply strained because of disputes over human rights, trade and the recent unofficial visit of Taiwan's President to the United States. 
 In the last year, China has delivered dozens, perhaps hundreds of missile guidance systems and computerized machine tools to Iran, the C.I.A. concluded in a report circulating among policy makers. The components could give Teheran the ability to improve the accuracy of North Korean Scud missiles already in its arsenal and enable it to build such missiles on its own, the report states.
The report also says that in the last three months, China has delivered to Pakistan parts that could be used in M-11 ballistic missiles.
In August 1993, the United States banned certain high-technology sales to China after American intelligence concluded that China had sent M-11 missile components to Pakistan in violation of an international missile accord.
"We have serious questions about China's missile-related exports to Pakistan and Iran, and we are in a position where we have to consider the question of sanctions," said John D. Holum, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. "There are substantial indications of continued missile-related transactions to both countries. We need clarification from the Chinese of what is under way. But as of now, that has not been possible."
Relations between the United States and China are at their lowest point since 1989, when the Chinese cracked down on the democracy movement and attacked protesters at Tiananmen Square in Beijing.
The private visit to the United States by President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan earlier this month touched off a campaign of diplomaic retaliation, including the recall of China's Ambassador in Washington, the cancellation of several high-level meetings between American and Chinese officials and China's refusal to approve the appointment of a former Senator, James Sasser of Tennessee, as the new Ambassador to Beijing.
An editorial Sunday in the official Communist Party's People's Daily accused the United States of plunging Chinese-American relations "into a danger zone" by allowing the visit by the President of Taiwan, an island China regards as a renegade province. The editorial concluded by asking, "Where does the U.S. Government want Sino-U.S. relations to go? We are waiting to see."
So is Washington.
The Administration is so determined to try to salvage its strategy of embracing rather than isolating Beijing that last weekend it offered to send Peter Tarnoff, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, to Beijing to take stock of the relationship. But a senior State Department official said today that the Chinese did not respond.
Since China has not shipped complete missiles or missile systems to either Iran or Pakistan, the report has generated a debate in the Administration over whether China has actually violated the Missile Technology Control Regime and should be punished with sanctions required under American law.
Administration officials who are trying to repair the damaged relationship with China contend there is no conclusive proof that the equipment is being used to improve Iran's missile capability in violation of the accord.
But other Administration officials primarily concerned about the spread of missile technology -- especially to a country like Iran, which the Administration has branded "an outlaw state" -- are eager to train the spotlight on the technology transfer and, if possible, punish the Chinese. They argue that the equipment will allow Iran to produce missiles that exceed the payload limits and range of the missile accord, which China has promised to uphold.
Some details of the report were in the current issue of Defense News. In apparent response, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, Chen Yian, insisted on Tuesday that China "is strictly honoring its commitment" to the accord.
The Administration has asked the Chinese for an official explanation through diplomatic channels, but has not received a response, senior State Department officials said today.
American officials were poised to discuss the issue formally in talks in Beijing this week. But China canceled the talks as part of its protest of President Clinton's decision to allow Mr. Lee's visit.
The dramatic and persistent reaction of the Chinese since the visit puts the Chinese in a bind: they must respond strongly to prevent further American ties with Tawian, but not so strongly as to endanger their own interests.
Administration officials say they are heartened by the fact that China has not canceled the visit of Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown to Beijing in August, a sign, they say, of the importance of economic ties.
In addition, Chinese leaders, including President Jiang Zemin and Prime Minister Li Peng, allowed J. Stapleton Roy, the outgoing American Ambassador to Beijing, to pay them farewell calls before he left his post in Beijing last weekend.
No matter that the Chinese officials railed against the visit by Mr. Lee as violating decades-old understandings between Washington and Beijing; the fact that they received Mr. Roy at all was viewed by the Administration as a positive sign that at least the Chinese are willing to talk.
But the visit of Mr. Lee to Cornell University, his alma mater, in Ithaca, N.Y., has enabled Taiwan to make additional diplomatic inroads.
Senator Frank Murkowski, the Alaska Republican, has invited Mr. Lee to visit Alaska this November, and other Taiwanese officials hope to follow him to the United States. The United States Congress, in voting overwhelmingly to allow Mr. Lee to visit in the first place, is willing to oblige.
Taiwan has mounted an aggressive and successful lobbying campaign in Washington, in which a research group linked with the Government is paying a Washington firm $4.5 million to improve its image. Among its arguments is that Taiwan has moved from a one-party, authoritarian state into a democracy, in contrast with China, which continues to repress its citizens.

HEADLINE: NatWest Plans to Retain 1,000 Workers at Melville Data Center

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., June 21

 BODY:
The National Westminster Bank, which provoked angry protests last year when it transferred 700 jobs from Long Island to Pennsylvania, announced today that it would retain 1,000 workers at its technical operations and data center in Melville.
The bank also said it would spend $66 million to refurbish the building, which it bought in 1991, and update its equipment there. 
 John Tugwell, the chairman of NatWest, made the announcement jointly with Robert J. Gaffney, the Suffolk County Executive, who a year ago led government officials in protesting the job transfers and called on local governments to withdraw all public funds from NatWest.
"That's all forgotten and in the past," Mr. Gaffney said today, noting that the flow of government funds had resumed. Mr. Gaffney, a Republican seeking re-election, did not disclose how much money had been withdrawn from NatWest, but said, "It was a lesson for the entire business community, as well as all elected officials on Long Island."
Mr. Tugwell said the county had agreed to provide lower-cost electricity through the Suffolk County Electrical Agency, bringing savings to NatWest of up to $200,000 a year.
In addition, he said, the county will provide low-cost financing through the Suffolk County Industrial Development Agency and waive the sales tax on all equipment bought for the data center, which Mr. Tugwell said would have come to $5 million. He said the Long Island Lighting Company had rejected NatWest's application for reduced rates available to businesses being forced to leave the Island because of electricity costs, now twice the national average.
Suzanne Halpin, a spokeswoman for Lilco, said the utility had provided NatWest with $150,000 in energy rebates. "And the Suffolk Electrical Agency is doing just what it was designed to do," she said.
County officials said the Suffolk Electrical Agency, which buys power directly from the State Power Authority to aid industrial development, could sell that power to NatWest at a price between 15 and 20 percent lower than Lilco.
Mr. Tugwell said that its electric costs in Scranton, Pa., were half that charged by Lilco but that the bank decided that Long Island's quality of life, business climate and wealth of highly skilled workers, plus Suffolk County's help, led to its decision to keep its data center in Melville. "Our service operations in Scranton," he added, "will continue to grow."
NatWest Bank has about 325 branch offices in New York and New Jersey, including 65 on Long Island. It is a subsidiary of the National Westminster Bancorp and has 2,400 employees on Long Island.

HEADLINE: With $1 Billion Deficit, Los Angeles County Begins Facing Painful Cuts

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 21

 BODY:
In a noisy conference room punctuated by cheers and boos, the five Los Angeles County supervisors began to wrestle urgently this week with a fiscal problem they say has been threatening the stability of the nation's most populous county for 17 years.
Faced with a budget deficit of more than $1 billion -- the cumulative result, in part, of years of reduced revenues that began with the adoption in 1978 of an anti-tax ballot measure -- the county must cut nearly $1 from every $10 it intends to spend in the coming year. 
 Addressing the stark numbers of a proposed 1996 budget, the supervisors began hacking away immediately at some of the smaller and easier targets, while recoiling at major restructuring that economic analysts said was all but inevitable.
"We need to make painful cuts," Supervisor Zev Yaroslavsky said.
Reviewing the $11.1 billion budget proposal for the first time on Tuesday, the supervisors ordered more than $250 million in cuts in an interim budget.
"It shows that the board has some real resolve to move forward," said Sally R. Reed, the county's chief administrative officer, who drew up the budget that calls for across-the-board reductions of 20 percent in most departments, including the elimination of 18,000 jobs, with 10,000 by layoffs.
For Los Angeles County, the worst pain still lies ahead. Even now officials are contemplating reductions in health services that could include the closure of one of the nation's largest hospitals, the 2,000-bed Los Angeles County-University of Southern California Medical Center. On Tuesday, the supervisors created a committee to review the county's choices.
None of this should have come as a surprise, economic analysts said. The fiscal problems of Los Angeles County have their roots in the passage 17 years ago of Proposition 13, a ballot measure that began a national trend by severely limiting property taxes, threatening municipal operating budgets.
Throughout the booming 1980's, the State of California was able to keep its counties afloat. Flush with personal income taxes, business taxes and retail sales taxes, the counties had little problem providing for health, social and child services, as well as financing jails and welfare.
But when the economy contracted in the 1990's, the revenue shrank painfully. Under intense budget pressures of its own, the Legislature over the last three years redirected $1 billion from Los Angeles County to the state's troubled school system.
"All of a sudden you have a lot of chickens coming home to roost," said Jack Kyser, chief economist at the Economic Development Corporation of Los Angeles County, a private jobs-promotion agency.
At the same time, the county -- with a growing population of 9 million and more than 30 percent of the state's economy -- is facing the grim new reality of municipal finance in the 1990's. Even as the Federal and state governments around the country want to pass on responsibility for many government services, they are handing over fewer dollars to help local governments like Los Angeles County, which relies on such money to cover two-thirds of its budget.
As the problems became acute here over the past three years, the county resorted to quick fixes in the hope that a rising economy would save it again. It tapped reserve funds, mortgaged oceanside property and borrowed against future pension fund contributions. But as Mr. Yaroslavsky said, time has run out.
"You can't do these short-term fixes any more," Mr. Kyser said, citing a drop in confidence among lenders, fueled in part by the bankruptcy of neighboring Orange County. "You can't do short-term borrowing, can't borrow from pension funds. You've got a significant crunch point."
Both Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's, Wall Street credit rating agencies, this week placed the county's long-term rating under review pending the resolution of its budget problems.
In this new atmosphere, the county on Monday moved to guarantee repayment of $1.3 billion in short-term borrowing by purchasing a letter of credit from a syndicate of American, German and Swiss banks. Economic analysts said the purchase, which tides the county over until next year's property tax receipts, had been made necessary partly by the Orange County bankruptcy and that county's threat not to honor its debts.
The wake-up call in Ms. Reed's budget is a proposal to save $310 million by closing the County-U.S.C. Medical Center, with its 9,000 employees and its broad array of services to the poor. If the hospital is not closed, she said, four other smaller hospitals might be forced to close.
On Monday, when these proposals were first made public, Mr. Yaroslavsky, who is considered a swing vote and a fiscal expert on the Board of Supervisors, reacted brusquely, saying, "I don't think we are going to close down the biggest hospital in the country."
But on Tuesday, in an indication that the supervisors are daring to peek into the abyss, his defense of the hospital was less firm.
"The hospital bears no relation to our city's medical needs," he said. "It is an anacronism in today's medical world. It is a dinosaur that supports a huge bureaucracy that is bleeding the county dry."

HEADLINE: S.I. Terminal to Be Reopened by Sending Silt to Landfill in Utah

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Port officials said yesterday that they had finally found a way to open a long-dormant marine terminal on Staten Island that had become the focus of an environmental dispute. They said they would take the unusual and costly step of spending $17.7 million to send contaminated sediment that must be dredged from the shipping berths around the terminal to a landfill in Utah.
The announcement means that by the end of the year, large freighters should be able to begin arriving at the terminal, Howland Hook, helping to revive the moribund maritime industry in New York City. 
 But port officials acknowledged that though they appear to have handled the problems at Howland Hook, they are still searching for a broader solution to a dredging impasse in the harbor that is threatening thousands of jobs on the busier New Jersey side.
"We can't stay competitive without an economically and environmentally sound method to dispose our material," said Frank N. Caggiano, the deputy port director at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. "When you have to go to Utah, it's a crisis."
The fight is over what to do with contaminated material that is scooped from the floor of the harbor during dredging, which deepens shipping channels. Environmentalists fear that if the sediment is improperly handled by, for example, dumping it into the ocean, the toxins will kill marine life and damage the ecosystem. They have often used lawsuits to halt dredging that they believed would lead to pollution.
Though dredging may seem an arcane issue, it can have a significant impact on commerce in the region, affecting everyone from dock workers to insurance agents to consumers, who must pay more for oil or gasoline that cannot easily be transported by tankers into shipping channels clogged with silt. The Port Authority estimates that the port generates more than 180,000 jobs.
The contaminants in the sediment at Howland Hook, the largest container port in New York City, include pesticides, trace metals and polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's. They are believed to have come from factories that once released their wastes into the harbor.
By disposing of the contaminated sediment from Howland Hook at a landfill, the Port Authority avoids a lengthy battle over a proposal it had made to dump the material into underwater pits off Coney Island and Staten Island. That plan had run into protests from environmentalists and residents, who maintained that the sediment could escape from the pits and foul the water.
But port officials conceded that Howland Hook, which closed in 1986 after its tenant went bankrupt, was a special case, and that it was not likely that they, or private operators, would be able allocate such large amounts of money to dredge other terminals that have had similar difficulties. City officials have long pressed the Port Authority to reopen Howland Hook.
Sending sediment to a landfill is far more expensive that dumping it at sea. If the 150,000 cubic yards of material from Howland Hook that is to go to Utah by barge and rail instead went to the Mud Dump, an area six miles off Sandy Hook, N.J., that receives uncontaminated dredged sediment, it would cost about $450,000, officials said.
For now, at least, private terminal operators who are independent of the Port Authority and have waited years to dredge remain stuck. A task force set up by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has called for the state to construct a different kind of pit in the floor of Newark Bay to receive toxic sediment, but that could take a few years.
Petroleum terminals on the harbor lose millions of dollars a year because their tankers often must stop in the harbor and unload some of their cargo onto barges. The tankers become lighter, ride higher in the water and can fit into shallow shipping channels filled with silt. This "lightering" is not only expensive, but the transferring of fuel from tanker to barge also increases the chances of a spill or accident in the harbor.
Cliff Zapp, a manager of the Stratus Petroleum Corporation in Newark, said he had been unable to dredge his terminal since 1987. The water depth, once 35 feet, is now 20 feet, he said. As a result of his increased costs and reduced business, he has had to lay off several workers.
"It has made it much more difficult to do business," he said.
The Citgo terminal on the Arthur Kill in Linden, N.J., has had to pay for 80 to 100 extra barges a year because the water depth had decreased from 30 feet to 15 feet since it was last dredged in 1991, said Jack McCrossin, its environmental and safety manager.
New York City is paying for $14 million of the $17.7 million cost of the Howland Hook project, with the Port Authority contributing the rest. The authority has invested $25 million in recent years to renovate Howland Hook.
The decision to spend so much money on the landfill surprised some environmentalists, who said it showed that the dredging policy in the port was poorly thought out.
Cindy A. Zipf, executive director of Clean Ocean Action, an advocacy group in Sandy Hook, N.J., said the plan was foolish, maintaining that port officials were spending exorbitant sums of money because they had no other options.
"The thing to remember here is that this problem has been creeping up on the Port Authority and the harbor region for 25 years," said Ms. Zipf, a member of Governor Whitman's task force on dredging.
She said she supported the Whitman plan to construct pits in Newark Bay, adding that in the meantime terminals like Howland Hook should construct small landfills on their own property to dispose of their contaminated sediment, instead of sending it elsewhere.
That sentiment was echoed by some residents in East Carbon, Utah, site of the landfill, when they heard the news that the sediment would be coming their way.
"It is disheartening," said Phyllis Johnson, who has led opposition to the landfill there. "They should just rename this city Garbage Town U.S.A."
