HEADLINE: G.O.P. LEADERSHIP ANNOUNCES ACCORD ON TAX REDUCTION

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
Republican leaders in the House and Senate struck a deal tonight to cut a variety of income and investment taxes by $245 billion over the next seven years, the final element of a compromise blueprint for balancing the Federal budget by 2002.
Speaker Newt Gingrich and the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, announced the tax and budget agreements tonight, ending three weeks of off-and-on haggling between their offices and Congress's ranking tax and budget officials. 
 Aides said that the final proposal called for spending of about $12 trillion over the next seven years, just under $1 trillion less than is currently assumed. It would also reduce projected "discretionary" spending -- on roads, education, the environment and other programs without fixed spending formulas -- by $190 billion through 2002, and increase projected military spending by about $34 billion during that period.
Two of the biggest and fastest-growing entitlement programs, Medicare and Medicaid, would also get major reductions in their rates of spending growth, although their budgets would continue to rise.
After the agreements were announced, the White House chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, said that the Republicans were going about their budget balancing in the "wrong way" and that their plans apparently called for "extreme cuts in Medicare and unwise cuts in education to pay for tax cuts to those who don't need them." His remarks echoed earlier White House rumblings of a possible veto if tax and spending cuts were judged unacceptable.
As a practical matter, the agreements reached tonight are less important as fiscal documents than as political symbols. The House and Senate took their biggest steps toward erasing the deficit in May, when they approved separate proposals to bring the Government to fiscal balance, and this compromise is devoted to eliminating what were mostly small differences between the two plans.
Both chambers are expected to give their final approval to the new budget outline before Congress adjourns for the July 4 holiday. That, in turn, would give Congress's committees the directions they need to write detailed spending and tax plans for the 1996 budget this summer.
Mr. Gingrich called the agreements "another historic step in bringing the Federal budget into balance" and added, "After decades of reckless spending, we are committed to making Government leaner, more efficient and cost effective."
But by no means does the accord insure that the Republican vision of a budget will become law. President Clinton has virtually promised to veto any budget containing deep reductions in the rate of spending on Medicare and Medicaid as well as deep cuts in taxes.
Mr. Clinton entered the budget-balancing competition himself last week, offering his own 10-year plan plan that included a tax cut of $111 billion. Mr. Gingrich said tonight that the President's proposal had "created an environment that made it easier" to reach an accord, but that the plan had never been seriously considered on Capitol Hill.
The $245 billion deal on taxes effectively splits a very big difference between the Senate and House versions of the budget resolution, one that had seemed to threaten the prospects for any agreement at all.
House Republicans voted nearly unanimously in April for a package of tax cuts totaling $350 billion over seven years and mainly intended to benefit families and investors. The Senate's more cautious Republicans, fearful that a package of that scale would undermine any plan to erase the deficit, voted in May to set aside $170 billion for tax reduction, but to be spent only if and when it could be proven that the Federal budget was headed toward fiscal balance.
The compromise announced tonight lifts elements from both positions. The $245 billion in tax cuts includes the principal breaks sought by the House, including a $500-per-child tax credit for taxpaying families and reductions in the capital-gains rate. The proposal would halve the current capital gains rate of up to 28 percent for private investors and cap the corporate rate at 25 percent. These provisions, if enacted, presumably would take effect sometime before the 1996 elections.
Other provisions could attack the so-called marriage penalty by giving a credit to couples whose taxes increase because of matrimony, create a tax-free retirement savings account for nonworking spouses, offer credits to adopting parents, reduce the alternative minimum tax for corporations and give small businesses more favorable tax treatment for deducting investments.
The critical word, however, is "could." The actual mix of tax cuts, while heavily influenced by the Republican leaders and the budget committees, will be determined by the House and Senate tax-writing committees in legislation to be written this fall.
One provision that seems destined to change is the House's proposal to extend the full $500-a-child tax credit to households earning up to $200,000 per year, gradually phasing out at a ceiling of $250,000. Democrats had attacked that as a giveaway to the rich. Negotiators said tonight that the full credit was likely to begin phasing out at incomes of $95,000 or even less.
But in other respects, the $245 billion package is roughly what the House had haggled for in the last week, and far more than the Senate wanted. The $170 billion that senators had reserved for tax cuts was based on experts' predictions that a balanced budget could bolster the economy and produce a so-called fiscal dividend of that size; to reach $245 billion, legislators will have to find more economic benefits or cut spending further.
As compensation, senators won the House's promise that no tax cuts would take effect until the Congressional Budget Office certified that spending reductions were locked in and sending the budget toward balance.
As many as a dozen of the Senate's 54 Republicans, many of whom wanted no tax cut at all, had expressed grave doubts about supporting such a hefty package. But their resistance collapsed in recent days.
The compromise on taxes promises to produce one unintended and unwanted effect: a crush of major political and fiscal decisions in late September, just as the fiscal year is ending and the budget battle between Mr. Clinton and the Republicans reaches its climax.
Republicans had already elected to postpone enactment of major changes in the Medicare program until September, just before those changes will be folded into a vast package of spending and taxing proposals that is the core of the budget.
But by requiring the Congressional Budget Office to certify that the budget has enough money to pay for a tax cut, Republican leaders have effectively postponed action on a tax package until September as well.
The two sides agreed to reduce projected spending on the fast-growing Medicare program by $270 billion over seven years, about $8 billion less than the House had sought, but almost $25 billion more than the Senate wanted. Medicaid would lose $180 billion from projected spending through 2002, splitting the difference between the two proposals.
The Senate also gave in to House demands to sharply cut spending on one of the more popular and politically sensitive Federal benefits: subsidized loans for college and graduate-school students.
The House had proposed to cut $12.5 billion from the loan program by 2002, mostly by requiring students to assume the interest costs of loans during their years in school.
The Senate had fought the House proposal, but in the agreement announced tonight, spending on student loans would fall $11 billion from current projections through 2002.

HEADLINE: Protection for Corporate Fraud

 BODY:
Two bills before Congress reveal how reckless the Republicans have become in their zeal to reduce regulation. The bills -- which would "reform" laws governing securities firms and banks -- go far beyond their stated purpose of ending frivolous litigation. What they would actually do is insulate corporate officials who commit fraud from legal challenge by their victims.
The Senate securities bill sets out to protect corporate officials from being sued when they issue overly optimistic predictions of corporate profitability that are simply innocent misjudgments. Sponsors cite cases where opportunistic shareholders waited for a company's share price to nosedive, then sued on the grounds that their investment was based on fraudulent representations of the company's health. 
 But to solve this infrequent problem, the bill would erect a nearly insurmountable barrier to suing officials who peddle recklessly false information. It would block suits against accountants, lawyers and other professionals who look the other way when the companies they serve mislead investors. The bill requires that suits be filed within a short statute of limitations and threatens plaintiffs who technically violate the court's procedures with heavy fines, including payment of the defendant's legal fees.
These provisions would ward off frivolous suits. But they just as surely ward off valid suits. Securities markets work well when investors are confident that the data on which they base decisions is honest. The bill threatens that confidence.
Banking legislation working its way through the House would also cause damage, both socially and economically. It would remove the Justice Department's authority to sue bankers and realtors who systematically block blacks and other minorities from renting apartments or getting mortgages. Apparently Justice has been too vigilant fighting discrimination for the G.O.P.'s taste. Astonishingly -- in the wake of the fraud that brought down savings and loan institutions during the 1980's -- the bill would weaken regulatory oversight over bank directors, requirements to provide independent audits and prohibitions against preferential loans to bank officials.
The bill leaves few customer protections in place. It would eliminate some requirements that banks report interest rates on customer accounts in uniform, easy-to-compare terms. It would also gut the Community Reinvestment Act, which requires banks to lend money in the neighborhoods where they take deposits or else possibly relinquish the right to merge or open and close branch offices. The act requires reform because enforcement is needlessly expensive. But the answer is to clarify and tighten standards, the solution the Administration has already taken.
The bill will make banks more profitable. But it will also invite some of the sordid practices that contributed to the $500 billion that the savings and loans failures cost taxpayers.
The Administration has expressed opposition to many of the banking provisions. But it has remained silent on the securities bill. Apparently, powerful Democrats, like Christopher Dodd of the insurance state of Connecticut, have pressured the White House to remain mum.
President Clinton seems eager to run as a candidate who could work with the Republican Congress but protect Americans from G.O.P. excesses. He could demonstrate his worth by vowing to veto the securities and banking bills -- and any others that would put the interests of deceptive executives above those of ordinary voters.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Remedial Education at CUNY

 BODY:
In the 25 years since it adopted open enrollment, the City University of New York has had to carry out a large and expensive remedial effort for students unable to keep up with college-level work. Now the city and state budget crises have forced the university to curtail many programs, including remedial instruction in reading, writing and mathematics. The remedial-education budget cuts need not be destructive, however. Indeed, they should be embraced as an opportunity to refashion a program that has grown too large and weakened the essential mission of the university.
For all its many problems, the City University remains one of the glories of New York. Despite this year's tuition hikes and cutbacks in departments and programs, enrollment is expected to keep growing. The city needs the university more than ever to help supply the trained work force to keep its economy alive. 
 A generation ago, a mixture of politics and idealism led to the creation of open enrollment and such programs as SEEK, which provides tutoring and counseling for the most disadvantaged students. The ideals remain worthy, but the programs have expanded out of hand. Too many students in the system are struggling with the basic language and number skills that should have been part of their education before they arrived.
Remedial education has grown because two-thirds of the incoming students at the senior colleges and nearly 90 percent at community colleges fail at least one of the assessment tests in reading, writing and mathematics. As a result, one out of eight dollars spent for instruction in the system goes to pay for remedial programs or to teach basic English to foreigners. Many students stay for years in remedial programs, raising doubts about the programs' effectiveness. As for the SEEK program, it enrolls nearly 11,000 students, but the overwhelming majority never graduate from the university.
It would be a mistake to abandon remedial programs entirely, as some critics demand. Special instruction in English will always be needed for some students. By the end of the decade, half the university's incoming students are expected to be foreign-born, many of them possessing skills that the city needs. In addition, many students from disadvantaged backgrounds should also be given a second chance in the university to make up for missed opportunities earlier in life.
The university leadership, taking a sensible initial step to reduce the remedial burden, will soon require that students at the four-year colleges complete their remedial work within their freshman year. Any remedial work beyond that will have to be done at the community colleges. Eventually, the university should cut back even further on remediation by expanding its cooperative efforts with the city's Board of Education to require completion of a rigorous course of study in high school for CUNY-bound students. Students in need of serious remedial help in English or other subjects might even be given help in the summer before entering college. Anyone who cannot pass the basic skills tests after extensive remedial work should not be allowed to stay in college.
No one gains if the City University is turned into a vast holding station for students struggling to learn basic reading and writing skills. But the university's historic goal of helping educate the next generation of skilled workers is no less vital than it was in the 1920's and 1930's. If that goal is not achieved, it is not just the students who will suffer. It is the whole city.

HEADLINE: Big Private Garbage Haulers, Linked to Mafia, Are Indicted

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

 BODY:
State prosecutors charged yesterday that a Mafia-dominated cartel used arson and threats to control the city's commercial garbage business for more than 50 years, forcing virtually every business, university, and hospital in New York City to pay up to 40 percent more for trash collection than they would have in a free market.
Culminating a five-year investigation led by an undercover police officer posing as a garbage hauler, a state grand jury indicted some of the largest garbage haulers in the city, as well as executives described as senior members of the Gambino and Genovese organized crime families. 
 The 17 people and 23 carting companies named in an indictment unsealed yesterday include some of the dominant figures in the industry here, among them the Barretti Carting Corporation and V. Aponte & Sons. Besides arresting executives of these companies, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan obtained an emergency court order temporarily freezing $268 million in assets of the indicted companies and individuals.
Judge Walker M. Shlackman also appointed receivers to manage the carting giants while the state seeks to seize their assets under a law in which property used in a criminal enterprise is forfeited.
Since 1957, when the city opened up commercial garbage routes to private companies, it has been an open secret in New York that trash haulers and their workers' unions are linked to organized crimes. One report after another has accused the companies of acting in concert with the Mafia to strangle competition, thus driving up prices and making New York one of the few major cities avoided by most national waste disposal companies.
But until yesterday's indictment, state prosecutors had only brought individual extortion cases, never managing to come up with enough evidence to take on an entire industry critical to the city's economy.
"We know how the cartel functioned because we infiltrated it," Mr. Morgenthau said during a press conference called to announce the sweeping, 114-count indictment. "We attended their meetings. We dealt directly with their leadership."
He said the investigation is continuing. "This is the beginning and not the end of this investigation and we are thoroughly determined to break up this cartel," Mr. Morgenthau said.
Lawyers representing some of the executives indicted declined to comment on the grand jury's charges. Others could not be reached for comment last night.
The indictment is the latest seeking to depict the Mafia as playing a dominant role in a local industry. Others have contended that organized crime once dominated the trucking industry that serves the garment district, the Fulton Fish Market, and huge portions of the construction industry.
In New York, commercial pickups are handled by private companies. Residential collection is handled by the city.
By Mr. Morgenthau's account, the cartel's ability to keep prices artificially high was demonstrated three years ago when Browning-Ferris Industries, one of the world's biggest waste hauling companies, tried to break into the New York market.
Browning-Ferris executives, who said they received threats, offered low enough rates to pick up about 200 customers. But hundreds of other businesses refused to switch carting companies even after Browning Ferris offered much lower bids than cartel members.
The businesses that did change companies saved huge amounts, said Mr. Morgenthau. For instance, a large office building at 55 Water Street that had been paying $100,000 a month to V. Ponte & Sons for pickups now pays only $10,000 a month to Browning-Ferris. Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center cut its monthly hauling bill from $100,000 to $40,000 by contracting with Browning-Ferris.
The District Attorney said that Browning Ferris officials cooperated with the investigation, after going to his office to say they were dismayed that their low bids were continually ignored.
Prosecutors said that during the last three years, a New York City detective worked undercover inside a company that was being extorted by the four trade associations that represent garbage haulers, and gathered information about the operations of the cartel. In addition to the activities of the undercover officer, who was not identified, investigators used wiretaps extensively and secretly recorded meetings with carting executives.
What they learned, prosecutors contend, was the broad outline of a complex conspiracy that represents a powerful example of organized crime's lingering influence in legitimate business.
Describing the defendants, Daniel J. Castleman, the chief of the District Attorney's investigations division, said, "They are some of the biggest haulers, and their customer list reads like a Who's Who of corporate America."
The garbage haulers were members of four trade associations, which, prosecutors said, provided a forum where carters could conspire not to compete with one another. The associations carved up the city, using a system of "property rights," the indictment charged. Each carting company "owns" buildings where their customers are located.
If an company that is not a member of the trade associations tries to offer a lower price for a building's business, the associations scare off the interloper with arson and physical violence, prosecutors said.
If a company inside the cartel takes a site away from another hauler in the cartel, prosecutors charged, the associations force the offending company to pay the former hauler up to 40 times the monthly pickup charge. The associations generally pocket part of the penalty money as well, the state contended.
During the investigation, the undercover police detective posing as a carting executive paid more than $790,000 in "dues" to the associations and in compensation to other haulers. In exchange, he won the right to pick up garbage at stops where he had submitted the lowest bid.
When necessary, some of the hauling companies named in the indictment turned to violence to protect their turf, prosecutors said.
Philip Barretti Sr., 56, of Essex Falls, N.J., the owner of three hauling companies, was charged with assaulting an independent carter and later setting fire to his garbage truck. The owners of Mongelli Carting Company in the Bronx -- Louis and Paul Mongelli, father and son, -- were accused of severely beating a driver for a rival company with a baseball bat.
The trade associations that controlled the industry were dominated by the Genovese and Gambino crime families, Mr. Morgenthau said. The dues collected by the associations amounted to a garbage tax for the Mafia, he said.
By the prosecutors' accounts, the Gambino family controls the Association of Trade Waste Removers of Greater New York, in Manhattan, and the Queens County Trade Association in Brooklyn.
Both associations were under the command of Joseph Francolino Sr., 57, of Staten Island, before his arrest yesterday. Prosecutors portrayed Mr. Francolino as a senior member of the Gambino organization, and the apparent heir to James Failla, the reputed Gambino carting boss convicted of murder conspiracy in Brooklyn Federal Court last year.
The other two trade groups -- The Kings County Trade Waste Association and the Greater New York Waste Paper Association -- are under the control of Alphonse Malangone, 58, of Staten Island, prosecutors said.
Mr. Malangone was described by prosecutors as a powerful captain in the Genovese family who controls virtually all the hauling operations in Brooklyn. Mr. Malangone's assistant, Frank Giovinco, 28, of Bayside, Queens, was also arrested and identified as a soldier in the family. Lawyers for Mr. Malangone and Mr. Giovinco declined to comment.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 26, 1995, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about the indictment of garbage haulers accused of using threats and arson to control the industry in New York City misspelled the names of a state judge who froze the assets of the companies involved, and misstated an element of his order. He is Acting Supreme Court Justice Walter M. Schackman; while he has scheduled a hearing on the issue of appointing receivers to oversee the companies, he has not yet appointed receivers.

ALTERING RECRUITMENT FOR MANAGED CARE
In response to a sharp rise in complaints about fraudulent sales tactics, state and New York City officials announced that in the city, they would no longer allow managed-care companies to enroll new members directly -- a practice several other states have banned because the potential for abuse is so great. Rather, the officials are seeking a degree of objectivity by training workers who will sit down with Medicaid recipients and enroll them. [Page 1.]

RIDING HERD ON JURY SELECTION
Having judges ride herd on lawyers during civil jury selection can move the process along three times as fast, according to a report on a four-month experiment conducted in some New York state courts. [23.]

HEADLINE: In Review of Albany's Budget, Moody's Remains Pessimistic

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 23

 BODY:
A leading state credit agency issued a skeptical report today on the first budget of Gov. George E. Pataki, who entered office in January with a pledge to restore fiscal responsibility to New York. The agency said "the state's fiscal picture remains stressed," and its analysts said that an upgrade in its low bond rating appeared unlikely soon.
 Mr. Pataki immediately attacked the report from Moody's Investors Service, one of two major agencies that assess the state's creditworthiness. He charged that Moody's had overlooked what he said were several accomplishments, particularly a 1 percent actual drop in state spending over last year. 
 The agency did praise the decrease. But the report also cited several risks in keeping the fiscal plan in balance this year and worried about projected shortfalls in the coming years -- gaps Mr. Pataki has estimated at $2 billion in fiscal year 1997 and possibly more in 1998.
 As a consequence, Moody's analysts said, they did not anticipate that the agency's rating committee would upgrade the state's A rating on general obligation bonds -- the second lowest in the nation, after Louisiana -- anytime soon. The analysts said they would watch in the coming months how well the budget stays in balance and what steps the state takes to addresses future shortfalls.
 "There still needs to be more work toward getting his budget in balance over the long term," George W. Leung, a Moody's vice president, said.
 An improved credit rating would save money by allowing the state to borrow money at lower interest rates. It also would have been a major political boost for Mr. Pataki, who often complained about the state's poor creditworthiness during the gubernatorial campaign. Despite Mr. Pataki's statements that his budget represented a major change over past fiscal plans, administration officials said they had not expected an immediate improvement in the credit rating.
 Claudia S. Hutton, a spokeswoman for the state budget division, said, "We felt that Moody's would want to see successive years of spending cuts leading to a structural balance," meaning a budget that does not cause deficits in future years. "It took the state a long time to get this unbalanced," she added. "It will take us more than one budget to get us back on the right path."
 The report said that keeping the $33 billion state budget in balance this year may be difficult: the budget was 68 days late, it noted, meaning there is less time in the fiscal year to make the savings. Many of the cuts, the report said, came in welfare and Medicaid, and local governments, which administer these programs, may not be able to keep pace with state's savings projections. The report also noted that slowed economic growth may mean that the state will not bring in as much tax money as anticipated.
 Looking ahead, the report said that the budget contained $900 million in so-called one-shot revenues, a fiscal gimmick Mr. Pataki had often criticized because these funds cannot be used in future years. "New York State will likely continue to experience contentious and protracted budget debates, and late budgets," the report said.
 The second major rater, Standard & Poor's, has not yet released an assessment of the Governor's budget. Richard J. Marino, a company director, said that analysts were scheduled to meet with state officials next week to discuss the budget.

HEADLINE: California Takes New Hit on Base Closings

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
A day after stripping California of an Air Force maintenance depot that employs more than 10,000 civilians, a Presidential commission voted today to close the naval shipyard in Long Beach, Calif., which employs another 3,500.
By following the Navy's recommendation on Long Beach, the commission was able to save the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard on the Maine-New Hampshire border. Dating from the War of 1812, Portsmouth is one of the nation's most historic bases, and is also the only one in the region able to service nuclear-powered submarines. 
 Last month the panel had added Portsmouth to the list of bases it would consider closing, but today it accepted the Navy's argument that Portsmouth played an irreplaceable role.
"I'm very pleased, to say the least," said Senator Robert C. Smith, Republican of New Hampshire. "But I didn't get any enjoyment out of the fact that someone else lost a base."
In its vote on the 50-year-old Long Beach shipyard, which the Navy uses to repair nonnuclear ships, the commission decided it was not worth continuing to spend $115 million a year to keep it open, despite the economic pain the closing would cause California. Already stung by the loss on Thursday of McClellan Air Force Base, a depot outside of Sacramento, the state's lawmakers promised a vigorous appeal to the White House.
"I'm disgusted," said Representative Steve Horn, a Republican whose district includes Long Beach. "The President should throw this out."
The votes came on the second and final day of deliberations by the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission, which decided whether to shut, shrink or retain 174 military installations. The panel's deliberations, which ended tonight at 9:30, represented the last scheduled round of base closings in the aftermath of the Cold War.
Among its other actions today, the commission dealt two blows to the metropolitan New York region. The commission voted tonight to close the Military Ocean Terminal in Bayonne, N.J., which employs more than 1,200 civilians and has packed off untold tanks, trucks and crates of ammunition to battlefields around the world. And the panel supported the Pentagon in voting to move a Naval nuclear training installation in Orlando, Fla. -- which has more than 2,000 military personnel -- to Charleston, S.C., instead of New London, Conn., where the 1993 commission had voted to move it.
The eight-member panel voted to keep open the Naval Air Station in Meridian, Miss. -- the third time in five years the panel has rebuffed the Pentagon's efforts to close the pilot-training installation, which employs about 450 civilians.
And it also effectively closed Fort McClellan in Alabama, a center for chemical defense and military police training that employs about 1,100 civilians and 10,000 military personnel. The commission chose to move much of its operations to Fort Leonard Wood in Missouri.
But the most significant development today was the decision to close Long Beach, which the commissioners debated for half an hour. Like the California lawmakers who watched nervously from the gallery, all the commissioners were aware that California had already lost 22 bases -- and more than 200,000 jobs -- in three previous rounds of base closings.
"This is nothing but pain," said the commission chairman, former Senator Alan J. Dixon of Illinois, before joining the 6-to-2 majority. The Navy plans to shift many of the shipyard's repair functions to private companies in San Diego. But elected officials in California have contended that the private sector is ill-equipped to handle the amount of work coming its way.
The commission further hurt California tonight by closing an Army cargo port in Oakland that employs 670 civilians.
The commission's decisions on California may have political ramifications for President Clinton, given California's 54 electoral votes in the 1996 Presidential election. Under the commission's charter, the President must accept or reject its decisions as a package, forwarding them to Congress or sending them back to the panel by July 15. Because of the pressure to cut the Pentagon budget in an era of dwindling troop levels, the commission's decisions have, in past rounds, been the final word.
In its deliberations this week, the commission signaled its independent streak early on: it voted on Thursday to retain Rome Laboratory, a high-technology Air Force installation in upstate New York that the Pentagon wanted to close. Then it voted to close the California McClellan depot and another huge maintenance depot at Kelly Air Force Base in Texas, both of which the Defense Department wanted to keep open. And soon after, it voted to keep open Lakehurst Naval Air Station in southern New Jersey, which the military wanted to close.
But it also followed the Pentagon's lead on an overwhelming number of recommendations, including its votes today to close three small Army bases -- Fort Pickett in Virginia, Fort Indiantown Gap in Pennsylvania and Fort Chaffee in Arkansas -- and the Naval Air Station in Weymouth, Mass.

GRAPHIC: Photo: News of the vote not to close the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard in Maine was greeted with cheers in the region. B. J. Bittner, right, and Pat Little, were among those celebrating at Chugger's Bar and Grille in Kittery. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

U.S. and Japan Extend Trade Talks Over Autos
Japanese and American trade negotiators in Geneva agreed to extend their bargaining sessions over the Clinton Administration's threatened sanctions on Japanese luxury cars through the weekend.
 Negotiators reported minimal progress in a session that focused on how Japanese auto makers could increase their purchase of American parts without explicitly agreeing to a numerical target or its equivalent. [Page 1.]
While business has been brisk at many car dealers, some are now seeing a falloff as the tariff deadline nears. There is still a decent supply of cars, but not in all models. [46.]
 
Bradlees in Bankruptcy Filing
Bradlees, the struggling regional discount retailer, filed for bankruptcy protection, saying it had to do so because many of its suppliers, fearing they would not be paid, stopped shipping their goods. The company said all its stores would remain open. [35.]
 
Plaintiffs Gain in Tobacco Suit
In what plaintiffs' lawyers hailed as a victory in a giant class-action suit against tobacco companies, a Federal district judge in New Orleans agreed to permit the discovery process to go forward, months before an appeals court rules on the class action. [35.]
 
Stocks Ease on Durables Report
Blue-chip stocks eased as news that durable goods orders had surged in May tempered hopes that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates soon to stimulate the economy. The Dow industrials were off 3.80 points, to 4,585.84, retreating from Thursday's record close of 4,589.64. For the week, the average rose 75.05 points. [37.]
 
Treasury securities prices fell, too, on the strong durable goods report. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.49 percent. [36.]
 
USAir Stock Down 6.5%
Shares in USAir Group fell 6.5 percent, to $12.50, because of rumors that the troubled carrier planned to buy Hawaiian Air, T.W.A., or both. USAir denied the rumors. [34.]
 
G.M. to Raise Prices 2.7%
G.M. said it planned to increase prices in the United States for its 1996 model cars and trucks by an average of 2.7 percent, which is comparable to Ford's price rises. [46.]
 
Shanghai Rents Are Soaring
With surging demand from American and other foreign companies streaming into China, Shanghai's real estate market has become one of the most expensive in the world. Real estate agents estimate that residential and office rents have more than doubled since 1992. [1.]
 
New York Warned on Budget
Moody's warned that New York State's "fiscal picture remains stressed" and said that the state failed "to rebuild reserves as a buffer against the next economic downturn." [22.]
 
Credit Cards on the Internet
Mastercard and Visa agreed to a standard for credit card transactions on the Internet. Mastercard plans to join -- with minor modifications -- an encryption system that Visa is developing with Microsoft. [35.]
 
F.C.C. Awards 99 Licenses
The F.C.C. said it had awarded 99 licenses to winners of its airwave auction, which ended in March. [35.]
 
Dickstein Claims Hills Victory
Dickstein Partners said it believed it had won its proxy fight for control of the board of Hills Stores, clearing the way for a sale of the regional discount store chain. [35.]
 
Duty-Free, a Hit in Manila
The Philippines has moved into the top ranks of the world's duty-free merchandisers, but with a twist. The main customers are incoming travelers, not outgoing. [34.]
 
Wheat Futures Up on Crop Damage
Wheat futures prices surged after early Kansas harvest results showed unexpectedly heavy damage from April rains. [43.]
 
The dollar weakened on news that inflation was accelerating in Germany, making a Bundesbank rate cut unlikely. [43.]

HEADLINE: Bikers Without Helmets Cost Us Big Money

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "The Case for No Helmets" (Op-Ed, June 17): While Dick Teresi and other motorcycle enthusiasts delight in feeling "the wind in their hair," the rest of us are feeling their hands in our pockets. Bikers without helmets cost the rest of us big money. 
 Mr. Teresi's "facts" don't add up. He makes statistically invalid comparisons between states and ignores the fact that every state that enacts a universal helmet law experiences fatality reductions and every state that has repealed a helmet law has seen motorcycle deaths go up.
He also rejects conclusions reached by the nation's premiere public health institution, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, because it doesn't support his position, but he accepts a study by an obscure college economics professor who does.
The facts are simple:
* Helmets work. According to the United States Department of Transportation, helmets reduce the risk of fatal injury by nearly 30 percent and are highly effective in preventing head injuries, the leading cause of motorcyclist deaths.
* Helmet laws work. Between 1976 and 1980, helmet laws were weakened or repealed in 28 states. Motorcycle fatalities increased 60 percent (registration went up only 15 percent). The 25 states currently with all-rider helmet laws have use rates near 100 percent, compared with 36 percent in states without.
* The rest of us pay. Taxpayers assume the majority of the cost for the care of injured motorcyclists -- up to 80 percent of the acute and long-term care costs.
Between 1984 and 1993, if motorcycle helmet use had been 100 percent, we could have saved an additional 4,100 lives, prevented more than 2,500 injuries and saved approximately $4 billion.
* The public supports these laws. A recent public opinion poll found that 79 percent of Americans oppose weakening or repealing motorcycle helmet laws and 63 percent believe doing so will place a greater burden on taxpayers.
 
JUDITH LEE STONE
President, Advocates for
Highway and Auto Safety
Washington, June 19, 1995

HEADLINE: Religion Journal;
On the Importance of Instilling Unity

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

 BODY:
Each year, summer's arrival means the start of a cycle of national religious meetings. The faithful of one particular group or another meet in conventions, assemblies and synods to debate resolutions, elect officers and spend time with people of shared beliefs in a country that grows evermore religiously diverse.
 Over the last 10 days, for example, more than 200 Roman Catholic bishops met in Chicago, while 20,000 Southern Baptists met in Atlanta. 
 From the style of their clerical garb to the language of their prayers, the bishops and the Baptists portrayed quite different points on Christianity's broad landscape. But it was possible to take a common lesson from their meetings: how a single individual can play a vital role in instilling a spirit of unity at such gatherings.
 In the case of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, that role has long been filled by Joseph Cardinal Bernardin, the Archbishop of Chicago. But this year he was unable to attend, after undergoing surgery the same week as the bishops' conference to remove a cancerous tumor from his pancreas.
 At the Southern Baptist Convention this week the talk focused on the Rev. Billy Graham, who managed to preach despite suffering his own health problems, though less severe than the Cardinal's.
 In Cardinal Bernardin's absence, the bishops found themselves without a man who has been a center of intellectual gravity at past meetings. The 67-year-old prelate has long held the distinction of being a moderate trusted by both the dominant conservatives among the bishops and their diminishing liberal wing.
 Admirers ascribe to him characteristics like those of an effective Congressional committee chairman -- a zest for detail, an abundance of patience and an ability to find common ground on which people of differing opinions might stand.
 Using a powerful Chicago basketball metaphor to describe the Cardinal's absence, the Rev. Thomas Reese, a senior fellow at the Woodstock Theological Center at Georgetown University, said, "It really is like losing Michael Jordan from your team."
 The bishops themselves were more guarded in their assessments. The conference's president, William Cardinal Keeler, the Archbishop of Baltimore, said he believed that Cardinal Bernardin's prayers were helping move other bishops to take quiet positions of leadership.
 But Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland of Milwaukee said he believed the Cardinal held a unique role. "Having the trust of everyone is important," he said.
 That would be particularly true given Archbishop Weakland's concern that the conference has changed over the last two or three years, with the bishops becoming less willing to take the bold stands they took in the 1980's with pastoral messages on world peace and the American economy.
 More and more prelates are not speaking out at all, the Archbishop said, adding, "Maybe the conference is typical of the whole nation." Differences among bishops "are greater," he said, and "there doesn't seem to be a clear vision."
 Mr. Graham, by contrast, has not played anything like the direct role among Southern Baptists that Cardinal Bernardin has among the bishops. The evangelist's appearances at Baptist meetings have been occasional; he has delivered inspiration rather than delving into committee work. And many perceive him as a sort of universal Christian clergyman, speaking to ecumenical gatherings around the world.
 But Mr. Graham is a Southern Baptist -- by choice, he points out, having been reared as a Presbyterian; he changed affiliation in college.
 His adopted denomination has suffered severe traumas in the last two decades, the result of a struggle between conservative and moderate factions that the conservatives won hands down. Some of those on the losing side have been forced from jobs on seminary faculties and in denominational agencies.
 And repercussions continue. The day before Mr. Graham appeared, officers of an alumni association at one Southern Baptist seminary resigned in protest over its new, conservative policies, among them what the officers said were narrow theological restrictions imposed by the administration.
 But Thursday morning, all eyes were on the 76-year old evangelist. Earlier this month, he was twice hospitalized in Toronto, where he had gone to preach one of his "crusades." Doctors diagnosed a bleeding colon and ordered several blood transfusions.
 Arriving at the Baptists' convention, which was held at the Georgia Dome, an indoor stadium, Mr. Graham walked more slowly than usual. And his sermon tended toward the conversational rather than the declamatory as he praised the denomination for its evangelistic efforts.
 He first spoke to the annual convention in 1951, Mr. Graham said. He had done so more than a dozen times since, and was now back on the denomination's 150th anniversary.
 "Think of it," he said: He had been around "long enough to have preached to one-third of the history of Southern Baptists."
 In all, he received four standing ovations.

HEADLINE: Teacher Accused of Asking Student for Bribe

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
A high school social studies teacher with a salary of $62,331 was charged with extortion yesterday, accused of soliciting $300 in bribes to improve the grade of a senior enrolled in his remedial economics course.
 The teacher, identified as Kenneth D. Cotton, 44, of Queens, was arrested on Thursday night at Jamaica High School in Queens by investigators from the office of Edward F. Stancik, the special commissioner of investigation for the city's school system. 
 Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines announced that he had suspended Mr. Cotton and directed the school system to seek his dismissal.
 "Extorting money from students to change their grades is a horrible, inexcusable exploitation of a teacher's position," he said.
 Mr. Stancik said he did not believe that accepting bribes for raising student grades was widespread. But he said his office was looking into a similar allegation against Mr. Cotton from another student.
 Officials in the school system and the Queens District Attorney's office said the student, Andres Namen, 18, of St. Helena's High School in the Bronx, had been told he was in danger of failing economics and not graduating unless he enrolled in a makeup course at night at Jamaica High School.
 The District Attorney's office said Mr. Cotton, who has worked for the Board of Education for 20 years and was teaching at Adlai E. Stevenson High School in the Bronx during the day, approached the teen-ager on May 23, told him he had too many absences from the class and offered to "stick his neck out" for him. But he said there would have to be some reward, the District Attorney's office said.
 Mr. Namen told the authorities that Mr. Cotton said he wanted money -- "not in the four digits, but not less than $100."
 Rachel Bluestein, a spokeswoman for Mr. Stancik, said the young man gave Mr. Cotton $150 in late May.
 "The teacher said he needed more money," Ms. Bluestein said. At that point, she continued, Mr. Namen began to feel he had done something wrong, and on June 16 he reported the matter to a safety officer at Jamaica High School.
 Mr. Namen was fitted with a recording device and given $150. "We have on audiotape that the teacher accepted the bribe and gave the kid his grade," Ms. Bluestein said. Mr. Namen was going to fail, but the teacher instead gave him a passing grade in exchange for the bribe, she said.
 The Queens District Attorney's office charged Mr. Cotton with grand larceny by extortion, receiving a bribe and other charges. He could receive a maximum penalty of 15 years in prison for extortion.
 He was arraigned before Criminal Court Judge Joseph Grasso and released on $1,500 cash bail pending a preliminary hearing on Wednesday.
 Mr. Cotton's lawyer, Douglas H. Krieger, said, "There is a lot that has not been said, and at the proper time it will be revealed." He said his client "is saying that it is not as pictured."
 Mr. Namen's class graduated on Thursday night. His status was reported to be unresolved.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kenneth D. Cotton, a Queens social studies teacher, was charged in a money-for-grades scheme.

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT ACTS TO SET ITS POLICY ON RACE PROGRAMS

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
Little more than a week after the Supreme Court ruled that Federal preference programs based on race must be held to an exacting constitutional standard, the Clinton Administration is beginning, occasionally with fits and starts, to develop its response.
Administration officials said today that the Justice Department would provide legal guidance on affirmative action to Federal agencies next week and ask them to review their programs to make sure of meeting the standard laid down by the Court. 
 But already, in an announcement today, the Federal Communications Commission has said that it plans to scrap its earlier intention to provide preferences to women and minorities in its coming sale of wireless-telephone licenses. Instead, F.C.C. officials said, those advantages will now be given to small business generally.
On the other hand, the Transportation Department today gave Oregon officials a go-ahead to continue with a program in which states are encouraged to set aside a percentage of federally financed highway construction projects for companies owned by women or members of minority groups. Oregon officials had suspended bidding on five such projects earlier this week, fearing that the Court's ruling would leave the contracts vulnerable to lawsuits.
The Court's decision, and the Government's effort to determine how that decision ought to apply to varying programs, come at a time when the Administration was already reviewing all Federal affirmative action programs to see whether they accomplished their goals and imposed no undue burden on whites. President Clinton will announce the results of that review, which must now conform with the standard set by the Justices, in a speech that Administration officials expect him to give in July.
In its 5-to-4 decision, the Court held on June 12 in Adarand Constructors Inc. v. Pena that any Federal program that classifies people by race can be considered constitutional only if it is "narrowly tailored" to serve a "compelling governmental interest." The Justices had applied such a standard to state affirmative action programs for years but had allowed the Federal Government far more leeway in administering its own programs.
Even as the Administration seeks to find its legal legs on the issue, civil rights, labor and women's groups are trying to ratchet up the political pressure in favor of affirmative action.
At a news conference in Washington this week, civil rights and labor figures led by the Rev. Jesse Jackson raised the possibility of an economic boycott against states like California where either legislation or voter initiatives would ban consideration of race or sex in employment, contracting or school-admissions decisions.
Indeed, officials of some civil rights groups said they had already begun to research the feasibility of a boycott of California. "It's very serious," said Barbara Arnwine, director of the Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law. "A number of things are being done, and all required steps are being taken to examine the potential of such a concerted effort."
An official of another civil rights group said the issues related to a boycott were many and complex. Among them are these:
*If the boycott succeeded in imposing economic hardship on California, what would be the political effect on politicians there who are friendly to affirmative action?
*What about the possibility of suits brought by California businesses that had played no role in the anti-preference policy but were nonetheless being hurt by the protest?
*Should supporters of affirmative action forgo travel to the state entirely or instead make a particular city the target?
*Or should they boycott a product like wine or table grapes?
Those pushing for a boycott say the point would be to bring pressure not only on California but also on any other state that might be considering a ban on preference programs. They say a boycott could sway politicians who are wavering on the issue.
"This is also directed at two Washington players: Congress and the White House," said one civil rights leader, who spoke only on condition of anonymity. "Both have to be reminded that there is going to be a major effort to bring political costs into this debate."
Experts in affirmative action law say Federal preference efforts are mainly concentrated in set-aside programs run by the Transportation Department, the Small Business Administration and the Defense Department; programs like the F.C.C.'s that give minority- and female-owned companies extra credits in bidding; the Federal Government's own personnel policies, and a program run by the Labor Department to prod Federal contractors to hire and promote women and minority-group members.
So far, the F.C.C. appears to be the only Federal agency making a major change in such efforts. The change applies to an auction of wireless-telephone licenses scheduled for August.
The commission's original intent was to provide minority- or female-owned companies engaged in the bidding a 25-percent discount, or "bidding credit." Responding to the Supreme Court's decision, however, the F.C.C. today formally proposed instead giving the 25 percent credit to all companies with annual revenue under $40 million.
In issuing their new plan, F.C.C. officials said they were primarily concerned about avoiding disruption of the auction. The auction was temporarily blocked by a Federal court earlier this year after a rural telephone company had sued the commission, then was allowed to proceed when the F.C.C. and the company negotiated a settlement.
Given the choice between the preference program and the possibility of further litigation that would cause them to fall behind competitors that have already received licenses in earlier bidding rounds, many minority-owned companies supported today's change in the F.C.C. policy.

HEADLINE: SESSION EXTENDED BY U.S. AND JAPAN IN IMPASSE ON CARS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Saturday, June 24

 BODY:
Japanese and American negotiators agreed early this morning to keep talking through the weekend in an effort to head off the imposition of $5.9 billion in sanctions against Japanese imports that loom just four days away. But officials from each country said neither side gave much ground in a day and night of intense talks.
Long after this city had shut down for the night, the Japanese and American teams remained holed up in a small American trade office on the edge of Lake Geneva, arguing over the demands from Washington for fundamental changes in the way Japan regulates its economy and organizes it industry to keep outsiders -- both foreign and Japanese -- at bay. 
 "There was no indication of any significant progress," a senior Administration official said.
As the evening wore on, the Japanese negotiators appeared to be in constant communication with Japan's car makers back in Tokyo, apparently in an effort to coax them into issuing "voluntary plans" for the purchase of American parts that could form the basis of an agreement. But there were no signs of any breakthroughs and several officials familiar with the talks said they still suspected that the Japanese plans would fall far short of what the Administration had demanded.
The painstaking progress underlined the uncomfortable choice facing President Clinton over the next few days: whether to take the best deal he can get by the Wednesday deadline in order to avoid a huge rift with America's closest ally in the Pacific, or whether to go ahead with the 100 percent tariffs, betting that they will spur the Japanese on to deeper concessions in the next few weeks or months.
"The issue is whether the sanctions themselves will motivate the Japanese to solve this problem," said a senior Administration official familiar with the debate, "or so anger them that our leverage will be gone. And there are reasonable arguments on both sides."
Another official involved in the discussion called sanctions "the nuclear weapons of trade, and they may not be worth much after you've used them."
In public, Mr. Clinton has struck an unyielding pose, saying last week at the economic summit meeting in Halifax, Nova Scotia, that he would neither delay nor drop the sanctions unless a deal was struck first. But with the Japanese now negotiating seriously, the question is what kind of deal represents the bottom line for Mr. Clinton. Will he settle for one that simply forces Japan to buy more parts in America and eliminates some regulations in Tokyo that have contributed for years to the problems facing American car makers? Or will he insist on one that begins to break the back of the corporate interrelationships in Japan that keep newcomers -- both foreign and Japanese -- out of the rich market.
Given the public hyperbole in both capitals, the tone of the two days of talks here has been surprisingly cordial. After months of refusing to even talk about inducing the Japanese car makers to issue so-called voluntary plans for their parts purchases, Japanese negotiators are now talking about such plans in some detail. The plans are always termed voluntary to skirt international trade rules that do not allow countries to set rules favoring one nation's imports over another's.
But on the hardest question -- getting American parts into the Japanese market in meaningful and measurable volumes -- there have been no reports of real progress so far. Only if that happens can the Administration truly assert that it has broken the back of the "keiretsu" relationships -- families of closely linked companies -- that are at the heart of the auto dispute.
One of the oddities of the talks here is that the most important participants in these negotiations -- Japan's car makers -- are 7,000 miles away. They hold the key to how many American parts will go into Japanese autos, and whether the parts will go into cars produced only in the United States or also into models made and sold in Japan.
Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry, whose industrial policies helped build the Japanese car industry out of the the ruins of World War II, insists that it no longer has control over the car makers. Therefore, it contends, the Japanese Government cannot and should notmake an agreement on their behalf.
American negotiators say that is a smokescreen, and that the Government's influence is still so vast over Japanese industry that it could, at a minimum, bless and help support any program to increase American content in Japanese cars.
Japan's strategy, officials close to the negotiations said, is to have the car makers prepare "business plans" for increased parts purchases over the next 48 to 72 hours, with the understanding that none of those plans would be binding. The Honda Motor Company was the first to edge toward such a plan, albeit in the sketchiest possible form. The company, which was the first Japanese auto maker to begin producing motorcycles and cars in the United States, said that it would begin importing more replacement car parts from the United States. But it did not say how many parts, or when they would be purchased.
The Honda plan addresses one of the three major American complaints about the Japanese automobile industry, focusing on Japanese repair shops. The shops conduct inspections of cars in Japan, often replacing a wide range of components. It is profitable work, and the shops are dominated by the car manufacturers, meaning they use authorized and very expensive parts. The American negotiators argue that Japanese consumers should have a choice, and should be able to choose foreign-made mufflers or brake linings that are only one-half to one-fourth as expensive as their Japanese equivalents.
A Honda spokesman said the company's announcement had nothing to do with the trade talks. Honda was motivated, he said, by the high value of the yen, which has made Japanese parts too expensive.
But the Toyota Motor Company, the biggest Japanese car maker, said it had no plans to follow Honda's lead, and without Toyota no deal is possible. As the most politically connected of the car makers, however, Toyota is presumably more subject to leverage by the Japanese Government.
For all the 11th-hour frenzy, none of the plans being discussed at the moment meet even the most minimal tests established by the Clinton Administration for a deal acceptable to the United States. The key problem is that the Administration insists that any plan to increase purchases must be measurable, so that it can keep the pressure on Japan rather than just sign an agreement and file it away.
The question is whether the two sides can come up with a formula that the Americans can declare a victory, and that the Japanese can claim does not constitute a "target" or a "commitment."

HEADLINE: Lakehurst Sleeps Easier After Decision on Base

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

DATELINE: LAKEHURST, N.J., June 23

 BODY:
When Butch Wood was growing up in this small borough in southern New Jersey, there was an expression he heard often enough that he recalled it today at the age of 54: "We had the apple."
 "The apple represented total care," he said, sipping a drink at the Airship Tavern. "You put your head down at night and you were secure that in the morning you had a job, benefits, for you and your family." 
 For the residents here, the Lakehurst Naval Warfare Center was the apple for most of this century. It had lost some of its polish in recent years, Mr. Wood said, as layoffs on the base had spun several of his longtime friends off to other parts of the country. And yet Lakehurst was still Lakehurst because of the base.
 But for months, this borough of 3,000 had lived under a shadow -- ever since the Pentagon recommended that the base be closed as part of a broad effort to save money. On Thursday, though, Lakehurst won an unexpected reprieve, as a Presidential commission rejected the Pentagon's recommendation and ruled that the base should stay in business.
 Many residents celebrated the news with the passion of a patient recovering from long a illness.
 On Wednesday night, the Airship Tavern, a popular place for many base workers, was thronged with hundreds of revelers after the end of the 4 P.M. shift.
 Shortly before 2 P.M., Capt. Leroy A. Farr, the base commander, had received the news from Washington, and word spread quickly throughout the base and the borough. From his office, the captain heard horns, including a distinct horn, once used to signal lunches and breaks, that had been long silent.
 "The last six months had brought a lot of stress," the captain said. "It would come out in conversations. You could see they were bothered about their future, their family."
 The base employs 3,000, of whom 500 are military personnel, Captain Farr said. About 2,500 of the jobs would have disappeared under the Pentagon's plan to relocate the center's responsibilities to design and develop aircraft launching and landing equipment.
 The closing of the base and the evaporation of its $100 million payroll were inconceivable to a town whose economy and identity were tied to the base. A chemical company used to be the largest employer in the county but closed in the late 1980's.
 "We were very happy yesterday," said Randy Perez, 28, whose family has owned the Airship Tavern for 43 years. "Happy for them. Happy for the bar.
 "I think it would have killed the town," said Mr. Perez, who like other natives refers to himself as a "piney," after the region's ubiquitous pine trees.
 It is perhaps a measure of the base's real and psychological importance to the community that Jacqueline Welch's mother, uncertain about the outcome, decided to sell her duplex of 23 years. Miss Welch, 30, grew up in the house on Maple Street. But she said her mother sold the house three months ago, fearing that property values would drop if the base closed and worried about rumors that the base housing might be converted to public housing.

HEADLINE: A Gingrich Budget Gain

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
The Republican balanced-budget proposal unveiled with some flourish on Thursday evening is a compromise that, on most of the issues that count, bears the stamp of the House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, more than that of his Senate counterpart, Bob Dole, the majority leader.
But the important thing to remember is that it is only a Republican proposal. In a Republican Congress, it is an impressive work of political deal-cutting. In the two-party world beyond Capitol Hill, it stands no chance of becoming law without major changes. 
 The best way to regard the seven-year, $898 billion package of deficit reduction is as a marker -- an opening statement of Republican fiscal ideology in a battle with Democrats for control of the Federal purse. And what it says is that that ideology is moving to the right.
The plan contains a mix of proposals that the Senate and House offered a month ago, when they first issued separate blueprints for achieving fiscal balance. Each side made some concessions, but on the biggest issues -- tax cuts and defense spending -- Mr. Gingrich and the revolutionaries who led the Republicans to victory last fall won the day.
The Speaker secured a commitment to enact virtually all the tax breaks the House had sought at a higher cost than the Senate's negotiators first said they could stomach. To pay for those cuts and still reach a balance, the new budget runs higher annual deficits in its first years than the Senate wanted, and cuts spending more deeply in later years than it preferred.
Mr. Gingrich also prevailed on welfare, where the budget plan adopts the House's proposal for deeper spending cuts than the Senate preferred. He largely prevailed in winning deeper cuts in Medicare spending. And he conceded -- for now -- that the only Cabinet agency to vanish under Republican rule is the Commerce Department, but the Speaker's aides say that battle is not over.
The Senate won an important assurance that the tax cuts would not take effect until budget experts certify that the deficit was in fact on a path toward zero as planned. But should a worsening economy or other factors change that path after the tax cuts are enacted, there is no real guarantee that Congress would rescind the breaks in the name of fiscal responsibility.
The shifts are small. At the day's end, all Republicans favor balancing the budget and all Republicans want to cut taxes, either now or sometime later. And all Republicans want the smaller Government that this budget would produce.
The difference is that the Senate, and Old Guard Republicans, would proceed cautiously, out of concern that they would harm the economy or the fabric of the Government itself. The budget proposal that the party's leadership agreed to on Thursday is clearly in a much greater hurry.
Senator Dole, the party's senior leader and its front-runner in the 1996 Presidential race, rose to power in an era when deficits were a matter of fiscal rather than political concern and tax cuts were rare. But he faces a fair number of Republican revolutionaries in his own chamber, and he needs the party's right wing if he is to prosper in the primary elections to come. So his views on the final shape of the budget package were muted, at least in public.
The House may come to regret its insistence on big tax cuts if the economy sours, deficits start rising again and the Republican pledge to balance the budget begins to look like political puffery, said Kevin Phillips, the author and conservative political analyst.
"But on its face, it looks like the differences were split in Gingrich's favor," he said today.
The new budget plan still must be ratified in separate House and Senate votes next week, but few anticipate that Mr. Dole or Mr. Gingrich will have much trouble rounding up the votes they need on its behalf.
How much it matters is a different question. The budget proposal may affirm Mr. Gingrich's status as a rising force in Republican politics, as if that were needed. But the remainder of the budget battle will be fought on a broader field.
Having promised in their campaigns to cut spending, and having said this week roughly how they plan to cut it, Republicans now have to make the actual cuts, in scores of committee meetings and floor votes.
Political and budgetary experts, many of whom have underestimated the party's resolve before, predict a rising chorus of protest from both Democratic and Republican voters as the reality of spending reductions and curtailed Government services begins to sink in.
Most Republicans will surely stick to their deficit-reduction pledge. But most will not be enough: The Republicans can afford to lose only 4 of their 54 votes in the Senate and 14 of their 231 votes in the House before losing majority control on spending and tax issues.
Those same slim margins make it highly unlikely that either the House or the Senate could override a Presidential veto of spending bills this fall. That means President Clinton will have a decisive say in the final shape of the 1996 budget, regardless of what Congress does this summer.
And Mr. Clinton has already made it clear that the Republican proposals at the core of the new budget agreement -- the big tax cut and the deep reductions in projected spending for Medicaid, Medicare and welfare -- will not survive in any final spending package.
Republicans in Mr. Gingrich's camp have got this far, budget analysts note, by refusing to compromise on their ideology. But in the end they almost certainly will have to decide whether to compromise and gain some of their goal, or fight and lose some.

HEADLINE: Clinton Calls G.O.P. Plan On Budget 'Too Extreme'

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 23

 BODY:
A day after Republican Congressional leaders reached an agreement on a seven-year blueprint for tax cuts and a balanced budget, President Clinton today began a public campaign to set out the differences between a plan he called "too extreme" and his own proposal to erase the deficit over 10 years.
In a conference call with five Democratic governors, Mr. Clinton said the Republican budget plan, which would cut a variety of taxes by $245 billion and sharply scale back Federal spending, would "complicate your lives as governors considerably." He said the Republican proposal would shift to the states new responsibilities even as the magnitude of the cuts risked sending the nation into an economic downturn. 
 "I believe that their plan is still too extreme, runs a significant risk of putting the economy into recession and raising unemployment," Mr. Clinton said.
Congressional negotiators never seriously considered Mr. Clinton's alternative 10-year plan, which he unveiled in a television address last week. That plan called for less severe reductions in social programs and taxes and would have protected education and some other domestic initiatives.
But the President indicated that he believed the debate was far from over as Congress moves into a phase this summer of passing the individual spending bills for 1996 that will put the budget plan into effect.
"Now that the Senate and House have resolved their differences, we can proceed to what I hope will be an honest open and civil discussion with the American people about the agreements and the differences in our two plans," he said. "And I hope in the end we'll wind up doing a balanced budget in the right way that will grow the economy."
The conference call with the five governors, broadcast over a sound system for reporters, preceded Mr. Clinton's address to a second $1,000-a-plate campaign fund-raiser in two days, this time in his home state in a ballroom of the Excelsior Hotel that was named for him after he was elected President.
Democrats packed the room, the largest hotel conference room in Arkansas, bringing in more than $1 million for Mr. Clinton's re-election campaign. But the event had its bittersweet moments in a state that has seen a number of its prominent citizens come under indictment or legal scrutiny since Mr. Clinton became President.
Showing touches of nostalgia for simpler times in Arkansas, Hillary Rodham Clinton deplored the "politics of meanness."
And Mr. Clinton said, "You know, some nights I watch the news, and I feel like that old country song, 'They Changed Everything About Me But My Name.' "
The audience rose to a standing ovation when Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the lifelong friend of Mr. Clinton who serves as counselor to the President, introduced the state's Democratic governor, Jim Guy Tucker. Mr. Tucker was arraigned Thursday on charges of fraud brought by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater special prosecutor. The crowd applauded again when Mr. Clinton said he was "especially grateful" for the ovation granted to his successor as governor.
Mr. Tucker pleaded not guilty to the charges, which stem from his purchase and sale of cable television interests in 1987.
For the second day in a row, Mr. Clinton criticized the Republican Senate for blocking the nomination of Dr. Henry W. Foster Jr. as Surgeon General, saying Democrats could have kept Justice Clarence Thomas off the Supreme Court if they had followed a similar strategy of using a filibuster to prevent the nomination from coming to a vote. "In this new world there are no rules except winning and losing," Mr. Clinton said in deploring the Republican tactics, "because one side is all good and the other side is all bad."
His voice becoming soft and impassioned, he blamed those same tactics for the troubles that have befallen colleagues in Arkansas since the Whitewater inquiry began into the real estate land dealings of the Clintons and after the suicide of the deputy White House counsel, Vincent W. Foster, Jr., who had been a partner with Mrs. Clinton at the Rose Law Firm in Little Rock.
"A lot of what's happened to you here, a lot of the outrageous, outrageous things that have been said in our state, and a lot of the licking that you've taken," Mr. Clinton said, "is a product of the confusion and the disorientation of the times, and the idea that there are no rules and people just sort of flailing around trying to win another one to get to tomorrow."
He added: "That is not what made this country great. And it's not what you taught me to do here."
Saying "the stakes are the highest they've ever been," Mr. Clinton urged his supporters to help him in his re-election fight for his economic priorities and for a politics that is more civil. "It's my last election," he said to laughter. "I'll never run for anything else. You'll never have to come to one of these again."
