HEADLINE: Road Gets Bumpy for Electric Car, And Presidential Politics Is Blamed

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
The future of the electric automobile, always uncertain, now appears tangled in Republican Presidential politics.
California requires that in the 1998 model year, 2 percent of the cars sold by major auto makers in that state have "zero emissions," and Gov. Pete Wilson has generally supported the program. But Mr. Wilson is running for President and has recently taken steps that advocates of the cars say amount to laying the groundwork for eviscerating the electric car plan to placate four Republicans whose support he needs for the nomination. 
 Officials in the Wilson administration deny the accusation.
The four Republicans Mr. Wilson is supposedly courting are all Midwestern Governors: John Engler of Michigan, Jim Edgar of Illinois, Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin and George V. Voinovich of Ohio. They sent a letter to Mr. Wilson on May 1 saying the "zero emission vehicles" that California will require would be of little environmental benefit and would be so expensive that they would have to be subsidized by raising the cost of conventional automobiles, which they said would cost jobs in their states. Instead, they endorsed a compromise drafted by the auto companies, calling for the production of conventional cars for all 50 states that are cleaner than what Federal law now requires.
"We are willing to organize and participate with you in an event here in one of the Great Lakes states, or anywhere else you choose, to announce your support for a national clean car," the Governors said. "Pete, your leadership can benefit the economy and the environment for all Americans."
All four states have their Presidential primaries on Feb. 19, 1996.
Mr. Wilson rejected the Governors' appeal, but he did call for a new "audit" to determine whether the electric car program was practical. The California Air Resources Board, which conceived the electric car program in 1990 as part of a broader strategy for cleaner cars, has held a technology review every two years, and will begin another one later this year to see if all phases of its requirements are working out. But this audit would be performed by outside experts, probably a panel of academics and consultants.
"We're not implying that we don't have confidence in the Air Resources Board, and we're not implying that they haven't done a good job," said Paul Kranhold, a spokesman for the Wilson campaign. The zero-emission vehicle quota rises to 10 percent in 2003, and Mr. Kranhold said, "The bottom line is that on a decision of this magnitude by a regulatory agency, the people deserve the benefit of this type of audit."
A major figure in the maneuvering is Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts, who is also Mr. Wilson's national campaign finance chairman. Massachusetts, along with New York, has adopted the California plan and has come under intense pressure from the auto industry to drop it. Mr. Weld recently sent a letter to Mr. Wilson suggesting that the two states conduct a joint review of the technology. Electric car advocates say they fear that the auto industry and the oil industry, which also dislikes electric cars, have enough fund-raising power to sway Mr. Weld and Mr. Wilson.
"I obviously can't prove what's on Governor Weld's mind," said Joseph L. Caves, a lobbyist in Sacramento, Calif., who represents the Union of Concerned Scientists and other proponents of electric cars. "But it appears to me that this decision has as much to do with Presidential politics as with environmental quality."
"The Wilson administration and its appointees have consistently supported the Air Resources Board, until he decided to run for President," he said. "There's never been any indication before that this decision was going to be made on anything other than its importance to the California air quality program. Now our concern is Presidential politics has entered into it."
State and Federal officials outside California raise the same fear, although they do so only in private. For years the Air Resources Board has pioneered the regulations that led to new technologies on automobiles, like catalytic converters.
But officials in the Wilson and Weld administrations say seeking another review is just being prudent.
At the California Environmental Protection Agency, the parent body of the Air Resources Board, Daniel F. Pellissier, a spokesman, said, "Pete Wilson has made it clear the environmental decisions in the state of California made by our agency are being driven by the environmental needs of California, end of statement, period, paragraph."
In the East, 12 states from Virginia to Maine, plus the District of Columbia, said they would adopt the California plan of rising proportions of ever-cleaner vehicles, but only two, Massachusetts and New York, said they would require zero-emission vehicles. The auto companies, complaining of a logistics nightmare in a fragmented national market, offered their compromise for all states but California: a car cleaner than the Federal standard but not quite as clean as that in the California plan. The companies later offered California the same arrangement.
Many of the Eastern states said they liked the idea, but the auto companies are demanding that New York and Massachusetts drop the electric-car requirement first.
But whether or not the requirements change, the discussion could make investors nervous, say officials at CalStart, a not-for-profit consortium, partly financed by the state, that promotes electric vehicle technology. "In California, folks have invested over $500 million already in this effort, with much more estimated to come within the next two years," said Michael J. Gage, president of the consortium.
The auto companies, meanwhile continue to maintain that the electric car is not ready for major marketing. Advocates, though, point to the performance of a new electric model in a race last month. A four-passenger sedan built by Solectria, of Wilmington, Mass., with approximately the same interior space as a Ford Taurus, it traveled 238 miles over public roads without recharging.
The car used nickel metal hydride batteries, a type that is already common in laptop computers. General Motors and the company that holds the patent, Ovonic, are gearing up to mass produce the battery in sizes appropriate for cars.

HEADLINE: Raghavan Narasimhan Iyer, 65, An Expert on East-West Cultures

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Raghavan Narasimhan Iyer, a philosopher, author and professor emeritus of political science at the University of California at Santa Barbara, died on Tuesday at St. Francis Medical Center in Santa Barbara. He was 65 and lived in Santa Barbara.
The cause was complications from pneumonia, said his son, Pico Iyer. 
 Dr. Iyer (pronounced EYE-er) was educated at Oxford University, and his work bridged the cultures of East and West, old and new. His writings and lectures could be spellbinding as he drew from sources from Plato to the Bhagavad-Gita, the Sanskrit poem and classic of Hinduism, from Agatha Christie to the pop songwriter Jackson Browne.
He wrote and edited scores of articles, book chapters and books. His body of work included "The Moral and Political Thought of Mahatma Gandhi" (Oxford University Press, 1973), which reflected his knowledge of the histories, philosophies and literatures of diverse worlds and placed Gandhi in the context of Plato, Kant, Buddha and Jesus.
Another notable book was "Parapolitics: Toward the City of Man" (Oxford, 1979). It gave his view on large-scale political theory with reflections on such themes as commitment and over-commitment, the relation of means to ends, the morality of revolution and the hazards of democracy in underdeveloped countries.
He increasingly became involved in theosophy, a system of thought akin to mysticism that claims special insight into the nature of God and the world. He was a leading member of the Santa Barbara branch of the United Lodge of Theosophists.
In 1976 he founded the Institute of World Culture in Santa Barbara, of which he was president until 1986. Its purpose is to explore the cultures of East and West and their interaction through history.
Dr. Iyer was born in Madras, India, and studied at the University of Bombay, earning a master's in economics. He won a Rhodes Scholarship in 1950 and studied philosophy, politics and economics at Oxford, where he was elected president of the Oxford Union and received a doctorate in moral and political philosophy.
In addition to his son, a travel writer who lives in Santa Barbara, Dr. Iyer is survived by his wife of 40 years, Nandini Mehta Iyer, a professor of religious studies at Santa Barbara.

HEADLINE: May Orders For Durables Jumped 2.5%

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
Orders and shipments of factory equipment and other costly manufactured goods surged in May, as business and consumer demand remained strong despite signs in other recent Government statistics that the economy was slowing.
 But most economists concluded that the extra manufacturing activity was not enough by itself to change the course of the economy or alter the Federal Reserve's policy on interest rates. 
 "We've seen some temporary bounce-back, which gives you some confidence" that the economy will not slide into a recession, said Richard B. Berner, the chief economist at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. But, he added, "These data don't convince me that the economy is poised for a rebound yet."
 Stock and bond prices dropped at the opening after the Commerce Department's announcement of the statistics on orders and shipments, as investors initially decided that senior Federal Reserve officials were slightly less likely to cut short-term interest rates at their next policy meeting on July 5 and 6.
 But prices soon recovered as analysts played down the importance of the figures, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed with a loss of just 3.80 points. [Page 37.] Bond prices ended the day slightly lower, with the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rising to 6.49 percent from 6.47 percent. [Page 36.] Yields and prices move in opposite directions.
 New orders for durable goods -- which range from washing machines to aircraft -- rose 2.5 percent in May after falling 4.5 percent in April, the Commerce Department said. It was the first increase since January. Shipments climbed nine-tenths of a percent in May after dropping 2.2 percent in April.
 Eric Falkenstein, an economist at Keycorp, a Cleveland-based banking company, said that he doubted that today's figures would dissuade those Federal Reserve officials who believed that the central bank should be cutting interest rates soon. "It didn't recoup the fall in the prior month, so if anything, I think this pushed the Fed further toward an ease," he said.
 Mr. Berner said that some of the improvement in orders might reflect a strengthening of demand from abroad after the dollar's fall in currency markets this spring. To the extent that is true, then business confidence may not be as strong as today's report suggests, making the domestic economy appear slightly less robust.
 Since the statistics on durable goods often show big swings from one month to the next, many experts distrust the figures for any single month. Today's figures were also an advance estimate, subject to revision.
 Orders and shipments of transportation equipment, like cars and planes, are particularly volatile. Those orders rose 3 percent in May after a fall of 10.2 percent in April, but shipments dropped for the fourth consecutive month.
 Economists were more encouraged by the orders for factory equipment and other gear used to produce goods and services. Orders for nonmilitary capital goods, an indicator of business confidence in future sales, climbed 6.8 percent in May after dropping 5.9 percent in April. Shipments were up just seven-tenths of 1 percent, after being unchanged in April.
 Nonmilitary capital goods include everything from steam turbines and computer equipment to ship components and furnaces.
 Orders rose even more sharply for military capital goods, which range from tanks to missiles. These orders increased 9.5 percent in May after plunging 27.7 percent in April.
 Orders for electronic and other electrical equipment were particularly strong, bouncing back from a dip in April to register the eighth increase in 10 months.
 Backlogs of unfilled orders for all types of durable goods, an important indicator of future economic activity, were unchanged in May, after falling by half a percent in April.

HEADLINE: State to Hire A Work Force At Javits Hall

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
Moving to break the grip that mob-influenced labor unions have long held over hiring practices at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, the state will soon begin hiring its own permanent work force there, stripping the unions of their rights to assign workers, officials said yesterday.
 The changes, they say, should sharply reduce what trade show exhibitors have described as exorbitant costs that they have had to pay to union workers for constructing booths and providing supplies. 
 Since the center opened in 1986, the three union locals representing teamsters, carpenters and other exhibition workers have wielded enormous power over the operations of the center. Because the unions had signed collective bargaining contracts with exhibition companies and contractors, they -- and not the Javits Center -- had the power to fill the jobs, which pay between $30,000 and $90,000 a year.
 Recent investigations by state officials and a court-appointed monitor have found that the influence of organized crime on the Javits unions is pervasive and that jobs there were routinely awarded to former convicts and mob-connected union members.
 Under the new plan, the state will begin hiring at least 500 new employees, all of whom will be screened to eliminate those with extensive criminal records or ties to organized crime.
 Although some of the workers may come from the current union rolls, officials said the jobs will be open to anyone, and they expect that about 200 carpenters, teamsters and exposition employees with tainted backgrounds will be permanently removed from the work force.
 "We want to clean up the enormous featherbedding that we now have as well as the notorious presence of organized crime," said Robert E. Boyle, the center's new executive director. "Whether we will succeed in doing that is still questionable."
 The new work rules are the latest in a series of crackdowns on organized crime in New York City. On Thursday state prosecutors indicted some of the largest garbage haulers in the city, and other recent efforts have focused on the Fulton Fish Market and the trucking industry in the garment district.
 The newly hired personnel will become state employees and will be subject to provisions of the state's Taylor Law, which prohibits strikes by state employees. In a radical departure from previous hiring practices at the Javits Center, officials said they would advertise the job openings in New York City and upstate newspapers.
 The officials said that new work rules will reduce the number of employees needed for shows and conventions and reduce costs for exhibitors by up to 40 percent. In some instances, the officials said, a single employee will perform the unloading and construction tasks that under old agreements had required four or five workers.
 Law-enforcement officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said that hiring booths for new applicants would be open at the center within two weeks. A squad of 25 state troopers will patrol the center when the hirings begin because of the possibility of demonstrations by current workers who are expected to be banned permanently from seeking jobs.
 For years, trade show exhibitors have complained about inflated labor costs, rules that require the hiring of unneeded workers, thefts, inadequate security and poor maintenance. In fact, some trade-show organizers say they have moved their exhibitions to other cities, draining money from New York's economy.
 In March, Gov. George E. Pataki branded conditions at the center as intolerable and appointed Mr. Boyle, a longtime supporter who had no experience in managing convention halls, as the center's top official and directed him to launch a cleanup campaign.
 In an interview yesterday, Mr. Boyle declined to comment on specific aspects of the hiring plan or when it will begin. "All I can say is that we are continuing to negotiate with the unions and we are reviewing all contracts," he said. Most of the center's employees unload materials for exhibitions and construct the booths and exhibits for trade shows and meetings. The number of daily employees can range widely -- from as few as 50 to as many as 1,000 -- depending on the size of a trade show or convention.
 The center's new managers say they are not bound by the old collective bargaining agreements and are negotiating revised terms with the unions. Under the new arrangement, the unions will have to seek certification as collective-bargaining agents by proving that they represent at least 50 percent of the employees in one of two new personnel divisions that the center will establish: the freight and erection units.
 State and union officials said that the center's negotiators have demanded that the unions accept their new terms on wages, welfare benefits and working conditions, before being permitted to seek recognition as the bargaining agent for either unit.
 On Thursday, Ron Carey, the general president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said that Teamsters Local 807 had accepted the new terms. In March, Mr. Carey ousted the top leaders of the local, charging that it was controlled by the Mafia, and appointed a trustee to run it.
 Matt Witt, a spokesman for Mr. Carey, said yesterday, "The hiring is now up to the Javits management." He said the union would urge Local 807 members who had previously been denied jobs by former union leaders to seek employment there.
 Mr. Witt said the union expected to win recognition in the freight unit and that wage scales would not be cut. But state officials said that the center had eliminated a clause that paid many teamsters about $5,000 a year as Christmas bonuses.
 State officials said that they expected that the District Council of Carpenters would also accept the new terms and seek to represent employees in the erection unit. The council has been accused by Federal prosecutors of being dominated by the Genovese crime family, and it is being monitored under a court order by Kenneth Conboy, a former Federal judge.
 Bernard B. Cohen, the council's chief lawyer, said the union "is concerned that honest, hard-working carpenters should not be laid off because of this new program." He said that Frederick W. Devine, the council's president, had been asked by aides to Governor Pataki and to Mr. Boyle not to discuss the specifics of the negotiations.
 Negotiations with the third union, the Exposition Employees Workers Union, Local 807, will begin Monday, said Jay McNamee, the union's secretary and treasurer. Law-enforcement officials said that the local also has been infiltrated by organized-crime figures and that the union has many featherbedding or unnecessary jobs at the center.
 Mr. McNamee declined to discuss the new hiring plan.
 Prosecutors in the Manhattan District Attorney's office said that the three unions are being investigated in connection with Mafia ties and corruption. In 1992, that office obtained the indictments of 27 men, including officials of the three unions, on charges of extortion and theft at the center.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Retreat After Durables Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities retreated in quiet trading yesterday as a strong report on durable goods caused traders to reassess the chances of a cut in short-term interest rates.
 The 30-year bond fell 13/32 , to a price of 11425/32 for a yield of 6.49 percent, up from 6.47 percent on Thursday. Shorter-maturity bill rates were also weaker, as were the intermediate-term notes. 
 Prices fell after the Commerce Department reported that orders for durable goods -- big-ticket items ranging from air-conditioners to aircraft -- jumped 2.5 percent. The market had been expecting an increase of two-tenths to seven-tenths of 1 percent.
 The report suggested that the economy might not be slowing as sharply as previously thought, which could forestall an expected cut in interest rates by the Fed when its policy makers next meet in early July.
 But the durable goods report tends to be volatile from month to month. So while the stronger-than-expected numbers may have put a dent in the case for a Fed cut in rates, they have not greatly damaged it. Traders say that is why coming data will still be critical and as Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, noted recently, there are still considerable uncertainties in the economy.
 "The process of assessing and fine- tuning monetary policy, and ultimately the economy, is a complex and gradual one," said Carroll J. Delaney, director of research at Stires, O'Donnell & Company. "The market's recent meteoric rise, on the other hand, has been anything but complex and gradual. Sooner or later the piper must be paid. We tend to think sooner."
 But the market's view of Fed policy is not the only factor moving prices. Peter McTeague, a market analyst with MCM Moneywatch, a market research and analysis firm in Boston, said quarter-end pressures to enhance money managers' portfolio performance were helping to drive the market. Expectations about the Fed's next move, he said, "are running wild and there's a real big chance of disappointment."
 The market must also turn its attention next week to a new supply of two-year and five-year notes. The two-year notes will be auctioned on Tuesday, and the five-year notes on Wednesday. In when-issued trading late yesterday, the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 5.57 percent and the five-year notes at a price to yield 5.80 percent.
 Rusty Vanneman, a senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said the market was "just simply overextended." He noted that the futures bond contract, which established a high of 116 in early June, reached 11530/32 yesterday.
 "What this implies is that the market does not have enough gas to go beyond that level," he said. "And raises the possibility of a double top, or a resistance level that will be a formidable obstacle in the future.
 "From a technical standpoint the market is essentially trading in a range and coiling for its next big move."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Weakens as Hopes Fade For German Interest Rate Cut

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was weaker yesterday after reports of accelerating German inflation dashed speculation that the Bundesbank would soon cut interest rates.
 Lower German rates would have helped the dollar by making bank deposits denominated in marks less attractive. 
 The dollar was little changed against the yen. Traders hesitated to sell dollars while the United States and Japan continue negotiations on automotive trade. Washington plans to impose sanctions on imports of Japanese luxury cars on Wednesday if no agreement is reached.
 "There are a number of conflicting tides affecting the dollar," said Varick Martin, manager of currency trading at the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company. "With the German price data, interest rate cuts in Europe seem further away now than yesterday."
 The dollar also suffered from a drop in bond prices yesterday in the United States, said Olli Enqvist, chief currency dealer at Skandaviska Enskilda Banken in New York. Lower bond prices hurt the dollar as foreign investors shy away from American assets.
 In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.3863 marks from 1.3981 marks on Thursday. The dollar slipped to 84.26 yen from 84.54 yen. The British pound, which fell on Thursday after Prime Minister John Major's announcement that he was resigning as leader of the ruling Conservative Party, edged back to $1.6066 from 1.5962.
 The dollar fell against the mark after the German states of Hesse, Baden-Wurttemberg and Rhine-Westphalia announced that consumer price increases were larger in June than May.
 The reports reduce the chances of annualized inflation slowing to the Bundesbank's target of 2 percent and throw a rate cut into doubt, said a Bundesbank council member, Guntram Palm. "These latest numbers make such a step tougher and more difficult," Mr. Palm said. Inflation in western Germany was 2.2 percent in May.
 The Bundesbank last reduced official rates March 30, when it lowered its discount rate to 4 percent from 4.5 percent.
 "The German price data and Palm's comments hurt the dollar," said Vicki Schmelzer Alicea, a currency saleswoman at Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale.
 The uncertainty surrounding the auto trade negotiations between the United States and Japan will help prevent a significant decline by the dollar, traders said.

HEADLINE: The Trash-Hauling Indictments

 BODY:
For half a century New York City has been prey to Mafia racketeers who control the commercial waste-hauling industry. Restaurants, hospitals, universities and businesses have been systematically gouged with prices 40 percent higher than an honest market would charge for their waste disposal. Now prosecutors have finally attacked the corruption broadly, with an indictment against 17 individuals, several of them associated with organized crime families, 23 carting companies and 4 trade associations accused of ripping off the city.
District Attorney Robert Morgenthau must still prove the 114 counts in the indictment. But there is no doubt about the city's long victimization. The $1.5 billion yearly business in hauling New York's trash should draw competitors from all over. Instead it is dominated by a mosaic of market-splitting cartels whose monopoly practices are enforced by mob muscle the moment an honest competitor seeks a slice of the business. 
 When Browning-Ferris Industries, a huge nationwide waste hauler, sought entry into the city's markets, a company executive's wife found a dog's severed head at their front door with a note, "Welcome to New York," tucked in its mouth. The company repeatedly found its low bids rejected, evidently because customers were too terrified to switch. When Browning-Ferris sought help from law enforcement, the District Attorney welcomed it to an investigation already under way since 1989.
The indictment cites violence and arson threats against potential competitors or any haulers who wanted to break ranks and compete with other cartelists. From an undercover detective who posed as an executive of a hauling company comes a charge that the cartel charged him more than $790,000 in trade association "dues" just to enjoy the business he had earned by a low bid.
Mr. Morgenthau seeks more than criminal convictions. He asks the courts for forfeitures and the appointment of receivers who will introduce competition. He hopes to draw outside bidders with a new climate and a safe environment. Similar reforms imposed on Long Island under Federal court supervision are beginning to take effect on equally notorious mob organizations that controlled trash collection there.
A secure victory will need an economic as well as a police response. Other haulers must enter the market, and existing haulers must compete with them and each other. Business customers, some of them huge corporations, must find the courage to shift their valuable patronage to low bidders.
Mark Green, the city's Public Advocate, has a promising bill in the City Council that could anchor the economic response. He proposes experimental collection districts where a single low bidder wins all the business in an area of several blocks now served by numerous small, non-competing carters.
It is time for the Council and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, a former prosecutor, to address this longer-term reform. Meanwhile New York can take pride in its newfound courage to break with 50 years of defeatist bondage to plundering trash haulers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Bad News for Workers

 BODY:
The economy has grown steadily for four years. Productivity -- output per hour of work -- shot up by 2 percent last year and by a gaudy 2.7 percent annual rate at the beginning of this year. Profits are near record levels and stock prices have surged 15 percent since January. By some measures, these are bountiful times.
But not for many workers. A disturbing report released this week by the Labor Department shows that average wages and salaries fell by more than 2 percent, after accounting for inflation, between March 1994 and March 1995. Total compensation, which includes fringe benefits like health insurance, fell even more, by about 3 percent. A big factor in that decline was health benefits, which fell 8 percent for unclear reasons. The losses were not caused by workers shifting from high-paying manufacturing to low-paying service jobs. 
 For long stretches of American history, the shares of total income going to low-paid workers, high-paid workers and owners of capital rarely budged. But in the 1970's, unskilled workers began to fall rapidly behind skilled workers. Even so, workers kept pace with owners of capital. Wages tracked productivity growth, so that as workers produced more -- with the help of more and better equipment -- they were paid more.
Now, according to new data, even that trend seems broken: for the past two years, wages have risen more slowly than the growth of output. As a consequence, the share of income going to workers has fallen since 1993.
Experts will need time to determine if the new data hold up under scrutiny. But if they do, the important yet unanswered question is whether labor's plight is temporary. There is growing suspicion that stagnation of wages might be due to permanent structural forces. One indication is that wages appear to be falling behind productivity in Western Europe as well. Perhaps the cause is modern technology. Perhaps it is global competition or the demise of powerful unions. No matter what the explanation turns out to be, the trends will not be easily reversed.
If the wages of those who work continue to lag behind returns to those who own places of work, the social consequences could be explosive. That is why the budget fight between the White House and Congress takes on an importance beyond politics.
President Clinton's budget would do far more to help workers than would the Republicans' proposals. The President narrowed the differences between his budget and theirs, but did not eliminate them. He would preserve public investments in training, education and research -- investments that can pay off in higher-wage jobs. The G.O.P. chops much of these investments away. The President's tax break for tuition payments is badly targeted and wasteful, but is still smarter than the Republican proposals to riddle the code with new tax shelters.
Although taxes and budget policy have little to do with recent trends in wages and profits, the Republicans will exacerbate income disparities by pushing a tax package that puts most of the savings in the pockets of wealthy families. Washington may not have the answers to the plight of workers. But it surely need not make matters worse.

HEADLINE: A Bridge to the 21st Century

BYLINE: By Alfred A. DelliBovi; Alfred A. DelliBovi, president of the Home Loan Bank of New York, was Deputy Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in the Bush Administration.

 BODY:
Think of it this way. A certain Monsieur Antoine boards the Concorde at 11 A.M. in Paris, crosses the Atlantic, takes a high-speed airport link to a renewed Times Square, enjoys lunch with a glass of red wine on 46th Street's Restaurant Row, takes in a matinee on Broadway and returns to the airport in time for a slower overnight flight home. And at no point does he worry about gridlock and missed connections.
That is a fanciful idea today. But it is precisely the vision New York must keep in mind if it hopes to remain a world-class international city tomorrow. 
 The transportation system is antiquated, especially its links to LaGuardia and Kennedy Airports. Getting to and from the airports is expensive -- especially for the ordinary citizen whose $35 cab rides are not underwritten by a benevolent employer. It is also chancy, with possible traffic jams everywhere, which of course slow down city buses to the airports.
This means the city loses money, because the traveler who survives this arduous journey has little energy to do anything else after arriving in Manhattan. And this is why New Yorkers must rethink two imaginative transportation proposals. If done right, both offer great benefits to residents and visitors alike. The first is the Port Authority project to link LaGuardia and Kennedy airports to the city. The second is the proposed 42d Street trolley.
There is general agreement on the need for a high-speed link to the planes. But the Port Authority's plan needs revision. The notion of placing the Manhattan terminus at 59th Street and Lexington Avenue has aroused strong opposition among East Siders. In addition, the costs of reconfiguring the 59th Street Bridge (reducing it by two lanes) and building a spur to Grand Central Terminal under Madison Avenue are considerable.
The Port Authority estimates the cost of redoing the bridge to accommodate a rail line at $135 million and the cost of the underground spur at $600 million. That is a big chunk of the total estimated project cost of $2.5 to $3 billion.
The long-planned 42d Street trolley has also generated criticism. A trolley makes economic sense compared to elevated or underground alternatives. Reputable estimates suggest that a trolley running westward from the United Nations to the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, would cost less than $100 million, including rolling stock and a maintenance facility, But skeptics question whether it could generate enough passenger revenue to operate the service and pay off the original capital costs of construction.
There is an answer to both problems: a new East River crossing at 42d Street -- a bridge to the 21st century. A Port Authority white paper did, in fact, explore the alternative of such a bridge. The study concluded that it would cost $213 million more than it would to reconfigure the 59th Street Bridge. It also foresaw a complicated and unattractive station on the East Side -- an unsightly three-story structure that would cross the river at the 130-foot clearance required by the Federal Government for the East River ship lanes.
But there is another way to cross the river: construct an adjustable bridge -- a conventional drawbridge or a bridge that can go up or down hydraulically. It would rise either from the existing 42d Street ramp of the Franklin R. Roosevelt Drive or a new ramp and would cross the river's navigation channels at 65 feet above mean high water.
This height level, which matches the height level on the Intracoastal Waterway, is sufficient for most river traffic. Besides, the bridge could be elevated to accommodate the occasional ship requiring clearance of up to 130 feet. An informal survey of East River traffic suggests this would occur no more than once a month, and probably less.
An adjustable bridge would obviously cost less than the Port Authority's 59th Street alternative. There would be no need to build a tunnel between Lexington Avenue and the existing 59th Street bridge and no need to build a separate tunnel to Grand Central. At 42d Street, passengers arriving at Grand Central could board the trolley, which in short order would have them on their way to the bridge and then to the airport.
The bridge would boost ridership on the trolley because it would link key destinations in Manhattan -- the Javits Center, Port Authority Bus Terminal, Times Square, Grand Central and the United Nations -- with the LaGuardia and Kennedy gateways.
Visually, the bridge would be less intrusive than a permanent structure with approaches reaching several blocks into Manhattan. An international competition, perhaps sponsored by the Municipal Art Society, could yield an imaginative design for what might well be the world's longest movable span.
The Port Authority should develop a plan that would make this vision a reality in affordable steps. In doing so, it would assure robust passenger revenues for the trolley and make it far easier and cheaper than it is today for travelers to move comfortably to and from the airports. It would also restore the Port Authority's long tradition as a force for regional economic development.

HEADLINE: METHOD & MADNESS;
The Great Escape

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS WADE 

 BODY:
TECHNOLOGY MAY BE THE engine of progress but its milestones are historic disasters -- Titanic, Hindenburg, Chernobyl, Challenger. Even its successes are built on unemployment and bankruptcy, the social costs that must be paid if the loom is to displace the hand shuttle and the sail yield to steam.
These destructive forces were brought to mind by a voice-mail message I received last month from a stranger, asking me to call about a "personal matter." The caller turned out to be a historian, Michael A. Findlay, who is studying the artifacts now being brought up from the wreck site of the Titanic two and half miles deep in the Atlantic Ocean. His news was that my grandfather's property tag had been recovered. 
 My grandfather was a high-school science teacher, 35, when he boarded the Titanic on April 10, 1912. The ship, the largest and most luxurious in the world, was bound on its maiden voyage from Southampton, England, to New York. Its owner, the White Star Line, described it as an "unsinkable lifeboat" because of its advanced safety features, including a double bottom and watertight compartments.
As is well known, the Titanic carried only as many lifeboats as the law then required, which was far too few for its 2,208 passengers and crew. Traveling at high speed on a moonless night, ignoring radio warnings of an unusual ice field in the area, the great vessel ran across an iceberg, which gashed through its metal plates like a can opener. Within two and a half hours the unsinkable ship had sunk, with the loss of 1,503 lives.
Though the captain knew at once that the Titanic was doomed, he did not warn the passengers of their imminent peril, and many refused to enter the first lifeboats. One reason for my grandfather's survival was that he had taken a keen interest in the ship's operation and realized from the outset of the collision that it was in danger of sinking. Another was his fortuitous decision to ignore a rumor that men were to be taken off from the port side and women from the starboard. While the other men moved to the opposite side of the deck, he stayed on the starboard side, and when no more women could be found on his deck to take places in an early lifeboat, a crew member told him to jump in. Though at this stage the passengers had no idea that there were not enough lifeboats, my grandfather seized the chance.
As his lifeboat rowed away from the Titanic, he could see the lines of lighted portholes, strangely unparallel with the sea surface. He watched the bow portholes slip farther and farther beneath the water. Then the stern rose slowly until the great ship stood vertically in the sea, all its lights still ablaze. There was a roar as of heavy machinery tearing loose from its mountings. For five minutes more the ship remained like a dark column in the water, then slid slowly from view.
As those in the lifeboats stared awe-struck across the icily calm waters at where their ship had been, they were appalled by an unexpected sound: the screams of the drowning, which continued for some 40 minutes until they fell silent one by one.
On board the rescue ship, the Carpathia, my grandfather decided to write an account of his experiences in order, as he loftily explained, "to calm public opinion and to forestall the incorrect and hysterical accounts which some American reporters are in the habit of preparing on occasions of this kind." His book, "The Loss of the Titanic," by Lawrence Beesley, was widely praised as one of the most accurate accounts of the disaster.
The shipwreck was a blow to the confidence of the age, and I think it also shook my grandfather's trust in science and technology. In postgraduate research at Cambridge University he had discovered a rare alga, which was named after him, Ulvella beesleyi. He was proud of being a great-great-great-grandson, though through an illegitimate line, of Sir Richard Arkwright, whose invention of the water-powered spinning frame transformed cotton manufacturing in the late 1700's and helped to bring about the industrial revolution.
But after his escape from the Titanic, my grandfather dabbled in all kinds of fringe science, as if to hedge his belief in rational inquiry. He practiced Christian Science and attended spiritualist seances. I remember as a child playing with a Ouija board he had, and watching him show off his expertise with a water-divining rod. Even then it seemed to me odd that so many underground torrents should course beneath his suburban garden.
His life, in a sense, had been changed by the turbulent forces of technical progress that his ancestor's spinning frame had unleashed. The weavers put out of work by Arkwright's machines tried to destroy his mills, but the decision made then to choose new technology over Luddism has seldom been revisited, at least in open societies. Yet the choice is fraught with dangers. To win backers and foil opponents, the promoters of a new technology often exaggerate its benefits and underplay its risks. The more glamorous a new undertaking, the keener are its advocates to dismiss disaster as unthinkable.
HAVING ESCAPED BECOMING A victim of new technology by the narrowest of margins, my grandfather thereafter married my grandmother, led an uneventful life and died in 1967. The Titanic's deep wreck site was not discovered until 1985, and in 1987 a salvage company, R.M.S. Titanic Inc., began with the help of a French submersible to retrieve objects from the debris field. Surprisingly, the cases strewn over the sea bed often contain documents that, after appropriate conservation, can still be read. Some of these cases are Gladstone bags that apparently contain the contents emptied out of the purser's safe as the ship was sinking.
Among the documents that emerged recently from the conservation laboratories in France was a property tag bearing the number 208 and the words "This portion to be retained by the purser." When news of the tag was reported to Findlay, the salvor's historian, he at once recalled the following passage from my grandfather's book: "Before me . . . is a small cardboard square: 'White Star Line. R.M.S. Titanic. 208. This label must be given up when the article is returned.' " The tag was the receipt for an envelope of money he entrusted to the purser's safe.
I don't know what became of my grandfather's half of tag 208. Its counterpart, buried for more than 80 years in 12,500 feet of water 400 miles off Newfoundland, was evidently in the safer place. Last month it joined the exhibition of Titanic artifacts at the National Maritime Museum in Greenwich, England, a fragile memento of one individual's escape from the savage tides of history.

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
Summer Musings

BYLINE: By MAX FRANKEL; This will be the last Word & Image column for the summer. The column will resume biweekly in the fall.

 BODY:
ON THE WAY TO A SUMMER'S sabbatical, I've been rummaging in a file marked "Media Thoughts Rarely Examined in the Media." Here are some of the seeds that I wish I had brought to life over the last nine months.
Policy Rut: "When Social Security was enacted, life expectancy was only 62 -- three years less [my emphasis] than retirement with full benefits. Today, life expectancy is 76 and still climbing. With the same relationship today, retirement would be set at almost 80!" -- Jessica Mathews in The Washington Post. 
 Semantic Rut: "We would not dream of keeping our checkbooks balanced the way a balanced budget would require the Government to. We borrow to buy houses and automobiles and to send our kids to college. If we lose our job or suffer a financial reversal, we may well borrow to tide ourselves over to a better time. In 1993, net borrowing of the U.S. Government was $256 billion; that of private households was $294 billion. . . . The great majority of state governments . . . balance only their operating or current budgets and borrow -- that is, run deficits -- for capital expenditures." -- Prof. Robert Eisner in The Wall Street Journal.
Statistical Rut: "The media wallow in stories of discontent. . . . As every American surely knows, household incomes have stagnated for nearly two decades. . . . But over time, the mismatch between stagnating household income and large expansion of the economy as a whole is so stark that it undermines the credibility of the figures. Part of the explanation is probably that the erosion of the two-parent family (as more people chose to stay single or become single parents or as widows live longer) depresses the median household income; in other words, the figures say more about the size of households than the size of incomes." -- The Economist.
Ideological Rut: "Representative Gingrich and his friends are moles, working within the Government to bring it down for the benefit of the people. This is an attractive idea, because it enables its users to be on the side of everybody and not against anyone -- only against the Government. . . . Tax reduction is routinely described as taking money from the Government and giving it to the people. . . . But tax reduction cannot give money to some people without taking it away from other people. . . . Transferring money to the people from the Government may be a metaphor for transferring to the people who earned it from people who did not earn it. . . . There is something in that, but . . . there are no self-made men or women in America. . . . We ought to be able to discuss the question of how much money to transfer from some people to other people explicitly, to try to learn what the effects are and where the community's conscience lies. The discussion is not helped by demagogic talk about the Government vs. the people." -- Herbert Stein, former chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, in The Wall Street Journal.
Computer Skeptics Unite! "I'm not a Luddite," says Prof. Neil Postman, the author of "Amusing Ourselves to Death, "although I secretly like it when something happens, as it occasionally does, where a group of people in political concert say no to a machine. . . . But our problem is not that we don't have enough information. I mean if there are children starving in Somalia, it is not because we don't have enough information. If crime is rampant on the streets of New York or Boston, it's not because people don't have enough information. . . . The problem lies elsewhere, and I think it is a loss of meaning. People don't know what to do with the information. They have no organizing principle -- what I would call a transcendent narrative."
Less News, More Media: At the inspiration of Jack Rosenthal, the editor of this magazine, its researchers have documented the explosive increase in news product over the last generation. Rosenthal thought there's no more going on in the world, indeed probably less news than 30 years ago, but that it's reported much more. His suspicions were easily quantified:
The number of all-news radio stations has grown from one, in 1961, to dozens, perhaps as many as 90 today, plus several hundred stations dedicated to news and talk or all talk. The time devoted to news by one television network (ABC) has increased from 2 hours and 15 minutes in 1960 to about 35 hours in 1994; the total for all networks is now about 110 hours, not counting CNN, Headline News, C-Span, Court TV, sports and weather news networks or breaking news stories like Oklahoma City.
More Media, Less Advertising: Despite dramatic growth in the economy, ad agencies that sell to mass markets are suffering from stagnation. Professors Roland T. Rust and Richard W. Oliver attribute that to the fragmentation of the media and of its audiences. Writing in the Journal of Advertising under the title "The Death of Advertising," they predict the transformation of the industry from one that intrudes with involuntary information to one that helps each consumer acquire individualized information --perhaps even charging for the service through interactive media. The professors conclude that schools and scholars specializing in advertising have about a decade to adapt to the new technologies before they are "hopelessly obsolete."
Illicit Advertising for America: The Voice of America (now supplemented by Worldnet television) is fighting for its life against Senator Jesse Helms and others who think of it as a cold-war relic no longer worth its annual $215 million budget. The Clinton Administration believes, as did the Reagan and Bush Administrations, that billions of people are still deprived of honest news by authoritarian regimes. It's hard to judge this debate because the Government is forbidden to air its propaganda domestically. But it is now possible to monitor the Voice via the Internet [gopher:// gopher.voa.gov/] and also to check the schedules of Worldnet TV and Radio Marti to Cuba. (Special bonus on the latter: a searchable file of 35 years' of speeches by Fidel Castro.) Feel free to scroll past the warning that "In accordance with U.S. law, the materials in this directory hierarchy are provided exclusively for recipients outside the United States."
I Am Still Not a Camera: I hope to return to this corner in time to argue again, and more persuasively this time, that cameras are different from ordinary "press" and should be barred from the second Simpson trial. Never quit while you're gaining.

HEADLINE: The Morale Crisis In the Workplace

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
SHE was earning $85,000 a year as an officer of a large company, but as the company reduced its staff and reorganized, a man being groomed for the president's position got the position she felt she deserved. So the woman resigned. "I won't ever work for a corporation again," she said. "I think you sell yourself out."
The woman, who spoke on the condition that neither her name nor her former employer's name be used, said she had been excluded from the powerful clique of male executives during the many years she worked with the company. In order to keep her job, she said, she was forced to compromise her values. 
 "I had trouble getting people to look at all sides of an issue before making a decision. The 'old boys' had their agenda set ahead of time. I decided that in order to survive, I needed to start playing their game," she said. "I became harder and more impersonal. I detached myself from people and treated them coldly. My goal was to do whatever was best for the corporation."
As she poured all her energy into her job, her health deteriorated, she said. She began working late into the night and taking a dozen aspirins a day to relieve relentless headaches and pain in her jaw. She was tired all the time and often angry. Her marriage broke up. The story has become a familiar one, and one by no means limited to female or minority workers, as Connecticut businesses continue to downsize in a lingering recession. In fact, low morale in the workplace has become a public health problem, said Stephen Advocate, a senior social worker at the Hospital of Saint Raphael's Mental Health Resource Center.
"Tremendous tension is building up in the workplace," Mr. Advocate said. "It certainly is the place where reality and ideology clash. Every year, it becomes more apparent that old, implicit contracts between boss and employee have turned to dust." Trust, honesty and loyalty do not seem to fit into the working world of the 90's, Mr. Advocate said. "The worst things you can lose are trust and a sense of participation," he explained. "When that spirit goes out of one part of life, it affects another part as well. People go home with less to offer."
Business leaders say that they are doing what they can, given the tough times being felt throughout the state. Some have attempted to avoid layoffs by turning to alternatives like a shorter workday, job sharing, voluntary furloughs and the four-day work week, said Robert D. Noonan, vice president and counsel for management services for the Connecticut Business and Industry Association. Businesses are also making a greater effort to keep employees informed about possible layoffs and provide counseling for employees and their families, he said.
Brian Beaudin, senior vice president of the management services division of the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, added that there are employers who choose to keep workers on the payroll even though business is slow. "While I'm sure there are exceptions, employers do not enjoy the tough part of running a business," he said, "which is telling people they don't have a job anymore."
But others say the morale crisis in the workplace does not yet hold high priority in the minds of company executives, preoccupied as they are with many pressing issues.
"I had dinner with about a dozen human resources executives of major corporations in the region, and nobody talked about it. They didn't even mention it," said Fabio Sampoli, senior vice president of regional issues for the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce. "It's not because it isn't perceived as a problem, but they're dealing with so many issues, like how to contain workers' compensation and health insurance costs and how to deal with a reduced work force and not only maintain but increase productivity."
That perception leaves a corporate critic cold. "There's a war going on in corporate America between the employer and the employee," said Barbara G. Lifton, a lawyer in New Haven who handles employment discrimination cases.
Ms. Lifton sees harassment used often as a tool to make employees leave. A boss may start to criticize a worker's performance and issue warnings that his or her job is in jeopardy. "Employers pick something vague like inability to get along with others or communication problems," she explained. "They get the person rattled and upset so he can't do his job, and then they fire him. They lay a paper trail so the person feels he has no recourse."
The constant pressure eventually affects the worker's health, said Ms. Lifton -- with insomnia, loss of appetite, nervousness, hysteria, depression, suicidal tendencies and symptoms resembling a heart attack showing up all too often. "The truth is, the problems are caused by the company's policies, not the employees," she said.
Connecticut's faltering economy makes it easier for employers to justify heavier demands on workers and reward-denying approaches, Mr. Advocate said. "Everyone is pointing to the other person and saying that in order to remain competitive, you have to sacrifice. While that is noble and worthwhile," he said, "it becomes cynical when the average worker sees chief executive officers getting larger salaries and bonuses while the worker suffers through uncertainty about whether or not he'll keep his job."
Older workers who have been laid off have particular difficulty finding other employment and maintaining confidence in themselves, said Judith Andrews, who until recently provided unemployed people with job counseling and other services at the Workforce Development Center in New Haven. (The New Haven program has been phased out, merged in part with the state's Department of Labor in Hamden, and Ms. Andrews is now doing career training for high school students in the greater New Haven area.)
The majority of her clients were between 35 and 45, Ms. Andrews said. But some, older, had been with the same company for as many as 30 years, and were laid off with only a day's notice. The common theme in their stories is that they believed they were obsolete. "They have their futures ahead of them," Ms. Andrews said, "but they were replaced by younger people just out of college, and they fear they will face that experience again on another job."
One way for employers to improve morale is by encouraging communication, Mr. Advocate said. "There is a tendency for management to insulate itself behind walls and barriers," he explained. "When you don't promote personal relationships with people you work with on all levels, a paranoid organization can develop, where you become fearful of what others think, and they become fearful of you. Then, criticism is seen as being disloyal or even plotting."
In addition, said Clifford R. Briggie, administrator of the Hospital of Saint Raphael's department of psychiatry, employers should reach beyond staff reductions and change the nature of tasks in the workplace so that more can be done with fewer people. That means streamlining procedures, eliminating the unnecessary.
The woman who lost the $85,000 job has not found other work, but, armed with the money from a severance package, has taken time out to read and travel and is considering studying for a master's degree in social work. "I want to work one-on-one with people," she said. Looking back, she added, she is grateful for the opportunity to leave a job she had disliked for a long time.
Other workers, too, are beginning to make changes, investing less time and energy in their jobs, she said. "They are saying, 'I'll give you eight hours only. That's all you'll get from me.' They're not doing that little extra for their employer because they feel the employer isn't doing anything for them," she concluded.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Hartford Trying to Rebound From a Long Recession

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
FOR five years, Hartford has been in the depths of a recession even worse than the one it experienced in the mid-1970's. Loaded with excess real estate built during the 80's, it is still struggling to recover.
But city officials say that in the last eight months, a growth of interest from both within and beyond the immediate region, buoyed by cheap rents and a trained labor pool, indicates that the situation may be on the cusp of change. 
 "We're coming back now," said Mayor Michael P. Peters.
Articulating a policy that depends less on the industry that gave Hartford the nickname of the Insurance Capital of America, Mayor Peters said: "We lost 20,000 jobs over the past five years. We are not necessarily looking for the company that employs 4,000 people; we are looking for 50 to 800 employees and a more stable economic base through diversity. We are keeping in constant touch to see that whoever is here stays, and we are marketing ourselves aggressively to outside companies."
Jon Putnam, director of commercial real estate for Cushman & Wakefield in Hartford, agreed that there was reason for renewed optimism. "We have mutual-fund companies looking at spaces of over 100,000 square feet," Mr. Putnam said. "Two insurance companies from Texas -- Trans General and Blue Ridge -- have moved here, and U. S. Homecare, situated in Westchester, is looking for a headquarters and administrative offices downtown."
He also said that Fleet Bank had renewed its lease for 130,000 square feet at 1 Constitution Plaza and that Shawmut had moved some of its divisions from East Hartford into 90,000 square feet downtown at 1 Corporate Center, at 20 Church Street.
"The activity level is clearly up," said Elizabeth G. Judd, portfolio manager for Koll Management Services, a building-management firm in Hartford. "Cheap rents are bringing businesses back from the suburbs, and financial and insurance companies from Boston are looking for back-office space. They are attracted by low rents and a trained labor pool of people who were laid off from Aetna and ITT and Phoenix" Home Life Mutual Insurance Company.
Crime that flourished downtown when the workforce went home to the suburbs has abated "by 45 percent since 1989," said Deputy Police Chief Thomas O'Connor. The decline is attributable, he said, to bicycle patrols, a substation and increasing numbers of people availing themselves of the city's night-time activities. Brokers also say that middle-class residents are beginning to return to Hartford.
"We have seen people come in from the suburbs because of the value in spacious, high-ceilinged Victorian houses," said Mollie Abend, a broker with Prudential Real Estate. "In the past six months activity in the West End has been in move-ups to larger homes, and move-ins from out of state." West End homes that were built for insurance executives at the turn of the century sell for $150,000 to $500,000.
"We feel the city has bounced off the bottom," said Scott Phelps at the Convention and Visitors Bureau. "Hotel occupancy is up by 10 percent to near 70 percent this year, and we have seen an increase in meetings and conventions."
A hotel that was once The Sonesta, then The Clarion, will reopen this summer under a new name -- still to be chosen -- and management, bringing the total number of hostelries to eight.
An encouraging development earlier this month was the announcement that Heublein Inc., the liquor company, will return to Hartford, where it was founded in 1875. Heublein's headquarters had been in Farmington since 1973. It will add 125 employees, for a total of 425, when it moves early next year into 150,000 square feet at Connecticut River Plaza, a two-building, 586,000-square-foot office complex building on Columbus Boulevard.
Additional boosts have come from the Phoenix Home Life Mutual Insurance Company, which recently bought an 80,000-square-foot building at 56 Prospect Street, next to its headquarters. It also plans to buy a 35,500-square-foot building at 38 Prospect Street now owned by the Travelers Insurance Company.
AND the breakup of ITT restores The Hartford, a 185-year-old insurance firm, as a self-governing hometown company.
The $22 million indoor-outdoor Meadows Music Theater, seating 30,000, is scheduled to open next month, and places like ZuZu's on Pratt Street and The Blue Star Cafe on Trumbull Street are indicative of a handful of new night spots that are keeping more adults downtown in the evenings.
The landmarked former Colt Firearms Company complex is now occupied by 80 artists living and working in some of its 755,000 square feet of space. About 45 percent of the complex of 30 buildings is being leased until a permanent use is found.
That's the good news.
Just about everyone agrees that Hartford, despite its abundance of landmarked buildings, its oasis of Bushnell Park, the cultural treasures of the Wadsworth Atheneum, the Hartford Stage Company, the Old State House and Bushnell Hall, and sporting events at the Civic Center, still has many problems.
Its three major department stores, G. Fox, Sage-Allen and The Richardson, all in national-landmark buildings, succumbed in recent years to two suburban malls flanking the city -- in Farmington to the west and Manchester to the east -- and many restaurants followed their patrons to the suburbs.
Business shrinkage is still occurring. The vacancy rate in the city's 8.1 million square feet of downtown office space is up to 24.2 percent so far this year, from 20.4 percent for the same period last year, according to Stephen Bastrzycki, market analyst for Farley Whittier Partners, commercial realtors.
But Mr. Bastrzycki said that "rentals of $11.25 to $19.78" a square foot "will eventually bring companies that went to the suburbs back to the city."
Mr. Putnam of Cushman & Wakefield said that his optimism was tempered by the fact that a Fleet-Shawmut merger, which is near final approval, is expected to have a downsizing effect. Also, he said, some large insurance companies whose leases expire in two or three years may not renew. "That could leave 100,000 to 300,000 square feet vacant," he said.
High taxes are a persistent drag on businesses and residences, almost everyone agrees. One-third of Hartford's $5.96 billion worth of real estate is tax exempt, and nearly half of that third is made up of state-owned buildings.
IN just two years, from September 1992 to September 1994, the state increased its real estate holdings by $94.9 million, creating a tax loss of $2.04 million, according to the assessor's office. Two of the most recently purchased properties are the former Xerox building, at 25 Sigourney Street, and an office building at 60 Washington Street. Other properties must make up for the shortfall.
"State-owned property has been a killer," said Mayor Peters. "We have asked for a moratorium on any more purchases, and a better formula for payment in lieu of taxes." The state now pays 20 percent of normal taxes on properties it owns, which translates into a net loss to Hartford of around $26 million a year. Total losses from a variety of more than one thousand tax exempt properties come to $2.89 billion, according to the assessor's office.
But Dennis Kerrigan, chief of administration at the state's Department of Public Works, said that the state's presence brought a significant number of people into the urban area that would not be there otherwise."
"The depressed real estate market put these properties, which were partially or entirely vacant, in a range that made it possible for us to purchase for the same money as renting," Mr. Kerrigan said.
In 1989 an effort was made to reduce the tax load on residents by using a state enabling law by which residential tax credits can be applied to commercial real estate as a partial surtax. On a $150,000 house, taxes of $3,400 are reduced to $2,100, and a commercial property valued at $150,000 pays taxes of $4,045 with the surtax, instead of $3,602 without it.
When times were good, the effect was positive. Today many small businesses are unable to survive the combination of recession and surtax, and homeowners can do better in suburbs like West Hartford or Avon, where taxes are $28.79 and $20.25 per $1,000 of assessed value respectively, compared with $33.30 in Hartford.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Office buildings at 25 Sigourney Street, left, and 60 Washington Street, both recently bought by the state. (Photographs by Steve Miller for The New York Times)
