HEADLINE: Now Playing: Invasion of the Multiplex

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
THE movie industry is riddled with angst these days. Costs are skyrocketing, there's a glut of products, movies are under attack for mindless violence, and mergers, management buyouts and executive defections are causing musical chairs at the top.
But apparently, the anxiety has not filtered down to movie-theater owners. Even in the metropolitan area, home of some of the country's most cramped and expensive real estate, every new project, from the redevelopment of Times Square to shopping malls in Long Island to sprucing-up attempts in downtown Brooklyn, seems to include a movie theater. 
 Landlords love them, because they soak up less-than-prime space in Manhattan, or allow shopping-mall parking to do double duty in suburbia. And theater operators love the sheer size of the region's potential audiences -- and the relatively few theaters existing to snag them.
"New York may be the most underscreened city on the planet," said Benjamin Fox, a partner in New Spectrum, a store brokerage.
Clearly, the pundits who predicted that cable television would mortally wound the movie theater industry, and that VCR's would kill it off, were as wrong as they could be. According to the National Association of Theater Owners in North Hollywood, Calif., nearly 1.3 billion movie tickets were sold last year, the most in 35 years. Movie theaters nationwide grossed nearly $5.4 billion, a record.
Theater chains believe the boom will continue. Sony Theaters, whose 12-screen complex at 68th Street and Broadway has recreated many of the ornately decorated theaters of the past, is building a four-plex at 1540 Broadway, the Bertelsmann building at 45th Street. Cineplex Odeon is negotiating for a site on the Upper East Side.
United Artists is putting up a nine-screen theater on Union Square, and a smaller one at 300 East 64th Street. And AMC Entertainment is negotiating a deal for a 29 -- count 'em, 29 -- screen theater on 42d Street, in the heart of the Times Square Redevelopment district.
"Clearly, theaters still provide something you can't get at home," said David Firestein, a former AMC executive and now senior vice president of the Westchester-based Northwest-Atlantic Partners retail real estate brokerage.
Theaters also provide something that has been in short supply for much of this decade -- tenants. "The real estate climate is really fueling growth," said Howard Lichtman, Cineplex Odeon's executive vice president of marketing. "We can get lease terms that make it truly viable to put up new theaters."
The push to accommodate theaters makes sense. Outside of Manhattan, movie theaters can round out an office or industrial park, since employee parking spaces can double as theater parking in evenings and weekends. In Manhattan, they can sop up unappealing space.
"Theaters are a great way to maximize the rent you can get," said Jeff T. Blau, vice president of The Related Companies, which is developing the Union Square site. Faith H. Consolo, managing partner of the Garrick, Aug store leasing brokerage, explains why: "Movie theaters absorb tremendous amounts of basements, subbasements and other space that used to be viewed as undesirable," she said.
So why were the pundits so wrong?
Probably a lot of reasons, but the main one, movie industry experts seem to agree, is that the forecasts of doom were predicated on a steady stream of movies flowing out of Hollywood. Instead, the studios have unleashed a tidal wave of product. And cable and video, rather than stanching the flood, are what opened the dam.
Studios no longer have to rely solely on box office sales to recoup the cost of making and marketing a movie. Now they add in cable channels, and, of course, video rentals and sales. And the best way to breach those ancillary markets is to make a killing in a first-run movie theater.
Conversely, seeing things on video can spur people to go to a sequel. Jim Kozak, a spokesman for the Theater Owners group, notes that Terminator 2 and Die Hard 2 both made twice as much as the original films.
"Were the sequels really that much better, or did a lot of people discover the series by seeing the original on tape?" he asked, quite rhetorically.
Since by now video stores and cable are available almost everywhere, the synergies have spurred theater development throughout the country. Mr. Kozak said that by the end of last year there were 26,689 screens extant, up from 22,921 five years before. And nearly all of the chains have announced robust expansion plans.
New York City is a particularly tantalizing plum for movie-theater chains. According to Oppenheimer & Company, there are only 353 movie screens in the city, an average of 5.3 screens for every 100,000 people -- well below the nationwide average of 9 screens per 100,000 people. And, that is based on a New York population of 6.7 million people. Considering that millions more commute to the city each day, and might want to stick around for a movie, the shortfall is even greater.
Moreover, Oppenheimer says that 61 percent of New York's movie screens are in theaters of just one to three screens, while just 3 percent of its screens are in multiplexes of nine screens or more. Nationwide, just 49 percent of movie screens are in tiny theaters, while 9 percent are in complexes of nine screens or more.
"People don't only build in underscreened areas, but in areas with aging small houses," noted Susan Isserman, a senior entertainment analyst at Oppenheimer.
Part of the reason for the multiscreen preference is simple economics of scale. The more screens, the more tickets sold, so the easier it is to amortize fixed labor and rental costs. And the more people coming in, the more food sold. Considering that profit margins on concessions can run as high as 80 percent, that is no small factor.
But the deciding factor has been the explosion of new movies. Generally, a theater chain contracts with a movie distributor to show a movie for a minimum period of time. If the movie does poorly, the theater owner is out of luck; if the movie is a blockbuster, the theater owner could show it longer -- unless the theater's screens are committed to another movie.
A multiplex offers more flexibility. Its screening rooms have different seating capacities. The theater operator can put a film that is expected to do incredibly well into the largest room. If it turns out to be disappointing, he or she can move it to a smaller room, and move a "sleeper" movie to the larger room.
"This way, if you pick a Christmas picture wrong, you aren't stuck with a dog for the entire holiday season," said Michael W. Patrick, chief executive of Carmike Cinemas, a Columbus, Ohio-based theater chain.
Or if ticket sales for a blockbuster film start dropping gradually, the theater owner can move the film from, say, a 500-seat room to a 250-seat room, making way for an incoming potential blockbuster in the larger theater while continuing to pack the smaller house with the first film.
The availability of small theaters within huge multiplexes also lets theaters run so-called "art" films that, while they appeal to a smaller potential audience than does a "Die Hard" or a "Rambo," are less expensive to rent from distributors and can find a profitable niche. The Angelika Theater, on Houston and Mercer Streets, specializes in art films, yet is known among movie industry analysts as a profitable house.
"If you don't have smaller screens available, you can't afford to show a movie like 'Priest,' " said Joyce Steves Storm, executive vice president for real estate for Sony Theaters. "But there is money to be made in that kind of movie."
Old theaters that cannot be effectively cut up into smaller screens, nor retrofitted with modern sound equipment, are falling by the wayside. The RKO movie theater on Main Street in Flushing, Queens, is closed and for sale. A group of foreign investors recently purchased the 68-year-old Oriental Theater in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, a landmarked 2,700-seat building that was converted to a triplex but still could not compete with nearby multiplexes. The new owners will probably convert it to retail use.
"There wasn't enough parking to convert it to a multiplex," said Barry Rossner, a Williams Real Estate broker.
Smaller theaters still do get built, but because of space or contractual considerations, not preference. Loews Theaters, which Sony has since purchased, had contracted to build a four-screen theater at 1540 Broadway nearly eight years ago, before the huge multiplexes had hit their stride in Manhattan. Ms. Storm readily concedes that Sony would prefer to build more screens now, but the rest of the building's retail space has been allocated to other tenants.
Similarly, United Artists, which already operates the single-screen Gemini I and II theaters on Second Avenue near 64th Street, is building a third screen at 300 East 64th Street, a 28-story residential building going up next door. United Artists wanted to put up more screens, but the developers had already let the space to a bank.
"We figure residents want banking and entertainment, so we will give them both," said Trevor Davis, head of Davis & Partners, one of the building's developers.
If United Artists had not already had the two Gemini theaters, it might have walked away from the deal. Instead, it is hooking the new screen into the existing theaters, and all three will share management, staff and ticket offices.
"You figure, we have the staff in place, so the incremental cost of another screen is not huge," said William J. Quigley, a senior vice president of United Artists Theater Circuit. "And most of the theaters on Manhattan's East Side are singles or twins."
That lack of competition from multiplexes gives the Gemini theaters the luxury of perpetuating the status quo. Few new theaters can safely do so. Indeed, most of today's theaters bear little resemblance, either in size or amenities, to their recent forebears. They are huge multiscreened entertainment palaces, with big plush seats, staffs trained to handle functions ranging from selling tickets to crowd control, concession stands that sell mineral water and espresso, expensive art on their walls and huge indoor waiting areas.
"We've all recognized that we have to provide a quality film experience, not just a good movie," said Sony's Ms. Storm.
And often, the theaters are surrounded by other entertainment-oriented retailers, as landlords scramble to find that ever-elusive synergy among tenants.
For example, the Sony-Imax theater on 68th Street is a tourist attraction in its own right. Each of its 12 auditoriums is framed with a miniature version of the facade of an ornate theater of bygone years. There are sphinxes, palm trees, Mayan temple arches, most requiring a steep, four-story escalator ride to reach. And, of course, there is the Imax theater, which offers three-dimensional movies.
Not surprisingly, Millennium Partners, which developed the 68th Street site, has tried to get a lot of ancillary mileage from the traffic the theater pulls. The Sony theater already is cheek-by-jowl with a huge Reebok sports center and store and a Coconuts music store. A Barnes & Noble book store and a Tower Records will soon open nearby. And, of course, Lincoln Center is right across the street.
"We've created an urban entertainment complex, with a merchandise mix of books, music, movies, all kinds of things that relate to people's leisure time," said Philip Aarons, Millennium's vice president.
Clearly, the theater is drawing more than neighborhood residents. Ms. Storm says that 13 percent of the moviegoers are from Queens and Long Island, 10 percent from Brooklyn, and 10 percent from New Jersey. In fact, she said that the influx had made the 68th Street multiplex the highest grossing theater in the country.
United Artists' planned Union Square theater will also be part of an entertainment center that will cover a square-block site stretching from 13th to 14th Streets and from Broadway to Fourth Avenue. According to Ms. Consolo of Garrick, Aug, The Related Companies, the site's developers, are talking to a book store, a record store, and a sports store.
"There are all these residents in the area, and Beth Israel is opening a clinic across the street, so the traffic will be really good," Ms. Consolo said.
Even the finest movie theater cannot overcome a rotten neighborhood. In the mid-1980's, Cineplex Odeon built a six-plex on 50th Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, an area that seemed poised for redevelopment. Instead, Worldwide Plaza, the office building that houses the theater, has remained an isolated modernity in an ungentrified neighborhood that moviegoers saw little reason to visit. The only way that Cineplex could stanch its cash hemmorhage was by running movies that were released months before, and charging only $2 for tickets.
But while all the chains see location as key, and bigger as better, they differ widely on their perception of the best markets.
Increasingly, New York's boroughs and suburbs are in that category. "Manhattan is getting saturated," said Steffen H. Warfield, managing director of the Northwest-Atlantic brokerage. "Downtown Brooklyn, Queens, all have good sites for movie theaters."
Clearly, the chains agree. National Amusements, a Dedham, Mass., theater chain, is planning a 12-plex at College Point, Queens, near the Whitestone Expressway, as a companion to Toys 'R' Us and Kids 'R' Us stores. Cineplex Odeon will soon open a 10-screen theater on Court Street, in Downtown Brooklyn. Sony is building a 10-screen theater at the former Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury, L.I.
Sony, United Artists, and Cineplex Odeon seem to be the biggest players in the urban markets. Sony Theaters, an outgrowth of the old Loews movie chain that has grown to 862 screens, is based in New York, and views operating in the urban market as playing in the home court. In fact, the company just formed a joint venture with Magic Johnson to open theaters in the inner city.
United Artists, the world's largest theater chain, already has about 2,300 screens worldwide, and is putting up 300 more this year, many in densely populated areas. By the end of this year Cineplex Odeon, which already has 1,617 screens in North America, will have added 68 new screens, and has another 249 slated for 1996, also primarily in large markets.
"Urban areas require greater rent, greater service and state-of-the-art amenities," Mr. Lichtman said. "But they also offer unsurpassed population bases, higher-priced tickets and a population that is more likely to buy bottled water and decaffeinated cappuccino at the concession stand."
Other chains are less tempted by big cities. Cinemark USA, for one, has 1,174 screens, and 200 under construction, primarily in mid-size markets of maybe 500,000 people. "In urban areas you typically find a lot more competition, and your operating costs are just so much higher," said Randy Hester, Cinemark's director of corporate development.
National Amusements, a 953-screen chain, sees its ideal locations as "at a major intersection of a major highway," said Shari Redstone, the company's executive vice president. The company, which owns Viacom, has traditionally built stand-alone theaters on land that it owns, and has been replacing many of its drive-in theaters with multiplexes, including big ones in Valley Stream, L.I., Newark and the Bronx.
But lately it has veered from its own rules. It recently opened a posh 12-plex in the Broadway Mall in Hicksville, L.I. And College Point is a shared and rented facility, too. "The area had great demographics, it was underserved and we couldn't pass the opportunity up," Ms. Redstone said.
And then there's Carmike Cinemas, a 2,190-screen chain that has grown primarily by buying up screens from larger chains that want to concentrate on densely populated areas. Most recently, it purchased 64 screens in Florida, and 17 in Georgia from Cineplex Odeon.
"We figure, why compete with the big exhibitors in their markets of choice, when we can buy them out in markets they no longer want?" said Mr. Patrick, Carmike's chief executive. The company is attacking economies-of-scale problems by turning into the ultimate do-it-yourselfer: It has developed its own theater-management software, builds its own projectors, and is about to open its own drapery company.
But strategic differences aside, each chain is planning explosive growth for the rest of this decade. It may be a foolproof strategy: Demographics show that teenagers, still the heaviest movie-goers, will be a growing part of the general population between 1995 and 2010.
"Can you imagine a teenager asking a potential date, 'Hey, want to come over Saturday and watch a video with my parents?' asked Mr Lightman. "They're going to want to catch the latest film."

HEADLINE: Paterson Hopes Hotel's Rebirth Will Lead the City's Way

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: PATERSON

 BODY:
The checkered history of the Alexander Hamilton Hotel sounds a lot like the history of Paterson.
In the 1950's, the hotel was perhaps the best in North Jersey -- an institution associated with elegance and power, a place where high-society wedding receptions were held in the Main Ballroom and political deals were cut in the Hamilton Bar. 
 By the 1980's, the hotel was the province of drug dealers and prostitutes, a dilapidated fire hazard teeming with roaches and vermin, another reminder of just how far this city had fallen.
Now, as Paterson struggles to revitalize itself, the hotel may get a new lease on life: a proposal by the New Community Corporation -- the nonprofit organization that made a name for itself by transforming a blighted neighborhood in Newark's Central Ward -- to turn the Alexander Hamilton into affordable housing for the elderly, complete with 100 new apartments, activity rooms and nursing and health-care services.
There are still many details to be resolved in the $12.5 million proposal, which was unveiled this month. But if the project becomes reality, it would mean a lot to New Jersey's third largest city, not just as a source of needed housing, but also as a poignant symbol of what Paterson was and wants to become.
"It's a turning point," said Donna Brightman, the city's director of housing. "Either you do it and it's part of a rebirth or you don't do it and it projects further decline. We're trying to fight to stay alive."
Alive was a feeling Paterson used to know well. For the better part of the century, Paterson was a vibrant hub nicknamed Silk City, a leading center for textile and locomotive manufacturing. It was the kind of place that nurtured Allen Ginsberg and inspired poets like William Carlos Williams, the kind of small city that was proud of its working-class roots as well as its luxurious indulgences.
When people talked about fancy hotels in those days, they talked about the Alexander Hamilton. Built in 1930, the 170-room hotel was a natural magnet for the rich and powerful, a handsome eight-story brick building just two blocks from City Hall and surrounded by cigar and fedora stores and the famed Fabian Theater.
It was only natural that the hotel was where the Passaic County returns would be tallied on Election Night. The Democrats would gather in the downstairs ballroom, the Republicans in the upstairs one.
A hotel brochure from the 1950's with bright color photos showed as much: "Traditionally Elegant: From intimate dining to lavish banquets, the magnificent public rooms of the Alexander Hamilton provide the perfect setting for social and business events of every description."
But as the city declined in the 1960's, so did the hotel. Factories closed because of labor unrest and high costs, the well-to-do fled to the suburbs, crime and unemployment rose and the hotel fell into disrepair.
A 1983 fire killed 15 people. The ballrooms were stacked to the ceiling with mattresses. Garbage was everywhere and there was a stench of sewage. People passed out in the stairwells. Only the cockroaches thrived.
In 1989, the hotel's owner, Paul Lachmann, died, and bequeathed the property to his grandchildren, not his children. A judge appointed James F. McCoole, a lawyer, to administer the estate and run the hotel.
"It had deteriorated beyond belief," Mr. McCoole said. "When you parked in the parking lot behind the hotel, all you did was crunch on the crack vials when you walked out of your car."
Mr. McCoole shut the place down for a month, put in new management and cleaned it up to the point at which 100 transients now live in spartan but functional rooms. Still, on a recent tour of the hotel with Mr. McCoole, Mayor William J. Pascrell Jr. and a reporter, it was apparent that the hotel still needed a lot of work. The ballrooms reeked of mildew, waterlogged ceiling strips dangled, wallpaper designs shown in the brochure were soiled and sliding off the wall.
In several years, however, the picture may be different.
The New Community Corporation plan would use bank loans, public financing and tax credits to buy the hotel for $1 million and renovate it for $12.5 million. Current residents would be relocated to low-cost housing. People older than 62 making less than $18,000 a year would be eligible to move into the renovated complex. Activities like bingo, films, music and aerobics would be offered, said Raymond Codey, the corporation's director of development.
Ground is to be broken by spring, and officials hope to open the new housing the following year. "The hotel is important because we look at every project in terms of a ripple effect," Mr. Pascrell said. "You can't just work on one tree and let the others rot."

HEADLINE: Abandoned 36 Years Ago, the West Shore Rail Line Creeps Closer Toward Revival

BYLINE: By States News Service 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
For many a Bergen County commuter a century ago, the New York Central's West Shore Line service to the Weehawken ferry was the best of all routes to midtown Manhattan. But by 1959, West Shore ridership had declined so far, said New York Central's president, Alfred E. Perlman, that he needed a 100 percent fare increase to break even on the line. It was shut down that year, and the ferry with it.
Since the 1980's, spurred by Bergen County's ever-greater traffic congestion, some commuters and public officials have been trying to bring back the West Shore Line. New Jersey Transit says it has spent about $3 million looking into the idea. Chester Mattson, Bergen County Planning Director, calls the restoration of the West Shore Line the county's "top rail priority." 
 Now, the revival has moved a step toward reality with the announcement on June 15 that the Federal Transportation Administration has awarded a $3.97 million grant to New Jersey Transit to conduct a major West Shore study.
"This is great news for New Jersey commuters," said Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, who had pushed to include the funds in legislation adopted last year. "As the most densely populated state, transit investments are critical to maintaining our economy, environment and quality of life."
Under current plans, the restored service would run along a stretch of about 30 miles from West Nyack, N.Y., to the Hoboken Terminal and Secaucus Transfer Station, which is scheduled for completion in 2001. Conrail is moving freight on the original West Shore tracks, so new tracks would be put down along the old right of way.
Instead of taking the Weehawken ferry, passengers would switch to trains to midtown Manhattan or to the Hoboken ferry service to lower Manhattan.
The efforts to restore of the West Shore Line, said Alfred Harf, New Jersey Transit's assistant executive director of planning, reflect increasing traffic congestion, reduced bus service and concern about air quality.
Studies commissioned by New Jersey Transit estimate that 9,000 people would make the round trip on the restored line every weekday.
But that is not going to happen soon. New Jersey Transit does not expect to complete the study before the summer of 1997. Among the issues it will consider is community support: new rail construction beyond the West Shore right-of-way could lead to neighborhood opposition.
The biggest challenge could be financing. According to preliminary research, the project would cost $500 million, this at a time when Federal and state budgets are both under the knife.
But New Jersey Transit has a contingency plan. If the new West Shore Line is not fully financed, Mr. Harf said, service might be restored along only a portion of the line -- to the Meadowlands sports complex, for example.
"We're optimistic about its chances," said Mr. Mattson, the county planning director. "We think, on the merits, we'll be able to make a good case."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A 1955 fight to retain passenger service. The cry was: "A hog can ride the West Shore -- why can't you?" (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Computer Transforms County Map Making From Glacial to Quick

BYLINE: By TOM CALLAHAN 

 BODY:
THE County Department of Planning can now access all sorts of geographic, demographic and zoning information for any street address in the county after installing a high-tech computer map-making system.
Planning officials used to work as long as half a year to prepare a general land use map. Map making was a painstaking process involving scribing, drafting and four-color inks. 
 "It was a dumb map," said Paul Gisondo, associate planner for the county. "All the measurements were made by hand and at each step of the way there were opportunities for errors."
The map, made just once every five years, was almost immediately outdated. "If there was a zoning change, for example, Pepsico buying some land and converting it into an office park, the map might not catch up with it until five years later," said Sam Wear, principal planner for the county. "You always have to wonder: was this accurate three years ago?"
The new mapping process, known as the Geographic Information System, uses an I.B.M. UNIX workstation to store geographic information. The system has access to 60 databases, including 1,400 variables taken from the 1990 census.
In addition to containing the county zoning and environmental characteristics, the computer can divide the county into 876 census block groups, which can be broken down by racial, income and demographic features. A new map containing that information, as well as updates, can be produced in a matter of hours, sometimes less. The system holds two gigabytes, or four million pages of data.
The county began developing the computer-mapping program in the late 1980's. In recent years, improvements in the cost and availability of the computer hardware and software have made it more comprehensive in scope and easier to operate. Mr. Wear estimates that the county has spent $250,000 on the hardware. Similar geographic information systems are operating in New York City and several counties around the state. Several New York State agencies also use the system.
"We can pull all sorts of different areas of data together through this system," said P. Lynn Oliva, the county's Planning Commissioner. "This is not a new function but the decades-old job of government providing information to citizens, government departments and municipalities. Before this technology, we spent 80 percent of our time gathering information and mapping and 20 percent planning. Now it's reversed."
The county government uses the mapping information to help manage the 15,918 acres of parks and parkland under county control as well as the various office buildings owned by the county. Within seconds, planners can have a printout of the floor plan of any government building.
If the county's Department of Environmental Services must repair a sewer line, they can obtain a map showing the effects of the construction on nearby roads and homes.
The County Health Department can get information on neighborhoods with the highest instance of Lyme disease or infant mortality or AIDS cases and compare that data with economic and demographic factors.
Westchester Community College has used the technology to produce a map showing where its students come from. The college has also traced the number of 14-year-olds to 18-year-olds in certain parts of the county and the number of people who didn't finish high school. The data are used for marketing purposes, even to the extent of including information on the nearest public transportation routes for prospective students. The computer can also create topographical maps to monitor runoff and possible pollution into Long Island Sound.
"The timing of getting information can be done in an afternoon, rather than having five people working with an atlas and drawing the information on tissue paper and overlaying that on a map," said Gerard E. Mulligan, the Deputy Planning Commissioner. "It provides remarkable decision-making ability."
The information in the computer mapping system is available to the county's 45 municipalities. Commissioner Oliva said she wants to form a consortium of municipalities with the technology, whereby local governments would be linked on the same computer network. That would allow zoning information to be updated immediately. The village of Croton-on-Hudson received a grant from the New York State Archives and Records Administration to obtain the mapping system. The county is working with the village on the project, which Village Manager Richard F. Herbek expects to have working in the next few months.
"It is going to help with so many different facets of what we do in local government," Mr. Herbek said, citing as examples the ability to retrieve information on properties and tax mapping.
"This is the wave of the future," he said. "Within the next decade, Geographic Information Systems will be in the mainstream of municipal planning around the country. These systems will replace the manual handling of information."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Paul Gisondo working on a new computer mapping system. (Claire Yaffa for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: STEINWAY & SONS;
In Tune

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The impression created by Edward Rothstein in his article "Made in the U.S.A., Once Gloriously, Now Precariously" [May 28] that Steinway & Sons is in decline stands the truth on its head. 
 The quality of today's Steinway pianos, far from being in decline, is in fact universally acclaimed. For example, 93 percent of all piano soloists performing with major orchestras in North America during the 1994-95 season played exclusively on Steinways. The instruments they are playing were manufactured not in previous decades but within the last five years. Similarly, virtually all finalists in the world's major piano competitions insist on playing on today's Steinway.
Regarding sales trends, while Mr. Rothstein's thesis fails to factor in the recession that swept the United States and the rest of the world during 1991-93, Steinway sold more pianos in the five years before the recession than in any such period in more than half a century. Dollar income over the last two years is once again setting records.
 
BRUCE A. STEVENS
President, Steinway & Sons
Long Island City, Queens

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Starbucks Pours It On

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
WITH designer coffee bars on almost every corner, terms like "slim grande" and "short latte" have become regular staples of the city's lexicon.
But the coffee bar business itself is far from settled. In the last year, the national chain Starbucks has descended on the city, opening in 15 locations, with another very likely to be coming soon to a corner near you. And, in the Darwinian economics of New York's storefront marketplace, the chic coffee bars that only recently displaced the old-time coffee shops are now concerned about being bullied out of business themselves. 
 Last September, for example, a Starbucks opened on Second Avenue and 81st Street, directly across the street from Timothy's Coffee, itself part of a small chain and just down the block from Seattle Bean. "We were upset," said Kalie Kimball, the manager at Seattle Bean, which has been open for about three years, "but we're not going to try to be them. We're going to try to be Seattle Bean."
Starbucks also recently arrived on Third Avenue at 66th Street, one block up from New World Coffee. At Columbus Avenue and 67th Street, Starbucks has plunked itself down diagonally opposite Cooper's Coffee Bar, and within five blocks of at least six other coffee houses.
Rivalry is nothing new to the world of New York coffee bars -- in fact, their explosion has compelled the Zagat restaurant survey to rate them for the first time this year in its new edition, due out in the fall. But coffee bar owners say the formidable strength of Starbucks intensifies the competition considerably. The Seattle-based company's national prominence, slick appearance and financial success make it the Goliath of the country's coffee bars, the Big Bean, if you will.
If the company's plans for expansion are any indication, Starbucks is going to become an increasingly prominent part of the landscape. The company says it plans to open about 80 more branches in New York City over the next four years and to have 1,500 nationwide (from the current count of nearly 600) by the year 2000.
The chain's confidence is so great that, in some cities, it has opened branches across the street from one another.

ONE wouldn't blame coffee-bar owners for quaking in their cups. But so far, most are holding to a determinedly positive party line, saying that competition can only be good for business and that finicky New Yorkers need a lot of choices.
"It's no different than when you have three dry cleaners on the same block," said Andrew Resnick, vice president in New York for Timothy's, which is based in Toronto. "We all benefit, in a sense. Competition makes you better. We need to be sharper, cleaner, nicer."
Despite such studied cool, many coffee bars are also clearly trying different ways to stay hot. But prices tend to vary no more than a nickel or a dime from chain to chain, and there are only so many creative things you can do with coffee. Timothy's posts a daily trivia question every day: the first 10 people to answer correctly win a free eight-ounce coffee. Seattle Coffee Roasters offered two-for-one deals for a while. And Seattle Bean counted among its claims to uniqueness using colored chalk on its outdoor sign -- until Timothy's down the block started doing the same. New World boasts of the two espresso shots in its tall latte, compared with one at Starbucks.
When Starbucks arrived across Columbus Avenue last March, the two-year-old Cooper's started offering half-price happy-hour granitas (sort of a coffee-flavored slushy) -- and Tanya Leach, a Cooper's manager, said the company was considering adding tables to its counter seating. The tables at Starbucks tend to be full into the night. "They're a huge company, they have all this money, so they're a little intimidating," Ms. Leach said. "And I think they're intentionally intimidating. But we have a lot of confidence in our customers."
Some independent coffee bars are trying to get mileage out of their comparative meekness, playing up elements like personal attention and an intimate atmosphere -- which the cynical might translate as less customer traffic and fewer square feet. "Our stores are a lot cozier than most of their's," said Stephen Levy, owner and president of Seattle Coffee Roasters on Columbus Avenue between 68th and 69th Streets.
"We know most of our customers by name," said Ms. Kimball at Seattle Bean. "We have more of a coffee house feel instead of a chain."
The Sensuous Bean, which has hung on at West 70th Street off Columbus Avenue since 1976, has apparently decided not to even try to compete. Although it offers coffee and tea by the cup from thermoses, the small, old-fashioned place concentrates on selling 72 varieties of coffee and 50 kinds of tea in bulk. "We don't have muffins, we don't have lattes, we don't have mochaccinos -- that's their thing," said Lucretia La Mura, a co-owner. "We're pounds -- volume."
Starbucks also stirs conflicting feelings among people who live near their branches. Some see the coffee bars as promising signs of upscale development and badges of sophistication. Others are put off by the sprawling uniformity of Starbucks stores and fear that they may threaten the distinctive character of old-time establishments in their areas.
The actor Bruce Willis, who arrived at the Muffin Shop, on Columbus Avenue at 70th Street, after a softball game in Central Park last Monday, puts himself in this camp. He was in search of an iced latte, and as if on cue for a commercial for the small independent coffee house, he said, "Great service, great coffee, and it's got more personality." He added that it was his second time there that day. "It's not the cookie-cutter thing that Starbucks has going," he said.
 

MANY West Siders living north of West 96th Street welcome the prospect of a new Starbucks -- due to open by the end of summer at 102d Street and Broadway -- as a chic counterweight in a neighborhood heavy with social service agencies. But some in the area are also concerned that the sleek newcomer may cut into the breakfast business of their local standby two blocks away, called Positively 104th Street, which serves help-yourself coffee, homemade cranberry-orange muffins and 35-cent refills under the honor system.
"I keep thinking of Starbucks as an elegant McDonald's -- it's become such a monolith," said Chris Huntington, 34, a television producer who lives on 105th Street and gets his morning coffee at Positively 104th. "I'm an underdog fan. I worry about stores that are urban pioneers when larger conglomerates come in."
Starbucks maintains that the coffee business is big enough for everyone. "A lot of street corners in the world have more capacity than any one person can handle," said Yves Mizrahi, vice president of real estate for Starbucks. "Having competitors nearby does nothing but increase the awareness of coffee in general, and we view that as a positive."
But others predict that Starbucks will leave casualties in its wake. "I think ultimately you will see a shakeout and a consolidation or an elimination of a number of operators," said Michael T. Moe, an analyst at Lehman Brothers who follows Starbucks. "I think Starbucks, both through its size and through its execution and quality of product, is a truly formidable player to go up against."
Then again, there are those hard-boiled New Yorkers who insist they couldn't care less who makes their coffee, as long as it has caffeine.
Bob Youngman, an iron worker employed at a site on West 67th Street, would just as soon get his Java and jelly doughnut for $1 from the truck vendor on the corner. He said he had tried the new Starbucks nearby and didn't recommend it. "They've got terrible coffee," Mr. Youngman said. "It's probably Folgers or something."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Starbucks at Columbus and 67th: within five blocks of a half-dozen coffee bars. (Carol Halebian for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI

 BODY:

MIDTOWN
Cool Sounds Abound Up on the Roof 
 The midtown Y.W.C.A.'s fifth season of rooftop jazz begins Wednesday. Curated by the composer and jazz cellist Diedre Murray (above), the series consists of new music by composers with backgrounds in blues, jazz, soul and Brazilian music. Ms. Murray and her band, MaGumbo, will perform the first night, with touches of jazz, soul and tango.
There is seating for 200 around small round tables. Drinks, sandwiches and snacks will be sold.
610 Lexington Avenue at 53d Street; Wednesdays through July 26; concerts begin at 6 P.M.; $8, $25 for a series pass, free for children under 12; (212) 735-9722.
 
PROSPECT PARK
Where Children Can Travel Back to the City's Past
A class of fourth graders from Public School 161 in Crown Heights (some pictured below) was asked to come up with questions about the site of the Lefferts Homestead Children's Museum in Prospect Park. The most frequently asked: "Who lived here?"
With a cultural grant from the state Council on the Arts and the city Department of Cultural Affairs, the directors were able to answer the question with a new interactive exhibit at the museum. The exhibit covers the period from 1650 to 1850 and deals with the Lenape Indians, the Dutch and African-Americans. "Kids can go there and experience what it was like to be a kid during these times," said Janine St.Germain, a spokeswoman for the park.
For example, children can crawl into an elk skin bed like that used by Indian families, or a mahogany sleigh bed from the era of the Dutch settlers, or a rustic rope-strung box bed used by the children of African-American slaves.
Lefferts Homestead Children's Museum, Prospect Park, Flatbush Avenue, north of Empire Boulevard; Saturdays and Sundays, 12 P.M. to 5 P.M.; free; (718) 965-6505.
 
UPPER EAST SIDE
Taking a New Look At Hungarian Artists
In the art world, Hungarian paintings have never captured the interest of high-end collectors.
"Only now are collectors beginning to recognize the value," said Janos Aranyi, an investor and a collector of Hungarian art, "but Hungarian masterpieces at this point still remain affordable." Mr. Aranyi has selected 23 paintings by Hungarian artists, ranging from impressionist to constructivist, for a new exhibit.
"Through the period of fascism and Communism there wasn't much cultural exchange between Hungary and the United States," he said. "Now Hungary is experiencing an economic and cultural resurgence, and a new collector class is beginning to assemble."
Murakami Gallery, 17 East 71st Street, third floor; Tuesday, June 27 to Sept. 9; Tuesday through Saturday, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; free; (212) 717-6085.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Credit Is Lax, So Why Buy Banks?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Sometimes the news you get from opening junk mail is more important than the information that makes headlines.
Last week there was a bit of a stampede into bank stocks on the news of the biggest bank takeover yet, of New Jersey's First Fidelity by First Union, the North Carolina-based bank holding company. Lots of people were searching for the next bank to be bought for twice book value. We wish luck to those doing the searching. 
 The more important news is available in your trash can. Banks are eager to lend and are cutting prices. That shows up in credit card applications and in the terms for second mortgages. The personal loan come-ons -- "Check this box and we'll send you a check for $10,000" -- are also on the rise.
What does that mean? It means that credit standards, and loan pricing, are on the way down. Martha Klessen, an analyst for the Loan Pricing Corporation, which monitors the corporate loan market, uses the word "desperate" in describing the attitude of banks trying to push loans out the door.
"Banking is such a relationship business that, even if they are going to lose mony on a loan, they have to do it to preserve the relationship," she explains. After all, some other bank would make the loan.
It was only a few years ago that everyone was talking about how tightfisted bankers were, complete with handwringing over excessive caution brought on by over-regulation. Of course, back then a bank could also lock in a good profit by taking deposits at a low rate and then lending them out to the Federal Government by purchasing two-year Treasuries. It was the beginning of a golden age for banks, and their share prices zoomed from badly depressed levels as weak balance sheets became strong. Standard & Poor's regional bank index is up 219 percent from its 1990 low, while the S.& P. 500 has gained 86 percent.
Now the average rate on six-month bank certificates of deposit is almost 5 percent, and some banks are paying 6 percent. A bank has costs to cover, and it can't cover them if it takes in money at those rates and then buys two-year Treasuries, which are yielding just 5.6 percent. So borrowers must be found, and more and more banks are willing to lend in both the junk and investment-grade corporate markets. The competition for lending is showing up in the junk bond market, which is requiring a lot less in the way of indentures before making loans. There are also suspicions that some banks are getting credit card accounts by being a bit too lenient in deciding who is a good credit.
One might think that the signs of declining credit standards and lower profit levels on new loans would have scared shareholders, but that is not the case. Bad loans are not showing up on profit statements now, so who cares? "Any notion that the credit cycle will re-emerge as an issue is not present in the valuations," reports Frank R. DeSantis Jr., the bank watcher at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. You can get more attention from investors by putting together a list of potential takeover targets.
Bankers say privately that the excesses now are nothing like those of the late 1980's, and they are probably right. But the trend seems to be in place. Bank profit margins have peaked, and are declining despite the fact that most banks are setting aside less than ever before to cover potential bad loans. We will not know until the next recession just how lax the lending standards have become, but it is clear now that takeover speculation and investor enthusiasm over lower interest rates is overdone.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
The Great Asian Steeple Chase

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: GUANGZHOU, China

 BODY:
THE skyscraper was born and raised, and raised some more, in the United States, defining the nation's proudest cities, enshrining its largest corporations and giving airline pilots the willies. But just as skyscrapers are leveling off here, they are reaching their gawky maturity in the Far East. Of the world's 10 tallest buildings finished in the 1990's or under construction, only one is in this country -- the headquarters for an overambitious Atlanta bank whose finances turned so shaky a few years ago that it was swallowed by a hostile buyer. The other nine are in Asia, including twin towers in Malaysia that, when completed next year, will be the world's tallest.
 In the Far East, every few years a new building claims the Tallest-in-Asia title: the Kompleks Tun Abdul Razak Building in Penang, Malaysia, in 1985; the Overseas Union Bank Centre in Singapore in 1986; the Bank of China Tower in Hong Kong in 1989; Central Plaza, also in Hong Kong, in 1992, and next year, the Petronas towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. 
 Why? The question in Asia is, "Why not?" "They all want to show off," said I. M. Pei, the architect, just back from discussing a new headquarters for the Bank of China in Beijing. "Everyone wants to outbuild everyone else."
 Kuala Lumpur's landmark will be 22 feet taller than Chicago's Sears Tower, built way back in 1974 and dubbed "the world's tallest real estate problem" before Sears, Roebuck & Company unloaded it last year.

 
 
See-Through Buildings
 Although Asia's upstart economies are expanding much more rapidly than America's, the architectural space race turns on more than economic growth rates. In the 1980's real estate speculators in the United States built office towers with all the space companies need into the next millenium, and maybe into the one after that. Despite several years of economic growth, many American cities still have vacancy rates higher than 20 percent, their downtowns filled with see-through buildings.
 No longer is the demand for office space growing as fast as the economy. Cost-crazed corporations terrorize their staffs with vast layoffs even when their sales expand. They hand out cellular phones and laptop computers to their sales, audit and service people, telling them to hit the road and stay there. And those employees who still haunt company premises find that while they once sprawled out in offices as large as hotel rooms, they are now crammed into spaces the size of hotel bathrooms.

 
 
Offices Like Hotels
 In fact, companies like the Ernst & Young accounting firm run many of their offices just like hotels, allowing employees to check in only temporarily. "I'm not sure how the staff thinks about it when they have 37 people operating at the same desk," said Ken Townsend, managing partner in Dallas of the firm's subsidiary, the E & Y Kenneth Leventhal Real Estate Group. "But management thinks it's great."
 In the United States, skyscrapers have become gauche, symbols of executive ego and corporate extravagance, objects of shareholder and neighborhood scorn. Donald Trump's schemes for raising the world's tallest building on Manhattan's West Side were soon discounted more than his junk bonds. A skyscraper planned for Columbus Circle has come no closer to construction than Columbus came to Asia.
 Companies now go for suburban greenery. The tallest building at Microsoft's headquarters near Seattle soars three stories, outstripped by the surrounding Douglas firs. Could there be a Microsoft megatower in the works? "Oh no," said Erin Carney, speaking for the company. "For us, what's truly important is the products and the software you produce, not a flashy, tall building."
 Arriviste Asians, meanwhile, are jumping straight from rice paddies to high-rises. Here in Gaungzhou, office towers stand right near apartments with no indoor plumbing, where residents begin their days by emptying chamber pots.

 
 
No Sewers
 The metropolitan area of Jakarta, Indonesia, has 16 million people and a new tower that rises higher than New York's former Pan Am Building, but, as yet, no sewers. In Engineering News-Record magazine, Rem Koolhaas, the prominent Dutch architect, questioned the wisdom of building skyscrapers for raising, as he put it, "chickens on the 40th floor."
 As the high-rise business has dried up in the United States, the nation's master builders fly off to court Asian executives and ministers. Mr. Pei designed the Bank of China building in Hong Kong and Cesar Pelli of New Haven has the Kuala Lumpur commission. Mr. Pelli vigorously denies reports that in order to win the commission he had to promise the Malaysian Prime Minister that he would top the Sears tower. He says he won the job by designing distinctively Malaysian buildings, although quarter-mile-high towers have not figured prominently in the country's architectural history. Meanwhile, Mr. Pelli's plans for a skyscraper in Chicago have languished for five years, with nobody willing to write the necessarily tall check.
 With the start of even loftier buildings planned in Chongqing, China, and Hong Kong this year, Asians are just beginning to learn a few American-style lessons in high-rise economics. Japan has already crashed, leaving real estate investors unable to even guess how much their property is worth. Hong Kong, where a parking space once sold for $500,000, is also teetering; real estate values there are now off more than 10 percent from their peak and the Chinese Communists are due to take over in two years. The next victim could be Shanghai. Western-style offices were virtually unknown there until about a decade ago, but Shanghai is confidently putting up the equivalent of five new Empire State Buildings for the fourth year in a row.

 
 
Everywhere but Up
 "One thing we learned in the United States in the 1990's," said Anthony Downs, a global real estate specialist for the Brookings Institution and Salomon Brothers, "prices always have someplace to go but up."
 Some engineers question how well the Asian towers can withstand the region's natural forces, its earthquakes and typhoons, let alone its market forces. Then there are the supernatural forces.
 Most major projects in many Far Eastern nations require the blessings of feng shui masters, who are able to divine whether the sites, the designs, even the alignment of escalators, conform with ancient Daoist tenets. "They earn more than the architects do," Mr. Pei whispered, betraying a trace of annoyance.
 Mr. Pei, an American born in Guangzhou, said his Bank of China building in Hong Kong had won approval from one feng shui master. Then another discovered that Mr. Pei's angular building was shooting destructive rays at the Governor's mansion. Some strategic willow-planting defended the colonial residence. Still, it might be harder to propitiate the heavenly powers as they hear clangorous Asian construction crews drawing ever closer.

HEADLINE: The World: ...Or Else;
Hostage-Taking Is a Weapon Of War Whose Time Is Now

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEN their citizens are taken hostage, most nations start out talking like Clint Eastwood. We won't negotiate with terrorists, they say through clenched teeth. Go ahead, make our day.
 It usually turns out to be bluster. The fact of life in modern democracies is that television pictures of handcuffed, blindfolded prisoners exert an inexorable, sapping effect on political will. Cutting a deal is almost always easier than explaining away bungled commando raids. 
 Just ask Jimmy Carter. Or Ronald Reagan. Or the French, who publicly proclaimed they would never yield to terror even as they privately proffered concessions to secure the release of NATO soldiers held by the Bosnian Serbs. Or Boris N. Yeltsin, the Russian President, who erupted in volcanic anger at the economic summit meeting in Nova Scotia last Sunday after the Russian Parliament demanded that he open direct talks with Chechen rebels holding nearly 2,000 Russian hostages.
 "This is a bad mistake, a bad move on their part, because now I, myself, have become a hostage to these very same bandits," Mr. Yeltsin blurted out, in a blunt summing up of what many Western leaders have felt but few have dared say aloud.

 
 
Comeback
 This century's conflicts have been accompanied by almost every imaginable brutality, from genocide to nuclear warfare to poison gas attacks to the indiscriminate fire-bombing of civilians. But it was not until quite recently that the time-honored tactic of taking of hostages re-emerged as a weapon of warfare or national policy, accompanied by the rise of global, instantaneous communications.
 Iranians held American diplomats hostage for 444 days from 1979 to 1981, giving birth to a nightly television special then called "America Held Hostage," and now known as "Nightline." Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi leader, grabbed "human shields" on the eve of the Persian Gulf war, paraded them around in televised interviews, and then released them.
 The Bosnian Serbs took United Nations peacekeepers as hostages after the latest NATO air raids, and set them free only after being allowed to reclaim their heavy weapons from depots in the Sarajevo hills. By some accounts, French officials promised the Serbs there would be no further NATO bombing, a charge France denies.
 Just last week, Moscow opened new talks with the Chechen rebels, shortly after permitting perpetrators of the raid to exchange their hostages for safe passage back home.
 "We're all vulnerable to hostage-taking," said Peter Rodman, a national security official in the Reagan Administration. "It's an effective tactic against a modern, industrial power that has inhibitions. It is the weapon of choice for the ruthless and weak."
 The modern era has heightened that vulnerability in several ways. Live TV pictures of captives put a human face on a problem that might otherwise seem remote. (It's no coincidence that France advised its networks to electronically obscure the faces of soldiers taken hostage by the Serbs.)
 The fall of Communism turned loose a host of tribal mini-states bidding for independence and unfettered by the niceties of international order. Neither the Bosnian Serbs nor the Chechen rebels seem to care much whether they end up with a seat in the United Nations or the other trappings of world status that they might earn by respecting international norms.

 
 
Barbary Payoff
 In Russia, the advent of democracy has opened up new possibilities for terrorism in the ethnically fractious country. Unlike his predecessors, Mr. Yeltsin has to deal with a free press, opposition legislators and public opinion, which is molded by TV footage of Russian civilians begging for their lives.
 Taking hostages, of course, is hardly a modern invention. It was commonplace in the brutal wars of the Balkans and the Caucasus for hundreds of years.
 Two centuries ago, a hostage crisis marred George Washington's second term as pirates operating off the coast of Africa seized more than 100 American sailors.
 An outraged Congress declined to pay ransom -- the custom at the time for dealing with pirates -- and in 1794 ordered the Administration to create an American Navy to challenge the Barbary pirates. Military procurement, however, proved as cumbersome then as it does today. Two years later, Washington won the captives' release, and peace with the pirates, by paying nearly $1 million, a huge sum for the period.
 Although the Japanese did put prison camps near some potential military targets, the big wars of this century by and large did not involve the use of the hostage weapon.
 John Keegan, the British military historian and defense editor of The Daily Telegraph, noted that Hitler's "curious legalistic streak" prompted the Nazis to generally follow the Geneva Convention on their treatment of Western prisoners. The Germans, he said, were also constrained by a fear that the Allies might retaliate in kind. Neither the North Koreans nor the North Vietnamese used prisoners as human shields, though both had ample opportunities.
 The Munich Olympics in 1972, with the seizing of Israeli athletes by Palestinian terrorists, marked the advent of a new era, in which blanket news coverage of an event was the goal rather than a byproduct.
 Throughout the 1980's, Islamic groups, the Red Brigades and others took hostages, and turned governments upside down. President Reagan swore he would never negotiate, and then ended up nearly destroying his second term with the covert sale of arms to Iran in a largely failed attempt to free American hostages held in Lebanon.
 Noel Koch, a former senior counterterrorism official who runs TranSecur, a private security concern, said: "When you're new to this business, it's very easy to swallow this 'no negotiations' thing. I can tell you, the first time you manage one of these things, that goes out the window."
 Over the years, hostage-takers have learned a lot about how to frustrate the West's counterterrorism commandos. The Bosnian Serbs, for example, made sure to scatter their prisoners at a variety of remote locales, making rescue missions all but impossible. Russian soldiers had little luck in dislodging an enemy that fired weapons while hiding behind civilian captives.
 So, is the late 20th century going to end up being the Age of Hostages in military history? Mr. Keegan argues not, saying the tactic has limited effectiveness, since after a while "people harden their hearts."
 Robert Kagan, former member of the State Department's policy planning staff, was less sanguine. Allowing the rogues of the world's new conflicts to break the rules invites imitation, he said.
 "People have said you could somehow cauterize this conflict, and keep it from disrupting the state system," Mr. Kagan said of the events in Bosnia. "But ultimately, history makes it clear that you can't cauterize these things. Retreat by the state system only accelerates the challenges."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Productivity Is All, But It Doesn't Pay Well

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT is a principle as old as capitalism and the antithesis of Marxism: workers should reap according to their labors. Yet over the last six years, compensation for American workers seems to have stagnated even as they have worked ever more efficiently and produced ever more goods.
 The trend is especially striking because it breaks one of the most enduring patterns in American economic history. Workers have fairly consistently collected about two-thirds of the nation's economic output in the form of wages, salaries and benefits. Owners of capital, like stocks or bonds or small businesses, have collected the other third, in the form of dividends, profits and investment gains. 
 "It is remarkable how constant labor's share has been over the last 150 years," said Lawrence Katz, a former chief economist at the Labor Department. "This is one of the strongest regularities of advanced economies."
 Wages and salaries and benefits actually climbed slightly faster than productivity for a while in the late 1960's and early 1970's. Productivity moved ahead a little faster than compensation during the late 1970's and through much of the 1980's. But it seems that the real gap opened after that.
 The strongest evidence so far that workers are receiving less of the fruits of their labors came last week, when the Labor Department revised its estimates of wage and compensation growth. After adjusting for inflation, average wages and salaries apparently fell 2.3 percent over the 12-month period that ended in March. Productivity rose 2.1 percent during the same period.
 Include fringe benefits, and the current numbers look even worse for the wage-earners. Overall compensation fell 3 percent in the 12-month period through March, as companies and state and local governments provided fewer health care benefits.
 The drop has provoked a profusion of historical comparisons. "A high-capital income society is no longer a middle-income society but something reminiscent of the Gilded Age," said Bradford DeLong, a former deputy assistant secretary of the Treasury for policy analysis in the Clinton Administration.
 Conservative economists question whether the new pattern will persist. People will tend to leave companies that consistently pay them less than the value of their work, they contend, so companies will have to increase pay as their workers produce more.
 Wages may be falling because many of the workers now entering the labor force are poorly educated and therefore have less value to employers, said John C. Weicher, a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute, a conservative research group here. The declining value of young American workers reflects the decline of the nation's educational system, he said, adding that during the late 19th century, the arrival of millions of poorly educated immigrants also held down wages.

 
 
Paychecks vs. Dividend Checks
The Labor Department's new figures are particularly striking because they suggest that wage problems in the work force do not just reflect a widening gap between high-paid workers and low-paid workers. People who rely on paychecks also appear to be losing ground to people with dividends and investment gains.
 The Labor Department figures are not the only word; data from the Commerce Department show a relatively modest erosion of labor's overall share of the nation's goods and services. But those figures are scheduled for a broad recalculation at the end of this year, and Professor Paul Krugman at Stanford University, who has argued that inequality among workers is more of a problem than an overall shrinkage of employment compensation, said that he would not change his mind until discrepancies among the two departments' figures are addressed.
 No matter how the numbers are calculated, workers with few skills seem to be losing out in the struggle for prosperity in America, Mr. Krugman noted. "We're only asking whether it goes to highly skilled professions or to capital," he said.
 Experts offer many explanations for falling pay. They include the increasing automation of workplaces, more competition from foreign countries and the declining power of labor unions.
 But there are fewer arguments about the effects on American society if the trend continues for many years.
 "If we lose our middle class and become a two-tiered society, we not only risk the nation's future prosperity but also its social coherence and stability," said Labor Secretary Robert Reich. "As the economy grows, people who work the machines and clean the offices and provide the basic goods and services are supposed to share in the gains, but that hasn't been happening."

HEADLINE: The Nation: Primary Politics;
In Congress, It's Nearly 1996

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE Senate majority leader had it all figured out. He would get the Congress to move quickly on a litmus test issue that would guarantee support from the key element in his party.
 That was in 1960, and the Senate majority leader was Lyndon Johnson. He arranged a Congressional session to follow the party nominating conventions so that a new minimum wage bill could be passed and the Democrats' concerns for the working man demonstrated. 
 History repeated itself, sort of, when Bob Dole maneuvered last week to kill the nomination of Dr. Henry W. Foster Jr. to be Surgeon General, thereby pleasing anti-abortion forces and the right generally and one-upping Senator Phil Gramm, who has wanted to slay the Foster-dragon himself.

 
 
The First Primary
 Despite ritual denials from Mr. Dole and others, Presidential politics was plainly at work. Democrats scoffed at "the first Republican primary" just as Republicans fumed in 1960 that Johnson was misusing the legislative process for partisan gain by putting off the minimum wage issue until close to the election.
 But there are important differences. This time it was 17 months before the election instead of 3. Mr. Dole was playing politics with Senate business -- arranging for Dr. Foster's nomination to be killed by a brief filibuster, since he had enough votes to keep a filibuster alive but not enough to defeat the nomination on the merits -- in pursuit of his party's nomination, not the general election. Moreover, Mr. Dole succeeded. Johnson did not. He got the Senate to pass the bill raising the minimum wage from $1 to $1.25 an hour, but the House would not go along. And he and John F. Kennedy did not have the issue for the campaign.
 It is commonplace for one party to accuse the other of manipulating Congressional business to help its chances for the White House. But it is also usually wrong. The lawmakers are generally far less worried about electing a President than about re-electing themselves.
 One recent Congress did seem to be dedicated to affecting a Presidential election. In 1992, the Democrats went to great lengths to embarrass George Bush. They arranged vote after vote on extending emergency unemployment compensation. They stalled on a family leave bill until not long before Election Day. They put nice-sounding bills before him that they expected him to veto so they could attack him for that. The most spectacular was their campaign reform measure, which passed in the House only after Speaker Thomas S. Foley personally guaranteed reluctant Democrats that Mr. Bush would veto the bill.
 Since their nominee won the election, by one standard the Congressional Democrats won. But the gridlock "fed the image of neither institution being able to do something," said Charles O. Jones, a Congressional scholar at the Brookings Institution, and ended up damaging the Democrats in Congress. They lost a dozen House seats and only held their own in the Senate.
 In the Foster debate, too, the Republicans showed that they are better at playing politics in Congress. Senator Edward M. Kennedy insisted it was not fair to Dr. Foster to have to vote on ending a filibuster, which needs 60 votes. So Mr. Dole came back with a list that showed there had been 24 filibusters against nominees since 1968, including a couple Mr. Kennedy had led. And he insisted that breaking filibusters was the normal way the Senate now does business.

 
 
What Was Fair Then
 Nor is it only the Democrats who find consistency a hobgoblin of political failure. In 1986, when Democrats were filibustering against a judicial nominee named Clarence Manion, Mr. Dole complained, "I hope we will do what is fair and what we customarily do in this chamber and that is give this man an up-or-down vote." Mr. Dole had his way. The filibuster was broken. Democratic filibusters have never defeated a nominee.
 Of course, this skirmish is not over for Mr. Dole. Ann F. Lewis, a former Democratic operative now working for Planned Parenthood, was sorry for Dr. Foster's loss, but said that standing against abortion worked better in Republican nominating politics than in general elections. "Bob Dole might have won the straw poll today," she said, "but this issue has a habit of swinging the other way in the general election."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Get on Line for Plato's Cave

BYLINE: By DAVID BERREBY 

 BODY:
"Bombardier beetle" seems an apt name for an animal that fights its enemies by shooting a burst of chemicals that explode with a tiny bang. But what if the beetle had been discovered before anyone had ever heard of bombardiers? It would have been known by some other name. Every age sees the world through the lens of its own obsessions, using its latest inventions as metaphors. For Rene Descartes to see animals as machines, there first had to be machines. It takes nothing away from Charles Darwin's observation that species compete and adapt to note that Darwin himself came from an industrializing society whose members were being forced to compete and adapt. 
 The digital revolution is based on the idea that things as disparate as love letters, Hollywood movies and Beethoven's Fifth Symphony can all be broken down into the digital code of 0's and 1's and distributed by various kinds of computer. Now there's no doubt that thought has followed the economy out of the industrial era; Rust Belt metaphors for both nature and society -- the sun is a furnace, New York is a melting pot -- have given way to images of information-processing. The sun is now an information system changing over time. So is New York. So are you.

 
 
Stock Prices and Traffic
 The brain is a computer. The essence of humanity is encoded in DNA, a highly efficient chemical for storing information. Advocates of complexity theory say they can find fundamental laws of change and use them to predict and manage that change, regardless of what is changing -- stock prices or traffic.
 What is common to these intellectual and commercial currents is the idea that the information itself is the most profound aspect of whatever is being studied. Hence the biologist Richard Dawkins argues that we are all only elaborate carrying cases for our genes. And the physicists Doyne Farmer and Norman Packard, of the Prediction Company in Santa Fe, N.M., make stock picks on the basis of numerical patterns, without worrying about what the companies do.
 Like Europeans of the Enlightenment, who perfected the clock and then saw all nature as clockwork, we moderns tend to think information is all that counts. Once a symphony has been encoded on a disk, what difference does it make whose stereo it plays on? The belief that information is all is the heart of the fantasy of "Jurassic Park," whose premise was that once dinosaur DNA could be retrieved, it would be no trouble to make dinosaurs. Get the code, solve the problem. The rest -- eggs, fertilization, care and feeding -- is trivial.
 Last week, David Bunnell, a man enough on top of trends to have been a leader of Students for a Democratic Society in the 1960's and to have worked at the New Mexico firm that made the first personal computer in 1975, announced that he would launch Content.com, an on-line service devoted to books and publishing. It will offer book-related clips and book excerpts when it first gets rolling next year, Mr. Bunnell says, but he foresees a day when users could download an entire book. How -- or whether -- they print it out will be their business. Typography and paper would be up to each computer user. Those are details, Mr. Bunnell suggests. "What are books, really," he asks, "but ideas?"
 But there is a dissenting view. The critic Walter Kendrick, an English professor at Fordham University in New York City, does not see books as mere packages for ideas. "Reading a book," he said, "is a physical experience -- holding it, propping it on your lap. Reading has never been just naked contact between your mind and the author's. Reading is a sensual pleasure."
 What about electronic mail? One of its virtues is that it has no physical existence. A subscriber to a network can get mail in New York or New Delhi. But there's something missing. "When I touch a letter from a friend, I value the knowledge that I'm touching the same paper that was in contact -- actual physical contact -- with the friend," said David Ives, a playwright in New York City.

 
 
The Messy World
 Part of the current backlash against the Internet is a desire to speak up for messy, specific, embodied things, as distinct from their information content.
 Actually, the idea of a split between the corrupt, confusing material world and the clear world of abstraction dates back to Plato, who saw perceptible reality as an imperfect embodiment of a realm of perfect forms. The current emphasis on information resembles a familiar turn in Western thought: denigrating the earthbound, elevating the abstract. "Cyberspace," writes the philosopher Michael Heim in "The Metaphysics of Virtual Reality," "is Platonism as a working product."
 But information is not all there is to human experience. Mr. Dawkins's notion of the "selfish gene" as the only important unit in evolution, for example, is hotly contested by other biologists. And the "Jurassic Park" notion of DNA as the be-all and end-all is not one shared by cell biologists. The code is important, but so are all the questions about how exactly the code is made flesh. "How a protein folds, how it responds in the cell to hormones and nutrients, all those things are tremendously consequential," said Dr. Rex Chisholm, a molecular biologist at Northwestern Medical School, in Chicago.
 Just as the clockwork universe receded, no doubt the information metaphor will eventually give way. Still, the idea of pure information may always have its adherents, for much the same reason that the perfect forms of Plato have endured. Immaterial abstractions seem appealing when the material world is bleak. "Our material world gets dirtier and shabbier and more brutal as we go along," Mr. Kendrick said. "So we're attracted to this ethereal bill of goods we've been sold, this wonder world elsewhere."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
One Perverse Distinction New York Can't Claim

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

 BODY:
IT is an article of faith among New Yorkers that if it happens in the Big Apple it is either top of the heap or bottom of the barrel.
 The famous New Yorker cover by Saul Steinberg showing the Manhattan skyline dwarfing the rest of the United States is a wry expression of New York City's outsized ego. That self-centeredness is also evident in the best-worst way New Yorkers rank their museums and their murder rate, their home teams and homeless, their roguish politicians and percolating night life. 
 Yet despite the way many of them gripe about New York City's schools as if they were in the national cellar, they are, by several measures, better than most urban school systems.

 
 
'His Brother Was Worse'
 With 47.5 percent of the city's students scoring above grade level on reading tests and 50.3 percent above grade level in math, according to results released June 12, New York City fares better than all but one of the 10 largest urban systems, and the gap with first place San Diego is small. In Los Angeles, Chicago, Miami and Philadelphia, only a third of the students read above the national average, though they perform somewhat better in mathematics.
 New Yorkers long exasperated with their schools may see the distinction as something like the tribute in the story about a scoundrel's funeral where no one could be found to deliver a eulogy until one mourner piped up: "His brother was worse!" Still, New York City's educational ranking, experts say, tells much about its uniqueness among cities.
 For one thing, New York City's sprawling geography and its place as the world's center of finance and communications has allowed it to retain more of a middle class willing to send its children to public schools than cities like Detroit or Newark, experts say. Economic class correlates closely with academic achievement, and middle-class families in leafy neighborhoods like Bayside and Douglaston in Queens -- where 80 percent of the students scored above grade level -- tend to be more demanding of their schools.
 "You've got a wider mix of students than most school systems that have largely been abandoned by the middle class," said Michael Casserly, director of the Council of Great City Schools, which keeps statistics on the 50 largest systems.
 As the nation's legendary port for immigrants, the city attracts thousands of students who may be poor but are hungry for the achievement that may have eluded their nomadic parents. It is even favored by its particular immigrant mix. The city's Asians, for example, tend more often to come from relatively stable countries like China and Korea than from countries like Vietnam and Cambodia where children were swept up in political turbulence and lost crucial school years.
 "With immigrant populations, you get high-achieving kids, but you also get kids who are illiterate in their own language," said Diane Ravitch, author of "The Great School Wars: A History of New York City Public Schools" (Basic Books, 1974). "But compared to other cities New York has a more dynamic mix of the kids who are incredibly ambitious and striving."
 Reading and math data, of course, must be interpreted delicately. The 10 largest cities use five different exams, test different grades and sometimes exclude all bilingual and special education students, thereby inflating their scores.
 Still, New York City -- which in recent weeks has been struggling with a departing chancellor, a flurry of sexual abuse incidents involving teachers and school guards, spoiled food in some lunch programs and decaying school buildings -- is nevertheless blessed by several hoary traditions.
 Emanuel Tobier, a professor of planning at New York University, cites the city's strong civil service system and that it is linked to merit. Just as its public housing managers are among the nation's best, so its teaching and administrative staffs have been somewhat shielded from the patronage and nepotism dogging other cities.
 Tom Loveless, who studies education policy at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, points out that New York State's Regents examinations force teachers to teach to a moderately high standard. And, he notes, New York City spends more per pupil than many urban systems, particularly those in California and Texas.
 Finally, because of its vibrancy and cultural life, the city has always attracted more than its share of imaginative people, and so have its schools. Over the decades, it has come up with some of the country's most celebrated innovations, including some of the first selective schools in the country, like the Bronx High School of Science and Stuyvesant, which have helped it retain bright children whose parents might otherwise depart for the suburbs. It is no accident that New York City turns out a sizable percentage of the 40 winners of the Westinghouse Science Talent Search.
 "New York City is a very sophisticated town," conceded Eugene Campbell, superintendent of Newark's ailing public schools, "and they know how to deal with things on a sophisticated level."
