HEADLINE: Celebration And a Plea For Spending On Seawolf

BYLINE: By ADAM NOSSITER 

DATELINE: GROTON, Conn., June 24

 BODY:
Under a gloomy sky as steel-gray as the boat being christened, Navy Secretary John H. Dalton today delivered an impassioned plea for continued spending on the nuclear-powered Seawolf submarine, even as its future remains highly doubtful in Congress.
In doubt, too, is what will happen to thousands of workers at the Electric Boat Division of General Dynamics, many of whom watched pensively as Mr. Dalton's wife, Margaret, broke a champagne bottle on the hull of the boat at a crowded ceremony in the shipyard here. 
 Construction of a second Seawolf is well under way here, and the Clinton Administration wants a third copy of the $2.4 billion attack submarine, even though its military usefulness has not been seriously defended since the end of the Cold War. But Republicans in the House have been hostile, and even supporters talk as much about preserving jobs and submarine-building skills as they do about facing up to the Russians.
"The nuclear submarine-building industry represents an investment we have spent over 40 years to develop," Mr. Dalton said today as hundreds of naval officers, several Congressmen and thousands of Electric Boat employees looked on. "We are gambling with a national treasure if we do not take steps to preserve it."
The New-Age piano music tinkling around the great gray bulk of the partially submerged vessel gave off a deceptive air of calm to a ceremony that might prove to have been a wake for a dead armament.
Hardly anyone questions the effect that shutting down Seawolf production would have on the economy of southeastern Connecticut. About 14,500 people are employed at the shipyard here, and if the third Seawolf is not built, all but 3,000 or 4,000, most of them engineers, will be out of work, said James E. Turner, Electric Boat's president.
"If we don't build the third Seawolf, there will be no work in the shipyards for a couple of years," Mr. Turner said in an interview.
But already, the House, in its version of the defense spending bill passed earlier this month, has refused to appropriate the remaining $1.5 billion needed to complete the third Seawolf, allocating instead roughly that amount for more work on the second submarine and the Seawolf's successor, known as the New Attack Submarine.
The Senate Armed Services Committee's seapower subcommittee takes up the Seawolf next week, with supporters predicting passage at least at that stage. But its future in the full Senate is much less certain. The program has some powerful opponents, including Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia, the home state of Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, which wants to compete with Electric Boat for submarine work.
"I'm concerned about my job more than anything," said Bob Berek, a pipefitter at the shipyard who has worked on the Seawolf. "It would be great to get a third Seawolf, but that isn't going to stop the layoffs.
"The workers know our time is limited, and we'll have to gear up and start looking for other employment."
In his remarks today, Mr. Dalton made an argument for the third Seawolf, casting it less as a necessity of international geopolitics than as a measure needed to preserve a valuable native industry. And he made oblique reference to a frequent criticism of the ship's expense.
"The third Seawolf which we need will be the bridge that preserves this industry to build a more affordable, littoral warfare-oriented New Attack Submarine," Mr. Dalton said.
"There is a chasm in our defense industrial strength," the secretary said. "If Congress does not authorize and fund the third Seawolf, the depth of this chasm will not simply be measured in lost jobs, or dollars wasted in higher overhead and contracting fees, but in the potential breakup of a defense industry that has always served our best interest in preserving the peace."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The first Seawolf attack submarine was christened yesterday in Groton, Conn. Construction of a second Seawolf is under way there, as the fate of a third is debated in Congress. (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.N., in Debt, Seeks Arrears From U.S. and Others

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 23

 BODY:
Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali is bound for the celebration of the United Nations 50th anniversary in San Francisco next week bearing a gloomy message: The United Nations is going broke.
Speaking to a working group on the organization's financial problems on Thursday, Mr. Boutros-Ghali said that only 48 of the 185 member states had fully paid their regular budget contributions by the end of May. 
 The deepening financial crisis this has caused could force the United Nations to stop reimbursing countries that contribute troops and equipment to peacekeeping, he said. He said the peacekeeping debt could rise from the present $800 million to $1.1 billion by the end of the year.
The Secretary General is trying to persuade the nations that are behind in their payments, especially the United States, that it is in their national interest to pay up.
On Friday, he told the World Affairs Council in Los Angeles that the United States could save money working through the United Nations. For example, Washington's cost of intervening in Haiti had fallen from $50 million a month to less than $8 million since the United Nations took over the operation.
He will take his case further when he speaks Sunday at the celebration, spelling out what the United Nations is doing to save money.
According to Mr. Boutros-Ghali's office, the United Nations is owed nearly $2.8 billion in assessments by member states, while it owes more than $1.7 billion.
The Secretariat has identified the United States as the worst delinquent, with $1.18 billion in arrears as of May 31. Others include Russia ($599 million), Ukraine ($217 million), South Africa ($113 million) and France ($81 million). The United States, disputing some calculations, says its arrears amount to $955.5 million.
The debts accumulated by the United Nations include $800 million owed to 60 member states that provided peacekeepers and equipment. About $375 million more is owed to businesses that supply the organization.
The arrears of South Africa include assessments for the years from 1974 to 1994, when it was barred from taking part in the General Assembly because of its apartheid policy. An official at the South African mission here said the post-apartheid Government is considering the issue.
Last week, the Secretary General proposed that countries that owe money for peacekeeping should issue bonds that other countries awaiting payment could hold and redeem, but the proposal received a cool response.

HEADLINE: Vote Today a Turning Point for Haiti

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: ST.-MARC, Haiti, June 23

 BODY:
The ballots have been stacked in a corner of a dark, bare room, 420 to a box in a pile that reaches almost to the ceiling.
Guarded by an armed police officer, they are waiting to be shipped off to polling places in this rundown Haitian port on the north coast and in the nearby countryside, where eager voters are expected to begin lining up at 6 A.M. Sunday. 
 Biron Odige, 28, deputy chief of the Communal Election Board here, appreciates the significance of those sheets of paper. He knows only too well, he said, that thousands of his countrymen died and hundreds of thousands were forced to go into exile or -- like him -- to go underground so Sunday's vote could take place.
"This is a turning point for all Haitians," said Mr. Odige, a student. "For me, election day represents the end of the coup d'etat and our entry into a state of law. There were many difficult moments during the time I spent in hiding, but I always held to the idea that some day this could happen."
As an exercise in democracy, the election will be even larger than the vote in December 1990 that swept Jean-Bertrand Aristide into the presidency. More than 10,500 candidates from 28 political parties are competing for 2,200 posts, from the Senate and Chamber of Deputies to mayors's offices and municipal councils.
Since Mr. Aristide's election, Haiti has experienced much.
There was a military coup that overthrew the President, three years of a brutal military dictatorship, a crushing economic embargo intended to topple that junta, the intervention last fall of 20,000 American troops to restore President Aristide to office and now the presence of United Nations peacekeepers.
But suffering has only enhanced the meaning of the election.
"To be able to cast a ballot is one of the biggest things in my life," said Dugariste Ditreuil, 21, a student who was studying for final exams with friends on a park bench in the main square. "I've been preparing myself for a long time to be able to take part in the betterment of my country, waiting for this moment to arrive."
The Government estimates that 3.5 million people, nearly 90 percent of those thought to be eligible, have registered for Sunday's vote -- a 25 percent increase over 1990.
Virtually no opinion polling has been done, leaving candidates of all political stripes free to forecast smashing victories.
But Haitian political analysts and foreign diplomats predicted that most votes would be won by three political groups that supported Mr. Aristide in 1990: the Lavalas Political Organization, the National Front for Change and Democracy and the National Congress of Democratic Movements.
"Yes, if two-thirds of the people voted for Aristide in 1990, it is logical that the democratic sector will be heavily represented" at all levels of power once the vote is in, said Gerard Pierre-Charles, leader of the Lavalas group, which has President Aristide's formal support.
But, he added, since Haiti has little experience with democracy, "no one knows what motivates people to vote, whether it is adherence to an organization or the force of a candidate's personality."
With a few exceptions, the campaign has gone more smoothly than predicted. There have been isolated episodes of candidates being fired on or election officials being beaten up, and one former leader of the despised Tontons Macoute threatened to disrupt the vote when he was ruled ineligible to run.
[Overnight Friday, two polling centers near Cap-Haitien, on the northern coast, were attacked, Haitian and international officials said. One center was set afire and about 3,000 ballots burned; election supplies were stolen from the other Election officials said new materials had been sent and they expect voting to take place normally.]
So far the systematic violence and intimidation led by the disbanded Haitian armed forces that forced the cancellation of the 1987 presidential election and threatened the 1990 vote has been avoided.
"This time there's been no security problem, and it feels like a holiday for the entire country," said Osler Lyndor, 49, a laborer here who said he was enthusiastically following the campaign. "For once we Haitians are not fighting with each other."
The Haitian organizers of the vote and their United Nations advisers have taken many steps to avoid the vast fraud that has almost always marred elections. For instance, all voters are to have their fingers daubed with indelible ink to prevent them from voting more than once.
Hundreds of official observers from the United States, Latin America, Canada and Europe, led by more than 300 delegates from the Organization of American States, will be deployed at polling places. The United Nations peacekeeping force of nearly 7,000 soldiers and police officers will protect voters.
The campaigning has been marked by many organizational problems and irregularities, though, leading some opposition parties to complain of a deliberate effort to hinder their chances. Criticism of Anselme Remy, president of the Provisional Election Commission, and the eight other members has been almost universal.
"They have made a lot of honest mistakes due to lack of experience and lack of competence," said Jean-Robert Sabalat, who was chairman of the electoral commission that supervised the 1990 election. "It's a pity, but they have lost their credibility, and no one trusts them anymore." Mr. Sabalat is running for a Senate seat.
Mr. Remy's most controversial action was his announcement late last month that a million or more voter registration cards had disappeared. In an interview, he said he had made the statement to "sensitize the public to the possibility of fraud in the system."
American, United Nations and O.A.S. officials have since said that the cards were not, in fact, ever missing. But Mr. Remy has continued to insist that hundreds of thousands of cards are missing, and foreign election observers say his statements have cast doubt, apparently unnecessarily, on the credibility of the election process.
The large registration fees that independent candidates and small parties are required to pay under the election code that President Aristide decreed into law in February are also controversial. Some opposition candidates fear they may triumph at the polls only to see their victories annulled because they have not paid the fees.
Mr. Remy said a final tally in Sunday's vote would not be available for 8 to 10 days. Much of rural Haiti, where nearly three-quarters of the population lives, lacks electricity or telephones. The ballots will be counted by hand and the results taken, in some cases on foot or by donkey, over a precarious road system to regional counting centers.
The vast majority of Haitian voters are illiterate, and each party has adopted symbols that will appear on the ballot next to candidates' names.
But many independent candidates, including Manno Charlemagne, a popular protest singer who appears to be running a strong race for Mayor of Port-au-Prince, have complained that a Haitian flag was used on the ballot next to their names instead of their individual emblems.
Mr. Odige, the election official, said he had his favorite candidates but he declined to disclose them. What is important, he said, is not so much the result as the process itself.
"Aristide's return opened the door for us," he said. "Now we must step through it into democracy."

GRAPHIC: Photos: In Port-au-Prince, the popular Mayor, Evans Paul, handed out election leaflets on Friday to an eager throng; Biron Odige, an election official in St.-Marc, said today's vote "represents the end of the coup d'etat." (Photographs by Robert Miller for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "AT A GLANCE: Haiti's Elections"
 Haiti is to hold its first elections today since President Jean-Bertrand Aristide was returned to power last October from three years in exile after a military coup.
 
AT STAKE: 18 members of the 27-seat Senate, all 83 members of the Chamber of Deputies, 133 mayors and 561 municipal councils, each with three members.
 
REGISTERED VOTERS: About 3.5 million, of a voting population estimated at 3.7 million-4.2 million or more.
 
POLLING PLACES: 10,031. Ballots will be counted at each polling place, placed in sealed envelopes and passed on to local and district centers for confirmation.
 
PARTIES INVOLVED: 28, ranging from a communist party on the left to extreme right-wing parties with links to the Tontons Macoutes.
 
CANDIDATES: 10,558 approved as of June 7.
 
LEADING PARTY CONTENDERS: The Lavalas Political Organization, endorsed by Mr. Aristide; the National Front for Change and Democracy, Mr. Aristide's original coalition; and the National Congress for Democratic Movements, a social-democratic party expelled by the National Front in 1994.
 
ELECTION OBSERVER DELEGATIONS: The Organization of American States, the United States Government and several independent foreign organizations.
 
SECURITY FORCES: 6,000 United Nations troops, 900 foreign civilian police under United Nations control, and about 400 newly-retrained Haitian police officers.
 
RESULTS: Expected to be announced in 8-11 days.

HEADLINE: U.N. Finds Skepticism Is Eroding The Hope That Is Its Foundation

SERIES: The U.N. At 50

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 24

 BODY:
Senator Claiborne Pell, the sole remaining member of Congress to have been present when the United Nations Charter was adopted here 50 years ago this Monday, nurtures vivid memories of a euphoric time.
The Senator, now 76, was among scores of young Americans and Europeans demobilized from the battlefields of World War II and shipped west to be the aides of statesmen pledged to create a new international order. 
 "It started out just right," he recalled in a recent conversation in his Senate office. "Instead of flying us to San Francisco, they chartered a train across the United States.
"You could see the eyes of all those people who had been in wartorn Europe boggle as we passed the wheat fields, the factories. You could feel the richness, the clean air of the United States. It was a wonderful image. We shared a spirit, a belief, that we would never make the same mistakes; everything would now be done differently."
In those heady days half a century ago, the United Nations emerged as a club of victorious allies pledged to prevent aggression and provide assistance for those in need. Today, for most Americans, it is no longer the hope of a better world.
As San Francisco has been preparing friendly and glittering ceremonies to mark the Charter's birth on June 26, 1945, the United Nations is under attack in Congress. This attack could significantly alter Washington's relationship with the organization, crippling its work in fields as diverse as labor practices and population control.
United Nations offices are getting more threatening crank calls and less access to Congressional committees, officials say.
President Clinton, who is to speak at ceremonies on Monday, has warned against isolationism but offers only lukewarm praise for the United Nations. "Sometimes, as bad and as ragged as it is, the U.N. is better than nothing," he said in an informal debate with Newt Gingrich, the House Speaker, in New Hampshire on June 11.
In Congress, on talk shows and on the street, Americans voice recurrent fears and complaints. The United Nations, almost entirely American in concept -- its name was coined by President Franklin D. Roosevelt -- had barely begun to function before it got trapped in the cold war. Soon Moscow and many newly independent nations were isolating and vilifying the United States.
"There were times when only the United States and Israel voted together, and people questioned whether we had any friends there," said Benjamin A. Gilman, the New York Republican and chairman of the House Committee on International Relations.
Resolutions defining Zionism as racism cost the United Nations Association of the United States, an important support group, thousands of members as whole chapters disbanded.
"Congress has been concerned about the extensiveness of our funds and about a great deal of mismanagement in the organization," Mr. Gilman said. In peacekeeping, he added, "there are some 17 missions around the world costing millions of dollars where the U.N. is engaged in nation-building and other activities which have not produced much peace."
"A number of things have added up to a questioning of the U.N.," Mr. Gilman said. Meanwhile, the organization seems too aloof, unable or unwilling to educate the American public on its accomplishments. "It would be extremely helpful," he said, "if people were to recognize, for example, how much goes into disease control and disease elimination, and how much goes into feeding the hungry."
Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana and the ranking minority member on Mr. Gilman's committee, said notions of threats to American independence of action also loom large.
"In some groups of Americans, there is a distinct fear of loss of U.S. sovereignty to the U.N.," Mr. Hamilton said. "In many of my public meetings people have gotten up to attack what they call the New World Order -- something President Bush first talked about. I'm not sure what the New World Order is in their minds."
Among radical armed militia groups, rumors circulate that black United Nations helicopters or white-painted all-terrain vehicles are coming to invade one part of America or another. Early this year, the military attache of the United States Mission to the United Nations had to write to the commander of the Michigan Militia to assure him that the United Nations was not about to take over a Michigan camp to train its troops -- and that, in any case, it had no troops.
 
Skepticism
Surges of Optimism About U.N. Fade
 Doubts about the United Nations are sometimes fundamental. At the Heritage Foundation in Washington, Charles M. Lichenstein, the resident expert on the organization and recently co-chairman of a Congressionally mandated, bipartisan Commission on Improving the Effectiveness of the United Nations, says there was considerable skepticism about the world organization's mission, even among Americans officials, right from its birth.
"The initial concept was terribly, terribly flawed," said Mr. Lichenstein, an academic from Yale and Notre Dame who served as alternate United States representative at the United Nations for special political affairs from 1981 to 1984.
"It is, I suppose, theoretically possible to set up an institution that is somehow or other going to be better than the people who set it up," he said, "that is going to be more responsive to an objective world view, that will identify aggressors rapidly, that will identify trouble spots rapidly and that will have mass resources to do something about it.
"It is theoretically possible, but it's very unlikely. I think that most Americans soon began to sense that."
He noted that the Korean War, which began within five years of the founding, was always perceived as an American operation despite its United Nations imprimatur. In 1991 the war against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq also had United Nations backing but American leadership. When no major country is willing to go to battle -- as in Somalia or Bosnia -- the results have been very different.
"When a great country feels its security threatened, it's going to reach out to the people who share that sense," he said.
A wave of optimism about the future of the United Nations that surged after the collapse of the Soviet empire beginning in the late 1980's is now almost universally thought to have receded.
Gallup and Roper opinion polls over more than 40 years show that the American public was most enthusiastic about the United Nations in October 1991, after the Persian Gulf war, when 67 percent of those polled said the United Nations was doing "a good job."
The highest previous figure, 58 percent, was registered in 1954, after the Korean War. This month, 42 percent of Americans polled were favorably impressed, 46 percent said the United Nations was doing a bad job and the rest had no opinion.
 
Reappraisal
Cuts by Congress Raising Fears
 So how to mark the 50th year of the United Nations, beginning here and culminating in New York on Oct. 24, the anniversary of the first General Assembly session?
"This is not a propitious time to celebrate," said Rita E. Hauser, a New York lawyer and chairwoman of the board of the International Peace Academy, a United Nations affiliate. The political climate, she said, is unfortunate.
"President Clinton has stuck his finger into the wind and is watching to see how it is playing, while the rest of the Administration -- except Madeleine Albright -- is really not out there," said Ms. Hauser, referring to the chief United States representative. Ms. Hauser has represented the United States in United Nations bodies and is president of the Hauser Foundation, which she established to work to resolve international conflict.
Although White House officials have spoken forcefully on occasion against a rebirth of isolationism, and Hillary Rodham Clinton has appeared at several major United Nations functions this year, the ranks of supporters in the State Department seem thin. It is Ms. Albright who is on the front line of the Administration's countercharge. A refugee from the Communist takeover of Czechoslovakia in 1948, she relishes the task.
Ms. Albright says all the 50-year commemorations marking the end of World War II have been instructive for people unacquainted with modern history.
"Given the climate here, I find that the anniversary will be a very useful taking-off point for creating an understanding in people as to why the U.N. is important," she said in an interview.
Morris B. Abram, an international lawyer, former United States representative at the United Nations in Geneva and later founder of a monitoring organization, U.N. Watch, articulated a more cautious theme for the anniversary.
"If we simply celebrate with drums and bugles and fifes, we're doing the U.N. a disservice, because the U.N. has many faults," he said. "This should be a time of re-examination and reappraisal, with a view not to destroy it but to improve it. Without honest criticism, particularly from outside sources, it will not be improved."
The House of Representatives did not wait long this year to demonstrate how it planned to celebrate the 50th anniversary. In early March it passed a bill significantly amending and tightening the terms under which the United States will continue to support the United Nations.
Among other changes, the House bill demands that the President run down a checklist of United Nations behavior before Congress pays the United States assessments in full. The bill also cuts contributions to peacekeeping and requires that the sharing of intelligence be monitored and controlled.
Further cuts and restrictions were included in a recently passed foreign aid bill. In the Senate, where a companion bill is being written, Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina and chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, proposed ending or sharply curtailing American support for nearly three dozen United Nations agencies or programs.
In a letter on April 26 to Senator Pete V. Domenici, chairman of the Budget Committee, Senator Helms said, "United States participation in most United Nations programs should be terminated."
Mr. Helms says this would cut hundreds of millions of dollars from about $2 billion that the United States pays annually toward the regular United Nations budget, specialized agencies, peacekeeping and programs supported by voluntary contributions.
Earlier this month in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, campaigns by two Democratic Senators, John F. Kerry of Massachusetts and Russell D. Feingold of Wisconsin, succeeded in restoring some of the proposed cuts. But the Senate version is still $200 million short of the Administration's $425 million request in voluntary contributions alone, for programs in areas like the environment and economic development for women.
Daniel L. Spiegel, the United States representative at the United Nations and other international organizations in Geneva, said a drop in Congressional support could threaten agencies like the World Health Organization, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, the International Committee of the Red Cross and the International Organization for Migration.
Mr. Spiegel said he believed that the magnitude of the cuts suggested not only a desire to save money but also a determination to withdraw from cooperation on many fronts, including health and environmental programs.
"Reckless cutting will hurt all international health efforts at a time when we are in the middle of dealing with the reappearance of the Ebola virus in Zaire, cholera in Latin America, the plague in India and diphtheria in Russia," he said. "The whole international civil infrastructure will be seriously eroded."
 
The U.N. at 50
 An article on Friday examined mismanagement and waste at the United Nations.

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
Extreme Rhetoric Bedevils Congress

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
The 104th Congress, which once marveled at its own legislative efficiency, is bedeviled by partisan sniping, wild exaggeration and a bizarre degree of self-confidence.
Its leaders even asserted that there was nothing strange about the Senate's failing to vote squarely on a nomination for an office with only symbolic power. Instead, they said, it made perfectly good sense to vote twice not to take a vote on confirming a Surgeon General -- and for 57 senators to be insufficient to make the vote happen. 
 That, believe it or not, made sense in the Senate.
That argument recalls the last time that Congressional leaders insisted that they understood reality better than anyone else -- and said the House bank scandal had amounted to no more than a few bookkeeping problems. That time it was House Democrats who were out of touch.
Today the leaders are Republicans, and they defend themselves by saying that they are only doing to Democrats what Democrats did to them. Sometimes they have a case. Senator Bob Dole pointed out on Thursday that Senator Edward M. Kennedy had led the 1986 filibuster against the nomination of William H. Rehnquist to be Chief Justice, as had other senators who were complaining that it was not fair to deny Dr. Henry W. Foster Jr., the Surgeon General nominee, a straight vote on his confirmation.
And the Democrats can hardly be expected to say that their inability to make their filibusters stick means that it was O.K. when they did it.
Nor is the problem merely in the Senate.
With an overnight break for a trip to a Republican fund-raiser in New York City, House members had to vote twice on the fate of an obscure Congressional agency, the Office of Technology Assessment. On Wednesday, a quick gavel kept two Democrats from voting and allowed the Republicans to eke out a 214-to-213 vote to kill its financing.
On thursday, faced with the prospect that Democrats would express their fury by bringing the legislative pace to a halt -- just the way Republicans did last year when they felt mistreated -- the Republicans allowed an unheard-of reprise of the vote and took a 220-to-204 defeat along with a serving of the humble pie that has seldom been seen on their plate much of this year.
But they are not overdosing on humility. A House Appropriations subcommittee unveiled plans on Thursday to abolish the President's Council of Economic Advisers, a Presidential agency set up half a century ago to give the Government scholarly advice on economics.
Democrats said they were startled at the lack of respect for a separate and equal branch of Government displayed by the gesture, and even the subcommittee chairman, Representative Jim Ross Lightfoot of Iowa, said he recognized that he could be accused of "micromanagement" and lack of proper respect for the office of the President. But he said the Administration had plenty of other economists in the Office of Management and Budget. "We were looking for anything that was duplicative," he said.
An extreme level of argument accompanied those efforts in both houses. To accompany the debate on the Surgeon General, Senator Bob Smith, Republican of New Hampshire, displayed photographs of fetuses. He was arguing that Dr. Foster had performed 700 abortions (Dr. Foster himself, after some initial confusion, put the figure at 39), and that any of them might have prevented the birth of someone better qualified to be Surgeon General than the Tennessee obstetrician.
In the House, Representative Earl F. Hilliard, Democrat of Alabama, who was denied the opportunity to vote on Wednesday when he arrived as the roll-call was finishing, proclaimed: "This is not Caesar's Rome, this is not Hitler's Germany and this is definitely not Stalin's Russia. This is where the voice of freedom should reign."
Much of the debate these days is wildly exaggerated. The argument that the defeat of Dr. Foster was a blow to abortion rights sounded as overdrawn as the contention that his confirmation would have hampered the anti-abortion forces in the nation.
But the day's record for hyperbole was set by Senator Dole. After boasting off the floor that by dooming the nomination he had out-slicked Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, his leading rival in the Senate for the 1996 Republican Presidential nomination, he told the Senate, "This is not about Presidential politics; that may be a good sound bite."
In fact, almost all debate here is for sound bites, fed by the hope that network television will use an extreme comment. Most members speak as if they think that not one of their colleagues is listening seriously -- or could be persuaded by thoughtful arguments.
One Republican who is not running for President, Senator William S. Cohen of Maine, spoke up on Thursday. A supporter of Dr. Foster's, he accused some other defenders of the nominee of following a double standard, of ignoring the excesses of liberal campaigns against conservative nominees like Judge Robert Bork, a Reagan choice for the Supreme Court whose nomination crashed in a storm of bitter attacks.
He said it was time for Congress to stop "shredding the character of the individuals who come before the body for confirmation."
"If we disagree philosophically, let us be very up front about it and base it on that," he said. "We have lowered the standard for civil debate and discourse in this country. What we have to do is lower the rhetoric and the charges and the countercharges about who is sacrificing whom on what altar."
But Mr. Cohen was speaking to an empty chamber, as senators usually do.
Not long after, Mr. Smith was on the floor. He argued that Dr. Foster could not be believed about the infamous Tuskegee syphilis experiment; Dr. Foster had denied knowing that the experiment abandoned black patients to suffering without treatment. Dr. Foster testified that he had protested angrily when he discovered what had been going on.
And the Senator brought his pictures of fetuses.

HEADLINE: WITH TRADE TALKS STALLED, TOP AIDES AGREE TO STEP IN

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: GENEVA, June 24

 BODY:
Negotiators for Japan and the United States said today that the top trade officials from both countries had agreed to fly here on Monday in a last-ditch effort to resolve their differences on automotive trade before American sanctions on Japanese luxury cars go into effect on Wednesday.
The two officials, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, and Ryutaro Hashimoto, Japan's Minister of International Trade and Industry, will try to bridge what both sides say is an enormous gulf on how Japan should organize its economy and how its businesses should interact with foreign suppliers. 
 But neither side expressed much optimism that the surprise meeting between the two longtime sparring partners would come in time to avert the 100 percent tariffs planned on 13 Japanese car models. The sanctions, the largest trade retaliation in American history, go into effect at midnight Wednesday.
"The situation is very difficult, but it is not yet hopeless," Japan's lead negotiator, Yoshihiro Sakamoto, said in an interview late this afternoon at the Japanese mission here, which has been converted into a temporary headquarters for scores of Japanese bureaucrats, experts and industry officials.
In an hourlong talk, Mr. Sakamoto said Japan was committed to deregulating its economy and weakening the hold of the keiretsu, the families of interlinked companies who keep outsiders from obtaining some of the country's most lucrative contracts. But he suggested that the changes would happen at Tokyo's own pace -- and not under pressure or threats from the United States.
Mr. Sakamoto, who is the highest-ranking civil servant in the Trade Ministry and one of Japan's most powerful bureaucrats, also said that if the sanctions hurt small- and medium-sized Japanese businesses, the Japanese Government would try to help them out, perhaps with subsidies.
"Whatever the cause of trouble -- a major earthquake or political action by another government -- it is part of the Japanese Government's role to provide assistance to medium- and small-sized companies that are hurt." But he said he did not expect that help to extend to the five biggest Japanese car makers, even if some -- including Mazda and Nissan -- are under extraordinary financial stress.
Mr. Sakamoto's comments came after a brief negotiating session, the shortest since the two sides began talking on Thursday.
Asked whether he agreed with Mr. Sakamoto's pessimistic assessment of the talks, Jeffrey E. Garten, the Undersecretary of Commerce for International Trade, said, "We are wide apart on all the big issues, but we're certainly not giving up."
Ordinarily Mr. Hashimoto and Mr. Kantor, two outspoken and combative trade officials who have come to personify a new age of economic foreign policy, would not come here to meet unless a deal was pre-cooked and ready for public consumption. But both sides went to pains today to suggest that an agreement had not been reached.
Certainly there will be enormous pressure on both Mr. Kantor and Mr. Hashimoto to reach a settlement. But the session seemed intended primarily for domestic audiences in both capitals. Mr. Kantor wants to make clear that he has gone the extra 3,000 miles to make good on President Clinton's commitment a week ago in Halifax, Nova Scotia, to make "every possible effort for a negotiated settlement" before the sanctions go into effect.
For Mr. Hashimoto, the politics of the meeting are more complex. If he reaches a deal without loss of face, he can return to Tokyo to proclaim that he has saved Japan's relationship with its most important ally. But if the talks fail, he can say he did everything possible to avert sanctions -- but that nothing could satisfy a bullying and unreasonable Clinton Administration.
Japanese political experts disagree on the question of which outcome would better improve Mr. Hashimoto's chances of becoming Japan's next prime minister, perhaps as soon as later this year.
As described by both American and Japanese officials, the negotiations have stalled on three major issues: Getting far more Japanese car dealers to handle American models, breaking up a virtual cartel in the business of replacing parts on Japanese cars and, most important, forcing Japanese car makers to buy far more American components when they build new cars -- in the United States and in Japan.
The dealership issue is primarily an argument about measurements: The United States insists that Japan commit itself to a clearly stated increase in the number of dealers handling American cars and that the two sides measure the progress annually. Japan has rejected that approach as a use of "numerical targets" and managed trade.
"They want a government commitment," Mr. Sakamoto said. "And this is not the Government's business. Governments don't sell cars; only car dealers sell cars."
The question of replacement parts is part of a broader effort to force Japan to break up what Washington calls a cartel: A system of car inspections that is dominated by repair shops that are tied to the Japanese car makers. Those shops carry virtually no foreign-made parts. Because of the rigid inspection system, Japanese drivers replace parts far more extensively than do American drivers who own the same models, and this is an enormously lucrative business in Japan.
The biggest differences, though, are on the "voluntary plans" that the Japanese car makers are expected to issue next week, spelling out their programs to purchase more American parts.
There are two areas of dispute. One focuses on verifying how the Japanese makers fulfill their goals. The more important difference, however, centers on the willingness of Japanese makers to buy those parts for use in their factories in Japan, not just those in the United States.
So far, the car makers have only hinted about greater use of American parts in their "transplant" factories in the American Midwest. But the United States has said repeatedly here that there would be no deal without major purchases for factories in Japan, where the keiretsu hold is the tightest.
Mr. Sakamoto portrayed that today as a new demand from Washington. American negotiators deny it is new; the Japanese "just weren't listening before," one official said.
"This isn't for us to decide," said Mr. Sakamoto, who claims his ministry long ago gave up controlling the Japanese auto makers. "This is up for the free and independent auto makers themselves to decide."

HEADLINE: 'Militia' Man Tells of Plot To Attack Military Base

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WATERFORD, Mich.

 BODY:
The way Eric Maloney tells the story, the plan to blow up Camp Grayling, a National Guard base in northern Michigan, was hatched in late January when 70 members of the Michigan Militia Corps, a statewide right-wing paramilitary group, met at a truck-stop restaurant northwest of Detroit.
Mr. Maloney, then a member of a local unit called the Oakland County Sixth Brigade, says the focus of conversation that night was photographs taken by a militia member of Russian tanks being transported to the camp on rail cars. Some at the meeting considered the photos proof of a conspiracy theory popular among far-right groups: that foreign troops under United Nations command are massing to take over the country. They wanted to act. 
 Three days later, Mr. Maloney says, when about 20 members of his unit gathered at a farm near Leonard, Mich., for their weekly military training, brigade leaders laid out a detailed plan to attack the camp on Feb. 12. He quotes one brigade leader as saying, "Let's go blow up those tanks and kill those bastards who put them there."
Mr. Maloney alerted Federal agents. The attack never occurred.
Some militia members flatly deny Mr. Maloney's account of a plot. Others, speaking on the condition of anonymity, verify it broadly but differ on some important details; one says it was Mr. Maloney himself who helped devise the scheme and pushed hardest for it. The Federal Bureau of Investigation continues to look into the matter, a case that adds at least to the perception that despite the disavowals of leading figures in the national militia movement, some of their members seem inclined to plot violence against the Government.
Mr. Maloney and his wife, Christine, who also attended the meeting at the farm, say Timothy J. McVeigh, now the principal suspect in the Oklahoma City bombing three months later, was sitting beside Mrs. Maloney when the assault plans were discussed and jumped up to volunteer for the mission.
Mr. McVeigh's involvement could not be corroborated, though. F.B.I. officials in Michigan and Washington declined to answer any questions about the episode.
As Mr. Maloney outlined the assault in a written summary for the F.B.I., it was to include the following:
*"Contact all the brigades in the state and storm Camp Grayling, killing anyone who attempts to defend the base and arresting anyone else who is left."
*"Photograph, for historical purposes, all foreign equipment."
*"Bring in the media" and blow up the camp "on worldwide television."
* "Hunt down anyone involved in bringing in the foreign equipment and try them for war crimes in a revolutionary court, which denies the accused a chance for appeal. The accused would be executed as soon as possible."
*"Hunt down all U.N. forces in the U.S."
Having concluded that the attack would be "suicidal for everyone involved," Mr. Maloney says, he spent the next few days trying to persuade his brigade's leaders to abandon it. When they ignored him, he says, he arranged to meet on Feb. 8 with agents of the F.B.I. and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. The next day he told one brigade leader, Kevin Shane, that he had exposed the plan to the authorities. Soon afterward, the brigade disbanded.
"It was like a B movie," Mr. Maloney, a 33-year-old auto mechanic, said in an interview at his home in this Detroit suburb not far from the truck stop where he says the plan was first discussed. "I was unwilling to let people get killed out of stupidity."
Others who attended one or more of several such meetings described by Mr. Maloney offer varying versions of what occurred.
Mark Koernke, a militia strategist widely known for his shortwave radio program, "Mark From Michigan," acknowledged in an interview that he had attended the truck-stop meeting but denied involvement in any plan to attack Camp Grayling.
Mr. Shane, a nurse from another Detroit suburb, Lake Orion, accused Mr. Maloney of promoting the assault and said brigade leaders had spent several days trying to dissuade him. Mr. Shane has sued Mr. Maloney for slander.
A member of the brigade who spoke on the condition that he not be identified said that Mr. Maloney and a brigade leader named Richard Binkley, whom other members describe as an unemployed real estate appraiser, were the chief architects of the plan and that Mr. Maloney went to the authorities only after he and Mr. Binkley had a falling out.
Mr. Binkley, who has no listed telephone number, could not be reached for comment.
Matthew Krol, a spokesman for the Michigan Militia Corps, said the state organization had conducted an internal inquiry and had concluded that other than for a few offhand remarks -- he quoted one member as saying, "Yeah, we should go in there and blow it up" -- nothing had happened.
But Federal agents were certainly interested. Mr. Shane, for one, said that agents had interviewed him about Mr. Maloney's account and that the F.B.I. had sent him a routine notification that it had completed a wiretapping of his telephone.
"The F.B.I. has taken this seriously," said the member who did not want to be identified. "And as far as I know, they are still poking around."
And what about the photos of Russian tanks that touched off the entire affair?
As it turns out, Russian tanks were indeed on their way to Camp Grayling at the time. A camp spokesman, Lieut. Col. Jerold Foehl, said they were part of a program, under way for at least 12 years, in which captured foreign military equipment is shipped by rail from Eglin Air Force Base in Florida for analysis by military contractors and the training of American soldiers.
Colonel Foehl said such equipment always traveled on open, uncovered flatcars, to avoid precisely the kind of suspicions voiced by paramilitary groups.
The name of the program, he noted, is Chicken Little.

HEADLINE: U.S. Asserts Iranians Plotted To Disrupt Rally in Germany

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
Iranian diplomats working out of their embassy in Bonn plotted to disrupt a huge opposition rally in Germany last week, perhaps with the intention of assassinating a leading Iranian dissident, American intelligence officials said today.
At about the same time, Germany asked two Iranian intelligence officials to leave the country because of evidence that they were planning potentially lethal operations from German territory, the American officials said. The expulsions did not appear to be specifically linked to the plot. 
 German Foreign Ministry officials denied any knowledge of the plot or the expulsions, although they abruptly banned the opposition leader, Maryam Rajavi, from entering the country to address the rally.
But United States officials said they confirmed the incidents both with German officials and through independent American intelligence-gathering efforts in Germany.
The American disclosure of the incident in Bonn is likely to embarrass the German Government and may further divide the Clinton Administration and its allies in Europe and Asia about how to deal with Iran.
For the United States, evidence of an Iranian-inspired plot in Europe is just more proof that Iran is, as Washington claims, an "outlaw state" that spends hundreds of millions of dollars a year on terrorism and has embarked on a "crash" course to develop nuclear weapons. The evidence is certain to be seized on by the Administration to bolster its uncompromising though much-criticized campaign to undermine the Teheran Government through economic means.
Both American and German intelligence concluded last year that Iran is using its embassy in Bonn as an informal headquarters of the Iranian intelligence services in Europe, and as a base from which to watch its 100,000 citizens in Germany and to buy militarily useful technology and equipment.
The German determination to remain silent about the plot and expulsion underscores the vast difference in approach between the United States and Iran's major trading partners, which have refused to join the American economic embargo. They argue that the best means of changing Iran's behavior is to embrace it, rather than isolate it.
President Clinton acknowledged that difference in a news conference earlier this month when he said, "I don't know that we're on the same wave length" with the allies, adding, "the evidence is that constructive engagement with the Iranians has, at least so far, failed to produce any positive results."
Most of the allies would agree with the American case -- despite official denials in Teheran -- that Iran is positioning itself to become a nuclear power, building its arsenal of chemical weapons and ballistic missiles, undermining Middle East peace efforts, and supporting terrorist groups and acts worldwide.
But the Europeans and the Japanese contend that the United States, with its relentless name-calling and sweeping charges often without concrete proof, has tended to distort the Iranian threat for domestic political reasons, including a desire to neutralize an anti-Iranian Congress. There is also a strong perception abroad that the anti-Iranian stance of the United States reflects the increased influence of Israel in shaping American perceptions of Iran, at a time when Iran is strongly supporting terrorist groups determined to undermine Middle East peace talks.
Iran has done little to help the Europeans and Japanese justify their conciliatory approach, as shown most recently by Teheran's rejection on Thursday of an appeal from the 15 European Union nations to lift the death threat imposed against the novelist Salman Rushdie.
Early last week, when the German Government abruptly banned Mrs. Rajavi, the Iranian opposition leader, from entering Germany, officials explained that as the head of a movement determined to violently overthrow the Government of another country, she was not welcome.
But American intelligence officials concluded that there was another reason as well: the discovery by German intelligence that Iran's embassy in Bonn was assembling a team from the terrorist group the Party of God to violently disrupt the rally, and perhaps assassinate Mrs. Rajavi.
Since Germany has led the Europeans in defending what it calls a "critical dialogue" with Teheran that is based on high-level exchanges and efforts to boost trade, it is not surprising that German authorities have kept quiet about the alleged plot, but have clung to the official line.
"We cannot allow cause for the violent overthrow of a government from our own territory," said Sabine Sparwasser, a Foreign Ministry spokesman in Bonn. Asked whether Germany has asked for the expulsion of two Iranian diplomats, she added, "To my knowledge there have been no recent cases where we told Iranians from the embassy to leave."
Officials in the office of Bernd Schmidbauer, the intelligence coordinator for Chancellor Helmut Kohl and the senior German official involved in contacts with Iran, declined comment on any matter involving Iran. It was Mr. Schmidbauer who infuriated the Clinton Adminstration after he allowed Ali Fallahian, the head of Iran's intelligence services, to visit Germany in 1993, and tour intelligence headquarters in Wiesbaden.
Of all the arguments the Administration has made against Iran, its case that Iran supports terrorism has been the most difficult to make. That is because American officials say they are reluctant to disclose information that could reveal intelligence sources and methods in gathering the information and thus compromise the operations involved.

HEADLINE: As Rugged Vehicles Take to the Streets, Gas Prices Take Off

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Thanks in part to America's growing love affair with vans and big sport utility vehicles, demand for gasoline is rising across the nation, pushing prices to their highest levels since the Persian Gulf crisis in 1990.
In the last 10 years, the number of mini-vans, pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles sold in the United States has more than doubled, now accounting for more than 40 percent of all vehicles sold. And in general their gas mileage is much lower than that of the cars they are replacing. 
"The trend toward more powerful engines, the shift to trucks and greater luxury, has offset the technical gains that we've made in fuel economy," said John DeCicco, a senior associate for the American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy, a nonprofit research group that has become a lonely voice of conservation these days.
Along with other factors, like rising taxes and higher refining costs to comply with tighter environmental rules, the growing demand for gasoline has produced a sharp increase in prices, particularly in the last year. Across the nation, the average price of unleaded regular gasoline stood at $1.22 a gallon on June 9, the latest date for which figures are available, up 12 percent from $1.09 a year earlier.
Call it Cherokee madness or Bronco fever. One symptom is that many drivers say they are not concerned about the higher cost of driving; indeed, they are using their rugged vehicles not only for outings like camping trips but also for running errands and commuting.
"I haven't looked at gas mileage in the last five years," said Richard Meyersburg, as he had his hulking Chevrolet Suburban filled with Exxon Plus, the middle grade of gasoline, at $1.31 a gallon at the Exxon station in Tenafly, N.J. "It gets us up to our house in Vermont on one tank load. That's my barometer."
Mr. Meyersburg also uses his Suburban, a utility vehicle with a V8 engine, to commute each workday from Tenafly to Paterson, N.J., where he owns a plastics company. And he said he paid little attention to the price of gas.
He is not alone. "If we run out of regular they just pull up to the next grade and fill up," said Denise Pristera, the manager of the Exxon station. "They just want to hit the road."
The recent increase in prices has been the biggest since 1990 -- when a 23-cent jump was registered in the month after Iraq invaded Kuwait. But the cost of gasoline is still not high in historical terms. After adjusting for inflation, economists say, the cost is roughly the same as it was in the days before the oil shocks of the early 1970's, a time when the pump price was a little more than 30 cents a gallon, and far less than in 1981, when the average was $1.35.
Gasoline deliveries to retail stations, a good measure of motorists' demand, have been running about 4 percent higher than last year. In May, they were up more than 5 percent from the corresponding month of 1994.
The surge in demand is "inherently implausible," said Michael L. Canes, the chief economist for the American Petroleum Institute, the industry trade group that compiles the delivery figures. "Yet we've gone over the numbers and we haven't found a mistake," he said.
The American economy, considered healthy but not booming, is an unlikely source of increased demand. The normal seasonal increase in driving at this time of year, plus the small loss in fuel economy from the switch last January to reformulated gasoline, is not enough to account for such a jump, he said.
The only possible explanation, according to some oil industry economists, is Americans' growing use of sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and mini-vans. Sport utility vehicles sell at prices in the neighborhood of $30,000.
A recent survey by Allison-Fisher Inc., an automotive research firm in Southfield, Mich., asked car buyers to rank 20 factors in their buying decisions. Dependability was first. Fuel economy was last.
"They drive recreational vehicles for errands," said Theodore R. Eck, the chief economist for the Amoco Corporation. "They don't ask what the mileage is. They don't want to know what the price of gas is. They're looking for comfort, size and performance -- not mileage."
In the early 1970's, before the Arab oil embargo, average fuel economy was about 15 miles a gallon, as measured in laboratory tests used to calculate the mileage figures on the stickers of new cars and light trucks. The embargo in 1973, and the resulting price surges and long lines at gas stations, led to legislation that encouraged Detroit to change its ways. The Big Three auto makers began turning out smaller cars to compete with the importers that were rushing into the market, and fuel efficiency climbed. It peaked in 1988, at an average of 25.9 miles a gallon. By 1993, the last year for which data are available, it had slid to 25 miles a gallon.
Some studies have shown that under real driving conditions, the average is much lower, Mr. DeCicco said. For light trucks, which have a listed average of 20.5 miles a gallon, the real figure is closer to 16.5, he said. And for some of the big sport utility vehicles, it can be as low as 10 in stop-and-go driving.
The Clinton Administration and Congress have shown little willingness to push up the fuel economy standards or to penalize people who own less efficient vehicles with new taxes, although higher Federal and state taxes have accounted for about 2 cents of the price increases of the last year. And new legislation in Congress would end federally imposed speed limits, a change that could encourage higher-speed driving and further cut fuel efficiency.
While the price of gasoline, adjusted for inflation, is about the same as it was more than two decades ago, gasoline's share of driving costs has actually declined because of improvements in fuel economy. Mr. DeCicco said the cost of gasoline was now about 6 cents for every mile traveled, compared with 9 cents in 1973, after adjustment for inflation.
And these days, many owners of less-fuel-efficient vehicles say they gladly pay more for the pleasure of sitting high above the traffic and knowing they have four-wheel drive.
"It's perfect for my life style," said Stephen Wisniewski, a student at Rutgers University, as he filled up his red-and-gold Jeep Cherokee. He likes the extra room, the acceleration and the knowledge that he will not be stuck in the snow as he commutes from Cresskill, N.J., to school in New Brunswick. Though he watches the price of gasoline, he said, he would find it difficult to go back to a small car.
Arnold and Elda Zandonella of Tenafly own two Grand Cherokees -- a 1993 model and a 1988, which they once drove to Alaska. After driving the newer version to downtown Tenafly recently for a morning cup of coffee, Mrs. Zandonella gestured at a small Chrysler Neon on the street and said, "I couldn't see myself in one of those." As she spoke, three sport utility vehicles -- a Toyota Land Cruiser, an Isuzu Trooper and a Ford Explorer -- were parked nearby.
Her husband said of their two Jeeps: "They're built a little sturdier than cars. We feel safer in it because we sit higher up." He said he would start worrying about the price of gasoline only if it reached $2 to $3 a gallon.
Jim Kelly, a salesman for D & C Chevrolet-Geo-Honda of Tenafly, said that when customers looked at a vehicle like a Tahoe, a Chevrolet sport utility vehicle, they often ignored the sticker that says it gets 12 miles a gallon in city driving and 15 on the highway.
"They don't ask about the mileage," he said. "It's irrelevant to most of them."
Many buyers, he said, bought "muscle" cars like the Chevrolet Camaro in the 1960's and 70's. "Then they got married and had kids," he said, "and now they're buying sport utility vehicles."
The effect for most of the nation's gasoline refiners, which have seen higher costs in producing reformulated gasoline, is that they will keep running near capacity all summer to meet demand and build inventories.
Mr. Eck of Amoco predicted that gasoline supplies could tighten in July and August, but that they would remain adequate. As a result, he said, prices are likely to rise only a bit further later this summer.

HEADLINE: Gov. Wilson at Last Sets Out on the Campaign Trail, and It Looks Very Long

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: DENVER, June 24

 BODY:
Sidelined and silenced for more than two months by surgery for a benign throat growth, Gov. Pete Wilson of California finally hit the Presidential campaign trail this week, finding his voice but not much political footing.
Measured by most campaigning standards -- timing, organizing, fund-raising and, not least of all, every national poll -- it appears he has a lot of catching up to do if he is to win the Republican nomination. 
 "I can do it," was his insistent, optimistic mantra, delivered in a scratchy but improving monotone as he crisscrossed the country twice in seven wearing days of rallies, speeches and photo opportunities.
Perhaps.
But the polls indicate that thus far he has won over only two of every hundred Republican voters.
Political experts and party officials attribute that skimpy support, in part, to the fact that the Governor is a moderate running in a party dominated by conservatives. But they also say the Wilson campaign is sputtering because the Governor is off to an unusually late start, lagging badly in fund-raising, raggedly preparing for appearances and taking far too much time to set up campaign organizations in crucial states.
"People don't even know who he is yet or that he's out there, if he's out there, so he'd better get it together fast," said Ruth Griffin, the Republican national committeewoman in New Hampshire, scene of the nation's crucial first primary.
"The other candidates have been on the trail for months, some even for years," added Ms. Griffin, who has not yet sided with a candidate. "He's got his work cut out, and then some."
There was ample evidence of that in every state the Governor visited on his inaugural national swing, starting with Florida last weekend, then going on to Iowa and Texas and finally ending up here in Colorado and in New Hampshire this weekend. In between was an appearance on Larry King's television talk show, now one of the stations of all Presidential candidacies.
Only in Iowa, the first caucus state, did the Governor have a campaign organization fully in place, with office space rented, posters printed and campaign chairmen and volunteers signed up.
Elsewhere, there were a few chairmen and volunteers scattered about, but no formal campaign organizations.
Here in Denver, he boasted that he had obtained campaign money "pledges" around the country totaling more than $16 million. But aides said privately that only $4 million had actually been collected, far less than has been raised thus far by contenders like Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas and former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee.
And at many stops, Mr. Wilson seemed to miss opportunities to work crowds, either because of scheduling foul-ups or because he simply chose to ignore the opportunities, passing through hotel lobbies without reaching for a single hand and departing speech sites almost headlong, again without a single handshake or a hearty back slap.
In Florida -- a state where, unlike much of Dixie, Mr. Wilson's moderate Republicanism could have some political resonance -- his visit to Miami went all but unnoticed.
His airport arrival ceremony and remarks were overshadowed by a convention of the nation's mayors elsewhere in town. They got the headlines that day -- along with Senator Dole, who, unlike Mr. Wilson, put in an appearance at the convention.
"It looks like a ragged start, as well as a late start," said Mark Goodin, a Washington-based political consultant who is a veteran of many Republican campaigns but is not involved in any of the current ones.
"The Governor can still recover," Mr. Goodin added, "because a lot of people still haven't focused on the race, and he's a savvy old pro who hails from the state with the most delegates and the most money. But he's going to have to get down in the trenches -- and stay there -- and start reaching for those hands and slapping those backs. California politicians are used to relying on television for campaigning, because the state is so big and diverse. That won't work in relatively small states like Iowa and New Hampshire -- and you have to do well in Iowa and New Hampshire."
Mr. Wilson acknowledged as much today in Portsmouth, N.H. Rather than work the back rooms and the reception circuit, his usual campaigning mode and one at which he is a master, he hit the pavement for a change, meeting and greeting in the city's streets, reaching for hands, slapping backs, retailing himself. If he did not bring a Lyndon Johnson-like zest to pressing the flesh, he nevertheless pressed on doggedly, at last doing what has to be done.
But then the Governor, in a move not likely to get him much political mileage in New England, demanded that President Clinton discard recommendations made this week by the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission.
The commission on Friday called for closing the Long Beach naval shipyard in California, a major blow to the already-struggling economy in Mr. Wilson's home state, which has taken the hardest hit from the military downsizing that has followed the end of the cold war. But to the surprise and relief of New Englanders, the commission did not call for closing the shipyard at Portsmouth, whose economy has also struggled in recent years.
"Don't get me wrong," Mr. Wilson added hastily as reporters began peppering him with questions about base-closing policy. "I think that Portsmouth should remain open too and that the whole situation should be restudied."
While the polls indicate that Mr. Wilson is still a little-known political quantity nationally, with more than half of all Republicans saying they do not know enough about him to have an opinion, he is not alone in that regard. And therein lies his 1996 strategy, his aides say.
"The only candidate who has thus far broken from the pack in the polls is Bob Dole," said Craig Fuller, Mr. Wilson's campaign manager. "That means second place is up for grabs, and we intend to grab it. We think we can more than hold our own early on in Iowa and New Hampshire and in places like Florida, Arizona, Colorado, New York and so forth. If Dole hasn't broken totally clear by then -- and we don't think he will have -- people will start looking for an alternative. That's Pete Wilson. Then it's on to California -- our state, the big one."
Wilson aides say the Governor will make a major push to get on the ballot in New York, the second-richest delegate purse, despite the expensive, labor-intensive petition effort required and despite the fact that Mr. Dole has already won the support of most of the leading Republican figures in the state.
Although the Wilson campaign was troubled this week with organizational and other campaign details, the message delivered by the candidate was cohesive and consistent, maybe not every Republican's ideological meat but nevertheless well thought out and well delivered, albeit in a voice still a bit scratchy.
The pitch: balance the budget, cut back welfare, enforce the death penalty, eliminate affirmative action, stop illegal immigration, defend a woman's right to abortion.
Will the message sell?
"Now that I've finally heard him, I'm willing to listen some more," Eldon Pridre, a retired oil jobber, said after the Governor addressed a meeting of Rotarians in Waterloo, Iowa. "It's early yet in the race, and he's got some catching up to do. I'm not sure he's mine. But I'm listening."

HEADLINE: Technological Curve Ball for Cuomo

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 24

 BODY:
Mario M. Cuomo, an Old World politician who has always preferred the ballpoint pen to the word processor, was haunted by technological demons today during the three-hour premiere of his live call-in radio show.
Three times during a half-hour interview, the show managed to cut off the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, a man whom Mr. Cuomo described as "possibly the next President of the United States of America." Mr. Dole finally got back on the air in time to announce, "I'm going to have to go." 
 At least outwardly, Mr. Cuomo remained calm throughout the dead air and screeching feedback that punctuated the second hour of his show. When "Emanuel" called to congratulate Mr. Cuomo on his new show, the former Governor responded drily, "Thank you very much. I hope someone out there can hear it."
A caller named Simon phoned to comment: "Sounds like you've got Dan Quayle running your phones over there."
The syndicated weekly program, a hodgepodge of Cuomo commentaries, celebrity interviews and debates with callers and faxers, is designed to present Mr. Cuomo as a liberal counterweight to conservative radio talk-show hosts like Rush Limbaugh and G. Gordon Liddy. It is broadcast from 9 A.M. to noon on about 20 stations, including WABC-AM in New York City.
The former Governor, who served three terms before losing last year to George E. Pataki, held forth on a wide variety of issues, from taxes and welfare to baseball and foreign aid. At one point, he took time out to pay homage to his mother, Immaculata Cuomo, and his mother-in-law, Mary Raffa, both of whom died in recent weeks.
Mr. Cuomo's strength on the radio, as in the Governor's office, was the power of his logic. His tone was measured and nonconfrontational, and his callers were mostly polite.
But Mr. Cuomo also quickly discovered the hazards of live radio. Taking his first call, he was ambushed by a fan of the radio host Howard Stern. Mr. Cuomo's second caller attacked him by using an Italian word for "lowlife."
And on occasion, Mr. Cuomo confronted the kind of hostility that had become familiar during the call-in shows he did while in office. One caller, Jim from Washington, an affirmative-action opponent, called to say that he was unemployed because he was a white male.
"You know what you need, what white males need, what black males need, what white females need, what black females need?" Mr. Cuomo asked Jim. "Jobs."
Jim responded: "The jobs are out there. They're not being given to qualified people. You were a big supporter of these big liberal left-wing policies that ruined New York State."
More than anything, however, Mr. Cuomo's debut was marred by the technical failures that undermined the coup of attracting Mr. Dole as an opening guest.
As a caller named Roy tried to ask Mr. Dole a question about why the Republican Party had "become so extreme," the call was interrupted by feedback.
Mr. Dole: "My view is that. . . ."
(Silence)
Mr. Cuomo: "You lost him. Hello. Don't tell me that Roy was able to dislodge Senator Dole, was he?"
A bit later, Mr. Cuomo tried to put Mr. Dole on the line with James from Cedar Rapids.
James: "Yes, I have a question for the Senator."
Mr. Cuomo: "Good."
James: "And congratulations on your show, Governor."
Mr. Cuomo: "Thank you, thank you very much. What's your question?"
(Silence)
Mr. Cuomo: "O.K., hello. Well, this is new equipment. I hope it came with a warranty. Either that, or people are going to be suing me for breach of promise."

HEADLINE: At a Base in New Jersey, The Time for Denial Is Over

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

DATELINE: BAYONNE, N.J., June 24

 BODY:
For Lori Starke, who has been an office worker at the sprawling Military Ocean Terminal here for two decades, the specter of the base's closure has been in the air for so long that "it was almost something you didn't think about if you didn't think too hard."
But when she learned yesterday that a Federal commission had recommended shutting down the base -- meaning that the Army might pull out as soon as the end of the summer if President Clinton and Congress accept the plan -- she felt as if she had been told a friend died. 
 "I thought, 'Well, this is finally it -- no more denying,' " said Ms. Starke, her eyes red-rimmed, as she drove through the base's gates to finish some work. "I just looked at my girlfriend and my eyes filled up with tears. I couldn't believe it."
For the base's 2,183 civilian employees like Ms. Starke and the 172 military personnel stationed there, the news that the commission had voted for its closure was accepted with resignation yesterday and only a glimmer of the hope that residents had held for months that some political miracle might save the base.
A statement issued by the commander of the base, which has shipped tanks, trucks and crates of ammunition to battlefields around the world, was already attempting to prepare workers for what seemed to be the inevitable. "It's not an easy decision to close an installation," the statement from Brig. Gen. Boyd E. King said. "It is a painful process for the people working and living on the base and their families as well as the local community."
June Pagan, a spokeswoman for the base, said that about 300 base employees whose sole function is to keep the Army garrison on the base running -- like food workers, patrol officers and maintenance workers -- would be hit the hardest if the base closes, because there are no plans to transfer them to other bases.
Others, like Ms. Starke, whose office keeps track of shipments of everything from Christmas trees and cars to M-1 tanks from the terminal, may be transferred to Fort Monmouth in Monmouth County or to other bases around the country.
"I can't say for sure that I'd want to go to someplace like North Carolina, but I would if I had to," Ms. Starke said. "At least I'm probably guaranteed a job. What about those other people who have kids in school and house payments?"
Several base employees and residents said they had seen the writing on the wall for several years as shipments of items like military cars to ports in Germany dropped from more than 700 several years ago to just a little more than 100 recently. And they said that the downsizing of the military and the base seemed to reflect the shrinking economy in Bayonne itself, where the base is the largest employer.
But not everyone in Bayonne will mourn the base's passing. The Mayor of the city, Leonard P. Kiczek (pronounced KIH-check), has maintained that the waterfront land on which the terminal sits, with its sweeping views of the Manhattan skyline, could provide more of a boost to the city if the land was turned over to private developers. While the Mayor's position made his name anathema to base employees, the idea has its supporters.
"I would like to see something nice down there eventually, maybe a terminal for cruises or a golf course," said Ray Fiuza, a research technician for General Foods who was getting a shave in the Roma Barber Shop on Broadway several blocks from the base. "Bayonne needs it."
But Mr. Fiuza and others, like Carmine Salerno, who owns the 33rd Street Market down the street from the barber shop, are also wary that the land may attract the kind of development that Bayonne residents will not be able to afford. "Everybody's afraid that somebody's going to come in and put up expensive town houses and advertise the view and only rich people are going to be able to pay to live there," Mr. Fiuza said. "And then what happens? Bayonne loses twice."
