HEADLINE: Excerpts From Giuliani Interview

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an interview with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in his City Hall office on Friday, as recorded by The New York Times.
Q. Do you believe that you encounter opposition at every turn when you try to change things like the budget and the schools? 
 A. Different degrees. Yes. The answer is yes, but the opposition on the budget and the economy is much less than on the school system. And there is much more understanding of the changes that have to be made.
I think we've changed the agenda on the budget and economy of the city. The questions now asked are the questions that we wanted to be asked. How much do we have to reduce, not how much more do we spend. Where can we find the savings? How can we put more money back into the private sector? How can we stimulate business?
We can disagree about the scope of that, but I believe that we've changed the agenda in the last two budgets on how budgets are dealt with in New York City. . . .
Q. You mentioned last week that you have to take on the establishment. Could you give a little more detail on who that is? Bureaucrats? Democratic interests?
A. No, no. Budget politics is much more partisan political: Democrats, Republicans, liberal, conservative. Because a lot of people define themselves that way based on how they think money should be spent and the need they see for a balanced budget or the need they see for more spending, social issues. Educational politics, I think, is a much more bureaucratic politics. Are you connected to the system? Sometimes I think when you get into that system it has like an illogic of its own. . . .
The Chancellor -- this was my first bit of advice to him -- made a crucial mistake in surrounding himself and steeping himself in that bureaucracy. Near the end he brought in some people like Barry Sullivan, a few others.
But you need a group, in a bureaucracy that large, of 10, 20, maybe 30 people who are your people, so that your pronouncement of direction doesn't immediately get undercut. The minute you do that, you become controversial. The bureaucracy rises up against you. They leak things on you. They try to do, they try to stop you. Because they've been there for a long time, they like the direction of the agency, they don't want it turned in a new direction.
And before you take a job like that, you have to know that you can withstand that kind of pressure. That your satisfaction is going to come in maybe looking back on it three, four, five years later and knowing, gee, I turned this place around. I was the the one -- if you're the Chancellor -- I was the one who finally got school-based budgeting. And whether they understand the significance of this now or they understand it four or five years from now, this will be a great contribution. I think that's how someone who is a reformer thinks, feels.
Q. But to get that reform, why is it necessary to challenge the power structures, like the Council, the Assembly, and now the board, rather than actually working with them? So many times we see you being critical of those groups rather than trying to work closely with them.
A. That isn't right, though. Almost everything that I've achieved, I've achieved by getting other people to agree that this is what had to be done. Very often people who started off disagreeing with me. I didn't pass two budgets on my own. That required a lot of work, a lot of compromise. It required taking the heat for proposing a lot of cuts, many of which didn't take place, but I was willing to take that heat.
Maybe when I proposed them I knew they wouldn't take place. But I knew I had to create that movement, that cover, in order to get it done. But I think, you know, after 17, 18, 19 months, people should look at the results and maybe to a large extent it works.
We brought about more change in the last 18 months than this city has had in a very long time. We've made virtually, quantitatively, the same changes that it took an outside monitor to accomplish in the mid-1970's and there's no way you could do that without controversy. It just can't happen. You can't take two, three, four billion dollars out of a budget without major controversy.
Now that we've accomplished that, and we've done it now four times, there should at least be some recognition that we can compromise, we can work with people. . . .
Q. Isn't there any room for political consensus with your opponents, as opposed to the unusually confrontational incidents that frequently occur with people who stand in your way?
A. I think there sometimes are confrontations. Most of them get resolved. And then nobody pays attention to the resolution of them. . . . If you are proposing things, and there are a significant group of political figures in the city who have consistently throughout their career opposed doing these things, they're going to oppose you when you do it.
Some of it then you can achieve by maybe proposing more of it than you really need and then stepping back. So you create a victory for them. But you're not going to get there and you never have politically -- politics is not all about harmony, it isn't all about -- specifically when you're going through an era of change and difficulty.
But I think if you look at the resolutions of most of these things they've ended up being harmonious. They've ended up being an agreement that we were able to reach eventually on what we needed. But I know that if I've got to take a billion dollars out of the budget, I can't start with taking a billion dollars out of the budget, I've got to start somewhere beyond that.
And I've got to challenge things. That's going to get a certain group of people angry at me politically. It doesn't mean we don't have a realization that we have to also then retreat to a position in which we can get it done. And I think if you are changing things, if you want to call it being a reformer, you take the heat for that.
Q. But aren't there ways in which you use controversy and criticism to get headlines and attention to the issues you're pushing? For instance, you must have been aware of the effect on the Chancellor of some of the very personal criticisms you made.
A. I'm a Republican Mayor in a city that is heavily Democratic and with at least one house of the Legislature that's heavily Democratic. Very often I have been bipartisan in my approach in order to bring over Democrats who support me. I supported the crime bill, supported Mario Cuomo, supported the assault weapon ban. I do that to try to get Democrats to then reach over to create the degree of support that you need to do the important things that have to be done.
Important things meaning the budget, the significant legislation that we passed. We passed more legislation in the City Council in my first year by an enormous factor as compared to David Dinkins in his first year, and that was a Democratic Mayor with a Democratic City Council.
So I think, I think that people aren't looking below the surface. The fact is that at times in order for me to build up public support, I've got to make the dispute public. I've got to try to get public opinion to work on the people that oppose a particular kind of change to see that maybe some of where they are has now changed. . . .
With the Chancellor, I don't -- I tried, I mean, I tried very hard to work with him. We would reach agreements on direction and then we would go back to the board and it would change. And the only way in which I could get my agenda out front was to go public with it. Otherwise I was going to sit here being blamed for their failures and there was nothing I could do about it.
Q. But often what people remember are not policy disputes but personal moments, such as your telling a 63-year-old man to grow up. That's the kind of thing that sticks in people's mind and I presume it sticks in his mind. Do you ever think back on the situation and wish that it had stayed at the policy level?
A. Sure. I wish I could have accomplished this internally. I wish I could have accomplished it in a way in which the Chancellor and I had a similar game plan which we would have when we met together and then he would stick to that because what he would have found if he did that was a Mayor who would support him. And would be there for him, and would fight for him. But what would happen is, we'd agree on what we were going to do and then he'd go back and give it back to the bureaucracy. And I only had certain options then. With the agencies I control I have different options. With the agencies I don't control, the only options that I have are to try to get public opinion turned around. And to try to persuade the person to move it in the right direction.

HEADLINE: A Shrinking Military Casts Long Shadows

 BODY:
Post-cold war reductions in the defense industry are hitting home in Bayonne, N.J., and Groton, Conn., where military jobs are a vital part of the local economies. Residents of Bayonne are coming to terms with the looming demise of the Military Ocean Terminal and its 2,183 civilian jobs. And even as employees of General Dynamics celebrated the launch of a new nuclear submarine in Groton, they expressed worry about the prospect of lost jobs at the shipyard, where 14,500 people work.

HEADLINE: Cortines Says He Quit Because Giuliani Forced a Choice Between Two Leaders

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

 BODY:
Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines ultimately decided to resign because Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was asking New Yorkers to make a choice between two leaders trying to repair the schools.
The city was asked "to choose between one R or another R," Rudy or Ray, Mr. Cortines said in a wide-ranging hourlong interview on Friday. 
 But, he said, "I don't bear him any hard feelings."
Beyond that, Mr. Cortines was reluctant to talk about their relationship, and the bruising and increasingly personal criticism that the Mayor had leveled at him in recent weeks, calling him weak, ineffective and "precious."
"He's my Mayor," Mr. Cortines said as he sat very still in his office. "I worked for him."
Later, he added, "I recognize the most difficult job in this city is being mayor, especially in these economic times."
Mr. Cortines described himself in the interview as a "sensitive person," but also said that he was thick-skinned enough for New York's raucous politics. "I've been accused of not being political," he said. "I'm extremely political. I just don't politicize every aspect of education."
When students asked him why he was leaving, "I said I've done as much as I can do," Mr. Cortines said.
The Chancellor was eager to talk about the successes in the schools and what remained to be done. Animated and passionate, he paced back and forth as he spoke, his voice rising as he described the system's potential.
He will continue speaking out on national education issues after leaving office in October, he said, but would not say where or how. He hinted that he might remain in New York, though he has three homes in California. He said he had received several job offers, but was not interested in any of them.
His mission in New York, he said, was simple: to emphasize teaching and learning in a system hampered by social and economic ills.
When he first came to New York, he said, he saw a bureaucracy that "had lost its focus." Administrators, and even some principals and teachers, had forgotten "that they are here to serve the schools."
Administrators in the central bureaucracy were hoarding information, he said, and principals were reluctant to report problems at their schools.
"Information in this system heretofore has always been a way to get someone," Mr. Cortines said. "And it's been a way to get rid of people."
One of his biggest accomplishments, he said, is that he helped make education the talk of the town. "What I've created in this system that people dislike is I have put education on the front burner in everybody's mind," Mr. Cortines said. "Everybody. You can't escape it. You can't go anyplace in this city and now people don't have an opinion."
He said that to repair the school system -- allowing parents and teachers to "take ownership" of schools -- the chancellor's office needed to highlight not only successes but also failures. He cited the arrests on Friday of a teacher accused of exposing himself, another accused of extorting $300 for a passing grade and a school safety officer charged with rape.
Mr. Cortines said he had demanded more honest reporting of school data, from test scores to dropout rates. He also created an atmosphere, he said, in which people inside the system, and parents, felt they had the right to criticize.
He said he has visited almost 300 of the city's 1,100 schools in less than two years, usually unannounced. Before each visit, he said, he consulted a report of vital statistics on each school that his staff puts together monthly.
The unannounced visits initially put fear in the principals, he said.
"The word would get around, 'Hey, the old man knows what your school looks like,' " he said.
Mr. Cortines said he would maintain the same pace during the next four months. He will continue working to cut the budget, a process that he said has hurt children. He will oversee the loss and replacement of 3,000 to 4,000 teachers and administrators who could take advantage of an early retirement plan.
He said he would continue to try to work with the Mayor. As an example, he pointed to his willingness to share the stage Friday during an awards ceremony for the Division of School Safety, which Mr. Giuliani wants the Police Department to take over.
Mr. Cortines received a standing ovation when he arrived at the auditorium at Murry Bergtraum High School in lower Manhattan. Mr. Giuliani was late, so the organizers told Mr. Cortines to deliver his speech. He got another ovation when he finished and left the auditorium, but he never saw Mr. Giuliani.
"I would have waited if he had been on time," Mr. Cortines said.
He learned during the interview that Mr. Giuliani had arrived during the Chancellor's remarks, but had stayed backstage until Mr. Cortines left.
"I didn't know that," Mr. Cortines said after a brief stunned silence. With the tiniest of shrugs, he said: "He's my Mayor."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In an interview on Friday, Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines said he quit because he thought Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was asking New Yorkers to decide which leader to support in the effort to save the city's schools. It was a choice "between one R or another R" -- Rudy or Ray, he said. (Linda Rosier/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 1995 STANLEY CUP FINALS;
It's All Quiet On One Devils Front

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE 

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 24

 BODY:
With the Devils clinching the Stanley Cup tonight, some of their players and management figures will enjoy more media exposure as celebrities.
But it's hard to envision Lou Lamoriello, their president and general manager, making the rounds of television shows to bask in the limelight. Imagine Lamoriello sitting in a chair at "The Late Show," answering David Letterman's wise-guy questions. 
 Lamoriello might charm the studio audience and the national viewership with a cold stare and responses of: "Dave, I don't think that's any of your business" or "Look, I don't want to discuss that in public" or "I really don't think that's very funny" or "What's that supposed to mean?"
Certainly, Lamoriello deserves plenty of credit for the Devils winning their first cup tonight in Game 4, beating the the Detroit Red Wings by 5-2 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.
Having reached the National Hockey League's final four three times in his eight years with the Devils, Lamoriello has shown the ability to recognize various streams of talent across the expanded hockey world and to mold it into one winning unit. An American from a college background, an unusual combination in his business, Lamoriello has 12 United States-born players on his 25-man roster, the most in the league. One of the first teams to aggressively recruit from Russia, Lamoriello's Devils generally dress three or four Europeans on their 20-man squad on game nights. In a league in which French-Canadian players are noticeably rare on some rosters, Lamoriello has three star players from Quebec and a head coach and an assistant coach from that province.
So why is a man so open-minded and so successful so reviled by so many? Could it be the hard-ball approach in contract negotiations that sometimes backfires and costs him extra salary payments, as it did in the case of Scott Stevens and as it will in the case of Martin Brodeur?
Could it be a management style that keeps employees timid and creates turnover in top positions? Could it be a marketing strategy that has yielded relatively low attendance until this year and a business plan that may include an imminent departure for Nashville? Could it be his dealings with local news media figures, some of whom trade support for gift-wrapped scoops but rarely get them from Lamoriello?
Consider the broadcasted opinions of Mike Francesa, a radio commentator who co-hosts "Mike and the Mad Dog" weekday afternoons on station WFAN in New York. One of the metropolitan area's important opinion-makers in sports circles, Francesa discussed Lamoriello Friday afternoon on the air when the Devils were on the verge of a Cup championship.
He called Lamoriello "an absolute clown" who is "never truthful," and he called his front-office operation "inept."
"It's a terribly run, paranoid and small-minded organization," Francesa said. "It's the worst organization I have ever dealt with."
This sort of opinion rankles Lamoriello's friends. One of them, the Rev. Thomas R. Peterson, is the chancellor of Seton Hall.
"I would say Lou is just the opposite," Peterson said, referring to Francesa's remarks. "Lou cares about people. Lou is not someone who will show great emotion. He doesn't wear his feelings on his sleeve. But he is a sensitive man, a man of great commitment, great honesty and great integrity."
Peterson first met Lamoriello when Lamoriello was a student at Providence College, and he later elevated Lamoriello from hockey coach to athletic director there. Lamoriello said Peterson is one of several Dominican priests who have been a major influence on his adult life.
"The philosophy of the Dominicans is discipline," Lamoriello said.
Peterson recalled Lamoriello as a diligent pupil in his sophomore ethics class where he tried to teach "a sense of values and of moral commitment." Lamoriello, Peterson said, is from "a fine Italian family" that stressed "family values."
But Lamoriello isn't one for discussing his family or his values or much of anything else. Although the media guide lists him as married and the father of three children, he lived alone in a hotel room near Byrne Arena for many seasons before moving to a private residence.
He said family matters are private, although he did briefly discuss his parents and his upbringing in Providence, R.I. His father was in the fish business and both parents were hockey fans. They took him to minor league games of the Rhode Island Reds. "They carried me in," Lamoriello said. "I was there before I could reach the knob on the door."
Lou became a stick boy for the team at the age of 6, he said. He later played baseball and hockey in college and moved up through the ranks.
But even a cordial one-hour interview with an accommodating Lou Lamoriello seems less like a conversation than the interrogation of a witness in a courtroom. Trying to explain his unease, Lamoriello said, "I find it uncomfortable to sit and talk like this." After another uncomfortable pause, he added: "One of the words I dislike is 'I.' "
Balding, with white hair at the temples and thick, darker eyebrows, Lamoriello, at the age of 52, still has the sturdy build and determined stride of the ex-athlete. He dresses in dark, conservative clothing.
He sat in a desk in an office that showed few personal touches. The most striking of them was a poster of Vince Lombardi behind him, over his head. In large letters alongside Lombardi's picture were the words "What it takes to be No. 1."
"I was an admirer of his fortitude and discipline," Lamoriello said.
As the conversation came into focus, Lamoriello's philosophy emerged not in spontaneous banter but in Lombardi-like pronouncements. "What I have is a line in what I do," Lamoriello said. "I'm the only one who knows what the line is. I don't move the line."
In college, he majored in math and economics. He presents himself as one who calculates. "This is a competitive business," he said. "The edge is important. It's important you keep the edge inside and not outside. You know what the edge is, not the other people.
"You don't talk to get accolades. Then it's no longer an edge. Your strengths can hurt you. If you have a problem, handle it internally, not externally. Don't be afraid to make a mistake. Always live for today, but never lose focus on tomorrow. Tomorrow comes awfully quick."
He said he is suspicious of flattery, even in the best of times. "You never know why they say it," Lamoriello said, "or what their reasons are for saying it."
When asked what he does for relaxation, Lamoriello replied, "I used to go to the movies," and "I used to read a lot of war books," and "I used to play golf," and "I used to fish."
During the 15-week lockout of the players that delayed the season, Lamoriello was one of the tough-talking spokesmen on Gary Bettman's bargaining team. "I enjoyed being part of it during a time that was a dark time," Lamoriello said. "It was a necessary evil."
Bob Goodenow, the executive director of the players association, said Lamoriello firmly believes in much of what he says. "I found him to really stake out his position and not be very flexible," Goodenow said. "He has some different perspectives from other general managers."
Brian Burke, a former player for Lamoriello at Providence, is now the N.H.L.'s senior vice president and director of operations, second in power only to Commissioner Gary Bettman.
"He still knows I'll tell him what I think," Lamoriello said.
Another friend is Steve Ryan, the former president of N.H.L. Enterprises Inc., the league's marketing arm. A management consultant, Ryan said Lamoriello doesn't fit into "a preconceived mold everyone wants him to fit into."
"He's his own individual," Ryan said. "Coming out of the college ranks, Lou's perspective and methods and style are different. He doesn't want to be one of the boys."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Devils General Manager Lou Lamoriello does know how to laugh. (Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Yanks Getting in Shape And Can See Sox Again

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH 

 BODY:
The Boston Red Sox, showing their Achilles' heel to the rest of the American League East in recent weeks, had to wonder if any team was willing to take advantage of their struggles.
The Yankees finally are sending quiet signals that they may be ready to respond to the opening being left by the East leaders. 
 Yesterday the Yankees used the arm of Melido Perez and 11 hits -- five of them doubles -- to topple Toronto, 10-2. The victory increased their winning streak to a modest three games, equaling a season high. It is the fourth time this season that the Yankees have won three straight, but the other sets of three came in the team's first 14 games. The last time the Yankees won that many in a row was May 10-12.
More important than the little streak is the larger trend: the team is 8-5 since June 11, a noticeable turn of fortune for a team still trying to find the .500 mark.
It is also a spurt that has given the third-place Yankees hope, because it has enabled the club to whittle three and a half games off Boston's once formidable lead. The Red Sox, losers of 6 of 10, were to play at Baltimore last night. Their lead over New York was reduced to seven games with the Yankees' latest victory.
"I think our players understand the sense of urgency each game brings, especially with the number of games we are behind," Yankees Manager Buck Showalter said. "There's just not much margin for error. Trends only happen when you make them happen on the field, not because they're perceived as such."
Dion James, who collected two of the Yankees' hits and drove in three runs, said: "We're swinging the bats a lot better, but you never want to say you've turned the corner until you've turned the corner. Let's just say we're playing better."
The Jays are not, having lost a season-high five straight and giving the Yankees a chance to win four straight for the first time since an eight-game winning streak from July 29 to Aug. 5 of last season.
"Thank God we're playing somebody on a downswing," Wade Boggs said. "I'm tired of being a punching bag."
Toronto's Juan Guzman might say the same thing. The Blue Jays right-hander was rocked early and often, by the Yankees and his own defense. He allowed four runs in the third, two of them unearned, thanks to a pair of errors, one committed by Guzman himself.
Four hits also helped New York in that inning. The first, a single, was delivered by the sizzling Bernie Williams, his 16th hit in 11 games. A Luis Polonia single and Guzman's bobble of a Wade Boggs's comebacker loaded the bases with one out. James's single scored one run, and a throwing error by left fielder Joe Carter allowed a second run to score.
Paul O'Neill then continued his run-producing binge by depositing a two-run double into right field. The runs batted in brought O'Neill's two-game total against Toronto to five. He has six r.b.i. in six games.
Guzman stepped into more trouble of his own making an inning later. He opened by loading the bases with a walk, a hit batsman and an infield single by Polonia. Boggs, facing two strikes, emptied the bases with a double into the left-field corner, the first of two doubles he would hit yesterday.
"It was just nice to contribute," said Boggs, who now has six doubles. "In that situation, you're looking to get the ball into the air, maybe get a sacrifice fly. With three fast guys on the bases, they all have a chance to score."
When Mike Stanley added a run-scoring double in the fifth, the Yankees had eight runs on eight hits, an economy of effort especially appreciated by Perez, the Yankees starter.
"It's a great feeling because I can play with the batters," said Perez, who is 5-4 after having allowed only two runs in six innings, one on a home run to Carter in the second.
The Yankees' final run scored on an eighth-inning single by Don Mattingly, the first baseman's 1,000th hit in Yankee Stadium. He then left the game for a pinch-runner, to a standing ovation.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Knicks Need a Coach To Stay on Sidelines

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
WE really need to stop obsessing about the coach around here. It isn't the Or Else predicament people think it is. At least it doesn't have to be. Nowhere is it written that the Knicks must have a Pat Riley or a Chuck Daly on the bench. Rudy Tomjanovich is the two-time defending coaching champion of professional basketball, remember?
A year ago, Jerry Buss was scribbling zeros all over his contract offer to Rick Pitino. Buss wanted someone sexy to coach his Los Angeles Lakers. He settled for dull Del Harris, who, after being dismissed in Milwaukee several years before, circulated a personal brochure, which was the closest he had come to being colorful, like Daly, or published, like Riley. 
 Hiring Harris hasn't turned out badly for Buss. The focus shifted back to the players at the Great Western Forum, where even the stars of screen returned for the exciting Nick Van Exel and the versatile Vlade Divac and the promising rookie Eddie Jones. That's what the Knicks now need, an infusion of young talent and a coach whose ego will allow the players to emerge.
"I didn't mind it always being Pat Riley and the Knicks," Dave Checketts, president of Madison Square Garden, said the day Riley quit. He should have. It wasn't all Riley's fault because there was no charismatic star, but for every day Riley was in New York, he was Hootie and the Knicks were his Blowfish. As well as Riley did, as close as he came to winning it all, the proportion of attention, of credit, was ridiculously out of whack.
We have been conditioned for too many years by the Garden's coach-hiring practices, to the point where we tend to read the equation for success backward, from right to left. The solid organization that makes judicious personnel decisions equals opportunity for intelligent coaches. Riley didn't invent himself. Less than a decade ago, Phil Jackson was making hotel wake-up calls to his Albany Patroons and lamenting his slim chances of landing a job in the National Basketball Association because he didn't have a rabbi in the league. Now, as Michael Jordan and Scottie Pippen's threepeat shepherd, he is a certified genius in suspenders. I knew him when.
Hubie Brown. Pitino. Riley. Fred Shero. Herb Brooks. Mike Keenan. Add up all the millions tossed at high-profile coaches -- the hot men of the moment -- by the Garden the last 15 years, and you get one Stanley Cup. That soon-to-be-jilted sports complex, the Meadowlands, is about to match the Garden's output, and its championship architect is the eminently unglamorous Jacques Lemaire.
Though he hasn't won anything yet, and may not be around long enough to, I can still see Buck Showalter shivering in the Yankee clubhouse, cheeks pink and raw, on a snowy opening night five years ago in Cleveland. Showalter was a grateful eye in the sky then. Who knew he would soon be the best Yankee manager since Dick Howser and Billy Martin I?
You can't buy chemistry, and you can't just proclaim the start of a new era, a 10-year run by some anointed savior who has no idea of what he's getting himself into. That would be nothing more than a public-relations cliche. The Knicks are an aging team in transition. They need a stable, organization guy who is not interested in power and resume building, who will not turn adversarial on Checketts and Grunfeld the way Brown turned on Dave DeBusschere, Pitino on Al Bianchi, Riley on anyone who didn't carry his book to church.
They need a coach who won't lose it when the time comes -- perhaps as soon as next winter -- for the Knicks to consider moving Patrick Ewing before it is too late.
Don Nelson, the most distinguished name on the unemployment list, may have been humbled by his Golden State flameout, but that doesn't mean the Ego Entrapped has been excised. Nelson has never had an All-Star center, so he would probably want to keep Ewing, whether it was right for the organization or not. If only Nelson could bring some of the smaller gems he has coached. Tim Hardaway. Mitch Richmond. Sidney Moncrief. The Knicks need players like that much more than they need a famous coach.
All you have to know about Nelson is this: When he first encountered trouble with Chris Webber, he called his old coach, Red Auerbach, for advice. That's like shopping for the latest in computer technology by going on an archaeological dig.
Auerbach to Nelson: "Tell him you'll trade him to Fort Wayne!"
Whom should Checketts hire? He's in Utah this weekend, perhaps trying to talk his old friend Rick Majerus into taking the leap from college to the pros. Chris Ford, late of Boston, has no box-office appeal but is an N.B.A. career guy who was a head coach in declining conditions for unstable ownership in a city that thinks big. Whomever the coach eventually is, here's the point: He's not indispensable. There have been a lot more Knick coaching saviors than there have been rings.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Former Celtics Coach Chris Ford lacks glamour, and that may make him a better fit for the Knicks than some better-known coaches. (Tim Defrisco/Allsport)

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

SECURITIES FRAUD
 
Crash Landing for Brennan
"Come grow with us," the ads said, and Robert Brennan's trademark helicopter hammered home the idea that First Jersey Securities, his penny-stock firm, could transform mere mortals into high fliers. For a decade, though, the S.E.C. has tried to prove that Mr. Brennan and his brokers did all the growing, while customers' accounts did a vanishing act. Mr. Brennan held them off, with one delay coming after he named a horse after a judge and the irate judge quit the case for fear of seeming biased. And all the while he built his sports empire, and his reputation as a philanthropist. But the S.E.C. kept at him, and last week Mr. Brennan's charmed life crashed into a wall: a Federal judge ruled that Mr. Brennan and his firm had engaged in "a massive and continuing fraud" and imposed damages of at least $71.5 million.
 
PUBLIC SPEAKING
 
What's That, Mr. Greenspan?
Clarity is a rare and wondrous thing. It sparkles. It illuminates. It sends all doubt scurrying to life's dusty, cobwebbed corners. So Alan Greenspan, one of the most powerful humans alive, avoids it like the plague. "I worry incessantly that I might be too clear," he said last week. Don't you worry yourself about that, Mr. Greenspan; you didn't even come close. The Federal Reserve chairman -- who could move the financial markets with a mistimed cough -- had just given a Big Speech with an unmistakable message: The Federal Reserve might lower interest rates in early July, or it might not. The economy might slip into a mild recession, or it might not. And to make his calculated obfuscation complete, he stated unequivocally that July's rate-setting meeting would be "most engaging." Any questions?
 
THEME PARKS
 
In Orlando, Real Mice
When you think of Disney and animals, you think of a grossly overworked mouse, an adorable lion or some ridiculous number of Dalmatians. Disney wants to change that, in its usual oversized way. Last week it announced plans for a Wild Animal Kingdom, at 500 acres its largest park yet, right in the thick of Disney World. It'll be a habitat for more than 1,000 animals, some of them endangered, and untold thousands of humans, all hot and grumpy. Disney overflowed with talk about preserving species and educating the public about wildlife. But if that sounds too educational, don't worry: one section will be devoted to mythical beasts, like unicorns, and another to extinct ones. (Are Disney's magicians off somewhere busily turning ancient amber into velociraptors?) As one observer put it, "They can say all they want, but this park is to make money."
 
THE DONALD
 
Did He Lose a Gold Sled?
Donald Trump has this thing about gold. It's as if he fancies himself some latter-day Midas, gleefully bestowing his touch on a sadly gray landscape. Look at the Grand Hyatt. Look at Trump Tower. And soon, like it or not, you'll be looking at something called the Trump International Hotel and Tower if you get anywhere near Columbus Circle. In its drab, pre-Trump incarnation, this was the Gulf and Western Building, but last week work began on its Trump rebirth -- same size and shape (no public scrutiny needed), but gold-tinted glass from head to toe. Never fear, though -- this is no quickie gilding: one designer is none other than Philip Johnson. Goldfinger would be impressed.
 
TOBACCO
 
A Recall Hazardous to Logic
Philip Morris recalled seven billion cigarettes last month, but now no one seems quite sure why. At first it said there was some irritant in the filters that could cause "temporary discomfort." But last week it said the filter problem was small and involved only a bad taste and odor. The irritant may have been in the packaging. But Westvaco, which supplied the packaging, denied that "minute trace amounts" of the irritant could be linked to the problem -- and, indeed, the existing packaging is not being destroyed. So let's see: it's not the filters, it's not the packaging, and the cigarettes inside, of course, continue to be harmless. What's the problem?
 
THE ENVIRONMENT
 
No Oil Rig Is an Island
The next time you agonize over insulting the environment by discarding plastic bottles, say, or junk mail, just be thankful you don't face this rather more sizable disposal problem. Royal Dutch/Shell has this old oil rig in the North Atlantic that it wants to get rid of, and it planned to sink it. But Greenpeace charged in, calling the rig -- with its 100 tons of sand, oil sludge, and radioactive materials -- an environmental time bomb. The company backed down, but then last week said it had no idea what to do with it. It could cost $70 million to dismantle it on land, vs. $16 million to sink it -- and to top it off, it wasn't clear that land disposal would in fact be safer. An Austrian financier offered to turn it into a floating casino, but that doesn't seem likely. So for now this 450-foot-long orphan wanders at sea.
 
CAR WARS
 
Wrong Side? Detroit Did It
The clock is ticking toward Wednesday, when those crippling tariffs on Japanese luxury cars could kick in, and negotiators in Geneva are doing the usual dance -- with no one likely to give in til the last minute. But here's an interesting side issue: Japan has all those Lexuses and Infinitis made with America in mind; they'd be tough to sell in Japan, because the steering wheel's on the wrong side. Japan has long scolded Detroit for trying to sell wrong-side cars in Japan, so it'll be awfully strange to say now that wrong-side Lexuses are just fine. Even a Toyota spokesman said, "It's a very funny idea." Of course, they could always call them Fords, sell them at a discount, and then blame Detroit.
 
THE BUDGET
 
A Bumpy Road Ahead?
In a family's budget, "discretionary" spending is the extra stuff, the frills -- vacations, dinners out, marble Pocahontas lawn ornaments. To Congress, though, the label is applied to things many would consider more basic: roads, schools, the environment. But these become "discretionary" because they lack law-given formulas, and are thus ripe for the Republican knife. So when House and Senate leaders agreed last week on $245 billion in tax cuts over seven years -- the final piece of the mad budget-balancing dash -- the plan included $190 billion in cuts from projected discretionary spending. A "historic step," said Newt Gingrich. "Tax cuts to those who don't need them," said Leon Panetta.
 
DETENTION
 
Capitalism as Jailer
A lot of people say the Government botches things the private sector could handle easily. But when a privately run immigration jail erupted in violence last week in New Jersey, it raised the opposite question: should human detention be at capitalism's mercy? The head of Esmor, the prison company, put the blame for the revolt on the immigration service, saying it took too long with its paperwork, and said Esmor had fulfilled all its obligations. But a former warden at the center said that he could find no doctor who'd work for the wages offered and that he'd been told that $1.12 a day was too much to pay for an inmate's meals. "They don't want to run a jail," he said. "They want to run a motel as cheaply as possible."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Does a Reporter Have the Right Stuff?

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
ON Tuesday, I face my moment of truth.
After more than 30 years as a business journalist, including more than 15 years of writing and broadcasting about personal finance, I will be put to the test. On that day, I will take the examination for certified financial planners. 
 I am petrified. This scary opportunity is available to reporters and editors thanks to the Certified Financial Planner Board of Standards, the Denver-based, nonprofit group that confers the C.F.P. designation.
Our test is not quite the real thing, of course. It is four hours instead of the usual 10, and we escape the normal prerequisites, such as 18 to 24 months of university courses and three years of related work experience. And if I fail, it's not fatal. I can still hang out a financial planner's shingle because there are no Federal or state licensing requirements for the nation's 50,000 to 100,000 planners.
But, still, I'm very nervous. The last examination I took was almost 40 years ago as a Navy officer. And although more than 30,000 people have earned the C.F.P. since it was initiated in 1972, the pass rate is just 55 percent.
Out of the generosity of his heart, my boss gave me three days to study at home. Day and night, I pored over the review course for the C.F.P., which, like the Ch.F.C. (chartered financial consultant) or the P.F.S. (personal financial specialist), is one of several competing and reasonably well-respected planner credentials.
How did my cram course go? Well, it was great to get back to the office.
My study text, from the College for Financial Planning in Denver, consisted of 1,000-plus pages on 175 subjects divided into six topics. In addition to financial planning fundamentals, the topics included insurance, investment, income-tax, retirement and estate planning.
Reading so much so quickly took its toll on my usually sunny disposition. I was befuddled trying to remember the ways a Section 2503(b) trust differs from a Section 2503(c) trust, for instance. Even things I knew -- say, the difference between inflation risk and interest-rate risk -- got cloudy the more I pondered them, especially at 11 P.M.
After a couple of days, my mind reeling, I decided to try some of the mock exams. I was warned that I would need a hand-held financial calculator with an internal rate of return function. But since I have no idea how to use this device, I wielded a simple calculator on these multiple-choice tests, and used whatever I could remember about fractions and equations. When in doubt, I picked the choice that was closest to my answer.
On the first 75 questions, I got 31 correct answers. I did somewhat better on the next 75, answering 36 correctly. The third series had 90 questions and I got only 32 right. But I finished with a bang, getting 60 correct answers in a series of 121.
I don't know if these scores are good enough. Tuesday's exam, to be given in Manhattan, will not be marked on a curve, but the passing score changes each time nonetheless. Trying to figure this out, I learned, courtesy of the C.F.P. Board of Standards, that a certification examination like this is "criterion-referenced," while curves are associated with "norm-referenced" educational tests.
It's a bad sign when you can't even figure out how a test's scoring works. In any case, I'll find out if I passed or failed in about two weeks. Look for the follow-up article.
And wish me luck.

SECTION: Section 13; Page 11; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 313 words

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;
CHILD WELFARE: Growing Up in New York

 BODY:
In a report, "Keeping Track of New York's Children," the Citizens' Committee for Children of New York Inc., measured the risks to children in each community board (for education, the surveys were based on community school districts). Overall, the report found, "in virtually every category, New York City children continue to fare worse than their peers at the state and national level." Low birth weight, high infant mortality, violent deaths, teen pregnancy, high drop-out rates and poverty are among the problems that disproportionately affect children in the city, according to the report. 
 Based on rankings in seven categories, the eight communities with the greatest risks are Bedford-Stuyvesant and Brownsville in Brooklyn; Mott Haven, Morrisania, Concourse and University Heights in the Bronx, and Central Harlem and East Harlem in Manhattan. Bay Ridge in Brooklyn and Rego Park in Queens rank among communities with the least risk for children.

HEADLINE: Extinct No More

BYLINE: By Charles E. Little; Charles E. Little's latest book, "The Dying of the Trees: The Pandemic in America's Forests," will be published in August.

 BODY:

THE COMPANY OF WOLVES
By Peter Steinhart.
Illustrated. 374 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25. 
PETER STEINHART'S comprehensive and up-to-the-minute book on North American wolves, that most enigmatic of all endangered species, comes at a good moment. The wolf, until recently extinct in the wild everywhere in the lower 48 states, is now in the news.
After years of delay, 14 gray wolves imported from Canada were released last January into Yellowstone National Park, from which they had been ruthlessly extirpated almost 70 years ago; and one of the Yellowstone wolves has already had a litter of eight pups. Meanwhile, Canadian wolves are migrating southward on their own into northern Montana and Idaho. In North Carolina, a reintroduction of the red wolf seems to be going well. And plans are under way for a release of the Mexican wolf into the desert country of Arizona and southern New Mexico. It would seem that wolves are making a comeback. Or are we?
In his essay "Nature," Emerson implored us to develop a modern, original and inherently American relation to the natural world, "whose floods of life stream around us and through us." But of course we paid no attention, and with mad abandon wiped out indigenous prairie and forest ecosystems and many of their wild inhabitants, including the wolf, which was subject to the most resolute government-sponsored predator extermination program ever mounted. What took millenniums to destroy in western Europe, we were able to wipe out in less than a century.
Yet the wolf returns, through human agency as well as its own. Are we now ready to heed Emerson and step back from the annihilation of any form of nature that is not managed to provide immediate economic gain or recreational amusement? At this point the answer is not clear, but in the wolf we do have, to use an ecological term, an "indicator species."
Although we still remain woefully ignorant, filled with notions about wolves that date back to the Middle Ages, increasing numbers of sophisticated field studies concerning the lifeways of the wolf have been conducted, most of them since the advent of the Endangered Species Act of 1973. Accordingly, Peter Steinhart, the author of several other works on natural history, including "Two Eagles/Dos Aguilas: The Natural World of the United States-Mexico Borderlands," has set himself the task of rounding up and offering commentary on all the new wolf research (as well as some of the old), to improve our understanding of this emblematic wild creature and therefore of our relation to wild nature as a whole.
The book first puts us in the company of a pack of wolves on Isle Royale, a national park near Lake Superior's northern shore, where 12 eastern timber wolves survive; then into the lowland bogs of the Alligator River National Wildlife Refuge in North Carolina, where there is a raging controversy over whether the reintroduced red wolf is a true subspecies or a wolf-coyote hybrid; into the Ninemile Valley of northern Montana, where a brave Fish and Wildlife Service biologist tries to protect a pack of wolves from the depredations of ranchers; into Alaska, where the wolf, unprotected, is still mercilessly hunted from airplanes, despite laws prohibiting this form of killing.
In the course of these and other accounts, Mr. Steinhart amasses an astonishing amount of lore on the natural history of wolves. For example, in the New World wolves evolved from coyotes (not the other way around, as one might expect) about a million years ago and migrated to Eurasia, whereupon some of them migrated back. The howling of the wolf can be filled with complex meanings, and a deep voice is as intimidating among wolves as it is among humans. Adult wolves love all pups, becoming in effect aunts and uncles. While wolves from one pack will fight wolves from another, often to the death, there is no record of murder within a wolf pack. Moreover, there has been no documented case of any human being in North America ever being seriously attacked by a healthy (i.e., non-rabid) wild wolf. Wolves are smarter than domestic dogs and can solve problems, but are not trainable like dogs. Wolf-dog hybrids are a bad idea, emotionally disorganized and genetically harmful to the wolf population if released to the wild.
These days, a book about wolves is necessarily a book about politics, and "The Company of Wolves" is no exception. While giving anti-wolf people their say in his pages, Mr. Steinhart views the heated reaction to wolf reintroductions on the part of gun-toting property rights advocates out in militialand as seriously retrograde. "I suspect," he writes, "that when we argue about wolves, we are arguing about love and hate, peace and war, killing and kindness. We are arguing about our own hearts and souls." Indeed, the essential paradox of the wolf is that our response to this wildest of creatures provides a measure of our own humanity. And for that reason alone, "The Company of Wolves" is worthy of our serious attention.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 33; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1243 words

HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
A Modern Master of Bottles, Scraps and Squares

BYLINE: By Pepe Karmel

 BODY:
THE NEXT TIME YOU GO TO Grand Central Terminal, take the escalators two flights up to the elevator lobby of the Met Life (previously Pan Am) Building. Turn around. There, over the escalators, is a tremendous abstract mural (28 feet high by 54 feet wide) of black, white and red strips arranged in interwoven columns. Like the Pan Am Building itself, the 1963 mural is a relic from the heyday of modernism.
There is no plaque to identify the mural, but it was done by Josef Albers, best known for the spare, geometric paintings of his "Homage to the Square" series. The Pan Am mural, entitled "Manhattan," is based on a 1928 glass painting called simply "City." A selection of these glass paintings, on view at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum through Sept. 17, throws new light on the development of an artist who is in many ways the quintessential modernist. 
 Albers was the son of a house painter from whom he inherited his skill with glass and other unconventional materials. Born in 1888 in an obscure German mining town, Albers joined the Bauhaus in 1920, the year after it was founded, and was quickly promoted from student to master. He headed the glass workshop at the Bauhaus until 1933, when it closed under Nazi pressure. His wife, Anni, a talented weaver and designer, was Jewish, and their future in Germany looked grim.
The architect Philip Johnson, then a curator at the Museum of Modern Art, arranged for Albers to be offered a job as head of a new art school, Black Mountain College, in North Carolina. Albers taught at Black Mountain and then at Yale and exhibited regularly in New York galleries. But his career as a painter didn't really take off until 1950 when he began the "Homage to the Square" series, at the age of 62.
The Guggenheim exhibition, "Josef Albers: Glass, Color and Light," originated at the Peggy Guggenheim Collection in Venice. It probably came as more of an eye-opener in Italy than it does here: the large 1988 Albers retrospective at the New York Guggenheim included an extensive selection of glass works. Perhaps for this reason it has been supplemented here by two mini-shows, one devoted to his photographs, which have not previously been exhibited, and one devoted to some of the paintings donated to the Guggenheim in 1991 by the Albers Foundation.
The glass pictures, done between 1921 and 1932, are the main event. The earliest pictures, done with bits of bottles and scrap salvaged from the town dump, are glowing, organic abstractions in the style of Klee and Kandinsky. Mounted in light boxes in a darkened room, they recall the grandeur of medieval stained glass. Abstraction serves as a vehicle for faith: in "Park," a gridded arrangement of green and blue panes, done around 1924, there's one pink box containing a Christian cross.
The next year, Albers's work underwent a dramatic change of style and technique. Instead of using found materials, he began fusing (or "flashing") thin layers of colored glass onto panes of milky-white translucent glass. Using stencils, he would then sandblast designs into the glass, etching the surface and grinding away the upper layers to reveal an underlying color. Anticipating the Minimalists, he sometimes sent his designs out to be fabricated in industrial workshops. (There are a few of Albers's preparatory studies in the show; drawn with gray pencil on tan paper covered with a salmon-pink grid, they're arguably more beautiful than the finished glass works.)
Along with this new technique, Albers adopted a new formal vocabulary of vertical and horizontal bands arranged in parallel rows, sometimes alternating, sometimes weaving one over the other. Many of his compositions from the period from 1925 to 1929 have architectural titles -- "Skyscrapers," "Factory," "Pergola" -- and they frequently resemble elevations of International Style buildings with strip windows and cantilevered floors. ("City," the prototype for the Pan Am mural, belongs to this series but is not in the exhibition.)
Not all of Albers's glass pictures are this abstract. "Glove Stretchers," done in 1928, adopts the Surrealist motif of truncated hands and the 1932 "Keyboard" shows three superimposed sets of piano keys: black on white, white on black and gray on black. It's an apt metaphor for the Bauhaus practice of challenging students with a series of design problems instead of teaching them rote theory. The problems were exercises intended to limber up their minds and fingers for the performance of more elaborate artistic compositions. This was the teaching method that Albers brought to Black Mountain and to Yale.
The wall text introducing Albers's photographs compares them to "the most celebrated voices of 20th-century photography." This seems an overstatement. For the most part they are studies of natural or architectural patterns, in the manner of Andreas Feininger and other photographers of the 1930's. Albers's best photographs are the portraits of friends and colleagues from the Bauhaus circle: Herbert Bayer, Klee and Kandinsky. The moody close-ups are eloquent reminders of an era that prized intensity of personality over mere good looks.
The selection of paintings at the Guggenheim is somewhat disappointing, particularly in comparison with the large survey of works from this series recently organized by the Andre Emmerich Gallery. Albers executed more than 1,000 versions of the "Homage to the Square," using four slightly different formats of concentric squares. Each square was painted in a single solid color, applied with a palette knife to maintain a smooth, impersonal surface.
In the 1950's, when Abstract Expressionism dominated the American avant-garde, the cool geometry of the "Homage to the Square" paintings seemed a bit old-fashioned. In the 1960's, with the rise of Minimalism and hard-edge Abstraction, Albers's paintings began to look prescient.
The canvases at the Guggenheim ring variations on closely related hues -- typically orange, red and brown. They tend to confirm the stereotype of Albers's work as pleasant but dull. In contrast, the paintings at Emmerich demonstrated how expressive his color could be. Juxtaposing browns, blacks and grays, he set cool colors aglow. A white square surrounded by blue, gray and green evoked the sensation of sky and earth more powerfully than most landscape paintings.
Albers's luminous colors and even his square format inevitably recalls the work of Mark Rothko, who began exhibiting his floating rectangles in 1948, two years before Albers began the "Homage to the Square." Compared with Rothko's large canvases, Albers's pictures look like finger exercises -- but finger exercises of genius.
In a sense, Albers's most important heir among American artists is Frank Stella, who did not even study with him. Mr. Stella's breakthrough "Black Paintings" of 1959-60 took the cool, impersonal geometry of Albers's earlier work and turned it into a demonstration of deliberate, aggressive meaninglessness: patterns that did nothing except cover the canvas.
Today, it is Mr. Stella who is called on to decorate the lobbies of corporate skyscrapers. Just as Albers's "Manhattan" expressed the 1960's dream of a vibrant but rational society, Mr. Stella's increasingly frenzied geometries provide an appropriate metaphor for the permanent revolution of today's global economy. It will be interesting to see what his pictures look like 30 years from now.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Allan Ludwig's portrait of the artist Josef Albers. (Allan Ludwig/Simon Gallery)(pg. 34); "Interlocked," sandblasted flashed glass, 1927, by Josef Albers at the Guggenheim Museum. (Lee B. Ewing/Guggenheim Museum)(pg. 33)

SECTION: Section 7; Page 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: One Nation After All

BYLINE: By Christopher Hitchens; Christopher Hitchens writes the Cultural Elite column for Vanity Fair and the Minority Report column for The Nation. He is the author of, among other books, "Blood, Class and Nostalgia: Anglo-American Ironies."

 BODY:

THE NEXT AMERICAN NATION
The New Nationalism and the
Fourth American Revolution.
By Michael Lind.
436 pp. New York: The Free Press. $25. 
TRY the following thought experiment: Suppose the United States to have been overrun or forcibly dismembered as a state. Would that much-invoked nation, "the American People," persist in maintaining and upholding its proud identity, as did the Poles between 1795 and 1919? Or would it become fissile and splintered, like the former Yugoslavia after 1991? If you incline to the second answer, then you are a Balkanist: one of the pessimistic tendency that sees pluribus emerging from unum in a welter of competing sectional, regional, ethnic and linguistic claims.
Against this tendency comes Michael Lind, a recovering neoconservative with a countertheory of "liberal nationalism":
"We Americans are more like our neighbors the Mexicans -- a racially diverse cultural nation -- than like our neighbors the Canadians -- a collection of two or more nationalities lacking any common Canadian culture or identity that would survive the breakup of Canada into several states. We Americans, in the liberal nationalist view, are defined by a common language and culture; and as long as these unite us, we will constitute an ethnocultural nation."
As may be inferred from the above, Mr. Lind (himself a Texan of Scandinavian provenance) has no patience in "The Next American Nation" with theories of the gene pool, "the browning of America" or any of the rest of it. For him, race and nation are related obliquely if at all. Very many Americans, I would venture, could more easily and readily picture themselves as Canadians (English or French) than as Mexicans, however Westernized. But what if Mr. Lind is correct, and the American idea actually more resembles the Mexican one? What if we all ceased to think with our epidermis?
Why, then, an opposite danger would immediately become evident to us. Instead of "Balkanization," there would be the menace of "Brazilianization," with the cracks and rifts in society running laterally rather than vertically, and with a pyramid of wealth, talent, privilege and skill that was ever more sharply apexed and whose layers (how to phrase this delicately?) got duskier as they went down. Decades ago, the Canadian John Kenneth Galbraith gave us the ironic title "The Affluent Society" for the coexistence between "private affluence and public squalor." Mr. Lind would seem to be running for the vacant position of Galbraith de nos jours.
He posits a society where the wealthy elites have been enabled, by a deft use of the tax system, the international market and the relationship between trusts and education, to arrange matters so that they live in a different country from their ostensible fellow citizens. They have their own schools, resorts, banks and information networks. They have their own private police and security systems. They have, by virtue of the "wealth primary," to which all candidates must submit, their own senators and Congressmen. To correct this plutocratic tendency, Mr. Lind advocates a bracing dose of class consciousness among the hard-working saps who, as the saying goes, "play by the rules" and are laid off or impoverished for their pains.
At present a senior editor at The New Republic, Mr. Lind is one of the few contemporary writers to have noticed the salient fact that identity politics is a perfect pretext for the traditional practice of divide-and-rule. How convenient it is, from the point of view of the oligarchs, that the saps should be tussling among themselves about second-order grievances like political correctness. Mr. Galbraith was writing about a society that, except in point of wealth distribution and the central black-white division, was relatively homogeneous. Mr. Lind depicts a fragmented culture where the winners and losers look as if they were from different planets.
How did we get here from there? He makes the case that there have already been three distinguishable American republics (not counting the American cultural nation that existed before the Declaration of Independence). Since the promulgation of the Constitution, there has been "Anglo-America" (between the years 1789 and 1861), succeeded by "Euro-America" (which ran between 1875 and 1957) and "Multicultural America," which took hold in 1972 and is the pattern of today and -- in one form or another -- of tomorrow too.
In Anglo-America, the national community was essentially Anglo-Saxon or Teutonic, with Protestantism as religion and Federal republicanism as ideology. Euro-America, by being more elastic about new arrivals, transmuted Americanism into something more European than English and more Christian than Protestant. An expanded franchise and the pressure for civil rights altered the ideology to one of Federal democracy. A "Judeo" prefix was sometimes generously added to the "Christian," without which the religious denomination would certainly have been incomplete.
Today's Third Republic is still in formation, but it has already seen a revival of the hyphenate principle. In other words, many old and new minorities prefer to emphasize their micro-diversities, while many among the majority regard that very stress as un-American and while the overclass, as we were saying, smirks all the way to the bank. Hobbes meets Babel, in other words.
Consider my own chosen profession. There is a single overwhelming power in American print and electronic media, one tycoon who is only technically -- we might now say "virtually" -- American but who has no trouble at all in getting action out of Congress, Wall Street and the Federal bureaucracy. Meanwhile, the orthodox right has but one complaint about the news media -- namely, their wanton excess of liberalism. At the same time, much of the correctness-minded left prefers to argue about the exquisite modulations of the proper mixture of epidermis and genitalia, while a surprising number of people (not without clout in a major political party) hint darkly that our organs of mass communication are directed by and for the Jews. It's enough to make a cat laugh.
In this moral and intellectual chaos, it is always interesting to ask cui bono? Let's just agree with Mr. Lind for now, and say that the transnational tycoons and the big political donors -- those who violate, as he puts it, "the separation of check and state" -- are not conspicuously numbered among the losers.
What we need, Mr. Lind argues, is a Fourth Republic that will protect the American idea simultaneously from the religious nativists and the promiscuous multiculturalists. A nation, as he says, "may be dedicated to a proposition, but it cannot be a proposition." In order to redress the general tendency to the centrifugal, a "social market contract" will be required. Essentially an update of the New Deal, it would finance Social Security and national health insurance out of progressive income and consumption taxes. Higher wages for American workers would be attained by a mixture of measures, of which the most controversial would be Mr. Lind's proposed restrictions on immigration and his suggested "social tariff" to prevent the import of cheap-labor products.
MR. LIND is a pleasure to read because he is so manifestly intelligent and because he has done a great deal of hard and consistent work. For example, as I read through the pages that marked America's transition from "Anglo" to "Euro," I thought I had caught him out. It was in 1898 -- well into the "Euro" phase -- that there occurred a vast revival of Anglophilia, linked to nativist reaction and also to American expansionism. (This was the period when Teddy Roosevelt made common cause with Rudyard Kipling, and the Vanderbilts and Astors started to marry Churchills and such.) But not long after I had marked that demurral in my margin, Mr. Lind took up this very anomaly in his narrative and discussed it with some dexterity.
There are occasional signs of haste. Mr. Lind describes the post-1865 South as "a low-wage internal resource colony for Northern capital," a formulation he likes well enough to repeat not many pages later as "an internal third world resource colony for the industrial North." But when one considers Mr. Lind's near-Stakhanovite recent output, these are small reservations to be entering.
The religious nativists, or monoculturalists, if one can capture them in that term, evince an obvious nostalgia for the First Republic. They forget that in order for Britain to become such a shining example of a solid society run by a competent overclass, it had to overcome differences among Scots, Welsh, Irish and English that were more intense, if not ultimately more sanguinary, than any North-South or black-white confrontation on North American soil. London also had to become, to its credit, the capital of the Huguenot exiles and one of the centers of world Jewry. Successive experiences of slump, social conflict, political reform and war had to be undergone for the country to become even a vestigial social democracy or welfare state. The "Saxon genius," so much revered by Thomas Jefferson and other founders and framers, had precious little to do with it.
America has thus far been incomparably more fortunate but, as Mr. Lind is quite right to admonish us, may also be living on borrowed time and credit. Its multiculturalism may very well metamorphose into an ugly tribal negation of itself, and could do so quite quickly if the economic topsoil continues to blow away.
